HEADLINE: Prada: Luxury Brand With World-Class Anxiety 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY and GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
Teetering on high heels at the top of a stair overlooking Mercer Street last Friday evening, the willowy Estee Lauder model Carolyn Murphy surveyed a crowd of fashion's elite and whispered, "This is so bizarre." 
 The occasion was a long-anticipated party celebrating the opening of Prada's 24,000-square-foot store in SoHo. Ms. Murphy could have been referring to the unseasonal December weather. But she could easily have been editorializing about the crowd, a throng drawn from a rarefied sphere where the worlds of business, fashion, film, art and architecture intersect. 
 Who else besides Miuccia Prada and Patrizio Bertelli, her husband and the chief executive of the Prada Group, could lure Rudolph W. Giuliani, Kevin Spacey, Milla Jovovich and the sculptor Mark di Suvero to the opening of a dress shop? What other corporate magnates possess the vision and drive to defy a depressed market and to commission world-class architects like Rem Koolhaas to erect temples of retailing not just in New York but also in Tokyo, San Francisco, Paris and Los Angeles? Who, at this grim moment for local business, could propose anything approaching this couple's vision for a downtown renewal hinged on a distinctly 21st-century fusion of mercantile and cultural agendas? 
In a sense, the evening was a triumph for the owners of a privately held company whose fashions of the 1990's transformed a family luggage firm, founded by Ms. Prada's grandfather Mario in 1913, into a powerhouse with global sales of $1.4 billion last year. Yet for all the flashbulb excitement, there was a bizarre cast to the event, an anxiety detectible by anyone who has followed the fortunes of a seemingly unassailable firm. 
The finger-gnawing nervousness displayed by Ms. Prada and Mr. Bertelli on Friday could have been chalked up to social unease. But they also have ample cause to worry. Although Prada sales last year increased by 56.6 percent, and the company posted 24.9 percent sales growth in the first half of 2001, it continues to grapple with a $1.6 billion debt load. It was accumulated over a three-year acquisitions binge, when demand for its $375 shoes and $1,200 chemises seemed insatiable. Now it is struggling with the burden of prime real estate bought at market peak, and a sense in some quarters that the label is in danger of losing its cachet. 
Over the course of its buying spree, Prada acquired controlling interest in Jil Sander, Helmut Lang, Church's shoes, Azzedine Alaia, Carshoe and the Genny Group, along with a sizeable hunk of Fendi. 
But an initial public offering the company planned, to raise money to cover the debt of these acquisitions and to fuel expansion, was called off twice this year because of the global downturn, most recently after Sept. 11. Steven Greenberg, the president of the Greenberg Group, retail analysts, was not alone in noting that the expansions initiated by Mr. Bertelli would have been next to impossible in a publicly traded firm. "He has built himself a house of cards," Mr. Greenberg said. 
When the stock offering was indefinitely postponed for the second time, there was talk that Prada would be forced to sell some of its brands. And by the end of November, it did indeed sell a 25.5. percent stake in Fendi to L.V.M.H. Moet Hennessey Louis Vuitton for $260 million, and the company was reported in the trade press to be shopping the labels of both Ms. Sander and Helmut Lang. Last week in New York, Mr. Bertelli, whose company had denied the brands were for sale, declined to comment. Two days before the gala opening of the resplendent SoHo store, Prada announced a $624.1 million bond to help offset its huge debt. 
As a luxury brand with democratic ambitions, Prada is caught in marketing limbo. Now that it has expanded to 150 stores worldwide, with five in Manhattan alone, its survival as a business is contingent on reaching a broad market -- while also retaining the intrinsic cachet of being the cognoscenti's chosen brand. Some industry analysts see these goals as conflicting. "They're never going to be the inner-circle kid anymore," said Donny Deutsch, the chief executive of Deutsch Inc., the advertising agency, and a longtime Prada customer. "By definition they're victims of their own success."
Perhaps too pervasive these days to excite the fickle appetites of the fanatical style makers who established the brand, Prada has yet to infitrate the consciousness (and pocketbooks) of a mass market. It is not alone in being an apparel company that cannot afford the luxury of catering to fashion insiders.
One measure of the extent to which the Milan-based company falls below the radar of many American women was provided last week when Women's Wear Daily published the results of a survey to determine the 100 most recognizable international fashion brands. The study found that, while Calvin Klein, Gucci, Christian Dior, Chanel and Givenchy were all ranked in the top 100, Prada's name was nowhere to be found.
At a news conference in June, Mr. Bertelli played down the effects of the American economic slowdown on a saturated high end sector. Quick reflexes, he said, "are essential." 
Yet it is those very reflexes that critics have begun calling into question. Among the problems that have beset Mr. Bertelli's expansion, the best documented are his creative disputes with Ms. Sander, who, to widespread astonishment, defected in January 2000 from the label that bore her name. Fashion insiders were surprised when Mr. Bertelli gave evidence of his management style by taking over not just the Jil Sander business but, for one season at least, the design of its clothes. 
There is also the question of whether the architectural grandiosity of Prada's retail expansion -- the SoHo store alone is estimated to have cost $40 million, and another Koolhaas-designed showplace in San Francisco has been delayed for expensive earthquake-proofing -- represents a lapse in business judgment, as some analysts contend. "These huge capital expenditures can be very telling on your net profitability," Mr. Greenberg said.
Prada opened 26 stores around the world in 1998 alone. And while the company shuttered its Prada Sport store on Wooster Street last week, it will maintain four emporiums and one outpost of Miu Miu, all within a two-and-a-half-mile stretch from upper Madison Avenue to the new Prince Street store, where its less than tony neighbors include Zale's and Ann Taylor Loft. 
"We don't feel we're overexposed," Mr. Bertelli said last week, when asked if Prada was in danger of glutting the luxury marketplace. "We have 150 stores around the world -- compare that to our competitors." Chanel has 105. Gucci, which has 153, maintains a single, hugely profitable outpost in Manhattan on Fifth Avenue. 
Despite the financial uncertainties, both Mr. Bertelli and Ms. Prada seem committed to the notion that experimental store design will keep vital the company's innovative image. "To go on being creative," Ms. Prada said, "that is the only way to fight overexposure."
As a strategy, the creation of elaborate retail stores is "high risk high reward or no reward," said Carol Murray, an apparel and footwear analyst in the equity research division of Solomon Smith Barney. "Successful retail strategies go back to germane, relevant, must-have products." Why, if its product is so robust, does the SoHo store bill itself as a purveyor of vintage Prada clothing? A part of the store has been turned over to the sale of Prada shoes, prints and handbags from earlier and more influential seasons.
Additionally, among retailers, shoppers and fashion observers interviewed, there was a sense that the Prada devotee is no longer as single-minded in her obsession as she was in the label's undisputed heyday, just a few years back.
"Prada developed the idea that you have to have that one single handbag each season or that important pair of shoes," said one major retailer whose store carries Prada. Once famous for their willingness to go lemminglike from floral appliqued Mary Jane shoes one season to a razor-toed Bond girl pump the next, the Prada fan may have moved on. "These women don't look at Prada and say, 'What do I have to have from Prada?' anymore," the retailer said. 
Not since the company engineered the design feat of transforming a clunky bowling bag into an $800 fashion essential in the spring of 2000 has Prada scored a major runaway success. If, as analysts suggest, accessories are the cornerstone of the luxury market, it is worth noting that it is Balenciaga's grommeted $950 shoulder bag that sold out all year at both downtown boutiques like Kirna Zabete and Barneys New York, while the widely copied Prada bowling bags turned up for $299 at Loehmann's, alongside other markdowns. 
"I don't want some brand trophy right now, especially one as easy as Prada," said Priscilla Glover, an avid shopper who lives in Paris and New York. "I want something original, special, beautiful, charming and even precious, and I haven't found that at Prada in over a year." 
Linda Dresner stopped carrying Prada at her store in Birmingham, Mich., 18 months ago because, Ms. Dresner said, "there was just too much of it around."
In response to the issue of keeping Prada fresh, Mr. Bertelli countered: "The novelty we've introduced is that instead of going on with uniformity, we have created unique and unusual environments," referring to the highly conceptual store designs. "The product now is so strong it no longer requires a sameness of spaces."
It would appear that the Prada strategy is to invigorate the act of shopping by creating museums of consumerism, which like all good museums today come complete with a self-critique. In an introduction to a specially published book documenting Mr. Koolhaas's architectural collaborations with Prada, he offers what could be read as an analysis of the philosophical problems underlying Prada's growing pains. "In a world where everything is shopping . . . and shopping is everything . . . what is luxury?" Mr. Koolhaas asks. 
"Luxury is not shopping," Mr. Koolhaas concludes.

An article on the Fashion page yesterday about the business of Prada, the Italian fashion house, misspelled part of the name of the company that bought its 25.5 percent stake in Fendi, the handbag maker. It is LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, not L.V.M.H. Moet Hennessey.

HEADLINE: In Tight Market, Toned-Down Resumes 

BYLINE:  By SHARON McDONNELL 

 BODY:
To underplay or not to underplay their qualifications to prospective employers -- that is the question facing many white-collar job hunters these days.
 In this recession, Frank Blazey of Los Angeles is all for playing them down. Mr. Blazey, 48, was laid off in August from a district sales manager job he had held since January at Thor Inc., a software-consulting firm in Manhattan Beach, Calif. Before that, he was vice president for sales for two years at Digital Venture Solutions, an educational-resources Web site in Newport Beach, Calif., that eventually went belly up, and before that district sales manager for six years at the Vantive Corporation, a maker of business software in Santa Clara, Calif. 
 "But you'll never see that on my resume -- it says 'sales leader,' " Mr. Blazey said. "I position myself as what's known in sales lingo as a 'bag carrier,' or regular salesperson, because there are so many more jobs for them than for V.P.'s of sales or district managers."
He also obscures his background in the military industry, where he was a marketing manager for Hughes Aircraft and held posts at two consulting firms in Washington, by limiting his resume to the last 10 years.
Divorced, renting a condominium, paying $2,500 each month to send two children to college, running out of savings and facing the end of unemployment benefits, Mr. Blazey is nothing if not eager to find work. In his most recent position, he earned about $7,000 a month just for making his quota and usually made a lot more by beating it. The next time around, he said, he will be willing to make do with a base rate of $5,000.
In contrast to Mr. Blazey's stance, David Hirsch of Berwyn, Pa., is against masking accomplishments. Mr. Hirsch was laid off in February, six months after becoming vice president for marketing at Millstar Inc., a start-up in Falls, Pa., that helps companies manage product data. Before that, he was director of marketing for two years at Synygy Inc., a software maker that helps companies manage variable salary plans, in Conshohocken, Pa., after nearly a decade in the broadcast equipment industry.
"I don't want to sacrifice the long term for short term, so I'm not downplaying my position or my salary," Mr. Hirsch said. His financial situation is not quite as dire as Mr. Blazey's -- his two young daughters attend public school and his wife is a self-employed violin maker -- but his severance pay ran out months ago and his unemployment checks will end soon. To help tide things over, he has been doing consulting work for a computer systems designer.
"As long as you can do it, you're better off holding out," he said.
Two job hunters, two approaches to coping with the toughest job market in over a decade. This year the number of unemployed professionals and managers soared 63 percent, to 1.2 million, and the situation is likely to get worse before it gets better.
Career consultants come down on the side of full disclosure -- to a point. John A. Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago outplacement firm, is a purist.
"What you've accomplished gives you a track record, and downplaying it doesn't make sense," he said. "Sometimes people do it out of loss of self-esteem, a feeling of 'no one wants to hire me.' " But, he advises, "Don't sell yourself short."
But other specialists say it's O.K. to fudge the salary and title of your last job a bit, given the overinflated pay scales and titles popular in the go-go 1990's. Lura Pittman, president of Fletcher Frost, an executive recruiter for the information technology industry in Littleton, Colo., says she knows of co-founders of failed start-ups who omitted their former titles of chief executive or chief information officer in their resumes, stating instead merely that they had experience in business development and sales.
Greg Faherty, who helps job seekers write resumes for Resume.com in New York, has seen the same phenomenon. "I see major changes in financial and technical fields, where people who had jobs as C.E.O. and chief technology officer realize they can't go to larger companies and get the same position," he said. "So their cover letters say they are sales professionals with management experience."
Of course, employers frown on any fiddling of the facts, whether the inflated claims that they have always tried to ferret out or the new-found humility that they fear will evaporate once good times return.
And while exaggerations can sometimes be forgiven, leaving out your last job -- and extending the time you spent at the previous one to mask the omission -- is a no-no, career experts say.
"An extraordinarily dangerous practice -- if human resources does a reference check and dates don't check out, you won't get the job," said Arnold Huberman, who heads Huberman Associates, a New York recruiter for the public relations and marketing industry.
But some job seekers, faced with relentless stacks of bills and tremendous competition in the job market, disdain the ivory-tower mentality of career professionals.
"If you have over 10 years' experience, you're in trouble," said Mr. Blazey, a Persian Gulf war veteran with 10 years in the Marine Corps Reserves and 3 on active duty. "What they want is people with three to five years in a technology niche specialty, and the next category is six to nine years."
Stephanie Schroeder, 38, who was laid off in February by a New York public relations agency, may have hit on a solution to the quandary. She has written three resumes, each tailored to a separate set of expectations. Her "dumbed down" one, for lower-level openings, lists jobs as an editorial assistant instead of features editor at a trade association magazine, and as a junior account executive instead of director in public relations. A second lists her higher titles but leaves out her law degree so she will not have to answer questions about why she is not practicing. And the "full scale" one includes her legal background.
The dumbed-down resume gets the biggest workout. "I've been on so many interviews I know what they're offering, and it's mainly lower-level jobs," Ms. Schroeder said. Even for them, competition is fierce, she said, recalling the sting of receiving a group rejection by e-mail from a trade publication recently, which listed the e-mail addresses of all the rejected candidates.

HEADLINE: THE BOSS; 
From a Factory to a Bank

BYLINE:  By TERRENCE MURRAY; Written with Jonathan D. Glater. 

 BODY:
When I was in college, I did not want to go into traditional banking; I wanted to be a stockbroker. I just thought that was the highest calling -- maybe because an older friend of mine talked it up.
 But I graduated from college just as the economy was falling in 1962, so I had 25 interviews with investment banks and brokerage houses and was rejected 25 times. My wife's parents lived in Providence, where we went after graduation, and there were two banks there. The first one turned me down, the second one, a predecessor of FleetBoston called Industrial National Bank of Rhode Island, gave me a job. 
 My first interview there was with a gentleman named Homer George. He asked me why I dropped out of high school, only to return and end up at Harvard. The answer was that I had spent a year working nights, 11 p.m. to 7 a.m., at a textile factory, and realized I did not want to spend my life doing that. The only reason I went to the factory was because my father told me to stop wasting time in school if I was not going to concentrate on it -- my grades had fallen during my sophomore year of high school.
Since then, I have tried to hire people who I thought had potential, a chip on their shoulder and maybe a resume that raises questions, too.
I collect American paintings from the period 1850 to 1930. There's something serene and beautiful about some paintings, whether they are still lifes or landscapes or portraits. I have one portrait of a little girl named Kathleen O'Malley by Robert Henri, and if all the lights are out in the room except for the lights on the painting, her eyes seem to follow you as you walk by.
Even though I often buy paintings at auction houses, I never go to bid on one myself: people get too caught up in the competition. I always tell someone else how much I am willing to pay and then send them to bid. Sometimes I win; sometimes I lose.
That's something I learned from investing in real estate, something my wife and I did as a sideline while I was pretty junior at the bank, in the early 1960's. Back then, you could buy a three-family house for just $10,000, and the down payments were very low. We rented apartments in a few buildings. My wife fixed windows, repaired doorbells and did other necessary odd jobs. My task was just to collect the rent, which was often a tricky business because I had to know when people got paid and when they would be home.
One tenant who worked as a shoe salesman at Thom McAnn in Providence had a drinking problem. I had to find out when he got paid and wait outside the store to catch him before he could get to a bar and spend all the money. Sometimes his wife would be there, too -- she wanted to make sure all the money was not spent on booze.
I always found out where tenants worked, which helped if I had to track them down on payday. Usually it was not that people did not want to pay rent, but that they simply did not have the money. Most people are good people.

GRAPHIC: Photo: TERRENCE MURRAY -- Chairman and chief executive FleetBoston Financial (Michael Dwyer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
In the Sensitive Office, Laying Off Is Hard to Do

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
Anna Marie Teague thought somebody would start crying when the vice president of a media relations firm in Dallas summoned her and three co-workers to a meeting last April and dismissed them.
 What she did not anticipate was that it would be her boss who shed the tears. "It was bizarre," said Ms. Teague, who was an account manager at the firm. "First, she began whimpering and telling us it wasn't her fault. Then, she just started sobbing uncontrollably." 
 As her colleagues gaped, Ms. Teague put her arm around her supervisor's shoulders. "I said: 'We're going to be O.K. Don't be upset,' " Ms. Teague said. But the vice president could not be consoled. "She even tried to hug us as we walked out the door," Ms. Teague said.
Such displays of emotion by a manager during a layoff used to be unheard-of. But, in today's slackening economy, they are becoming more commonplace, career experts say. In an effort to appear more compassionate, many managers are taking a kinder, gentler approach, displaying emotions that range from empathetic to simply pathetic.
"Layoffs today have a different tone," said Maury Hanigan, chief executive of the Hanigan Consulting Group, a human-relations consulting firm in New York that urges managers to tell employees how bad they feel about dismissing them. "One of the things the labor shortage of the 1990's taught us is that employees are viable resources. The people you're laying off today are the same people you may have to rehire when the business cycle picks back up, so you've got to show some concern when you let them go."
The desire to maintain good relations with laid-off workers is what has driven Jay Moses, president and chief executive of UGO Networks, an online entertainment company in New York, to deliver the news gently. In the last year and a half, Mr. Moses has undertaken three waves of layoffs that have shrunk his company to 37 employees from 180. Each time, he said, he has tried "to establish an emotional connection with them."
"I've been moved to tears more than a few times," Mr. Moses said, noting that he has had to lay off friends whom he recruited away from other companies. "I'll hug people and spend as much time with them as they need."
Not only that, he invites all of his employees -- both those who are leaving and those who are not -- to a bar for drinks. And he writes personal notes to departing employees, thanking them for their hard work and commenting on how their efforts have helped the company.
"What's really been nice is that I've been able to retain my personal friendships with these people," Mr. Moses said.
The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, too, have increased the need for managers to appear more sympathetic, said Andrew Birol, president of Pacer Associates, an executive-coaching company in Cleveland. "Managers are feeling guilty about letting people go, and they're doing their best to soften the blow," he said.
One company that says it made a concerted effort to be more empathetic during layoff announcements is Delta Air Lines, which after the attacks announced that it would have to let go at least 13,000 employees.
But affected workers did not receive the news through a company memo or a human-resources lackey. Instead, Delta deployed 35 executives to company offices, hangars, break rooms and other meeting spots throughout the country to explain the situation to workers and lay out their options, including a voluntary leave program, according to Bob Colman, Delta's executive vice president for human resources.
Each executive received intensive training on how to anticipate employee reactions, like anger, and handle them with compassion, Mr. Colman says. Surprisingly, most workers took the news in stride. "A lot of people came up to the executives afterwards and actually comforted them," he said.
Of course, managers who abandon the traditional tone of detachment for a more caring demeanor should take care not to overstep the boundaries of decorum, specialists say. Otherwise, they risk appearing maudlin or just plain ridiculous.
Mr. Birol of Pacer Associates recalls attending a layoff meeting at a telecommunications company that had hired him as a consultant. In an apparent effort to lighten the mood, the manager breaking the bad news belted out a few bars of "Smile Though Your Heart Is Aching" in the middle of his speech.
"Everyone had these really perplexed looks on their faces, and he's sashaying around the room with a grin on his face singing, 'There are clouds in the sky, you'll get by,' Mr. Birol said. "Some people didn't even realize at that point they were getting fired."
An even bigger danger than looking foolish is coming across as insincere -- a common enough risk for managers who are forced to deliver the pink slips.
Brian Flynn, president and chief operating officer of RLM Public Relations in Manhattan, remembers sitting through a layoff meeting at his former company, Citibank, in 1999 and listening to a senior manager's expressions of contrition. "Somebody next to me whispered, 'Listen, dude, you're making $300,000 a year, and you've still got your job -- I bet you're real sorry,' " Mr. Flynn recalled.
Since then, Mr. Flynn has vowed to handle layoffs the old-fashioned way: unemotional and to the point. Most recently, he used that approach when he laid off 10 members of his staff in August.
"I said, 'We've lost a significant number of clients this month, we're making significantly less money, and so it should come as no surprise to anyone that we have to lay some of you off,' " he said. "The meeting took no longer than 10 minutes."
Many workplace specialists prefer the traditional terseness to the newfound sensitivity. "Once a manager gets into apologizing, or talking on a personal level, it muddies the water for a departing employee," said Sherry Cadorette, president of Drake Beam Morin, an outplacement firm based in New York.
But Mr. Moses, the chief executive who hugs employees he is laying off and then goes out drinking with them, begs to differ. At the latest drinking session in October, he says, several departing employees came up to him and "said remarkably good things about the company."
"They didn't feel like they had been messed around with," he said. "I have no doubt that some of these people will work for me again some day."

HEADLINE: City Ticket Plan Grows; Off Broadway, Some Grouse 

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
Broadway officials yesterday announced a new group of shows, including a bevy of long-running hits, that would receive city aid through a mass public purchase of tickets in January, while some Off Broadway producers voiced concerns that their theaters were missing out on the city's largesse. 
 Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, said that 10 shows had qualified for the second month of the three-month program of ticket purchases and giveaways devised to alleviate a post-Sept. 11 slump. To be included, a show must have low advance sales and demonstrate it won't meet its running costs. 
 The program, in which the Giuliani administration has agreed to spend $2.5 million on 50,000 tickets at a reduced price of $50, is meant to be a stimulus not only for the shows but to ancillary night life in Manhattan as well. 
The January list includes eight musicals -- "Beauty and the Beast," "Cabaret," "Chicago," "Contact," "Les Miserables," "The Full Monty," "Phantom of the Opera," "Urinetown" -- and two plays, "Proof" and "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife." 
"If you lost $5 for the week, you didn't qualify," Mr. Bernstein said. "The program is made for shows that could conceivably close because of weak advance sales." 
While Broadway has rebounded from the exceptionally dismal period following the World Trade Center disaster, many producers are afraid that the usually weak months of January and February could be exceptionally harsh this year, as tourism struggles to recover. 
But even as the measures to buffer Broadway were being announced, owners of smaller theaters across the city were increasingly upset about being left out. 
Scott Morfee, a downtown producer and founder of Downtown NYC, a promotional group formed last month, said he had fielded dozens of angry calls about the plan. 
"I think its boneheaded," said Mr. Morfee, whose show, "Underneath the Lintel," is struggling to survive at the SoHo Playhouse. "There's a lot of insulted theater owners downtown right now."
Some producers also said yesterday that they were upset by e-mail messages from officials at NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau, offering to help promote Off Broadway shows via newspaper advertisements and on the Web -- for a $300 fee. 
That figure, said Cristyne L. Nicholas, the president of the bureau, is necessary to cover marketing costs in a time of tight city budget. 
That was a price that Tom Smedes, the producer of "Naked Boys Singing," a long-running comedy revue, said he had no intention of paying. "We are insulted that New York City is buying $2 million in tickets for Broadway, which is not suffering compared to Off Broadway," he said in an e-mail message. "And the only way we can participate is if we pay."
After buying the Broadway tickets, the city is distributing them in two ways. Fifteen thousand tickets will be given to rescue workers and families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. The remaining 35,000 tickets will be part of a promotional program called Spend Your Regards to Broadway, in which consumers who produce $500 in receipts from New York City stores, restaurants and cultural institutions dated between Jan. 1 and Jan. 16 would receive a free pair of Broadway tickets.
Ms. Nicholas said that Off Broadway shows would benefit from one element of the Broadway ticket program in that receipts for purchases of tickets to Off Broadway shows could now be used as part of the $500 total. 
Mr. Morfee, the downtown producer, however, said that offer was too little, too late. "If they thought it was such a good idea, why were we not contacted about this last week?" he said. "It was all after the fact. It just appears to be a mop-up of a mess."
Officials at larger, institutional theaters were more measured in their feelings about the plan. 
"On the one hand, we are very supportive of the Broadway community and very enthusiastic about the idea of the city pumping money into the community and into culture in general," said Karen Brooks Hopkins, president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. "On the other hand, we would like to see that largesse spread around the nonprofit community as well, especially as many of us are taking it hard on the nose right now."
The money being spent by the city is not insignificant, especially in tough economic times. 
For the January cycle, Mr. Bernstein said the city will spend $750,000 to purchase 15,000 tickets for the 10 shows. In December, the city purchased 14,000 tickets -- worth about $700,000 -- for six struggling shows. In February and early March, the city has agreed to purchase an additional 21,000 tickets.
Most of the 10 shows on the January list are commercial hits, including two long-running musicals, "Phantom" and "Les Miserables," which have earned tens of millions of dollars for their producer, the British impresario Cameron Mackintosh. The list also includes four more recent profit-makers: "Cabaret," "Chicago," "Contact," and "Beauty and the Beast," produced by Disney. 
The two plays, "Proof" and "Allergist's Wife," also have returned their original investments; both are produced by the nonprofit Manhattan Theater Club. Only "Urinetown," which opened shortly after the attacks, and "The Full Monty," which opened last year, are still working to earn back their investors' money. 
Four of January's shows -- "Les Miserables," "Phantom," "Contact," and "Beauty and the Beast," -- were also included in December. 
Mr. Bernstein defended Broadway's being singled out for help because of its role as a major economic engine in the city. 
"I would never say that Broadway is more or less worthy than anything else," he said. "But I can say very confidently that you put money into Broadway, you get multiple effect on other businesses in the area."

HEADLINE: To Jolt the Economy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It's not surprising that partisan bickering has prevented Congress from passing a bill that would provide a much-needed economic stimulus ("Government Fiddles and the Economy Burns," Week in Review, Dec. 16).
 That's why we need a system in place that goes into effect automatically any time the economy slips into recession. 
With unemployment insurance, we already have the skeleton of such a plan. 
 A modernized unemployment insurance system could automatically put money into the hands of many people who are currently ineligible for benefits -- money that the unemployed would spend, providing a significant boost for the economy.
With an improved unemployment insurance system, we wouldn't have to wait for our elected leaders to wade through a morass of ideology and special interests to deliver a jolt to the economy.

JEFFREY WENGER
Washington, Dec. 17, 2001

The writer is an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
Despite some improvem ents, post-Sept. 11 flying is still a chore, especially at security checks.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IRONY is supposedly passe after Sept. 11, so I had no reason to doubt the earnestness of the admonitions being displayed on a video screen at the security gate at Newark International Airport when I checked in for a flight to New Orleans early last week.
 "No Knives," flashed the screen. "No Guns," the next message said. "No bombs," said the next one, which depicted the familiar red-outlined circle and diagonal slash across a bowling-ball-shaped bomb with a sparking fuse sticking out of it. The cartoon bomb looked like something the Road Runner might hand to Wile E. Coyote. 
 "Over here," a security guard ordered after the metal detector went off when I passed through. In airport language these days, that means "Stick 'em up."
Under the steely gaze of a rifle-toting National Guardsman wearing camouflage attire that stood out startlingly against the airport beige, I obediently reached for the skies. Even though I had placed on the conveyor belt every imaginable possession having metal components, including my sports jacket and watch, the penitentiary-quality frisking soon discovered contraband in my pocket.
"Aluminum foil on those Tic Tacs!" the guard announced triumphantly. "You're not getting through here with anything metal."
Generally reassuring as that might be, there appear to be exceptions, by the way. On Sunday, aboard an American Airlines plane taxiing toward takeoff from San Diego, a passenger removed a jacket from what she thought was her carry-on bag -- and a dummy hand grenade fell out into the aisle.
After a three-hour delay back at the gate, it was determined that the hapless woman had evidently inadvertently fetched the wrong carry-on bag from the heap of bags and laptops that now routinely pile up on security belts, as passengers stand nearby being searched. The one she grabbed, similar to her own, had actually been sent through by guards who had placed the dummy grenade inside to test the system.
Loose carry-ons, especially laptops, have become a real concern for business travelers in the new security era. Laptops must be removed from cases and placed on the conveyor belt while their owners often wait to be frisked off to the side. With their owners otherwise engaged, computers and other valuables sit there at the end of the conveyor belt for anyone to grab.
"Someone accidentally picked up my laptop in Chicago," an airline executive told me at the National Business Aviation Association convention in New Orleans last week. Wisely, he had put his business card on the keyboard, and an overnight-express transfer was arranged.
Such, alas, is business air travel three months after Sept. 11. Airports are sometimes a mess and air fares range all over the board. Schedules have been slashed, yet seating is often more cramped than ever because the airlines are increasingly flying smaller planes.
To be fair, airlines have been doing a better job in recent weeks addressing some security check-in delays. On most carriers, you can now arrive 90 minutes or less before departure, rather than two hours.
On Monday, United Airlines said that it was increasing the number of "priority" security checkpoint lanes it maintains at several major airports for "premium" customers.
This highlights an issue that we will be hearing more about in the new year, as airlines scramble to address growing passenger unease over discourtesy, harassment and long lines at security checkpoints. Airlines are quietly trying to devise ways to expedite security check-ins for their most valued customers: first-class passengers and those in various elite-level frequent-flier programs. Of course, there are several potential big public relations problems with such V.I.P. initiatives, including the fact that many of the Sept. 11 terrorists flew first class.
More on that in a later column. For now, let me just describe my most recent experience with the new world of fares and schedules.
Three weeks ago, when I made arrangements for a four-day business trip from Newark to New Orleans, commencing Dec. 11, American Express quoted me a $1,478 round-trip economy fare on Continental Airlines. By comparison, Northwest Airlines had a $175 round-trip fare to New Orleans, out of La Guardia Airport at 7 a.m. Resigned to getting up at 3:30 a.m., I booked that one.
A few days later, though, my itinerary changed. I needed to be in New Orleans a day earlier.
Booking now through Orbitz, the online travel site, the best fare I could find to match my itinerary was $1,200 round trip on Continental -- a 7 a.m. flight out of Newark via Cleveland, with a return trip four days later from New Orleans to Newark via Manchester, N.H.
I booked that, but a few days later I called Continental itself to see if I could leave a little later than 7 a.m. "You have a fully refundable ticket, so it's no problem at all," the Continental agent said.
Good enough. But when I called Continental from New Orleans last week to see if I could fly to Newark by some way other than through New Hampshire, another agent had a different story. "You have a special fare, and that's the only flight available for you," she insisted.
Yet on departure day at the New Orleans airport, the ticket agent at the Continental counter, Michael Richardson, tapped on his keyboard a little and quickly found me a more direct flight that would arrive earlier in Newark.
It's good to know that sharp employees can still make a difference, whatever the air transportation industry does to make flying miserable.
"Glad to be of service," the amiable Mr. Richardson said.
"Glad to know somebody's paying attention to business," I replied.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Agencies add their creativity to the campaign to urge shoppers to return to Lower Manhattan.

BYLINE:  By Aaron Donovan 

 BODY:
WHILE most television advertisements try to persuade consumers that a product or service is superior to others and thus worth their hard-earned dollars, TV spots that began last week in the New York area seem to neglect the customer entirely. 
 One shows a bald man asking for a haircut; another shows a tough-looking gray-haired man receiving a manicure. In both cases, the men buy services not for their benefit but for the sellers'. 
 Using a hefty dose of humor but an underlying tone of urgency, the spots are part of a campaign to encourage consumers in the metropolitan area to visit the small businesses south of Chambers Street in Manhattan. Businesses there have reported a sharp drop in the number of customers since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. 
The TV spots, in addition to radio and print ads, were created free by Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, for the Alliance for Downtown New York, the business improvement district for Lower Manhattan.
The ads are part of a campaign that agencies in New York have provided free to clients who are looking to help small businesses since Sept. 11.
The New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of Interpublic, has created print ads about promotional weekends sponsored by the TriBeCa Organization, a coalition of businesses in the neighborhood north of ground zero. The group was formed days after the attacks as business owners noticed the drop in customers.
"I was really pleased that we were able to help out," said Austin Handler, the graphic designer at McCann-Erickson who worked on the project. "There are so many little organizations and groups that really were looking for pro bono help during this time. Like with every charity, you want to help everybody but you just physically can't."
Ziccardi Partners Frierson Mee created a print ad free for the Alliance for the Arts, a nonprofit organization that encourages people to patronize arts and cultural institutions in New York City. 
"It's something you feel really good about working nights and weekends on," said Heather Mee, a managing partner for strategic planning at Ziccardi, who worked on the ad. "This is a particularly important time to be able to do something good for our city."
Both large and small agencies have been asked to do pro bono work on behalf of small businesses in neighborhoods south of 14th Street, many of which rely heavily on tourism. Paul Perlow Design, a one-man graphic design firm in Midtown Manhattan, created a print ad free for the Asian American Business Development Center. Using the image of the actor Jackie Chan, the ad encouraged people to visit Chinatown.
Kirshenbaum was the first agency that the Downtown Alliance called when it was looking for help. 
"We feel that it's important for us to commit to this neighborhood," said Richard Kirshenbaum, co-chairman of Kirshenbaum Bond, which has its offices on Varick Street in the West Village. "We felt strongly about doing some work for some of these businesses that are suffering."
Underneath the humorous tone are hints of urgency that come through more in radio spots that will begin in January. In one, the announcer says that if you do not have your shoes shined at Bob's Shoe Repair soon, the store itself "won't last long."
"The tone was so important and so hard to really hit on the head, without depressing people, without making too much light of the situation," said Debra Simon, vice president for marketing at the Downtown Alliance. "They really got what we consider the hardest part of this, which is the right tone."
As for the selling point for Bob's Shoe Repair -- why you should go there instead of another repair store -- the ad appeals to that warm feeling one gets after helping someone.
While the Kirshenbaum spots are humorous, the problem they address is not. The downtown alliance reports that stores in the area have lost 20 percent to 80 percent of their revenues since Sept. 11. 
"Even if you don't need to get your hair cut or necessarily use a support service downtown," Mr. Kirshenbaum said, "we're trying to help people understand that downtown needs their support."

HEADLINE: McCall Sees $4.7 Billion City Budget Gap 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall issued a report yesterday warning that the budget gap that New York City would face next year would be even worse than other officials had predicted: $4.7 billion, which is more than $1 billion larger than the gap forecast by the Giuliani administration.
 It was the second ominous forecast about the city's finances this week. On Monday, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi cautioned that the city's economy would shrink by 3.1 percent next year, its first yearlong decline in more than a decade, largely as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center. 
 But while some of Mr. Hevesi's predictions were actually rosier than those of the Giuliani administration, Mr. McCall's were significantly grimmer.
The McCall report charges that "the city may be underestimating the magnitude of the problem" by counting on several sources of income that are by no means assured, including $250 million from the sale of the Off-Track Betting Corporation, which needs state approval; $238 million in increased state aid for education; and $175 million in higher airport lease payments from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
And it warns that the city may be underestimating the expenses it will face from rising health insurance costs, wage increases for municipal workers and lawsuits against it.
The report by Mr. McCall, a Democrat who is running for governor, repeats several criticisms that he made in past years of the Giuliani administration's budgeting practices. In particular, it charges that the city's failure to use its budget surpluses in the boom years that just ended to save for a rainy day and pay off debt has left it hard-pressed to face the coming fiscal crisis. 
"By irresponsibly using the surpluses to balance the budget a year at a time, instead of to build up a reserve fund and pay down debt, the city avoided making tough choices," Mr. McCall said in a statement. 
"With the surpluses now nearly exhausted and the economy slumping, the difficult decisions have been left for the next administration to make."
Adam L. Barsky, the director of the city's Office of Management and Budget, said that the city stood by its forecast that the budget gap for the next fiscal year, which begins in July, would be $3.6 billion.
He said that the city had always used the surpluses prudently, and added that if the city had done what Mr. McCall suggested, it could be facing an even bigger gap now.

HEADLINE: For Some Retailers, a Rescue By Buzz, Click, Point and Whirr 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Between the sputtering economy and the terrorist attacks, this holiday season was expected to be bleak for retailers. But stores selling consumer electronics have found a silver lining.
 Products like DVD players, big-screen televisions, video game consoles and digital cameras are selling exceptionally well. In the third week of November, which includes the all-important Friday after Thanksgiving, sales of home-theater systems leaped 173.2 percent over the period last year, according to a survey by NPDTechworld, a market information company. Sales of DVD players were up 53.1 percent, color televisions rose 23.1 percent and digital cameras increased 40.1 percent. Those trends have stayed consistent since then, the company said. 
 For people who have canceled trips and are worried about job security, equipment that makes home life more entertaining has significant appeal. In addition, prices have fallen on many products, and stores are making them easier to buy. 
"Consumer electronics are a good reward," said Burt Flickinger III, a retail consultant with Reach Marketing.
Prices range from $399 for a home-theater system with five speakers and a DVD player to $299 for the Microsoft XBox game console and $1,999 for a big-screen TV to go with them. Shoppers are also showing strong interest in flat-panel computer monitors, Compaq Pocket PC personal organizers ($499) and bundles of peripherals, extra memory and software, much of which is priced lower than ever.
The purveyors of consumer electronics, which were battered in the last recession but are proving surprisingly resilient in this one, include specialty chains like Best Buy and Circuit City as well as huge discounters like Wal-Mart and Target.
Other retail sectors are flat or in decline. Fashion is not a priority, and sales of clothing and accessories are down. Luxury retailers are having their worst year in a decade. Many families are fearful about terrorism and have canceled travel plans, while others see layoffs all around them and do not want to take on a large purchase like a car. 
The money they might have spent on those things in the past is flowing into consumer electronics stores instead. "You certainly did not see that in the last recession" in the early 1990's, Carl Steidtmann, the chief economist for Deloitte Research, said, noting that apparel purchases rose then. "Consumer electronics got beat up pretty badly. It's one of the dimensions of this recession that is different from the last one." 
Shoppers seem to be drawn to consumer electronics for several reasons. Price is a big one; a basic DVD player now costs less than $100, and prices have fallen on other products, too. 
"I just bought two music systems for my wife and my daughter, and they're so reasonable," said Steve Naru, a public relations consultant. "The one for my daughter was about $80." His wife also sent him out to buy a new VCR recently, he added, and told him to get a good one. "Don't come back with a cheap one," Mr. Naru said he was told. 
But that was easier said than done. "I couldn't find one for over $100," he said. "They must have eliminated a whole cottage industry of repair people."
Then there is the aftershock of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, which is leading many people to say they crave more time at home. Restless teenagers can be drawn in with a souped-up family room, at least in theory, where they can watch movies and listen to music. That is where the popularity of the home-theater-in-a-box, which starts as low as $399 and escalates into the thousands of dollars, comes in. 
In addition, some new products, including the Microsoft XBox and Sony PlayStation 2 game consoles, just appeared last month and had been hotly awaited by adult and teenage shoppers. 
Most retailers are limping through this season, compared with the holiday period last year. "We saw very few bags this time around at the mall, with very few people carrying bags from more than one store, and almost no one carrying more than one bag from any one store," one analyst, Maura Hunter Byrne of Salomon Smith Barney, wrote in a note to investors describing a trip to the Garden State Plaza mall in Paramus, N.J., and several Manhattan stores. 
But the consumer electronics stores are whistling a different tune. Circuit City, reporting third-quarter earnings yesterday, said sales in stores open more than a year dropped 4 percent, less than the 6 to 7 percent that analysts had predicted.
Best Buy, which also released third-quarter earnings yesterday, reported that same-store sales increased 1.6 percent, compared with a 5.9 percent jump in the period last year. The company exceeded analysts' estimates, and said earnings rose 40 percent, to 37 cents a share, in the quarter.
Chains like Target, Wal-Mart and even Ames, which is in bankruptcy, have also recorded strong sales from consumer electronics, Mr. Flickinger said. "It's the proverbial rising tide lifting all boats," he said. Many consumers used their federal tax rebates to buy digital cameras, he added, if they did not use them to pay down debt. 
The stores have reaped as much profit as possible from add-ons like service contracts and credit cards, said Michael Collins, a retail consultant with Bain & Company. So even as prices drop, "there are a lot of people who are getting a better understanding of these two other profit pools within consumer electronics," he said. Prices of DVD movies and other software have not fallen, leaving stores other ways to fatten profits. 
Still, not everything is selling well. The most expensive products -- deluxe flat-screen TV's, for example, priced at $3,299 for a 34-inch model at Circuit City -- do not exactly gallop off the sales floor. Personal computer sales have also slowed, although Marie Driscoll, a retail analyst for Argus Research, said that "the velocity of the slowdown is starting to ease." Digital TV recorders, which allow viewers to pause or stop their favorite shows and replay them later, have also sold more sluggishly than expected.

HEADLINE: LTV Seems on the Vergeof a Shutdown 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
After more than half a century in business, the LTV Corporation will soon shut its doors, barring a government-supplied miracle.
 One of the nation's biggest steel makers, LTV put its mills earlier this month on what is called "hot idle," which would allow the company to restart them quickly if a government-backed loan comes through at the last minute. 
 But if help does not arrive by today, the company will ask the bankruptcy judge to end its labor contract.
A shutdown would leave about 70,000 retirees and recent employees with no or reduced pensions and health care benefits, and force the government to pick up at least some of the tab for what remains. The pension costs alone would be at least $2 billion. 
LTV's predicament -- with creditors on one side saying life support no longer makes sense and workers on the other fighting to preserve jobs and benefits -- may become all too familiar in the future. More companies are liquidating in bankruptcy under pressure from creditors.
In the steel industry alone, 12 companies have shut down since 1998, according to the United Steelworkers of America, and 17 more are now in bankruptcy. The steelworkers union is lobbying for government assistance -- as are Bethlehem Steel, U.S. Steel and Wheeling-Pittsburgh, which want permission to consolidate in an effort to avoid LTV's fate.
LTV's decision to shut down, announced last month, comes a year into its second bankruptcy. In its first bout with Chapter 11, the company spent seven years in bankruptcy -- one of the longest reorganizations of any American company. Now, LTV's management has concluded that its losses, $2 million a day, are simply too large.
"The company was running out of cash," said James Bonsall Jr., chief restructuring officer of LTV. Unless it began to liquidate, it would be unable to pay off $100 million in bank debt due at the end of the year, he said. Officials at J. P. Morgan Chase, which provided LTV with $582 million shortly after the bankruptcy filing in return for first claim on LTV's assets, declined to comment.
If LTV closes, it will mean the end of a company with roots far from the steel industry. Founded by James Ling, a high school dropout from Hugo, Okla., the predecessor company, known as Ling-Temco-Vought, had interests in electronics and aerospace. An avid conglomerator, Mr. Ling's endless stream of acquisitions landed his company in 14th place on the Fortune 500 in 1967. The following year, he entered the steel business with LTV's $425 million acquisition of Jones & Laughlin Steel. (Mr. Ling was ousted in 1970 under pressure from LTV's banks and has since emerged as an oil industry entrepreneur in Texas.)
LTV sold off the other businesses during its first bankruptcy. "We tried to get rid of the steel business, but we couldn't," said Mark Tomasch, a company spokesman. The steel business was unattractive to buyers, he said, in part because of the large health care obligations.
With $5 billion in revenues last year, LTV was the third-largest integrated steel producer in the United States, operating steel mills in Cleveland and East Chicago, Ind.
LTV's employees, aware that jobs are hard to come by, are fighting to keep the company alive. Their situation has won them the support of members of Congress from the region. Analysts and investment bankers say the workers' expectations are unrealistic, and ultimately side with LTV's management. Demand for LTV's product is too meager to justify the company staying in business, these executives said.
 On Tuesday, the U.S. and 38 other nations agreed to reduce world output of steel by nearly 10 percent over the next decade in an effort to drive up demand. C8. 
"All these politicians want the steel mills to open or reopen, but they never look at the other side of the equation," said Charles Bradford, an independent steel industry analyst and consultant based in New York. "They say, 'Let's make steel,' " Mr. Bradford said, citing a rallying cry of the steelworkers. "But they never think about who's going to buy the stuff."
LTV's business, along with that of the other large steel makers, has steadily weakened in recent years, thanks in part to cheap foreign imports that have been flooding the United States since 1998. (Operators of so-called "mini-mills," which are not always small and recycle scrap steel into new products, have generally remained profitable.)
All the integrated steel companies, including LTV, are also paying benefits to a population far larger than their employees. At LTV, there recently were at least 10 retirees for every worker. The precise number is unclear because the union counts 10,000 more retirees than the company does.
Waves of layoffs beginning in the 1980's and continuing in the last 2 years have swelled the ranks of retirees at most steel companies. A provision in many steelworkers' contracts guarantees them the right to claim retirement benefits early if they are dismissed or if their mills shut down, said Cary Burnell, a member of the research staff at the steelworkers union. As part of their push for industry consolidation, U.S. Steel and Bethlehem Steel asked Congress two weeks ago to assume some of their health care costs.
LTV's workers are laboring furiously to pull off an 11th-hour rescue, but their prospects are dim. Their union is hoping for a $250 million loan backed by the Emergency Steel Loan Guarantee Board, an arm of the Commerce Department. "We're going to fight like hell to get this loan, and fight like hell to save this company," said Leo Gerard, international president of the steelworkers union.
The company's banks, National City and KeyBank, suspended their efforts to secure such a loan last month, after deciding that they could not adequately demonstrate that the loan could be repaid.
Senator Paul Wellstone, a Democrat from Minnesota, was hoping to attach an amendment to the economic stimulus bill that would loosen such loan standards, but it is unclear when the bill will come to a vote, said a member of his staff. The union also delivered a letter, signed by 91 members of Congress, to the Commerce Department on Friday urging approval of the loan.
But with the union due to report its progress to the bankruptcy judge today, time may be running out for LTV's workers. Even if the loan is approved, the company says it will not be enough to keep LTV alive. "The company would need close to $1 billion to return to business," said Mr. Tomasch, the spokesman.
If the bankruptcy judge permits, LTV will soon stop paying retirement and health benefits. Some of these expenses will be assumed by the government. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation will take over LTV's retirement plan, at what it estimates will be a cost of $2 billion. Retirees over 65 will qualify for Medicare.
Many of LTV's remaining employees will be out of luck. There are limits on the benefits the pension agency will cover, according to Mr. Burnell of the steelworkers. It will not cover, for example, a payment of $400 a month from the company to many steelworkers dismissed between the ages of 50 to 62, intended to tide them over until they qualify for Social Security. Someone with 20 years at LTV typically qualifies for a pension of $1,450 a month, including the $400 monthly payment, but the pension agency would exclude recent enhancements to the pension plan and probably pay about half that amount, Mr. Burnell said.
Employees younger than 65 will also be on their own for medical costs. A fund set up by LTV when it last emerged from bankruptcy to pay for employees' health care probably will be out of money in less than a year, said Mr. Tomasch, the LTV spokesman. Among the benefits that will be lost is a medical plan that covers 80 to 90 percent of the cost of prescriptions ordered by mail. Last year, the company paid $200 million in health care costs, he said.
If LTV's unions are unable to secure the loan, their best hope is to find a buyer for the mills. 
"Plan A is to keep LTV operating and to do our work in Washington, D.C.," said Stephanie Tubbs Jones, a Democratic representative from the Cleveland area, where LTV has it's biggest mill. "Plan B is to prepare our community to invite a new buyer for LTV, including providing incentives."
Finding a buyer for the Cleveland mill will not be easy. "There is excess capacity around the world, and the Cleveland mill is one of the highest-cost mills," said Mr. Bradford, the independent analyst.
Even if a buyer is found, that might not help LTV's current employees. The mills will be more attractive to a buyer without the workers, Mr. Bradford said, because then they would not be forced to assume the health care costs.

HEADLINE: Pataki Looks At the Past And Future 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
Looking back on 2001, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that the horrific events of Sept. 11 had marked him and the entire state forever. Looking forward, the two-term Republican predicted the coming year would be one of the hardest periods in the state's history.
 "We are facing the most difficult financial situation in the state since probably before the Great Depression," Mr. Pataki said in a wide-ranging interview with reporters. "We are all going to have to tighten our belts. We are all going to have to understand when you talk the magnitude of six or eight billion dollars in lost revenues, it means the state is not going to be able to do some of the things we were able to do before Sept. 11." 
 Mr. Pataki has yet to officially announce his candidacy for re-election, yet he laid out in forceful terms why he wants a third term as governor, despite having said in 1994 that a governor should serve no more than two terms.
"There are many important decisions that have to be made, and I would like to be in the position to make those decisions," he said.
The governor maintained that he had made the right financial decisions over the last six years, restraining spending and setting aside large reserves. He argued that the state was better prepared to face this economic downturn than it had been in 1990, when a recession forced midyear cuts to school aid.
"We have changed this state's finances in a way that few would have thought possible in 1994, turning the record multibillion-dollar deficits into surpluses while at the same time being able to lead the nation in cutting taxes and having record investments in education and in the environment," he said. "All of this now is at risk."
Mr. Pataki has raised state spending about 34 percent since he took office in 1995, more than double the 16 percent rise in the cost of living over that time, state records show. He has also cut taxes dramatically. The booming economy made it possible to do both and still build up a $3 billion surplus in recent years, fiscal monitors say. The governor has also added about $10 billion to the state's debt load during his tenure.
But Mr. Pataki warned today that the state was entering into a more austere period. "We have to look at all new proposals in light of the new realities post-Sept. 11," he said.
For example, he declared that the state would not help finance new sports stadiums in New York City, though he said he might consider paying for improving the infrastructure around new arenas. He said many smaller restoration projects would not be financed. He said he was re-examining how to spend $150 million set aside for environmental programs.
The governor acknowledged that he had failed to reach an agreement with lawmakers on a number of important pieces of legisation. A bill that would compel insurance companies to pay for womens' cancer screenings, for instance, has stalled. So have several bills aimed at reducing the cost of auto insurance. Mr. Pataki also failed to reach an agreement with lawmakers on lessening the harsh penalties for drug crimes first passed under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. 
He said that the idea of reaching a policy agreement on changing a law more than 30 years old was not "necessarily the most realistic."
For his part, he said Sept. 11 had caused him to re-examine his family life. He spoke about making time for movies with his family and to read "The Lord of the Rings" to his son.
"I think all of us just appreciate our families, our communities, our homes, more than we did on Sept. 11, because we can't take them for granted," he said.

HEADLINE: Panel Asks Raise for Low-Pay Harvard Workers 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
A study commission forced on Harvard University by protesting students recommended yesterday that the university sharply increase the pay of its janitors, guards and other low-wage workers. But the proposed raises would mean pay that still falls short of the "living wage" the students continue to demand.
 For three weeks last spring, nearly 40 students occupied the first floor of Massachusetts Hall, where Harvard's president has his office. Their noisy sit-in, the longest ever at a Harvard building, ultimately led Neil L. Rudenstine, then the president, to appoint the commission. 
 In acting yesterday, the 19-member panel approved the recommendations unanimously. But several members said Harvard's low-end workers had to earn at least $15 to $20 an hour, rather than the $10.83 to $11.30 that the commission recommended, to support a family in the Boston area adequately. Harvard now pays as little as $8.50 an hour to some of the 970 workers cited in the report.
In a statement, Lawrence H. Summers, Harvard's current president, indicated that he would act on the report in January. He called it a "very constructive document that outlines a promising direction."
The commission, whose members include 12 Harvard professors and administrators, as well as students and workers, decided against proposing a fixed "living wage." Instead, it recommended a floor of $10.83 to $11.30 an hour; increases above that level, for union and nonunion workers alike, would be determined in collective bargaining.
If Mr. Summers agrees, wages will rise immediately to the floor level, at a cost that the committee put at roughly $3 million. That comes to an increase of about $170 a year for each of Harvard's 18,600 students, for whom tuition is now $30,000. Or the money could come from Harvard's endowment, of $20 billion. 
The proposed $10.83 to $11.30 would have been the wage level today for janitors, security guards, cafeteria workers, gardeners and the like if employees of outside contractors had not increasingly taken over work once done by Harvard's own employees, said the commission's chairman, Lawrence Katz, a Harvard economist. In doing so, they drove down both Harvard and contracting workers' "real" pay, adjusted for inflation, by as much as 20 percent in the 1990's, the commission said. This erosion was pronounced among janitors but did not occur among clerical workers, for example, who did not face competition from outside contractors.
"The early 90's was clearly a time when the university had some financial issues, and it was looking for ways to cut costs," Mr. Katz said of the increased use of contractors. 
Unions represent nearly all the low-wage workers still employed by Harvard. The commission recommended that the pay levels reached in collective bargaining with these unions apply not only to the Harvard employees but also to nonunion workers furnished by contractors to do the same tasks.
"You use outside contracting for its good qualities -- the efficiency and expertise that it can inject," Mr. Katz said. "We don't want a lazy inside monopoly. But you have to pay the outsiders at least the same wages and benefits that you provide for inside workers."

HEADLINE: With Promise Of Rate Rise, Insurer Halts Plan to Leave 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
New Jersey insurance regulators said yesterday that they were permitting the American International Group, the state's sixth-largest auto insurer, to increase its rates, and the insurance company said it was suspending its plans to shut down operations in the state.
 The agreement, which permits A.I.G. to raise its rates by an average of 8.9 percent and to increase some by as much as 30 percent, was the latest of several steps by the regulators to encourage insurers to continue doing business in the state. 
 A.I.G., which insures 213,000 autos in New Jersey, announced plans to leave the state last June, shortly after State Farm, the state's largest insurer, said it was leaving. 
In another development yesterday, the regulators said that Ohio Casualty-NJ had decided to get out of the auto insurance business in New Jersey and turn over -- at no charge -- its 109,000 policyholders in the state to a relatively new and small company, the Proformance Insurance Company in Freehold.
Many New Jersey auto insurers, which were forced by the State Legislature to reduce rates by 15 percent in the spring of 1999, say they cannot operate profitably and, because of heavy regulation, lack the flexibility to cope with changing economic conditions.
In the last several weeks, the regulators have approved increases for several companies, including State Farm, and they permitted State Farm to shift drivers to more expensive pricing categories, sharply increasing costs for many drivers and increasing the insurers' revenues.
Chris Neal, a spokesman for State Farm, said the changes would allow his company to increase its annual revenue by at least 14 percent, or about 2.8 percent less than it had requested. He said the company's finances were still deteriorating and that it still intended to withdraw.
Under the agreement reached yesterday, A.I.G. will add a second subsidiary in New Jersey. The old one will increase rates an average of 8.9 percent; the new one, beginning with riskier drivers, will charge 10 percent to 30 percent more than its predecessor.

HEADLINE: Budget Talks Going Down To the Wire At City Hall 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
As night fell over City Hall yesterday, officials were still negotiating over the city's budget, unsure whether they would reach an agreement before the final voting session of the City Council, scheduled for today.
 Giuliani administration officials and Council officials were trying to reach agreement on cutbacks in city programs that could help close a projected budget gap of more than $1 billion for the fiscal year ending June 30. At issue are the depth of cutbacks in items like day care slots or AIDS prevention plans, or the hours at libraries and parks services. 
 "There are so many issues that we're trying to resolve," said Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Council Finance Committee, adding that discussions would probably continue into the night. Even though there was "a desire to reach an agreement," he added, it was impossible to say whether they would. 
Some officials were optimistic. Jordan Barowitz, a spokesman for the Council, said the two sides were close. "There is the framework of a deal, but the t's still need to be crossed and the i's need to be dotted," he said.
If an agreement is reached and the proposed modification to the budget comes before the Council for a vote today, it would have to pass by two-thirds rather than a simple majority, and Council officials were only cautiously optimistic that they could find the 34 supporters necessary. If the Council votes against the modified budget, then the books would be left unbalanced for the next administration to work out, Mr. Barowitz said.
A City Hall official said yesterday that the administration had been negotiating with Council staff members for several days, and that some Council projects that had been cut would be reinstated and that some substitute measures like leftover campaign finance money would be used to plug the holes.
The Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, is eager to come to an agreement, the official said, because failure to reach a deal would reflect poorly on his final year in office. Mr. Barowitz would say only, "Throughout his career, the speaker has always done what is best for the city."
Mr. Vallone clearly prides himself on his ability to negotiate with the administration. Throughout his unsuccessful candidacy for mayor this year frequently boasted of the Council's prowess under his leadership in budgetary matters, from accurate revenue forecasts to fiscal responsibility, and cited its record of passing balanced budgets by the mandated deadline, unlike legislators in Albany.
Earlier in the week, Mr. Vallone was hopeful he would be able to collect enough votes to pass a budget at this afternoon's session, but by last night, officials were somewhat less confident. 
"Peter knows it's very difficult to get members to vote on a budget 11 days before the end of office, and how hard it is to get a vote to cut the programs these people have fought for their entire careers," an official said.
Another official, agreeing that some Council members had been less eager to work with the mayor's office, said, "Peter wants to make sure he can get to members."
The cuts, made necessary by a projected $1.2 billion deficit caused by the terror attack and a weakening national economy, include financing for child care, library programs, mental health services for the elderly and school maintenance, as well as savings achieved through technical budget alterations.
Also targeted for reduction or elimination were various projects that had been financed by the Council but not yet started, including a $5 million program to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs, an infant mortality prevention program in the city's 10 poorest areas and a $5 million H.I.V. prevention program.
Recently, there have been almost daily protests or news conferences on the steps of City Hall by advocates whose programs are threatened. Just yesterday, members of the NYC Coalition for a Smoke Free City protested a Giuliani administration proposal to halve and eventually eliminate $13 million in tobacco settlement money earmarked for a smoking reduction program.
Already, said Joanne Koldare, a spokeswoman for the coalition, smoking cessation programs, run mostly by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation to serve poor New Yorkers, are being eliminated and workers are being told to find new jobs. 
"This is something that will have short and long and medium-term effects" on the city's health and its economy, she said.
Around midday yesterday, it had appeared that the two sides might reach an agreement before the day was out. Asked how close they were to a final budget, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said, "Close, but no cigar." The mayor made his remarks while in the light-bulb aisle of a new Home Depot store in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. "We've resolved a lot of differences, but we're not quite exactly there yet, although we've narrowed the gaps quite a bit."
Later yesterday, city and Council officials haggled over still more details but Council officials said they hoped to restore financing for about half of what the administration had wanted to cut from various programs, including libraries, cultural institutions, parks, infant mortality reduction and AIDS prevention.

HEADLINE: Talks in Congress Break Down Over Health Benefit for Jobless 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
Talks between the two parties in Congress on a proposed economic recovery package moved to the brink of collapse tonight, with Democrats and Republicans deeply divided over tax cuts and how best to deliver health insurance subsidies to the unemployed.
 After another day of fruitless back and forth, House Republican leaders said tonight that they would bring their own stimulus bill to the floor on Wednesday to highlight their plan and what they say has been a substantial effort on their part to compromise. 
 Neither side declared the effort to address the recession dead. But Democrats had made clear that they would view a decision by House Republicans to bring up their own bill a political stunt that would undermine any remaining chance of a deal. 
"They have an open invitation to call me," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the Republican majority leader in the House, referring to Democratic leaders.
But Mr. Armey said no further negotiations were scheduled. And throughout the day, members of both parties highlighted the depth of their differences rather than common ground.
Democrats and Republicans remained at odds over a number of issues, including tax cuts for individuals and businesses. But the most difficult issue remained providing health insurance coverage to people who have lost their jobs.
Republicans pushed an approach built on giving laid-off workers a tax credit that they would use to buy coverage from insurers. Concerned that such an approach would leave unemployed workers little leverage with insurance companies, Democrats demanded that the subsidies be delivered through existing health plans provided by employers.
"There's a real difference of approach here," said Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia, "and I'm not sure it's mendable." 
The bill the House intends to take up has almost no chance of winning the 60 votes it would need to overcome procedural hurdles in the Senate, and members of both parties said they saw it as an opportunity to make clear the differences between them heading into an election year.
The new bill would cut the current 27 percent income tax rate to 25 percent starting Jan. 1, scale back the corporate alternative minimum tax, provide breaks to businesses for investment and give low-income workers a one-time $300-a-person rebate.
The bill would not include some provisions included in the stimulus bill passed by the House in October, including full repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax and a reduction in the capital gains tax. It would provide $33 billion in assistance to unemployed workers next year, up from $13 billion under the original House bill.
Republicans said Democrats were obstructing a reasonable deal that would help laid-off workers and help generate jobs by cutting taxes for individuals and their employers. Republicans singled out Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, suggesting that he was playing politics with the economy. 
Mr. Armey said Mr. Daschle, "more than any other single person, is the guy standing there with his foot on it." 
Mr. Daschle said Republicans were insisting on tax cuts that would primarily help upper-income Americans and businesses at the expense of people who were struggling after losing jobs.
