HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FEDERAL AID; 
NEGOTIATORS BACK $8.2 BILLION IN AID FOR NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
Negotiators for the House and the Senate agreed tonight to provide New York with an additional $8.2 billion in emergency aid to help recover from the World Trade Center terrorist attack and also approved billions more dollars for tighter domestic security nationwide as part of a broader defense appropriations bill.
 The negotiators planned to set aside slightly more, $8.3 billion, to pay for the domestic security provisions, including fighting bioterrorism, protecting the food supply and toughening security along the nation's ports and its borders. 
 The allocations for aid to New York and improving domestic security had held up passage of the far-reaching $317.5 billion defense legislation for days. 
The relief package for New York ends months of wrangling on Capitol Hill. New York lawmakers had become increasingly concerned that unless the city won a $20 billion allocation now, it would never get that amount of reconstruction aid promised by President Bush in the days after the Sept. 11 attack. 
Many New York lawmakers have argued that given Republican control of the White House and the House, the city's case has been growing weaker as memories of the attack fades and competing demands for federal dollars emerge from other states.
The $8.2 billion aid package for New York falls short of initial pledges after the attack, even when it is combined with nearly $3 billion in federal assistance that has already been spent to cover the costs of rescue and recovery at ground zero. The compromise will provide money for for grants and loans to small businesses, compensation for losses suffered by hospitals, and help for the disabled and displaced, among other things. 
But the White House and Republican leaders in Congress have said that they intend to deliver the rest of the money to New York -- though they have not said when, exactly, that will be.
Today, New York lawmakers sought to put the best face on the agreement, declaring it a victory of sorts. But they also vowed to return next year and press their colleagues to deliver the remainder of the $20 billion.
New York's senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, called the $8.2 billion aid package just one more step toward getting the city the money it needs. "Every day, we make a little progress," he said. "It's like the Battle of Stalingrad. You fight house by house, but eventually you win."
Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from New York, put the matter more bluntly than her colleague. "It's deeply disappointing that we don't have the entire $20 billion," she said. "New York should have the money now."
For days, the negotiations over how much aid to provide for New York and domestic security had held up final agreement on the $317.5 billion defense appropriation bill. The House planned to vote on the package as early as Thursday, and the Senate may follow suit.
The additional money for New York and for domestic security will be included as an amendment to the annual spending bill for the Defense Department. Negotiators also agreed to provide $3.5 billion for defense, money that the Bush administration had requested.
Democrats had initially sought to spend far more on the reconstruction effort in New York and on domestic security than the $16.5 billion that was agreed upon today. But the president had threatened to veto a bill with that amount.
Democratic and Republican lawmakers predicted that Mr. Bush would seek additional money for New York in January when he submits his annual budget request to Congress.
Roughly speaking, the deal reached today on the New York aid package represented the middle ground between competing proposals approved by the House and the Senate. The Senate had sought to provide about $9.5 billion for the reconstruction effort in New York, while the House approved a smaller amount for that purpose, roughly $7 billion.
The $8.2 billion includes some money for relief efforts in the other areas that terrorists struck: in Virginia, the site of the Pentagon, and Pennsylvania, where one of the four hijacked planes went down. 
The overall aid package for New York provides about $4.3 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency to spend on the debris removal and rescue and recovery efforts at ground zero.
More than that, New York lawmakers said, the package also includes about $2 billion in economic development money that that does not come with as many strings as other forms of federal aid.
City and state officials had been lobbying heavily for this federal money. They say they plan to use this money to, among other things, provide grants to small business owners and residents in Lower Manhattan who do not qualify for money from FEMA.
The New York rescue plan also envisions spending $140 million to reimburse New York hospitals; $175 million for workers' compensation insurance; $32.5 million for job training for displaced workers; $75 million for repairs on the West Side Highway; $120 million in loans from the Small Business Administration; $51 million for crisis intervention counseling; and $110 million to repair roads in Lower Manhattan.
In a statement issued by her office tonight, New York's junior senator, Hillary Rodham Clinton, called the agreement reached today a down payment by the federal government to help rebuild New York. 
"We are not letting up on our continuing battle to insure that resources continue to flow to the city and state, and we will begin the next session of Congress with new requests for funding, because the needs are great and time is of the essence," she said.
As part of today's overall agreement on defense spending, House and Senate negotiators approved a contentious deal involving Boeing. The airplane manufacturer persuaded negotiators to approve a plan under which the Air Force would lease 100 new wide-body Boeing jets for use as refueling tankers, at a cost of $20 million a year for each plane -- up to $20 billion over 10 years. 
Some members of Congress said it would have been less expensive for the Air Force to simply buy the planes.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
Recipe for Rebuilding: Afghan Muscle, Marine Planning, Lots of Dollars

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: KANDAHAR INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, Afghanistan, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
Marine C-130 cargo aircraft lumbering into the airport here in total darkness each night have carried in troops, equipment, water and, now, large amounts of American dollars.
 The cash -- the exact amount is something of a secret -- represents a new beginning in the American war in Afghanistan. After relentlessly attacking the Taliban's political and military stronghold here in Kandahar, the marine-led force occupying the airport has set about rebuilding it, providing a welcome boost for the desperate local economy. 
 The first investments arrived this morning at the heavily fortified base that the marines are establishing here: two new water pumps, made in Japan, bought in Kandahar and brought to the airport by six Afghans who immediately got to work installing them. 
They cost $325 each, "which is less than what we'd pay for them in the U.S.," said Master Sgt. Perry A. Toomer, an Army contracts officer and now the man with his hand on the military's till.
The marines who occupied Kandahar's airport four days ago now face a monumental task repairing it as they turn it into a hub for military goods and eventually for relief supplies.
The undulating fan-shaped terminal is aging and badly damaged. Most of its windows were blown out by the blast of an American missile just outside the main entrance. 
The runways are precisely pocked at each intersection by gaping craters, preventing larger cargo jets, like C-17's, from landing just yet. From one end to the other are mines, unexploded bombs and war debris, including the twisted remains of Soviet helicopters and transport planes.
As they begin their task, though, the marines have made clear that they intend to turn as much of the work as possible over to Afghans, a potential boon for an economy ravaged for years by civil war and international isolation.
"The first phase was winning the war," Lt. Cmdr. Glen Cooke, the commander of the Navy's detachment of Seabees, said today as a crew filled a 12-foot crater in the center runway. "Now we're here to support these people."
That support began almost immediately.
Sergeant Toomer arrived from Fort McPherson, Ga., on Saturday, a day after marines rolled into the airport in convoys of armored vehicles. On Sunday, three Afghans appeared at the base's wire gate, asking for a generator they had left here. 
Their generator had already been put to use, but Sergeant Toomer seized the opportunity and a new partnership was born. "I started talking to them," he said, "and found out they had knowledge of how to get this place started."
The three came back not long after daybreak today with three more -- all fighters loyal to Gul Agha Sharzai, the new governor of Kandahar Province -- and began the backbreaking work of removing a broken-down, American-made well pump and installing the two new ones.
"Because you are our guest, we should help each other," said one of the men, known as some in Afghan tradition by only one name, Gulalay, who serves as commander of Mr. Sharzai's forces around the airport. "We want to help you for a long, long time."
Around the airport, there is certainly plenty of work to be done.
For the American force here, the priority was the well; water is needed to make concrete and flush the toilets. Once the well is working, commanders plan to fly in a water-filtration system, easing the strain on cargo aircraft hauling in pallets of spring water. Next, the Seabees will work on electricity and permanent repairs to the runways. 
"Anything we can do to reduce the stuff we bring in here is a good thing," Commander Cooke said. "Not only does it help reduce our footprint here, it also helps the local economy."
Sergeant Toomer, the contracts officer, said he would negotiate contracts for work under the same guidelines the military uses everywhere else. Still, these are clearly not normal Pentagon procurement procedures. "I'm still getting into it," he said. "This is totally new for everybody here."
For the pumps, he simply asked for a receipt. By day's end, however, there seemed to be some confusion over pay for the six men laboring over the well.
"We're still working out the labor costs," the sergeant said, adding that it would be based on a fair local wage so as not to skew Afghanistan's economy with a flash flood of dollars.
The men, however, said they were happy to volunteer. In addition to the pumps, they even brought the local bread, dodi. "It is our happiness to fix the airport," said Assad Jan, an aide to Commander Gulalay who once worked for the United Nations. "It is our country. Money is nothing to us."
Later, he pulled out a scrap of note paper. "One of your commanders gave me a list," he said.
On it were a generator, a metric ton of cement, plywood, two-by-fours, 200 yards of electrical wire and a circular saw -- all of which he promised to bring, even though the Id al-Fitr holiday for the end of Ramadan had closed many stores.
"Today, we brought in bread," Mr. Jan said. "Inshallah, tomorrow we will bring everything, like Pepsi-Cola."

HEADLINE: Study Says a Slumping Economy Doesn't Mean Crime Will Rise 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN FLYNN 

 BODY:
Higher unemployment and a faltering economy will not necessarily lead to higher crime in New York City if the police continue their effective enforcement efforts, according to a study released yesterday by the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research.
 In fact, the researchers found that many areas of New York that had higher unemployment in recent years actually had slightly sharper declines in crime, in part because of innovative patrol strategies by police officers. 
 "They really make a difference," said Prof. George L. Kelling, a criminologist at Rutgers University and a co-author of the study, titled "Do Police Matter? An Analysis of the Impact of New York City's Police Reforms." 
Professor Kelling is a senior fellow at the institute, a conservative research group, and is an author of the "broken windows" theory, which says that the key to fighting crime is to address all offenses, even seemingly minor ones. In remarks yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan, Professor Kelling said his study was intended to empirically test the assumption that the decline in the use of crack cocaine and the booming economy of the 1990's had more to do with the drop in crime than police enforcement efforts.
As part of the analysis, the researchers looked at crime statistics for all 76 police precincts from 1989 to 1998 and correlated them against data that measured the borough unemployment rates, the number of young men in the neighborhoods and the use of cocaine. They found that crime dropped sharply in nearly every precinct, including those that had widely divergent numbers of poor people or drug users.
In particular, the study found no evidence that the declining use of cocaine, as measured by hospital discharges for cocaine-related episodes, was associated with a drop in crime, or that the escalating use was associated with an increase.
More likely, Professor Kelling said, the declines were precipitated by the "broken windows" approach to law enforcement, in which the police made many more misdemeanor arrests for lesser offenses in hopes of creating a sense of social order that deterred crime.
Alfred Blumstein, a professor of criminology at Carnegie Mellon University, said he was not convinced that the study had damaged the thesis that the economy and a drop-off in drug use were important contributing factors. For one thing, he said, the data used to measure unemployment was too blunt and unreliable.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
KOLODNY, SAUL

 BODY:
 KOLODNY-Saul on December 11, 2001 at age 83 in Danville, California. Devoted husband of Myra. Beloved father of Nancy, Carol, and her husband Richard Lees. 
Loving grandfather of Laura. Born in Yonkers, New York, graduated from Columbia College with honors in 1940. He began his career at the U.S. Cane Sugar Refiners Association as a chartist while in college and joined the U.S. Department of Agriculture to oversee the wartime sugar program. In 1944, he received a direct commission to the U.S. Naval Supply Corps and served as a supply officer in two Advanced Bases in the South Pacific Theatre. After the war, he returned to the Department of Agriculture. In 1947 he was employed by the American Sugar Refining Company, the world's largest sugar firm. He served as Economist, Manager of Planning and Analysis, and Director of Economic Research and Distribution. In 1975 he was named Corporate Vice President of Economic Research for Amstar Corporation. Twice he was designated Official Industry Advisor to the United Nations International Sugar Conferences. He was greatly honored when his collected personal papers from 45 years as a leading sugar industry expert were taken to reside in the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C. He retired from the company in 1983 and enjoyed an active retirement with family and friends in Florida. His love of life was a great gift to all who knew him and he will be remembered and loved forever.

HEADLINE: Pact to Cut Steel Production Doesn't End Risk of Trade War 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
After two days of talks here intended to ease the world's glut of steel, representatives from 39 nations announced an agreement in principle today to cut production by about 10 percent over the next decade.
 But the agreement is not binding, and it does not eliminate the risk of a serious trade war between the United States and other big steel exporters. 
 Last week, the United States International Trade Commission recommended tariffs of up to 40 percent on imported steel products and President Bush is supposed to decide on what action to take by the third week in February. 
Even as officials here were putting the final touches on their communique today, the European Union's top negotiator warned that the United States was dangerously close to inciting a spiral of trade sanctions.
"Those who have their finger on the trigger of protective actions carry a huge responsibility," said Peter Carl, the European Commission's director general in charge of trade issues.
The United States is pressing steel-producing countries around the world to lower output by closing inefficient and unprofitable factories.
United States officials contend that the world has an annual excess production capacity of 200 million tons of steel. European officials say the number is about 100 million tons, but virtually all countries agree that the glut of unwanted steel is huge.
Prices for crude steel have plunged about 30 percent this year and are at the lowest levels in two decades.
The United States is most worried about imports from the European Union, not Asia and Latin America. But European officials said today that the proposed tariffs would affect most if not all of their exports to the United States, and they have vowed to fight them in the World Trade Organization.
Pascal Lamy, the European Commission's trade commissioner, complained last week that the United States was making countries negotiate "with a gun at their head."
But Grant Aldonas, the United States under secretary for commerce in charge of trade issues, rejected European contention that a resort to "safeguard" measures like high import tariffs would violate laws of the World Trade Organization.
"I don't know how you draw the conclusion that somehow that the W.T.O. doesn't allow it," Mr. Aldonas said. "What they are basically asking us to do is give up our W.T.O. rights."
But while American officials deny any intention of using the threat of sanctions to press other countries into production cutbacks, bargaining is definitely under way.
In the meetings that took place here, sponsored by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, about 26 countries laid out forecasts that entail reductions in output of nearly 100 million tons of steel a year.
The forecasts are goals, not contractual commitments. The idea is that even in countries where steel mills are privately owned, governments can bring about reductions in output by removing subsidies and other public incentives that keep unprofitable mills going.
The United States predicts that American steel production will decline by 14 million to 17 million tons this year, based largely on announcements that American companies have made.
The European Union estimated that its production could drop by about 13 million tons a year. South Korea, one of the world's biggest and most competitive producers, said it could cut annual production by three million tons and Japan proposed about four million tons.

HEADLINE: Drive for More Mental Health Coverage Fails in Congress 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
A bid to give millions of Americans greater access to mental health care died in Congress tonight as House members rejected a Senate proposal to eliminate disparities in insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses.
 The action followed 45 minutes of impassioned debate over the rights of people with mental disorders. "This is one of the most important social and civil rights issues in the United States," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who had offered the proposal approved by the Senate in October. 
 Mr. Domenici, who has a daughter with schizophrenia, and Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, whose brother has severe mental illness, pleaded with House members to outlaw the widespread limits on treatment for psychiatric disorders. 
But at a meeting of House and Senate negotiators, the House members rejected the Senate proposal by a party-line vote of 10 to 7. The House Republicans all voted no. The House Democrats all voted yes.
Mr. Domenici and Mr. Wellstone said they wanted to require health plans and insurance companies to provide equivalent coverage, or parity, for mental and physical illnesses.
House Republicans, employers and insurance companies objected to the proposal, saying it would increase costs for employers in a recession, when many businesses are already cutting health benefits because of a resurgence in medical inflation.
The Senate had required "mental health parity" in an amendment to the annual spending bill for the Departments of Health and Human Services, Education and Labor. Mr. Domenici, Mr. Wellstone and their supporters, including the American Medical Association and the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, vowed to continue their efforts next year.
"We let insurance companies operate on the ridiculous presumption that people with schizophrenia are not sick," Mr. Domenici told members of the House-Senate conference committee. "I am begging you to use your influence to get a vote on this issue in the House."
Democrats described the question as a moral issue. "This amendment is directed against injustice," said David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the senior Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee. Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, Democrat of Rhode Island, said, "If we pass this amendment, we save lives." Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, said, "This issue is a challenge to the conscience of this committee and Congress."
But Representative Anne M. Northup, Republican of Kentucky, said the Senate proposal would force insurers to increase premiums, co-payments and other charges. "Insurance companies won't take in $1 million worth of premiums and pay out $2 million worth of benefits," Ms. Northup said.
Powerful House Republicans, including Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and three committee chairmen, said the appropriations bill was not a proper vehicle for setting national policy on health benefits.
President Bush steered clear of the fight. In a letter to Senator Domenici, Mr. Bush said he wanted to "reduce the stigma of mental illness," and he noted that, as governor of Texas, he had signed a bill to reduce disparities in coverage of mental and physical illnesses.
But Mr. Bush said he had concerns about the effects of the Domenici-Wellstone bill on "employers' ability to provide benefits and coverage, particularly during a time of economic recession and rapidly rising health care costs." In particular, Mr. Bush said, "I am concerned that employers may scale back health benefits or that individuals will lose coverage because they cannot afford the premium increases that are expected for next year."
Mr. Bush said he would work with Congress next year to devise "a solution" that reduced disparities in insurance coverage without significantly increasing health costs.
At present, people who are treated for mental illnesses like schizophrenia or depression often face higher co-payments and deductibles than they would pay for the treatment of physical ailments, like diabetes or cancer. Likewise, many insurance plans cover fewer visits to a doctor, and fewer days in a hospital, when the patient has a mental illness.
The appropriations bill, which is expected to win quick approval from both houses of Congress and Mr. Bush later this week, provides a total of $123.8 billion, up 11 percent.
The bill would increase the budget of the National Institutes of Health by nearly 15 percent, to $23.3 billion in the current fiscal year, which began on Sept. 1, up from $20.3 billion.
Congress is in the fourth year of a bipartisan effort to double the budget of the N.I.H., which had a budget of $13.6 billion in 1998. But the agency has been without a presidentially appointed director since Dr. Harold E. Varmus left in December 1999.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 After Fighting, Fleeing

OVER THE BORDER -- Hundreds of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters have slipped across the Afghan border and evaded the Pakistani Army to disappear into remote tribal areas of Pakistan, Western and Pakistani officials said. A1

REBUILDING AN AIRPORT -- After relentlessly attacking the Taliban's political and military stronghold in Kandahar, the marine-led force occupying the airport has set about rebuilding it, providing a welcome boost for the desperate local economy. B3

CLOAK OF THE PROPHET -- In Kandahar, inside a shrine that is considered one of the most holy places in Afghanistan, lies an ancient, sacred robe. Said to be the cloak of the prophet Muhammad, it inspires so much awe among Afghans that it has caused the Taliban's leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, to tremble. B1

Fragile New Regime

UNCERTAINTY AT TORA BORA -- The commanders of an eastern anti-Taliban alliance have declared total victory over the final remnants of Osama bin Laden's troops in their midst. But a trek through Tora Bora reveals a more complicated denouement. A1

DEAL ON SECURITY FORCE -- After a week of intense negotiations, Afghan and British officials agreed that fewer than 100 British royal marines would deploy in Kabul before a new interim government takes power on Saturday, western diplomats said. The marines will be the vanguard of an international force that will expand to 2,000 to 4,000 soldiers in the next several weeks. B1

SUPPORT FOR NEW LEADER -- Hamid Karzai, who is to become Afghanistan's new leader on Saturday, received the blessing of his country's deposed king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, and a pledge of assistance from Italy's prime minister. Mr. Karzai said his government's first priority would be to combat terrorism "not only in Afghanistan, but everywhere in the world." B2

Redefining the War

NATO'S ROLE EXAMINED -- Declaring that the war on terrorism will not end in Afghanistan, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld urged America's NATO allies to shift their focus and resources to fighting terror around the world. B1

DETAILS OF ANTITERROR EFFORT -- The United States will present to the United Nations today a detailed report of steps it has taken to combat international terrorism, hoping it will give teeth to a Security Council resolution requiring all nations to join in the struggle. B4

VIOLENCE IN YEMEN -- Yemeni special operations troops exchanged fire with tribesmen in remote parts of central Yemen as the troops tried to capture suspected members of Al Qaeda. Four tribesmen were killed and eight people, including soldiers, were injured. B4

Suspects and Inquiries

A DEFENSE STRATEGY -- A prominent San Francisco lawyer, James J. Brosnahan, is trying to alter public perceptions of John Walker Lindh, the American captured with the Taliban. But in trying to fend off a treason charge, he must persuade an audience of just one, President Bush, who will probably make the final decision on how the government handles the case. A1

QUESTIONS FOR PRISONERS -- Eight F.B.I. agents arrived at the airport in Kandahar to begin interrogating captured Al Qaeda fighters, including 15 prisoners in the custody of the marines, and hardened fighters from the battle in the mountains above Tora Bora. American officials hope for a potential investigative bonanza into the workings of the terrorist network. B5

ON THE MONEY TRAIL -- Interpol has reached an agreement with the United States to create a database to provide law enforcement agencies around the world with quick access to information for the crackdown on terrorist financial networks, Treasury Department officials said. B5

JORDANIAN EX-OFFICIAL DETAINED -- A retired Jordanian lawmaker, Sheik Dib Aneef Shihadeh, who was in Chicago to lead local Muslims in a celebration of the end of Ramadan, is being detained by the I.N.S. on accusations that his visa was revoked, his lawyer said. B4

Challenges of Recovery

PROGRESS ON AID PLAN -- Negotiators for the House and the Senate agreed to provide New York with $8.2 billion in emergency relief to help recover from the terrorist attacks. HEADLINE: All Alone, Again 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
Anyone in Washington planning to take the war on terrorism to Iraq after Osama bin Laden is eliminated should not count on Russia's help -- at least for now. The word here when you ask about marching on Baghdad is very simple: "Nyet."
 In case you missed it, President Vladimir Putin of Russia told The Financial Times Monday that the next priority for the war on terrorism should be to "block the financing of terrorist activities. And so far I have no confirmation, no evidence that Iraq is financing the terrorists that we are fighting against." 
 Mr. Putin is not alone in this view. If one looks at the core U.S. coalition against bin Laden, what the different countries have in common is both outrage at the terror acts in America and their own national interest in seeing bin Laden and the Taliban defeated. When it comes to Iraq, that sense of outrage is missing for most coalition members, and more important, their national interests work against an anti-Saddam crusade.
Turkey, which does a big business selling smuggled Iraqi oil, is concerned that a war in Iraq could lead to the creation of a Kurdish mini-state in northern Iraq that would link up with Turkish Kurds. Saudi Arabia is unnerved by the thought of Iraq being weakened as the Sunni Arab counterweight to Iran and the possible creation of an independent Shiite enclave in southern Iraq that would stir up the Shiites of eastern Saudi Arabia. 
Jordan, which is badly infiltrated with Iraqi agents and depends heavily on trade with Iraq, fears being destabilized by any war over Baghdad. Egypt is not eager to see a "nice" leader in Iraq, which would fully reintegrate Baghdad into the Arab state system and enable it to resume its natural rivalry with Egypt for influence over the Arab world. Syria would never support a war on Iraq that, if it succeeded, could lead to Damascus's being targeted next. I could go on.
Russians were never keen on hitting Iraq, but since the Bush team embarrassed Mr. Putin by unilaterally pulling out of the ABM treaty, both he and Russians generally seem even less inclined to help the U.S. attack Baghdad -- absent a taped confession by Saddam. And without the Russians, many European and Arab allies would shy away too. 
"What America is doing in Afghanistan corresponds to our interests and understanding of the situation," said Aleksandr Bovin, a former Russian ambassador to Israel. "Iraq is a different matter. We had well-developed economic ties. We don't want to lose them, and we don't see any danger now from Iraq. Iraqi missiles won't hit either Russia or the U.S. I personally don't care for the ABM treaty, but Bush put Putin in a difficult position that was not necessary. He scrapped ABM right when Putin was saying to people here: 'Look, we're friends with the U.S. now.' It disappointed me and many Russians -- as if Bush wanted to offend someone on purpose. The next time there is a choice to help America, Putin may choose not to help." 
Mr. Bush looked into Putin's eyes, but he didn't look at the world through Putin's eyes. Shortsighted "R" U.S. 
Don't get me wrong. There is no love lost here for Saddam. The Russians could, at best, be brought around to what the foreign affairs analyst Aleksei Pushkov calls "a negative neutralism" toward any U.S. action against Iraq. But the rubles would have to be sorted out in advance. Iraq ran up an $8 billion debt with the Soviet Union that Russia wants paid. The Russians want assurances that Washington will back their view that this debt was incurred by Iraq, and not just by Saddam, in case he is removed and a new Iraqi government says it's not responsible. The Russians also want assurances that if a pro-Western regime is installed in Baghdad, Russian oil companies will not be frozen out of lucrative oil exploration there. With bin Laden, our allies said: "Show me the proof." With Saddam, they will say: "Show me the proof and show me the money. Then we'll think about it." 
Bottom line: the shooting-fish-in-a-barrel part of this antiterrorism war is over. Unlike the Taliban, Saddam has real money to buy off adversaries. Unlike Afghanistan, his country is strategically critical to all its neighbors, most of whom fear any change to the status quo. And unlike bin Laden, Saddam may not make himself an easy, obvious target. That doesn't mean America can't, or shouldn't, look for ways to oust him, but it does mean we should start by planning to do it alone.

HEADLINE: Deficits and Rate Cuts 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Paul Krugman is right for the wrong reasons in his contention that the Federal Reserve's cuts in short-term interest rates have not encouraged business investment because long-term rates have stayed up (column, Dec. 14). 
 Lower long-term rates would help little now. 
Business is not investing because entrepreneurs see few investment opportunities. Until they do, lower rates will have little effect.
In the meantime, federal deficits, which Mr. Krugman says are driving up interest rates, will fill the gaps left by lower private investment and stimulate consumer spending. At least that is true of the Democratic version of deficit spending, which stresses public investment in education and infrastructure and puts money into the pockets of lower-income recipients, who will spend it right away. Republican tax cuts for the rich and corporations are more questionable.

ROBERT A. LEVINE
Los Angeles, Dec. 15, 2001

The writer was deputy director of the Congressional Budget Office, 1975-79.

HEADLINE: Ballet Theater Drops Evening Of Stravinsky 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
American Ballet Theater will not perform its scheduled Stravinsky program at the Metropolitan Opera House in June, because of a revenue shortfall.
 "It's just fiscally prudent," Wallace Chappell, the company's executive director, said of the decision, which is to be formally announced today. 
"We're looking at the potential of a 5 to 10 percent problem on a $30 million budget. It's primarily a result of the recession that already existed before Sept. 11, but it's certainly been heightened since that time." The postponement of the program will save Ballet Theater about $400,000, he said. The company said it had saved an additional $600,000 through staff attrition and cutbacks in publications and the use of consultants. 
 Mr. Chappell said ticket sales were down about 10 percent for the company's fall season at City Center in October. The opening-night gala party raised about 20 percent less than projected. And the company lost much of its audience for its school performances at City Center, when schools did not come.
"We've heard that from other arts organizations in Manhattan as well," Mr. Chappell said. "A lot of the foundations we go to regularly are very preoccupied, and understandably so, with disaster relief. There haven't been too many riding to our rescue like the Mellon Foundation." Ballet Theater has applied for a grant from the $50 million fund created by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation last month for arts institutions affected by the attack. 
The Stravinsky evening, which was to include Glen Tetley's "Rite of Spring" and James Kudelka's new "Firebird" will be replaced by programs already in the company's repertory for the season at the Met.

HEADLINE: Battling for Bullion 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
In the high stakes struggle between Newmont Mining of Denver and South Africa's AngloGold for control of Australia's largest gold producer, Normandy Mining, Barrick Gold of Canada has so far been a silent spectator.
 But Barrick has the highest market value and the strongest balance sheet of any gold producer in the world. And last week, it completed a $2.3 billion acquisition of the Home stake Mining Company of Walnut Creek, Calif., a combination that made Barrick the world's second-largest producer, after AngloGold and just ahead of Newmont. 
 Now all eyes are on Barrick for clues about the outcome of what has become known as the Battle of Normandy, as well as the future shape of the gold-mining industry. 
"They have been the company that has been the most acquisitive," said Margot Naudie, vice president at TD Asset Management in Toronto, which owns about 4 percent of Barrick's stock. "The gold industry is in the throes of a major consolidation. Barrick has played a leading role in that."
AngloGold, which is controlled by the Anglo American Corporation, opened the battle for Normandy in early September. Then Newmont entered the fray with an offer for Normandy as well as for Franco-Nevada Mining of Toronto, which derives most of its income from mineral royalties and is already Normandy's biggest shareholder, with a 19.9 percent stake.
A series of sweetened bids followed.
This month, Normandy's board recommended Newmont's latest bid, valued at around 4.2 billion Australian dollars ($2.2 billion), compared with AngloGold's best offer of 4 billion Australian dollars ($2.1 billion) Both bids are a combination of stock and cash, and the value of both offers has climbed in recent weeks as the gold price has risen. Normandy's share price has risen, surging to a three-and-a-half year high yesterday.
AngloGold has not said whether it will proffer another bid. But last week it said that it would appeal a decision by Australia's Takeover Panel turning down its challenge to the terms of Newmont's offer, and on Tuesday it extended the closing date for its bid from Dec. 27 to Jan. 4.
Should Newmont gain control of Normandy, it would catapult over both AngloGold and Barrick to become the world's biggest gold producer, with 22 mines on five continents producing 8.2 million ounces of gold this year.
The addition of Franco-Nevada, rich in cash and with no debt, would also help put Newmont in a stronger position to challenge Barrick as investors' favorite gold stock. The three companies combined have a market value of $8.8 billion, about the same as Barrick after the Home stake acquisition.
But Barrick has other advantages, including more efficient mines, with total production costs averaging $215 an ounce in the third quarter, compared with $241 for Newmont.
Newmont has also sought to woo investors by pledging to unwind Normandy's hedge book, thereby giving it full exposure to day-to-day movements in the bullion price. Barrick takes a more cautious approach, hedging about a quarter of its reserves. With the gold market largely stagnant in the last decade, that policy has served the Canadian company well, enabling Barrick to receive a price higher than the prevailing market price every quarter for more than four years. But an unhedged company would reap a bigger windfall from an upturn in the gold price.
"If investors are looking for leverage to the gold price, they're likely to choose Newmont" if and when it gains control of Normandy, said Victor Flores, an analyst at HSBC Securities in Toronto.
It is an open secret that the Toronto-based Barrick would prefer to see AngloGold, rather than Newmont, in charge at Normandy. With the bulk of AngloGold's operations in a country with a weak currency and an uncertain political future, the South Africans are seen as a lesser threat. And Barrick's chief executive, Randall Oliphant, is good friends with Robert M. Godsell, AngloGold's chief. (Mr. Oliphant said in a recent interview that he also liked Wayne W. Murdy, chief executive of Newmont, but did not know him as well.)
Mr. Oliphant sees the tussle for Normandy as another stage in a long-overdue consolidation in an industry where 56 companies are significant players, each producing more than 100,000 ounces a year.
And citing Barrick's own recent forays into relatively unstable parts of the world like Peru and Tanzania, Mr. Oliphant said, "We're going to have to become larger to absorb these risks, similar to what oil companies have done."
Furthermore, large and liquid companies will be "more appealing to fund managers," he said, and in a better position to cooperate in promoting new uses for gold.
Experts differ about whether Barrick will turn its attention to Normandy, now that the Homestake deal is completed.
According to a manager of a gold fund in the United States that has equity stakes in all four companies involved, "Strategically, it makes a lot of sense for Barrick to step in, and it wouldn't surprise me if they did." For instance, Homestake and Normandy are already partners in Kalgoorlie Consolidated Mines in western Australia, known as the Super Pit.
But Barry Allan, an analyst at Research Capital in Toronto, said Barrick would be wise to "do nothing." Instead, he said, it would do better to wait for an opportunity to snap up Newmont. The two companies have operations in several parts of the world, including Australia, northern Ontario and Nevada, where they could reap sizeable economies of scale. "Every time they look across their property line, they see eyeball-to-eyeball," Mr. Allan said.
Barrick's chief is playing his cards close to his chest. On one hand, Mr. Oliphant said that "if anybody's got synergies with Normandy, it's Barrick." He added that, with the Homestake deal, "we're more knowledgeable about Australia than we've ever been before."
But he also said that Barrick would take "the traditional disciplined approach that we bring to everything."
"Producing lots of gold," he added, "is not the way to produce market value."

HEADLINE: Group to Give 150,000 Tickets To Victims' Families 

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
As part of a continued push to provide emotional solace to victims of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 as well as economic stimulus to New York cultural institutions, two new plans to give away thousands of free and discounted tickets to cultural and other events are beginning this week.
 The first plan, to be announced today, is the Gift of New York and involves the donation of 150,000 tickets to families of victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center, the Pentagon and United Airlines Flight 93, the hijacked airplane that crashed in Pennsylvania. 
 The tickets, available through April 2003, are to a wide array of cultural and entertainment events and institutions, ranging from giants like the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, an 80-seat alternative comedy space on West 22nd Street in Chelsea. More than 100 organizations are involved, including the New York Yankees and the New York Mets, the 92nd Street Y, the Central Park Zoo, "Saturday Night Live" and more than a dozen Broadway and Off Broadway productions. 
"Nobody said no," said Andrew Tisch, the chairman of the executive committee of the Loews Corporation, who started the effort with Andrea Bronfman, who is the deputy chairwoman of the Andrea and Charles Bronfman Philanthropies of New York. 
"Nobody has talked about how do I get paid," Mr. Tisch said. "They just want to be a part of it."
The plan will begin shortly after New Year. Mr. Tisch said he expected 30,000 family members to be eligible for the tickets, which will be listed on a Web site, www.thegiftofnewyork.org. Organizers estimate the value of the tickets at about $6 million. Families will initially be sent a letter signed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor-elect, and they will receive a pass card listing the institutions that they can attend free. For ticketed events, like a New York Knicks game or a Broadway show, families can order seats through the Internet only. Tickets will be handled by the new, nonprofit Gift of New York organization rather than through a commercial tickets broker like Ticketmaster. 
While those tickets are being distributed, another plan to promote Broadway, one of the prime tourist draws in New York, will begin. Starting on Jan. 6, the League of American Theaters and Producers, backed by $1 million from New York State, is to deliver 3.4 million coupon booklets offering discounts on Broadway tickets, Midtown hotels, parking garages and theater district restaurants. The booklets will be in many Sunday newspapers throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. 
While winter discounts on Broadway tickets are common, such a widespread campaign is rare. The state money, from the Empire State Development Corporation, will cover the cost of printing and distributing the 28-page booklets. 
Nancy Coyne, one of Broadway's leading advertising executives, said the goal was to keep a flow of local audiences pouring into the theater district as the number of national and international tourists has dropped. A recent survey by the league found that since Sept. 11, half the Broadway audience has come from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, compared with about 43 percent last season. Over all, Broadway sales this season are about 85 percent of what they were last season. 
"The goal is to encourage the people who have come this fall to keep coming back," said Ms. Coyne, whose agency, Serino Coyne Inc., is leading the program. "They went all out to support us, so we wanted to make a concerted effort to thank them."
The plan is just the latest in a series of promotions to bolster Broadway, which has mostly rebounded from its post-Sept. 11 malaise but remains on shaky ground entering the tourist-starved winter. Last week, the Giuliani administration announced a $2.5 million stimulus plan to buy Broadway tickets to struggling shows.
That plan has drawn criticism from smaller Off Broadway theaters whose managements say that their economic concerns are being overlooked. Perhaps in reaction to that, the coupon book includes a page that entitles holders to a 25 percent discount on 28 Off Broadway productions. 
The league also wants to lure audiences from beyond the region with a U.S.O.-style tour of Broadway stars. Details were still being firmed up yesterday, but tentative plans have called for a 13-city tour beginning in late January, with about 15 performers in a musical revue. No actors have been announced. 
Stops would include Atlanta, Austin, Chicago, Cleveland, Denver, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, Phoenix, Raleigh-Durham, San Francisco, Tampa and Washington. In each city, the troupe would give away Broadway tickets as well as discounts for flights and hotels.
As with many of the promotions, the New York Loves America Tour, as it is being billed, aims to entertain and entice the audiences that Broadway needs to survive. 
"We thought this would be a perfect way to give back to our country," said Jed Bernstein, the league president, "while helping build tourism at the same time."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Adcritic.com's creators say it is a victim of its own success.

BYLINE:  By Andrew Zipern 

 BODY:
ADCRITIC.COM, a Web site that gained a broad following among devotees of television commercials new and old, collapsed on Tuesday. The site, which offered streaming video versions of the ads, was a victim of its own success, its creators said.
 "AdCritic.com is offline until further notice," the site informed visitors. "Our business, although strong, has been unable to weather the current economic realities besieging the United States today. The short answer: we became so popular so fast that we couldn't stay afloat!" 
 Late yesterday, Peter Beckman, AdCritic's chief executive, said the company was engaged in acquisition discussions with a number of potential buyers, but that no deal had been reached.
Mr. Beckman, a computer administrator, was an amateur commercial enthusiast when he started AdCritic in January 1999. The site, with a collection of more than 3,000 goofy and sometimes rarely seen TV spots, quickly became a hit both inside and outside the marketing industry. Its popularity, media pundits observed, suggested that television commercials were more interesting than the programs they interrupted.
The company was done in by the high costs for the Internet bandwidth needed to stream the commercials to the throngs of visitors it attracted, said James Riley, AdCritic's president, and was unable to develop its research business quickly enough to cover its expenses.
Daniel Summer, the chief executive of DVLABS, the company that was the host of AdCritic's video, said that in the days immediately after last year's Super Bowl, 1.8 million users rushed the site and, at their peak, downloaded more than 12 terabytes of data -- equal to more than half of the entire Library of Congress -- in a single 24-hour period. The usual cost to stream that much data is around $120,000, he said. Even though DVLABS charged AdCritic about one-fifth of that, the debt from the January event plagued the company for the rest of the year.
"They still haven't been able to pay off their Super Bowl bill," Mr. Summer said. Nevertheless, he added that he was confident AdCritic had the potential to become a viable business. "AdCritic is the most popular broadband site on the Internet, bar none," he said.
"It is the largest focus group one can possibly imagine," Mr. Summer said, giving agencies and advertisers a quick way of judging a given ad's effectiveness.
AdCritic, which was started for just $7,000, was regarded as having a deeply irreverent attitude toward the advertising business. But it nonetheless became something of an industry favorite. The site offered a forum for commercials that were too risque for network television or that simply were not deemed effective. The site encouraged advertising agencies to post their "spec ads" -- commercials intended to get a client interested in a particular creative team.
One interesting thing about AdCritic, said Patricia Williams, assistant professor of marketing at the University of Pennsylvania, was that it was entertaining and refreshingly free of ad world protocol. "A lot of the things on the site weren't even ads," she said. "They really attempted to push things that were unusual."
Professor Williams said she was sorry to see it go. "I used it a lot in my classes," she said. "It was a great place to find ads to show students." But she was not surprised. "It clearly had really no revenue model."
Rob Drasin, vice president for United States sales at AdForum.com, another Web site that archives and streams TV commercials, said AdCritic's demise was inevitable given its decision to cater to a huge consumer audience. "It's a classic dot-com failure in that they had the assumption that if you built a lot of traffic, the money would just come."
He said that AdForum, which is based in Hoboken, N.J., but also has offices in London and Paris, workedmore like a business-to-business research library. "It's a dating service between advertisers and agencies," he said. "AdCritic was giving away spots for free. It was almost like free advertising for everyone. That's not our structure."
AdForum charges agencies $4,950 a year to post and update their creative material and related information like contacts and previous work. The company now has 750 member agencies in its database, slightly more than half of which are based in the United States. Its consumer audience is negligible, he said.
Mr. Riley, the AdCritic president, said his site had 500,000 visitors a month and 40,000 registered members who work in the advertising industry. Earlier this year, it began charging agencies to post their material and had signed up more than 100 paying clients, he said. But that was not enough to support the site's daily operation. "Compelling content alone can't change that," Mr. Riley said.
Predictably, AdCritic's many loyal fans are crestfallen. "Wait, a site that was 'All ads, all the time' became too popular," wrote one user on Slashdot, the technology discussion site. "And advertisers could track which ads were more popular than others objectively and exactly? I've always said most marketers wouldn't understand technology if it smacked them in the face. Guess I was right."
Mr. Riley said interest among potential investors was there. But it is unclear whether a buyer will emerge during a media recession. We "hope that we will be back in full swing someday soon," the Web site says now. "Interested in helping out? You could always just send us some money. . . or send your condolences."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Web site for AdCritic.com now informs visitors that it is offline until further notice.

HEADLINE: Galveston Rejects Houston Port Merger 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GALVESTON, Tex., Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Residents of Galveston voted Tuesday to reject merging their port with the Port of Houston, 50 miles to the northwest.
 Though the deal would have brought needed repairs to the crumbling Galveston port and bailed it out of some $21 million in debt, inhabitants of the cash-poor island town resented what they claimed was an attempt by "nouveau riche" Houston to steal their history. 
 Galveston was the leading center of commerce and trade in Texas acentury ago.
The Port of Houston, meanwhile, has run out of docking space to serve its growing volume of cargo traffic. Shippers will soon be forced to anchor at ports farther away, like Charleston and New Orleans.
The defeat of the port merger is a blow to Houston's local economy, which is already reeling from the collapse of its largest corporate citizen, Enron, and layoffs at Compaq Computer and Continental Airlines.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Balloons Again, and Leadin g Indicators Rise 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit widened sharply in October as payments from foreign insurance companies, which increased after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, fell back to normal, below the level of premiums collected, the government said today.
 With sluggish demand keeping a lid on imports and exports of other goods and services, the trade gap grew $10.4 billion in October, to $29.4 billion, after narrowing in September to $19 billion, the Commerce Department said. 
 In a sign that the economy could climb out of recession in the first half of 2002, a closely watched forecasting gauge rose for the second consecutive month. 
The Conference Board, a private business research group based in New York, reported that the index of leading economic indicators rose 0.5 percent in November after a 0.1 percent gain in October. It was the largest rise since a 0.6 percent increase in May.
The index has risen in four of the last six months, suggesting that "the recession could be losing steam," the Conference Board said.
The index was led higher by declining jobless claims, rising stock prices and improved consumer confidence. It was also buoyed by a greater spread between short-term and long-term interest rates. Building permits rose, and the money supply expanded.
The negative factors influencing the index were faster delivery times, a reduction in average weekly hours worked at factories and fewer expected orders for consumer goods as well as for nonmilitary capital goods.
The Conference Board's index of coincident indicators, a measure of current economic activity, fell 0.2 percent in November after a decline of 0.3 percent in October.
The main force behind the ballooning trade deficit figure was an $11 billion month-to-month increase in imports of goods and services, to $106.8 billion. That change included $10.5 billion that mostly reflected a return to the normal relationship between premiums paid to foreign insurers and claims received. A sharp increase in claims received after Sept. 11 dwarfed premium payments to foreign insurers that month.
Imports of other goods and services in October were little changed from the previous month, reflecting the sluggish economic picture.
Exports in October totaled $77.3 billion, up only $500 million from the depressed September level as overseas demand remained weak.

HEADLINE: LTV Extends Benefits Through February 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
The LTV Corporation reached a tentative agreement with its workers today to extend unemployment and insurance benefits for displaced workers through February. 
 The agreement was worked out during a United States Bankruptcy Court hearing that had been convened to consider the company's request to void its union contract. 
Voiding the contract would have eliminated health care and unemployment benefits for up to 100,000 workers and family members. 
 Instead, the company and the unions agreed in principle that the company would extend those benefits to some workers through March. 
The company has already agreed to keep its steel mills in operating condition until then. 
LTV, the nation's third-largest integrated steel company, produced about 5 percent of the nation's steel. The company has been in bankruptcy protection since Dec. 29.
Earlier this month it received permission to idle LTV Steel mills in Cleveland; East Chicago, Ind.; and Hennepin, Ill.

HEADLINE: A Stubborn Fight Revived 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
The deadlock over the economic stimulus legislation makes one thing very clear: the health care wars have resumed with a vengeance.
 Washington policy makers are confronted with the dangerous combination of a recession, soaring health care costs and an uninsured population that was already close to 40 million last year and could grow substantially in the coming months, experts say. But the two parties are stubbornly divided over what to do about it. 
 The details of the dispute are complicated and arcane, and technically apply to just a small slice of the uninsured -- those who have recently lost their jobs -- for a limited period. The debate highlights one of those fundamental philosophical divisions that have so often blocked agreement on health policy. 
Republicans want to use tax credits to help individuals buy insurance in the open marketplace. Democrats want to shore up the employer-based system with federal assistance, a direct 75 percent premium subsidy, to help laid-off workers maintain the coverage that they had when they were working. Democrats also want to pump more money into Medicaid, the government health program for low-income people.
In short, the debate touches on some of the basic fault lines between the parties, the Republicans' faith in the virtues of tax cuts and an unfettered private marketplace and the Democrats' trust in the government as an instrument of social equity.
Republicans assert that their proposal would give individuals an empowering choice, the right to decide which plan meets their needs, rather than relying on former employers or government programs. Democrats assert that the Republicans offer just a false promise, that they will never deliver a tax credit large enough to make a decent plan affordable to average Americans. Nor, Democrats argue, will individuals have anything close to the bargaining power with the insurance industry that big employers or the government have.
Gail Shearer, director of health policy analysis for Consumers Union, said the tax credit proposed in the House Republican plan, intended to cover 60 percent of the premium cost, could still leave an unemployed family paying hundreds of dollars a month. Moreover, Ms. Shearer argued, "there's an awful lot you'd have to do" to make sure that people with health problems were not discriminated against.
Both sides have clearly come to see the health provisions in the economic stimulus legislation as an important early skirmish in a larger war. 
Stuart Butler, a health expert at the conservative Heritage Foundation, and an advocate of the tax-credit approach, argues that liberal opponents are holding low-income people "hostage to ideology." 
"They don't want anything other than an increase in the government programs," Mr. Butler said. "That's the consistent theme that runs through all of this."
Democrats and their allies argue that they are trying to preserve a private system; 65 percent of Americans younger than 65 have their health coverage through their employers. For those laid-off Americans who cannot preserve their employer-based coverage -- many work for small businesses and are not eligible -- many Democrats argue that Medicaid is the most efficient way to meet their needs.
Republicans argue that the Democratic plan is too bureaucratic, skewed toward workers at big companies and too slow to send the aid those who need it. 
Anita Dunn, a top aide to Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, said, "The genuine sticking point is whether individuals are thrown out there to fend for themselves with a tax credit, which our caucus by and large finds abhorrent."
Health experts say the debate will intensify next year. Governors in both parties are warning that they need help to deal with the growing demands on Medicaid, which is jointly financed by the federal government and the states. A variety of health experts are warning that the substantial increases in health insurance premiums in recent years will put new strains on employers and workers.
The economic downturn will heighten the anxiety about health coverage for many more Americans. According to Families USA, a consumer advocacy group, more than half of those who lost their jobs in the downturn from 1990 to 1992 became uninsured.
The politics of the issue could become as powerful as they were in the last recession, which ultimately helped produce the Clinton presidency and his effort to create universal health insurance. That effort, of course, ended in legislative disaster and turned the problems of the uninsured into a political third rail for many lawmakers for many years.
The debate over economic stimulus shows, if nothing else, how much the issue has returned.
"It's the issue that won't go away, and the economy brings it four-square back to the front of the political agenda," said Diane Rowland, executive vice president with the Kaiser Family Foundation, a health research group.
Of course, the new debate is rousing much of the passion of the last -- not an auspicious sign for producing actual legislation.

HEADLINE: Global Crossing Looks Overseas For Financing 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Seeking to prevent a messy financial collapse, Global Crossing is trying to reach a restructuring plan that would include large investments from Asian and European companies, people close to the companies involved said yesterday.
 The investments would allow Global Crossing, which led the late 1990's frenzy for globe-spanning communications systems, to avoid a protracted bankruptcy filing. But they hinge on delicate negotiations with its senior lenders, a group of about two dozen banks including Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase. 
 The banks, which met with company officials yesterday in New York to discuss the plan, need to approve changes to their financing agreements before it can restructure with the new equity. Global Crossing and the lenders hope to work on the plan over the next month. 
Under the proposal, Li Ka-shing, a Hong Kong businessman, would invest at least $1 billion, and Singapore Telecommunications is also considering a big investment, people close to the situation said.
Deutsche Telekom could also become a large shareholder through a complicated multiyear deal to acquire capacity on Global Crossing's network. As part of that agreement, which is potentially valued at several billion dollars, it would receive warrants that would allow it to buy a large block of Global Crossing shares, these people said.
The companies involved in the restructuring effort declined to comment. Dan Coulter, a spokesman for Global Crossing, said the company was working with the banks to reach a resolution to the looming violation of its financing agreements. 
Global Crossing, which lost $3.35 billion in the third quarter, is expected to be in technical violation of these covenants by next month. The breach is being attributed to weak sales and plunging prices for capacity on its network. 
Global Crossing had epitomized the promise of transmitting phone calls and Internet data over vast fiber optic systems, but the expansion of competing systems resulted not only in a glut of capacity but one of companies. Global Crossing cut 3,200 jobs this year and plans to lower capital spending next year to about $1.25 billion from $4 billion.
The company's greatest fear is if its creditors decide it is worth "more dead than alive," a person close to the situation said, an assumption that could push Global Crossing into liquidation, where its assets would be auctioned to the highest bidder.
So far, investors appear confident that Global Crossing is worth more alive. Since Gary Winnick, a former sales executive at Drexel Burnham Lambert under Michael R. Milken, founded the company in 1997, it has invested $15 billion to build a fiber optic network linking 200 cities in 27 countries in the Americas, Asia and Europe. 
With greater reach than its competitors, Global Crossing has a varied list of customers, including carriers like Deutsche Telekom, government institutions like the Navy and corporations like Microsoft and American Express. 
Its most prized possessions are transoceanic cables linking Asia and Latin America with North America and Europe, said Robert Rock, a debt analyst at John Hancock mutual funds. Less valuable are fiber optic holdings in the United States, where competitors operate similar systems.
The equity investments would give Global Crossing some of the capital it needs to restructure, allowing it to provide lenders with a combination of cash and equity worth pennies on the dollar compared with what the company originally borrowed.
Global Crossing has $10.9 billion of debt and preferred stock, including about $2.2 billion of bank loans and about $750 million of annual interest costs. 
Debt speculators have largely priced in a default, with Global Crossing bonds trading as low as 8 cents on the dollar yesterday and bank loans as low as 28 percent of face value. Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's further downgraded Global Crossing's debt ratings below investment grade last week.
It remains to be seen whether Mr. Winnick will retain control of his brainchild if it restructures. A person close to the negotiations said Mr. Winnick, through his investment firm, the Pacific Capital Group, might also be willing to invest more money in Global Crossing.
The interest of some potential investors may depend on Mr. Winnick's personal relationships, especially in the case of Mr. Li of Hong Kong. Mr. Li and Global Crossing operate a venture together in China. In this way, Global Crossing's restructuring effort is similar to a recent deal put together by the financier Theodore J. Forstmann.
Mr. Forstmann's buyout firm, Forstmann Little, may gain control of XO Communications, a telephone and Internet company based in McLean, Va., through a deal in which it and Telefonos de Mexico will each inject $400 million to rid XO's balance sheet of debt.
The essence of that deal is Mr. Forstmann's success in luring Telmex's chairman, the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helu, to take part in the transaction. If the XO restructuring succeeds, it will wipe out the existing value of the company's stock.
Depending how the Global Crossing deal is structured, there may be a similar fate in store for its shareholders, whose holdings could be drastically reduced or wiped out in value. Shares of Global Crossing, which rose as high as $61.38 two years ago, have plunged 95 percent in the last year. They rose a penny yesterday, to 73 cents.
Despite the decline, Mr. Winnick reaped more than $800 million from sales of his shares since Global Crossing went public in 1998. Other early investors that made money from stock sales are the Tisch family of New York, through its CNA Financial Corporation, and the pension fund for Union Labor Life, an insurance company controlled by a group of unions.
Of course, if Global Crossing revamps its capital structure, its current shareholders would be lowest on the totem pole seeking to recover value from the company. But what is perhaps more crucial to the process is the status of its senior lenders.
Unlike senior bank lenders for other companies in situations of financial strain, Citigroup, J. P. Morgan and other banks may not, effectively, be senior over Global Crossing's bondholders. This is because these lenders may have received securities, which are now almost worthless, as collateral instead of network assets.
The distinction is important because the consent of the banks is crucial for a smooth restructuring. If the banks, already smarting from losses on loans and bonds, interpret Global Crossing's actions as particularly guileful, they could withdraw from talks and put the entire process in danger. A person close to the situation described the negotiations as "cordial."
In the meantime, Global Crossing has said it is not headed for a liquidity crisis, saying it has enough cash to remain in business through the coming year. At the end of September, it had $2.4 billion. A spokesman declined to say how much it now has.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: REDEVELOPMENT; 
Downtown Renewal Head Vows Independent Effort

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
John C. Whitehead, the newly appointed chairman of the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Commission, has been making the rounds of business and civic groups for a week assuring them that he will lead a politically independent effort to rejuvenate the area and build a monument to rival the Lincoln, Jefferson or Vietnam Memorials.
 Last week, he told a group of business executives at the Association for a Better New York that he was not beholden to Charles A. Gargano, the state's top economic development official, executives at the meeting said. In an informal meeting with real estate developers Tuesday, he went further, saying he was seeking an executive director for the downtown group who would be independent of Gov. George E. Pataki. 
 To many who heard him, Mr. Whitehead, 79, seemed to be embarking on a bold, perhaps foolish, path. After all, it was Mr. Pataki who named him chairman of the corporation, which is charged with rebuilding the area. It is a subsidiary of Mr. Gargano's Empire State Development Corporation, although little is certain about the commission's powers, its financing or its relationship to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the 16-acre site where the World Trade Center stood.
But then Tuesday night, negotiators for the House and the Senate agreed to provide New York with $8.2 billion in emergency aid for downtown, including $2 billion for Mr. Whitehead's Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation. State officials, who had expected the money to go to the Empire State Development Corporation, were stunned. 
The provision giving the commission the money may not survive a final Congressional vote on the aid bill Thursday, but it was what Mr. Whitehead called a pleasant surprise. He said the money would be "well spent no matter where it is lodged," adding that his remarks about Governor Pataki and Mr. Gargano had been exaggerated. But Mr. Whitehead, a former chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company and a deputy secretary of state in the Reagan administration, continued to emphasize his independence.
"I am independent," he said in an interview yesterday before the commission's first meeting. "This body is independent. At the session where the governor and the mayor introduced us, they made it clear that we were independent."
He added that he wanted the 11 directors of the commission to set aside partisan politics in the development of an overall plan for the redevelopment of downtown. "I believe that we have a marvelous opportunity to create a truly great center of the city."
Mr. Whitehead's remarks have caused more than one Pataki advisers to wonder "Why is this guy sticking his thumb in Gargano's eye?"
But Michael Marr, a spokesman for the Empire State Development Corporation, played down the matter.
"We recognize that this will be a cooperative effort with many parties at the table, including the Empire State Development Corporation, the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation, the Port Authority, the M.T.A., local businesses and others," Mr. Marr said. "We look forward to working with all interested parties to ensure that Lower Manhattan's revitalization will help New York come back stronger than ever."
Mr. Whitehead describes himself as a conservative Republican, and no one thinks his overall vision differs from Mr. Gargano's. But people who have talked with Mr. Whitehead in recent weeks speculated that he may be positioning himself as a nonpartisan broker who can prevent the effort from being mired in politics and delays, and deal effectively with varied and competing groups. Those groups include the families of the 3,000 people killed Sept. 11 as well as real estate developers, local residents, people who work in the area and financial companies there.
Mr. Whitehead was selected by the governor because of the breadth of his contacts, from New York to Washington. He knew Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg; Richard Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange; and Lewis M. Eisenberg, former chairman of the Port Authority, from his 37 years on Wall Street. He swore in Mr. Gargano as ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago when he was at the State Department in the 1980's.
The commission met for the first time yesterday in Lower Manhattan, where Governor Pataki addressed the group, saying they would help not only to rebuild downtown but also to create a place where people once again wanted to be. No decisions were made yesterday, but Mr. Whitehead said each director would work with a different constituency and relay his or her concerns to the board.
"The views of every citizen who has a stake in the area will be taken into consideration," he said.
It is still unclear how the development corporation, a subsidiary of the Empire State Development Corporation, will function. Do its boundaries extend from the Battery to Chambers Street, or farther north to Canal? Where will its staff come from? How will it work with the Port Authority, which controls the trade center site as well as the PATH rail system that connects Lower Manhattan with New Jersey?
Some of the downtown redevelopment work is already in motion. The Port Authority authorized spending $540 million last week to build a temporary PATH station downtown to replace the underground network destroyed Sept. 11 and to plan a more ambitious permanent transportation terminal. The PATH trail will essentially create a development route, no matter what the commission decides. The building sites closest to PATH stations would become the most valuable.
Mr. Whitehead acknowledged the problems, but said he envisioned not only office towers, but also residential buildings, restaurants and cultural institutions on the site of the World Trade Center, while reaffirming Lower Manhattan as the financial center of the city and the region.
