HEADLINE: Families Without a Beacon; 
Many Who Lived Near Trade Center Feel Extra Strain

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
If many outsiders saw the World Trade Center as a cold and sterile place for business, the children of 125 Cedar Street found it a magical playground with two looming giants.
 The high-speed elevators might as well have been seesaws. That odd bit of structural bracing in a bridge across West Street? A perfect slide. Cool parties and get-togethers at a sky-high observation floor. The daily cavalcade of hawkers and commuters -- "anonymous soldiers" and "corporate robots," in the words of one young tenant -- inspiration for essays and poems. 
 "No shadows are visible, no greenery, no semblance to the planet Earth -- only the piles of paperwork and the infrequent flash of color amidst the gray and brown of corporate business suits," David-Michael Cook, 15, wrote a few years ago as he stared out his window overlooking the trade center plaza. 
He hardly recognizes the view today, for 125 Cedar Street fronts Liberty Street, directly opposite the heaping ruins of the trade center. 
Their building is undamaged structurally, but the collapse of the towers produced a storm that filled the apartments with dust, debris and rubble. The tenants have not been allowed to return and, with a major cleanup planned and the building's location at ground zero, they may not be able to until September.
Today, David-Michael, a high school freshman, finds little will to write or focus on schoolwork because "I have this weird thing; I can't bring myself to accomplish anything." There are only a few families among the tenants of 125 Cedar Street, a loft building stocked mainly with artists and white-collar workers who, after renovating the former office building a quarter-century ago, stood at the vanguard of residential living in the financial quarter.
But in some ways they have felt the strain of dislocation more sharply than their fellow tenants. 
They have moved into temporary apartments much smaller than the spacious lofts of 125 Cedar, and in some cases had to buy or borrow furniture, clothes, toys and other articles to recreate a home. 
Anxieties are heightened over how the air around ground zero and the debris in their apartments may affect children, not to mention the shock of returning to an upended neighborhood once so familiar.
David-Michael's parents, Sandra Rubel and Michael Cook, both artists, have grown frustrated looking for an affordable apartment before the lease expires next month for their temporary, cramped apartment on the Upper West Side.
Gerald Pryor and Dawn Smith, the parents of Chance, 8, and Reed, 4, the youngest children in the building, said it was enough to have survived in light of the thousands who were killed.
But they have seen the toll on their children's psyches. Reed was with Ms. Smith in their apartment when the planes crashed into the towers with an unspeakable roar, and now when he sees steam he wonders aloud, "Should I run?" Chance grows anxious when he loses sight of his parents in public and in frustration asks: "Why can't it be the way it was? Why don't they put the towers back up again?"
Peter Wheelwright said he thought his family was pulling through well, but he noted his 12-year-old son showed little interest in seeing the building in its damaged state. "I think it's too overwhelming for him," Mr. Wheelwright said, "it looks too out of control."
And although he has e-mailed pictures of the apartment to Josephine, a teenage daughter studying in China, he cannot bring himself to show her pictures of her rubble-strewn bedroom, which bore the brunt of the damage in their apartment.
"She lost everything," Mr. Wheelwright said. "The rubble is piled up against her door."
The building always was an odd duck, a 23-apartment, turn-of-the-century building in the midst of the hurly-burly of commerce. The families found this a blessing and curse.
Cedar Street lofts are spacious, in the 2,000-square-foot range, with more than a dozen windows to accommodate curious young eyes. The relative isolation of the building among corporate towers made for a safe neighborhood that, after business hours, was generally quiet and peaceful.
The trade center in essence functioned as a barrier that kept people out of the neighborhood but also made it hard for Cedar Street tenants to venture north. The nearest schools were north of the towers, in TriBeCa. The construction of Battery Park City to the west brought traditional playgrounds to the area, but it was still another neighborhood, separated by busy West Street. 
"It was always a bit of a struggle where their pals were concerned," Mr. Wheelwright said.
The children, however, came to regard the towers as comforting beacons of home.
"Visually, those towers became associated with my house," said Lily Wheelwright, 19, who grew up in the building, even learning to ride a bike in the expansive trade center concourse. "I could see them from any part of the neighborhood. My dad would always say, 'Look up for the towers if you don't know where you are to get home.' From the subway, I would get out and follow the towers."
The towers became part of family traditions. Every year for Mother's Day, the Wheelwrights would go up to the top for a group snapshot. David-Michael recalled a birthday party one year at the 107th floor observation plaza and his fascination with crowds of commuters streaming out of 7 World Trade Center.
"There were so many things there that are not anywhere else in the world," David-Michael recalled. "There were millions of people, the strange reflective bars of the buildings and the shiny and shimmering towers that seemed like a fairy tale."
At Christmastime, streams of lights hung in the towers' lobbies, carolers drifted through the plaza, and the underground mall filled with holiday shoppers.
The Pryors' children took note of large toy soldiers taking up positions near the lobbies.
"That was how they knew it was Christmastime," Mr. Pryor said.
He and Ms. Smith cannot bear to bring the children to see the ruins. Their apartment is frozen in time, with breakfast dishes still in place and little removed or disturbed because they believe the debris is contaminated. 
Mr. Pryor said testing of dust samples in their apartment found levels of asbestos at 3 percent of the dust, not high enough to pose a short-term risk, according to scientists, but well above Mr. Pryor's threshold of concern.
"If you have the children in mind, you don't chance it," he said.
They try to keep their problems in perspective; the family is intact and they mourn for the thousands killed in their backyard. But Mr. Pryor said he and his wife had struggled to explain the disaster to their children, particularly Chance, who is certain the bad men hid in the airplanes' luggage compartments to pull off the strike.
Only in a few months, they reason, will he be ready to see the area.
"I want him to be whole again, but I don't know how to make him that way yet," Mr. Pryor said.
There is also reconciling the desire to move back to a place they regarded as special with the reality that the neighborhood will never be the same.
After much deliberation and negotiation, the landlord has agreed to clean the building and the apartments. But the work requires specialized treatment because of the asbestos contamination and, with the building in ground zero, the police still restrict access to the building to short, escorted visits of 15 minutes or so. The building management has told tenants not to expect to return until September.
Even so, some tenants are hesitant to move back until there are strong assurances that it is safe.
"When the cleanup is done and the building is ready to be inhabited, that's when I am interested in testing," said Mr. Wheelwright, an architect whose office was in his home at 125 Cedar Street.
Mr. Cook and Ms. Rubel, David-Michael's parents, are also concerned about contamination, but returning to 125 Cedar sooner than later would end a frustrating hunt for suitable temporary lodging for their family. 
A church near Cedar Street has allowed them to stay at a church apartment on the Upper West Side for much of the last three months at a reduced rent, but in January it will revert to market rates, and prospective landlords have not been sympathetic.
"We have been struggling with the bureaucracy," Mr. Cook said. "FEMA has sent some checks. But we lived and worked at Cedar Street, and now we are basically unemployed. So we don't look good on paper."
And their son, David-Michael, so taken by the trade center and its bustle, finds it hard to reconcile the new world sure to emerge there with the lost one that so entranced him.
"It's a weird feeling," he said, "to think of all those people who would run by you and hit you with their elbows. It's strange to think that a lot of them are gone."

125 Cedar Street
This is the third article in an occasional series on the residents of 125 Cedar Street in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
AT&T to Sell Cable Unit To Comcast for $47 Billion
AT&T agreed to sell its cable television business, the nation's largest, to Comcast for $47 billion in stock.
 The deal would create a cable giant with more than 22 million subscribers, almost twice the size of the next-biggest cable operator, AOL Time Warner, which was a losing bidder for the operation. Page A1. 

No Deal on Stimulus Package
Congress gave up hope of reaching a deal this year with the Bush administration on an economic stimulus package. A1.

Tyson Charged in Immigrant Case
Tyson Foods, the meat producer and processor, was indicted along with six employees on charges of conspiring to smuggle illegal immigrants across the Mexican border to work in its processing plants. The government said at least two Tyson executives participated in the scheme and that the company engaged in the practices to cut costs, to meet production goals and to maximize profits. A1.

Morgan Stanley Profit Drops 28%
Morgan Stanley reported a 28 percent decline in earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter, providing the first glimpse of how poorly a depressing year ended on Wall Street. C9.

Two Hawaiian Airlines to Merge
Hawaiian Airlines and Aloha Airlines, battered by the steep drop in tourism after Sept. 11, agreed to merge in a deal that would place Greg Brenneman, the former president of Continental Airlines, in charge. C9.

Sale of Stake in Enron Unit Allowed
A federal bankruptcy court paved the way for Enron to auction off ownership interests in a joint venture that would operate the company's energy trading operation. C4.

Dow and S.& P. Rise; Nasdaq Falls
Stocks ended mixed despite strong gains in the financial and energy sectors. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 72.10 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,070.49. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.64 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,149.56, but the Nasdaq composite index fell 21.87 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,982.89. C10.

Barrick Looms in Gold's Future
In the high stakes struggle between Newmont Mining of Denver and South Africa's AngloGold for control of Australia's largest gold producer, Normandy Mining, Barrick Gold of Canada has so far been a silent spectator. But Barrick has the strongest balance sheet of any gold producer, and all eyes are on Barrick for clues about the outcome of what has become known as the Battle of Normandy and the future of the industry. Barrick's chief executive, Randall Oliphant, sees the fight for Normandy as another stage in a long-overdue consolidation. World Business, Section W.

P&O Princess Delays Vote on Deal
P&O Princess Cruises postponed by a month a meeting at which shareholders are to vote on a merger with Royal Caribbean and asked Carnival, which has made a competing conditional bid, to revise its offer. But it balked at a meeting with Carnival to work out the details. C5.

Sale of Liquor Business Approved
Diageo of Britain and Pernod Ricard of France received approval from United States antitrust regulators for their joint acquisition of the Seagram wine and spirits business. C2.

Bank of Japan to Add Cash to System
The Bank of Japan said that it would step up its purchases of government bonds and pump even more cash than before into the nation's money markets. World Business, Section W.

Overreliance on Social Security
Despite significant incentives for saving in tax-deferred plans like individual retirement accounts and Keoghs, many people save almost nothing for retirement, making them highly dependent on Social Security benefits. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Chapter 11 Filings Point Fingers at Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The fallout from the World Trade Center terror attack has started landing in a new place: the Federal Bankruptcy Court at Bowling Green.
 In the last two weeks, companies that depend on travel and tourism have begun citing the events of Sept. 11 as reasons for seeking Chapter 11 protection from their creditors, saying the attacks pushed them over the financial edge. They include a hotel at Kennedy Airport, the coffee shop of a Midtown hotel and a company that rents audio-visual equipment for business meetings. 
 Analysts say this is probably only the beginning of a wave of travel-related bankruptcies. "I suspect this is not the end," said Arnon A. Mishkin, a partner at the Boston Consulting Group, which has studied the effects of Sept. 11 on travel and tourism in New York City. 
While tourism was stronger than expected during Thanksgiving week, Mr. Mishkin said, the national economy remains weak and the outlook for travel remains uncertain. "That double whammy will probably cause additional stresses," he added.
To be sure, many travel-related businesses had problems well before the attack on the twin towers. One of the companies that filed for Chapter 11, the Best Western Carlton House at J.F.K., faces increased competition from new and recently renovated hotels at the airport. A few of those hotels are not unionized, and in its court filing, the Best Western blamed "a very onerous collective bargaining agreement" for some of its financial problems.
That is hotly disputed by the New York Hotel Trades Council, which represents the hotel's workers. "The union has already helped that hotel out on a number of occasions," said John F. Turchiano, a spokesman for the union. The contract allows any hotel that feels it needs relief to ask for an emergency hearing before an arbitrator, he said.
The union still has 4,000 members on layoffs citywide, he said, adding that the union's philosophy on hotels is, "If they're not in business, we're not in business."
The hotel's biggest problem is probably the customers it most often serves: international passengers who are stranded when airlines cancel or postpone flights, said Scott S. Markowitz, the lawyer who is representing the hotel in bankruptcy court. "I wouldn't be surprised if we see other hotels in the New York City area" with similar problems, he said.
Neither would John A. Fox of PKF Consulting, an expert on New York hotels. City hotels are likely to be only half full in January and February, he said, down from more than 70 percent in recent years. In November, 76 percent of rooms were occupied, down from 86 percent last year, and only because hotels offered large discounts.
The Audio Visual Services Corporation is not expecting a quick rebound, either. The company is based in Long Beach, Calif., but does business across the country, including at about 15 hotels in New York City. It has an office here, and filed for bankruptcy protection here because this is where its major lenders are.
The company took on heavy debt to buy small equipment suppliers in 1996 and 1997 and has been losing money for several years. "But the events of Sept. 11 gave us the final push," said Digby J. Davies, the company's president. While business improved in October and November, compared with September, he said, it has not returned to the levels of a year ago.
Filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection does not mean a company is closing or liquidating; regulars are still filling tables in the back of Raffles, a coffee shop in the Radisson Lexington Hotel on Lexington Avenue at 48th Street.
But "a high proportion of its customers are visitors to New York City who take occupancy in the hotel," according to its filing, and their numbers have been few. As a result, according to the filing, the coffee shop lost $100,000 on sales of $683,000 in its latest year.
This has left it indebted to the hotel, which was already involved in an unrelated legal dispute with Raffles's owners, said Stephen H. Penn, the lawyer representing the coffee shop owners in the bankruptcy filing.
On a recent rainy day, only two-dozen or so people were eating grilled cheese sandwiches or burgers in the coffee shop at lunchtime. Down the block, some storefronts were vacant. A shoe store had only one customer. Only a few small groups of suitcase-towing tourists trundled down the stretch of Lexington Avenue known as hotel row, and none of them stopped to shop.

HEADLINE: Thousands on Welfare Face Face a Temporary Gap in Aid 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Several thousand of New York City's poorest families have been cut off all government assistance and are facing at least 45 days without benefits, falling into a gap between the end of their federal welfare benefits and the start of the state-financed alternative, known as Safety Net, city and state welfare officials confirmed yesterday.
 Neither city nor state officials would provide exact numbers, but officials at the city's Human Resources Administration confirmed that the city had cut aid to more than 3,000 families who would have been transferred into the Safety Net program after exhausting their federal welfare benefits this month. 
 Debra Sproles, a spokeswoman for the city agency, said the 3,000 families had been cut off because, for unknown reasons, they had not responded to notices sent in October and November summoning them to apply for Safety Net. 
City officials said another group of welfare recipients were denied for refusing job offers, but would not say how many refused, or how many jobs were offered. 
Late last month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani referred to 3,000 people cut off because they were "hard cases" who "either refused jobs, or failed to do anything in order to qualify."
But examples of people whose benefits were cut off in error have multiplied. They include James Howard, a workfare subway car cleaner and a father of three whose wife is disabled. They lost all aid, including the children's food stamps, despite rules that officials said should have maintained his aid until his appeal could be heard.
Advocates for the poor have criticized the Giuliani and Pataki administrations for requiring applications, rather than following the original plan for a seamless transition to Safety Net. Critics said that bureaucratic errors, compounded by damage to the welfare computer network in the Sept. 11 attacks, could interrupt basic aid to thousands. 
But Gov. George E. Pataki said applications were necessary to make sure that the families were still eligible. The state programmed its computers to transfer welfare cases automatically unless a city caseworker intervened to stop aid by entering a denial code.
Last month John B. Madden, a spokesman for the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, said that until Dec. 1, anyone who was denied could appeal and receive aid in the meantime. But Mr. Howard's experience bears out complaints by welfare lawyers that aid often ends prematurely. Likewise, though city officials said that food stamps were supposed to be continued automatically for three months, that measure did not work for the Howards either.
Robert Doar, deputy commissioner of the Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, said that 15,000 to 20,000 needy city families were automatically transferred to Safety Net this month without having to apply, because the city had not summoned them before their federal grants expired this month. But the city did summon 10,000 to 15,000 of the 30,000 families reaching the five-year welfare limit this month, and their fate remains uncertain. From scant city figures, it appears that about 1,600 of them took subsidized jobs, joining 3,100 other recipients placed earlier as seasonal parks laborers.
For 18 months, Mr. Howard cleaned subway cars in exchange for his family's welfare grant and the hope of being hired. He received the notice to apply for Safety Net in October. But he was told that he was to be hired as a regular subway employee with a salary of $30,000 a year. That prospect vanished later as the economy worsened.
His wife, Gaynell, said she went to the Safety Net appointment in October, tried to explain the situation and asked to reschedule the meeting. But she was denied, in error, Mr. Madden said, who promised last night to try to rectify the problem. Since late November, Mr. Howard has kept half a dozen appointments in an effort to activate Safety Net and restore food stamps, all without success. 
Mrs. Howard said the family, including two daughters, 17 and 9, and a son, 19, are being threatened with eviction from the apartment where they have lived for 17 years.
"The children's Christmas is gone," Mr. Howard said.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Like Avatars Of Crime, They're Back

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
THE statistics say New York just went through a spike in crime.
 Want to know what a spike feels like? 
 Come to East New York.
Walk around New Lots Avenue beneath the elevated subway station and look around. You'll see them. The unsmiling guys in the hooded sweatshirts and bubble jackets. The ones whose eyes never meet yours. 
They're back, blatantly back, milling about on the corner near the pizza place, up to no good in a neighborhood that, though still among the most dangerous in the city, has come far since the nadir of the early 1990's. Stores that had been boarded up reopened. Empty lots became two-story attached homes. Windows and doors guarded by iron cages of protection still are. But there are so many more of them.
Now the people in this Brooklyn neighborhood are nervous, fearful of a return to the past, when violence scarred the nights and drug dealers ruled the streets.
"As soon as they see the cops leave, they surface again, just like cockroaches," said Johnny, a storekeeper in the neighborhood for 30 years. Like most people encountered in East New York one afternoon this week, Johnny, fearful of the hooded drug dealers, agreed to be interviewed only if guaranteed anonymity.
"I don't care about the statistics," he continued. "It's the people on the streets. I see things I should not be seeing."
Like all statistics, the Police Department's numbers show many things.
They show that the 75th Precinct, which includes East New York and Cypress Hills, is still the homicide capital of New York. But so far, there have been 33 homicides in the precinct this year, compared with 40 in the same period last year. In 1993, there were 126 homicides. Reports of crimes in the seven major categories, from murders to auto theft, have gone down 56 percent in the last eight years (63 percent citywide).
The statistics also reveal a spike in murders and shootings citywide this fall. Police officials cite Sept. 11, which drew thousands of officers from their regular assignments. A few weeks ago, in response to the bad crime news, police officials returned many officers to their original duties. 
Murders and shootings began to fall again throughout the city the week ending last Sunday. That week in the 75th Precinct, major crimes -- 36 percent higher than last year in the five weeks that ended Dec. 9 -- dropped almost 10 percent from their 2000 levels. In other words, the trend is beginning to move in the right direction.
BUT it does not feel that way on the ground. Michael Mazzariello, who grew up in a gentler East New York and stubbornly refuses to give up, has been increasingly worried about backsliding, in part because of the impending departure of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who responded to his complaints about the neighborhood in the mid-1990's.
"Giuliani made quality of life in the neighborhood substantially better," said Mr. Mazzariello, who runs the nonprofit East New York Legal Services. "It all comes down to the cops."
Some people in the neighborhood say things started to feel more ragged than usual even before Sept. 11, maybe because of the economy and the related rise in unemployment or for reasons not yet quantified. Not everything is, after all, a statistic.
It is not a statistic that people avoid a known drug house on Cleveland Street. Or that there are more neighborhood drunks in front of a corner church. 
"They don't cause any problems, but the group has gotten larger," said Sebastian, a local merchant. "It's the sight. It's unpleasant. And there's the guys. You see them walking the streets. I have not seen open dealing, but we know what they are doing. They're not being harassed by the cops. If you don't have constant pressure, the problems magnify.
"Just last week, I heard this noise, I thought a car backfired," Sebastian continued. "It was a gun shot. A guy stole a car, someone pulled a gun out and shot at the ground. They let him live. At least nobody got killed. I've been here five years; I never heard a gun shot."
Deputy Commissioner Thomas Antenen, a spokesman for the Police Department, said people in East New York should soon begin to feel the impact of redeployed officers. "The numbers are reversing. When all is said and done, it's effective policing is what it is. It's not a mystery."
It's not. Neither is the reason those hooded guys get away with owning the sidewalk of New Lots Avenue. They stand there day and night, in the malevolent path of people who pretend they don't see them because, for now, they can.

HEADLINE: Hawaii's 2 Airlines to Merge via Stock Swap 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Hawaii's two airlines, battered by the steep drop in tourism after Sept. 11, agreed to merge yesterday in a deal that would place the former president of Continental Airlines in charge of the new combination. 
 Hawaiian Airlines and Aloha Airlines, which have competed for 55 years, never very profitably, said that they would merge their operations in an exchange of stock. Greg Brenneman, who helped lead the turnaround at Continental before resigning in May, helped broker the deal. He will receive an ownership stake of 20 percent in the new airline and become its chairman and chief executive. 
 Mr. Brenneman said in an interview that the proposed combination would generate $90 million in cost savings and create a flagship airline for Hawaii that would be able to grow. 
"If I do a good job of working with employees and pull this off, I will do very well," he said. "That was the kind of alignment of incentives I was looking for."
The deal is the first proposed airline merger since the terrorist attacks sent the industry into its worst downturn in history. In Hawaii, where the economy depends on tourism, the number of visitors fell more than 30 percent in October from the month a year earlier, according to the state's tourism office.
The proposed deal is likely to attract attention from the Justice Department's antitrust division because the two airlines dominate travel between Hawaii's seven main islands. In a bid to head off criticism, the new company, which will be called Aloha Holdings, has agreed to freeze interisland fares for two years and to work with state officials to guarantee levels of service and agree on a formula for future fare increases. 
Gov. Ben Cayetano, a Democrat, said yesterday that he would not oppose the deal, according to The Associated Press. Mr. Brenneman said that Senator Daniel K. Inouye, also a Democrat, was an early backer of the plan. Mr. Inouye did not return calls seeking comment. A spokesman for Representative Neil Abercrombie, a Democrat, said that the congressman would defer comment until he learned more about the deal. 
Three union representatives that sit on the Hawaiian Airlines board approved the merger proposal. But airline combinations are often messy because of the difficulty negotiating seniority among various employee groups. The deal could also lead to layoffs at the two airlines, which each have about 3,000 employees. 
Another challenge will be combining fleets. Aloha flies Boeing 737's while Hawaiian is in the process of introducing the Boeing 717 to replace its aging DC-9's. It is also phasing out the wide-body DC-10 in favor of the Boeing 767. Mr. Brenneman said he would have to meet with Boeing to work out a plan and might add some 757's. 
Under terms of the agreement, shareholders of Hawaiian Airlines, which trades on the American Stock Exchange, would receive 52 percent of the shares of Aloha Holdings plus a six-year, 8 percent note with a face value of $2 a share. Shareholders of the closely held Aloha, which is controlled by the Ching and Ing families, will receive 28 percent, while Mr. Brenneman's company, TurnWorks Inc., will get 20 percent. 
The current chief executives of both airlines agreed to resign.

HEADLINE: As Economy Slumps, Even Manhattan Rents Fall 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Rents on thousands of apartments in Manhattan have tumbled in the last few months as the economy has worsened and fallout from the terrorist attack has spread beyond Lower Manhattan.
 Rent reductions in the World Trade Center area have been widespread and deep since the attack on Sept. 11, as tenants have fled. But what is surprising now is how deep the rent cuts are in other neighborhoods of Manhattan. 
 Brian Edwards, director of rentals at Halstead/Feathered Nest, one of the city's biggest rental brokerages, said that half the rental properties coming on the market now above Houston Street that are unregulated have been marked down. Unregulated properties above Houston and below 96th Street are now renting for an average of 18 percent less than they were a year ago, Mr. Edwards said. 
These unregulated apartments, for which rents are not set by law, make up about a fifth of the total number of rentals in Manhattan, analysts say, but the trend of reductions carries over to rent-regulated apartments on a smaller scale. Low-income, subsidized housing is not affected. 
Although this is traditionally a slow time for rentals, brokers, apartment hunters and landlord representatives seemed to agree that negotiation over the price is more common today than it has been in almost a decade, and that new opportunities exist for those who are looking for apartments in Manhattan. 
"Some rents are off 30 percent in Battery Park," said Mr. Edwards, referring to a neighborhood abutting the World Trade Center site. "The Upper West Side is 15 percent off. The Upper East Side is 15 to 20 percent." 
While most of the cuts have been in the asking rents for vacant, unregulated apartments, landlords have also begun to reduce prices in hundreds of rent-stabilized apartments, both for new leases and in occupied apartments as tenants threaten to leave, rewriting leases at lower prices and granting free months of rent, said Joseph Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a group that represents landlords. Many but not all of these are in the financial district, near ground zero. But throughout Manhattan, Mr. Strasburg said, landlords are finding that they need more tenants to fill their spaces.
After years of dictating take-it-or-leave-it terms in a skyrocketing rental market, landlords are now being forced to negotiate one-on-one with their tenants and are agreeing to monthly rent reductions and upgrades to bigger or more desirable apartments in the same building, for the same money. Landlords are also advertising anywhere from one to three months "free" rent, effective discounts of 9 to 27 percent. But in many cases, the landlords are refusing to write more than a one-year lease at the new lowered prices, hedging their bets that prices will rise again in a year.
The apartments affected span a broad range of neighborhoods and prices, from an $1,800 studio on East Eighth Street (now $1,450) to a four-bedroom $14,000 high-rise rental off Riverside Drive (now $8,900.)
The neighborhoods that have been affected the least, brokers said, are the so-called blue-chip neighborhoods: Central Park West, Park Avenue and Fifth Avenue, but there have been scattered rent reductions even there.
R. Kenyatta Punter, of the Central Harlem agency that bears his name, said rents on renovated brownstone apartments in Harlem had retreated to where they were two and a half years ago. "A two-bedroom that a year ago was $2,400 to $2,500 has dropped back down to the $1,800-to-$2,000 range," he explained. 
In Washington Heights, also in upper Manhattan, rents have fallen slightly less than 10 percent, said Gus Perry, of Stein-Perry Real Estate. A one-bedroom apartment there now goes for $1,200, compared with $1,300 a year ago. The reason for the relative stability? "We're much cheaper here to begin with," Mr. Perry said. 
Brokers attributed the rent markdowns primarily to the recession, with its job layoffs and fear of overspending, worsened by the construction boom of the last five years, which created thousands of new apartments.
"Clearly a lot of rentals are on the market now, in new buildings," said Paul Purcell, the president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, the city's largest real estate company. "And a lot are still trickling in."
Brokers, including Mr. Purcell, said that the diminishing pool of newcomers often prefer to buy rather than rent, taking advantage of lower interest rates.
After all, Manhattan rents still remain high; although apartments may have dropped, an entry-level, no-frills one bedroom can easily hit $2,000 a month. Two years ago, that was the going rate for a studio, said Stan Ponte, who handles downtown rentals for Stribling and Associates. "But a rare, beautifully finished, high-end one bedroom still go into the $4,000's -- and do," he said.
Scott Durkin, the chief operating officer of the Corcoran Group, predicted more drops in rents.
Mr. Durkin and his roommate got the rent on their own SoHo loft reduced in October by $500 when "we saw the same type of loft advertised for $500 to $700 less than we were paying," he said. Mr. Durkin, like many others, threatened to break his lease. When had he moved in? Only last May. That represented about an 11 percent cut, he said.
David Lowenfeld, an executive at World-Wide Holdings Corporation, which owns four buildings in Lower Manhattan, said he had received dozens of calls from tenants asking to break their leases or lower rents. Yesterday, Mr. Lowenfeld said that he let any tenant out of his lease who demanded it, and reduced rents of tenants who agreed to stay by 10 to 20 percent.
In Battery Park City, Julie Gaines, 38, and her husband, David Lenovitz, 42, were living with their two children in an 1,100-square-foot apartment when their landlord, Milford Management, sent out notices offering every tenant a 25 percent rent drop if they would stay -- at least until their leases were up. 
Nevertheless, Ms. Gaines said, a lot of renters left. "We know several couples who moved to their summer homes" in the Hamptons and New Jersey, she said. Yet even with the drop in rents, some Battery Park apartments are still standing empty. 
But Mr. Lenovitz and Ms. Gaines, who own Fishs Eddy, a domestics shop on Broadway at 19th Street, had another strategy. They offered to keep paying their old rent, $5,500, if they could move their family into a 1,900-square-foot apartment in Liberty Terrace, a neighboring high-rise owned by the same developers. That would give them almost double the space, for the same rent. The landlord quickly agreed. They moved 10 days ago.
Some developers and brokers said they believed that the rents have indeed hit bottom. But Bob Esnard, the president of the Zucker Organization, disagreed. "It's not like '93, when we hit the bottom of the barrel," he said. "We haven't gotten there yet." That year is generally considered the nadir of the last real estate recession.
Steven Schleider, a real estate analyst who helps prepares the statistics for the Real Estate Board of New York, dismissed doom-and-gloom predictions that rents were in free fall. 
Some new leases may be 15 percent less, he said, but he continued, the white-hot market of a year ago was "hyperinflated." After a meteoric rise, rentals leveled and began to decline gently last January, then dropped sharply after Sept. 11. "It was a straight line, slightly tilted down, since January," said Mr. Edwards of Halstead/Feathered Nest. "After 9/11, we really got kicked, it really got rolling."
While rents have fallen, the city's homeless population is still increasing, as the worsening economy strikes particularly hard at those at the bottom of the economic ladder. Also, the lower end of the rental market, where most of the poor live, is highly regulated and thus not affected by the new cuts in rents. 
Outside Manhattan, the softening of the rental market appears to have hit some neighborhoods harder than others. In Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Suzy Klein, owner of Klein Realty, said the rental market is "very quiet." Landlords are reducing prices of rentals about 15 percent, she said.
In the Riverdale section of the Bronx, where demand is strong and inventory is tight, rents remain the same as a year ago.
That's not true at 200 Riverside Boulevard, at the corner of West 70th Street, where the owner of a condominium in one of Donald J. Trump's West Side high-rise has finally rented his apartment for $8,900. The original rent for the five-bathroom, four-bedroom apartment was $14,000. 
Mr. Schleider, the analyst, predicted that rents would rise again. Until then, he suggested there may be a silver lining. The areas affected by the biggest rental reductions may become affordable for young people, who, he said, "will be able to live in Manhattan again."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Lacking Suitors, Bonds Remains With the Giants

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In the nearly 30-year history of baseball's salary arbitration procedure, no arbitrator has been asked to decide the salary of a player who hit 73 home runs the previous season.
 Neither the San Francisco Giants nor Barry Bonds's agent expects that scenario to occur in February, but Bonds took the unusual step yesterday of accepting the Giants' offer of arbitration, ending his free agency and ensuring his return to the Giants next season. 
 The step was unusual because free agents of the caliber of Bonds seldom accept arbitration. They sign lucrative multiyear contracts instead. But no market appeared to develop for Bonds despite his astounding season at age 37, and he opted to remain with the Giants. 
Asked if Bonds's decision reflected the absence of a market for him, Scott Boras, his agent, said, "It's an indication that there wasn't anything there in Barry Bonds's mind to compel him to leave a situation in San Francisco he was very comfortable with."
One baseball official said Boras created a virtually impossible economic goal given that his client is approaching 40. "Scott set the bar so high," the official said, "he created a difficult situation for himself." The official said Boras had been seeking a five-year, $105 million contract for Bonds, who not only broke Mark McGwire's home run record but also eclipsed two of Babe Ruth's records with an .863 slugging percentage and 177 walks. The Giants offered Bonds four years for $72 million. No one else has admitted to offering anything.
Boras is not accustomed to falling short of his goals. A year ago he attained the biggest contract in sports history, the 10-year, $252 million package for Alex Rodriguez with the Texas Rangers. "Barry isn't looking to be the highest-paid player in the game," Boras said by telephone from his home in Newport Beach, Calif. "He just wants to be properly situated among his peers."
Translation: Behind Rodriguez but ahead of a group of six players, including Derek Jeter and Jason Giambi of the Yankees, whose contracts have annual values of $17 million to $19 million.
If he were to go before an arbitrator, Bonds, given his 2001 performance and his career statistics, could conceivably gain a salary for next season of more than $20 million. But Boras said: "That's on the back burner. Our goal is to continue discussions with the club for a multiyear contract."
Larry Baer, the Giants' chief operating officer, took a similar view of the Bonds development. "Might it go to a hearing?" he asked. "I suppose there's always a chance for that. But we've made some progress and we're continuing to work with Scott Boras on reaching agreement on a long-term contract. We'll work something out. It just gives us more time to work something out."
Players who were offered arbitration and rejected it by last night's midnight deadline have until Jan. 8 to negotiate with their teams. If they fail to sign, the teams lose rights to them until May 1. A player who accepts the arbitration offer is considered a signed player.
When he was in New York in August, Bonds said the money in a new contract was "not the issue"; winning and going to the playoffs were the important things. The Giants did not get there.
"This was a lot about what Barry's objectives were when he went into this," Boras said. "Unless it was overwhelming, I think Barry intended to exhaust things with the Giants. The arbitration process allows him to have a solid floor for a year."
Bret Boone and David Bell accepted arbitration from the Seattle Mariners. Boone's agent, Adam Katz, tried to negotiate a long-term contract yesterday but said the Mariners would guarantee only three years, not four. Katz said negotiations would continue.
Among the free agents who rejected the arbitration offers were Juan Gonzalez (Cleveland), Johnny Damon (Oakland) and Chan Ho Park (Los Angeles).
Four free agents joined new teams yesterday: Moises Alou and three pitchers. Alou agreed to an offer of $27 million for three years with the Chicago Cubs; John Burkett, two years, $11 million with Boston; Dave Burba, one year, $2 million with Texas; and Dennis Cook, one year, $1.25 million with Anaheim.
Sammy Sosa, a countryman from the Dominican Republic, heavily recruited Alou, an outfielder with a career .306 average. "Tell Moises he's got to pay me some interest, a percentage," Sosa said, joking.
The Yankees had been interested in Alou but opted instead to sign Rondell White, whose departure from the Cubs created the opening for Alou. The Houston Astros, concerned about their payroll, did not try to re-sign the 35-year-old Alou.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
FLEETBOSTON LAYS OFF 700 AND WRITES OFF $650 MILLION

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The banking company FleetBoston Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off 700 of its 55,000 workers and take hundreds of millions of dollars in write-downs for the job cuts, investments that have gone bad and exposure to the Argentine financial crisis. 
The company, which is based in Boston, said the charges would total $650 million after taxes in the fourth quarter. FleetBoston, the nation's seventh-largest financial holding company and the parent of Fleet Bank, said the largest component of the charge would be a $475 million write-down of investments. The charges will all but wipe out FleetBoston's profits in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: The Bank of Japan Moves to Halt Economic Slide 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
The Bank of Japan said today that it would greatly step up its purchases of government bonds and pump even more cash than before into the nation's money markets.
 The steps are intended to help combat Japan's mounting problems with debt and deflation by further easing monetary policy, at a time when short-term interest rates are already effectively at zero. 
 The bank also said today that it would consider accepting a broader range of financial instruments as collateral for loans, including commercial paper backed by real estate and mortgages, a policy change that might make it much easier for banks to unload their nonperforming loans more easily.
The decision was made at the central bank's final meeting of the year, after weeks of lobbying by senior Japanese politicians, American officials and others, who called on the bank to loosen monetary policy to brake the country's descent into recession. 
"Japan's economy is deteriorating broadly, and is likely to undergo a severe adjustment phase for the time being," the bank said. "Today's decision is intended to secure that the financial markets continue to work in a stable manner and to ensure that economic recovery will be effectively supported from the monetary side."
The bank said it would step up its purchases of government bonds, known as rinban operations, by one-third, to 800 billion yen ($6.25 billion) a month. And it will make up to 15 trillion yen ($117 billion) available for short-term loans to companies and banks; it had been keeping 6 trillion to 9 trillion yen available.
Investors and analysts had been expecting both steps, and there was little evident reaction in the stock market.
Japanese bank stocks have been deeply depressed recently by fears that one or more of the big lenders will exhaust its capital and collapse under the weight of nonperforming loans. Reports that bad loans are piling up faster than banks can write them off have heightened investors' alarm.
The central bank and the government have been publicly chastising one another for months for doing too little to address the banks' problems. Masaru Hayami, the governor of the central bank, has argued that pumping more money into the banking system will do little good unless bank managers rapidly shed their unprofitable assets and lawmakers give them the tools to do it. Today's decision signaled that the central bank would do its part to help.
"The Bank of Japan has taken pre-emptive steps to protect the banks and markets," said Akio Makabe, an economist at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Research Institute in Tokyo. "Now, the bank will look to see if government policy makers step forward, too."
The decision to accept real estate and mortgages -- which Japanese banks hold in abundance -- is "perhaps the most bullish part of today's decision," said Ronald Bevacqua, an economist at Commerz Securities in Tokyo. "It opens the possibility that the stalemate on banking policy will soon be broken."
Representatives from Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's cabinet, the central bank and the Finance Ministry have formed a committee to discuss reviving the economy.
More broadly, though, economists said that today's policy changes were not likely to have a major impact on Japan's $3.9 trillion economy, which sank this year into its fourth recession in a decade. The bank's near-zero short-term interest rates have yet to entice either businesses or consumers to borrow more and spend more; loan demand has not grown in nearly five years. "The economy will get very little short-term boost from the Bank of Japan's moves," said Soichi Okuda, senior economist at Aozora Bank. "But if the yen weakens as a result of the monetary easing, that will be a plus for exporters."
A weakening yen may indeed prove to be a byproduct of the central bank's monetary steps, with many analysts expecting a decline to 135 yen to the dollar by March.
"The yen will continue to deteriorate for fundamental reasons," said Haruya Ida, senior analyst at Thompson IFR in Tokyo.
A rising chorus of officials on both sides of the Pacific have said they are comfortable with a weaker yen if it gets consumer prices headed up again. Inflation has been almost wholly absent from the economy for the last four years, and Japan's already high-saving consumer population now feels little urgency to buy when prices are likely to be the same or lower tomorrow. 
Haruhiko Kuroda, the Japanese vice finance minister for international affairs, signaled he was happy with the yen's 7 percent slide against the dollar since mid-November, which he said "corrects its level, which was too strong" given Japan's weak economy.
Officials from the United States Treasury Department and the International Monetary Fund have said they will accept a weakening of the yen if it results from reforms that include a reorganization of the ailing financial industry.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
For too many people, including some of the rich, Social Security is the main retirement plan.

BYLINE:  By Hal R. Varian; Hal R. Varian is an economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley. E-mail: hal@sims.berkeley.edu.

 BODY:
THE basic problem facing Social Security is that as the baby boomers age, there will be fewer workers to support more retirees. Either benefits have to be reduced or more money has to be found.
 The Commission to Strengthen Social Security focused on the latter approach, describing three plans to redirect Social Security contributions into individually owned, privately invested retirement accounts. 
 Regardless of one's views about the wisdom of private investment accounts, it is important to recognize that nothing prevents people from saving more than their Social Security contributions now. 
In fact, existing tax-deferred plans -- individual retirement accounts, Keoghs and the like -- offer attractive subsidies for private saving. Despite these significant incentives, a remarkably large component of the population saves almost nothing for retirement, making them highly dependent on Social Security benefits.
Why are personal savings so low?
Stephen F. Venti and David A. Wise, economists at Dartmouth and Harvard, respectively, recently released a fascinating glimpse of savings behavior based on data from the Health and Retirement Survey, a continuing study of approximately 7,700 households nearing retirement age. ("Choice, Chance and Wealth Dispersion at Retirement," National Bureau of Economic Research Working Paper 7521.)
Mr. Venti and Mr. Wise started their analysis by estimating the lifetime income of each household, then sorted the households into 10 equal-sized groups based on their estimate. Their most striking observation was the extreme variation in total asset accumulation within each income group. For example, the wealth held by the top 10 percent of households in the group just below the median was 35 times the wealth held by the bottom 10 percent of that same income group. The dispersion of wealth for higher-income groups was slightly smaller, but still high.
(The authors consider various definitions of wealth, some limited to financial assets, some including housing, some including the actuarial value of Social Security benefits. I use the most inclusive definition, but the other definitions tell the same story.)
It has long been known that most Americans do not save much. What is more remarkable is that even a substantial fraction of relatively wealthy people do not save much. The bottom 20 percent of every income group has zero or negative wealth, with the only exception being the households with the highest lifetime income.
Just as some high-income households had minimal accumulated wealth, some low-income households had substantial wealth. The top 10 percent of the lowest income group had accumulated more than $150,000.
Even though nearly every group in the sample had the opportunity to contribute to an I.R.A. or a 401(k) plan, only about half the households did so.
Mr. Venti and Mr. Wise consider three explanations for the large variations in wealth accumulated for retirement: household wealth was significantly affected by chance events like illness or inheritances; household investments performed far differently; and some people saved substantially more than others.
They cannot offer a definitive answer, because their data was only a snapshot at a single point in time, but they offer suggestive evidence that the first two effects were relatively small. Even after one accounts for chance events and investment performance, the dispersion in wealth remains large. They concluded that most of the observed variation in retirement wealth is primarily a result of different propensities to save.
Reluctance to save is costly. In the data Mr. Venti and Mr. Wise examined, the middle-income households had, on average, financial assets totaling about $45,000. If these households had saved 10 percent of their income and invested it in a stock market index fund, they would have had more than $250,000 of wealth by retirement age. Even if they had invested in long-term corporate bonds, they would have accumulated over $100,000.
These households were generally aware that their savings were inadequate: over three-fourths of the respondents said they had saved too little, and virtually none said they had saved too much. Most people were worried by their minimal savings: only a quarter of them thought that "Social Security or employer pensions would take care of my retirement income."
It seems that people just have very different attitudes toward saving: some people do it, and some do not. I have my own theory about why there is such a low personal saving rate: I blame it on advertising. Businesses spend billions of dollars encouraging people to spend, and many people just cannot resist the temptation.
By contrast, only a pittance is devoted to advertising that encourages people to save. A typical ad for an I.R.A. shows a gray-haired middle-aged man playing golf. A more realistic ad might depict a bag lady sitting next to a grocery cart. O.K., that is a bit extreme -- but that sort of ad would send the right message: look what happens to you if you do not save.
Other analyses of consumer behavior show that I.R.A.'s and 401(k) plans have increased aggregate savings. But less than half the population takes advantage of such plans. There should be more plans aimed at the lower end of the income distribution.
It is not impossible to save $5 or $10 a day -- many people spend that much on lottery tickets and cigarettes. But $10 a day is $3,650 a year, and that amount can accumulate significantly over a lifetime.
As the Venti-Wise study shows, many low-income households save this much now. And many high-income households, to whom $10 a day is surely insignificant, do not bother to save even that tiny amount.
President Bush's Social Security commission was not asked to consider plans to encourage more voluntary saving. Instead, it focused on how mandated savings -- Social Security -- will be structured. One would hope that some part of whatever plan emerges from Congress's deliberations will offer better ways to encourage Americans to save more in addition to their Social Security contributions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard D. Parsons, left, a Republican who will be chief executive of AOL Time Warner, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, right, the former senator from New York, who is a Democrat, led the President's Commission to Strengthen Social Security. The group sought ways to redirect money into private investment accounts. (Susana Raab for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: White House Scuttles Plan For G.O.P. Ad Campaign 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Republican Party officials were on the verge of going forward with their first political advertising campaign since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, but the White House scuttled the project more than a week ago.
 The centerpiece of the campaign, party officials said today, was a television commercial that upbraided the Democrats and called on them to work with Republicans on an economic stimulus bill. The commercial was to be supplemented by radio advertisements in House districts tailored to help -- or hurt -- specific candidates. The effort was so far along that party officials had already prepared a news release about it that was never made public. 
 Karl Rove, President Bush's top political adviser, said today that he intervened and concluded that the campaign would be "a waste of time and money." Mr. Rove said he had anticipated that the Democrats would have put more resources into their radio advertising campaign that they began last month, which castigated House Republicans for favoring "Washington special interests" in the stimulus package.
"The original intent was to run the ad if the Democrats got serious about their ads," Mr. Rove said in an interview. "If their ads were nothing more than slightly expensive news releases -- i.e. they bought a couple of dozen spots in a district -- there was no need to run it. So the reason that it didn't run was everyone agreed that the threshold had not been crossed by the Democrats."
Other Republican officials said another reason they decided against the commercials was that they did not want the party and the president to appear too political with the nation at war.
Trent Duffy, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said the party had broadcast only one commercial this year. He said it ran in late August and criticized Democrats on Social Security.
"You don't want to spend those resources in December," one Republican official said, "when there's no indication politically that the Democratic attacks have any traction."
Mr. Rove said the party spent three thousand or four thousand dollars to produce the commercial. But he said that broadcasting it for wide viewership would have been another matter.
"If you want to be serious about it, it will cost you," Mr. Rove said. "It takes real money to put it up."
The White House keeps a tight grip on the Republican National Committee. But the committee is in a transition because Mr. Bush recently named Marc Racicot, the former governor of Montana, as chairman and he has not yet taken over.
Mr. Rove said plans for the advertising campaign were never as far along as some party officials believed. "Somebody over there who is not part of the process heard about it and started talking about it," he said.
Two weeks ago, House Democrats released radio commercials attacking three Republicans for contributing to the economic slump: Representatives John Hostettler of Indiana, John Shimkus of Illinois and Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia.
Democratic officials would not disclose the size of the advertising campaign, but Mr. Rove said the party spent "barely enough to be heard."
But in Illinois at least, the advertisement was potent enough against Mr. Shimkus that he responded with a radio commercial in which he defended his efforts to reduce unemployment.
Jenny Backus, a spokeswoman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said that in not broadcasting the commercial, the Republicans had demonstrated that "in the House they have a big vulnerability on the economy." She said the commercial "would have made them look defensive."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid Package Lifts FedEx Earnings 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
The FedEx Corporation said today that its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 26 percent as the company received government aid after Sept. 11. FedEx said it might earn less than forecast this quarter. 
 Net income climbed to $245 million, or 81 cents a share, in the quarter ended Nov. 30, compared with $194 million, or 67 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 4.9 percent, to $5.14 billion. 
 Analysts had expected the company to earn 64 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
FedEx carried more mail from the United States Postal Service than expected in the first full quarter of a contract that Frederick Smith, the company's chairman, pursued to make more use of FedEx's jets. He created a home-delivery unit last year to stop customers from switching to cheaper, slower shipments at rivals like United Parcel Service Inc. The moves will not insulate profit in a recession, FedEx said.
"They expressed very reasonable caution regarding the business for the next quarter," said Nicholas Moore, analyst at Jurika & Voyles.
FedEx received $116 million in government aid before taxes after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks grounded planes for two days, help that will not be repeated this quarter, said Alan Graf Jr., the chief financial officer. The company does not expect the economy to improve until the second quarter of 2002.

HEADLINE: Senate Vote Rejects a Bid To Increase Aid to Farms 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Senate Republicans effectively killed the $171 billion farm bill today, blocking the Democratic measure for this session. 
 The wide-ranging bill, which covers food stamps, rural development, and conservation programs as well as crop subsidies, would have added billions to the current subsidy system. Those federal payments act as a safety net for thousands of American farmers, providing over $10 billion in direct payments every year. 
 A similar measure passed the House in October over the objections of the Bush administration, which had warned it was too expensive and gave too much money to commodity subsidies and not enough to conservation efforts. 
In response, the Democratic-sponsored measure in the Senate offered an additional $22 billion for conservation and environmental programs over the next decade.
But Democrats failed three times this week to win enough votes for their bill, underlining the deep divisions in Congress over how best to support American farmers who have been struggling with depressed crop prices and increasing competition in the global market.
After the vote today, the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, said he planned to bring up the measure again next month. But he warned that the deficits in next year's budget could mean there would be far less money for farm programs.
"The real losers today are not Democrats or Republicans," Mr. Daschle said, "the losers are hard-working family farmers and rural America." 
But Republicans themselves disagree over how to recast farm policy that dates from the Depression era. Especially contentious is how to alter the system that rewards a fraction of American farmers, those with large grain and cotton operations, with most of subsidies.
Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana and ranking minority member of the Agriculture Committee, rejected the accusation that Republicans were blocking the bill and hurting farmers. 
Instead, Mr. Lugar argued, there was ample time to replace the current law, which will not expire until next October, with a bill that he said should cast the safety net of subsidies far wider to help all farmers.
"This bill was crafted to benefit a fairly small number of farmers in America," Mr. Lugar said. "It is not in the best interest of a large majority of farmers."
During the debate, lawmakers from both parties argued for payment limitations, spurred by growing complaints from smaller farmers. Farmers can now learn which of their neighbors are receiving subsidy money, and how much, on a Web site opened last month.
Republican and Democratic senators also disputed whether the measure provided enough money for the food stamp program.
With unemployment rising and welfare benefits running out for many families over the coming year, food stamps will become critical, lawmakers said.
The Senate bill would increase financing for food stamps by $6.2 billion. The House measure would add about half that amount, or $3.6 billion, to a program that suffered deep cuts in the effort to overhaul welfare in the Clinton administration.
Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee and sponsor of the bill, said these differences paled in comparison to problems in rural America that he said needed to be addressed urgently by the passage of a new farm bill.
"This is a really sad day for farmers and ranchers," Mr. Harkin said. "We've essentially said to them, Go take a hike -- we'll deal with you later."
But Democrats are as divided as Republicans over subsidies. Midwestern lawmakers like Senator Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota were pushing for a ceiling on payments that would allow more farmers to receive smaller payments. But Southern Democrats opposed limitations because they would hurt large rice and cotton farmers who are among the biggest beneficiaries of the current system.
The administration has criticized both Senate and House measures, saying many of the price supports under consideration would encourage overproduction, which keeps prices low and pushes up land rents. 
Those subsidies, in turn, could be in violation of international trade agreements and undercut American farm exports. Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman has said the best hope for farmers is to increase their exports overseas.

HEADLINE: AT&T'S CABLE DEAL: THE REGULATORS; 
New Era in Washington Paves Way for This and Other Deals

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Beyond its business rationale, the proposed merger of the nation's largest and third-biggest cable television companies announced tonight reflects the sea change in the regulatory thinking of Washington policy makers.
 A series of favorable court decisions this year and the appointment by President Bush of senior regulators skeptical of the old rules have ushered in a new era of deregulation in telecommunications. As a result, the proposed deal between AT&T and Comcast, which would have been unthinkable only a year ago, is not expected to encounter any serious impediments here. 
 Analysts predict it will lead to other cable television mergers, as the losing bidders scramble to find new partners to compete with their ever-growing rivals. 
"This is only the starting point," said Blair Levin, a former top telecommunications official in the Clinton administration who is now a regulatory analyst at Legg Mason.
It will also give some legal ammunition to supporters of the proposed merger of EchoStar Communications and the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors, the two players in the satellite television industry, which have encountered significant criticism by some experts who fear that the deal would lead to a monopoly. The companies contend they need to merge to compete effectively with cable TV.
The change in policy is lamented by consumer groups, and others critical of industry trends toward greater consolidation who fear the consequences of too few players controlling programming decisions and access to viewers. The old restrictions on ownership were justified on a theory first enunciated at the dawn of the radio era in the 1930's that the control of media outlets should not be left to too few players because diversity of viewpoints is so vital to a democracy.
"I think it's sad we're losing so much diversity of thought and opinion," Ted Turner, the cable television pioneer and largest shareholder in AOL Time Warner, said last month in a speech in California before cable television executives. "We're getting to the point where there's going to be two cable companies left. I doubt the government will let the last two merge, but you never know."
A year ago, the proposed deal was unimaginable in Washington. The proposed merger would give the combined company control over more than 22 million subscribers, about 34 percent of the paid subscription television market, which includes cable and satellite, and nearly 40 percent of the cable market alone. 
A set of regulations prevented cable companies like AT&T from growing any larger, and antitrust and telecommunications officials who had already approved a spate of big deals that had catapulted AT&T to the top of the industry were growing fearful of the concentration of the market. Last December, the Federal Communications Commission went so far as to order the company to sell some cable assets. 
But three months later, in March, a Federal appeals court struck down the regulations that had prevented the largest cable companies from growing larger and broadcasting more of their own shows. The panel found that the rules violated the companies' First Amendment rights to reach new audiences and to control their programming, a decision that the Supreme Court declined to review last week.
At the same time, a new administration took over at the Federal Communications Commission led by Michael K. Powell, who has repeatedly voiced skepticism about concentration rules and has said they appear to have outlasted their usefulness. Mr. Powell has said that for all the concern about the concentration of media there is no shortage of diverse news and entertainment on cable television, and that the Internet also provides consumers with a virtually unlimited menu of choices.
The commission and a Federal appeals court here are in the midst of proceedings that many expect will lead to the repeal of a raft of restrictions on ownership in the broadcasting and newspaper industries. Still, consumer groups say that there are other problems with permitting cable companies from growing too large. 
"This deal puts AT&T and Comcast in a position of having undue power on the programming market," said Gene Kimmelman, a senior director at Consumers Union. "We are on a path of massive consolidation."
"Further consolidation generally means that the large companies can expand their dominance over the delivery of cable programming, slow down competitors and have greater control over what channels and programming the public receives," he said.
Mr. Kimmelman noted that since Congress approved cable deregulation in 1996, basic cable rates have risen an average of 38 percent, rising annually at a rate of two to three times the rate of inflation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael K. Powell, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is skeptical about rules limiting cable concentration. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Fills Nine Posts With Government Veterans 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
With less than two weeks before he takes over as mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced the selection of nine more people to serve in his administration, saying that he expected to have most of the senior jobs filled by the time he takes his oath of office on Jan. 1.
 The appointments by the Republican mayor-elect included five people who had served in the administration of Rudolph W. Giuliani, one who worked for Mayor Edward I. Koch, and one who worked for Gov. George E. Pataki. 
 Mostly, though, the choices announced by Mr. Bloomberg -- a business executive who is about to take his very first job in public service -- were notable for their extensive experience in city and state government. 
Mr. Bloomberg's appointments included a chief of staff and commissioners to run the Departments of Probation, Sanitation, Transportation, Correction, Records and Information Services, and the mayor's Community Assistance Unit.
He also reappointed Tino Hernandez chairman of the city Housing Authority, and appointed Vincent A. La Padula, an adviser to Mr. Giuliani with strong ties to the city's Republican Party, as his senior adviser. Mr. Bloomberg, who was a Democrat before changing his registration to run for mayor, had come under fire from some city Republican leaders for naming mostly Democrats to senior positions.
Mr. Bloomberg has now chosen 16 people to serve in his administration. A number of key positions remain to be filled, including a deputy mayor for economic development, a budget director and commissioners for the Human Resources Administration and the Health, Fire, Buildings and Parks Departments.
Nonetheless, Mr. Bloomberg made it clear that he was satisfied with the pace of his transition, and said he was confident that his government would be mostly in place by the time he took over. He said he had requested that commissioners in those agencies where appointments had not been made to stay in place until after the holidays.
The mayor-elect is expected to name another raft of commissioners, probably including a budget director and deputy mayor, on Dec. 26.
"Our anticipation is that we will not have everybody in place by Jan. 1, but no administration has ever done that," Mr. Bloomberg said. He then proceeded to make a comparison with past administrations, though characteristically, he took care not to be critical of his predecessors.
"Having said that, we think that we are as far -- if not further ahead -- than comparable periods in the past," he said. "We are pleased with our progress. The most important thing to do is find the best people -- the best and the brightest. And we will take whatever time is necessary to do exactly that."
Along those lines, Mr. Bloomberg said that he was not considering gender, ethnicity or political registration in making his selections. Nonetheless, he said he was confident that the ultimate makeup of his administration would reflect the city's population.
"When we're done you will find a group of commissioners that pretty much reflects the population of New York City," Mr. Bloomberg said.
He then paused and took note of the group around him, which included eight men, seven of whom were white, and one woman.
"It's an accident that today there was only one women, for example," he said. "There are others we are very close to appointing. It just happened to work out today, this way. I have no particular targets. I am not looking at race, ethnicity, gender, whatever."
The woman Mr. Bloomberg was referring to was Iris Weinshall, whom he reappointed as commissioner of the Transportation Department, and who is the third woman to take a major post in Mr. Bloomberg's administration. Ms. Weinshall is married to Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat. ("Iris, are you a Democrat, really?" Mr. Bloomerg said. "I'm shocked. Do you have any affiliation with the party that I don't know about?")
Similarly, Mr. Bloomberg said he had not asked the party registrations of this latest raft of appointments. "Well, I haven't asked anybody here who is what," he said. "But presumably, after we finish this, you'll be rushing to ask and trying to make something of it."
In response to questions from reporters, four of the appointees said they were Democrats, four said they were Republicans, and one said that he was not registered in either party.
Among the Democrats who received top positions was Peter J. Madonia, who worked as a deputy chief of staff under Mr. Koch. He has been running his family bakery in the Bronx since the death in 1998 of his older brother. He will be Mr. Bloomberg's chief of staff.
In addition to reappointing Mr. Hernandez and Ms. Weinshall, both Democrats, Mr. Bloomberg also reappointed William J. Fraser, a Republican, as commissioner of the department of correction. And he announced that John H. Doherty, a Democrat who had run the Sanitation Department from 1994 to 1998, would return to the post.
Mr. Bloomberg also appointed Jonathan D. Greenspun, an executive assistant to Mr. Pataki with extensive ties to the city's Orthodox Jewish community, commissioner of the mayor's community assistance unit. He also named Brian G. Andersson, now an assistant commissioner, commissioner of the Department of Records and Information Services.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg was surrounded yesterday by nine people he named to his administration, which takes over in two weeks. Six of the appointees worked for previous mayors. Asked for a show of hands by party affiliation, the four Republicans in the group raised theirs. (Justin Lane for The New York Times)
