HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Military Sweeps

SEARCH PROPOSED -- The American commander in Afghanistan, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, has proposed that United States troops be deployed to comb the wild terrain of Tora Bora to determine the fate of Al Qaeda leaders. The proposal stems from a recognition that the Afghan allies may not be able to establish control over Tora Bora, an untamed region that borders Pakistan. A1

FORCES IN YEMEN -- Troop reinforcements moved into the remote hills of central Yemen, where government forces have battled tribesmen in an effort to capture suspected operatives of Osama bin Laden. B2

Tracking Efforts

ELUDING CAPTURE -- Almost all the top leadership of the Taliban has survived the American bombing campaign and eluded capture by American-backed Afghan forces. A1

A DISAPPEARANCE -- Qari Akka, a militant mullah who harbored Al Qaeda terrorists at his compound outside Kunduz, has slipped from Northern Alliance detention and into the Afghan landscape. B3

BRITISH MOVE -- Britain told the United Nations that it would lead a security force in Kabul and that an advance contingent of 200 soldiers was expected to arrive in the Afghan capital by Saturday for the swearing in of the new interim government. B3

Looking to Future Threats

SECRET WORK IN IRAQ -- An Iraqi defector said he worked on renovations of secret facilities for biological, chemical and nuclear weapons in wells, private villas and under the Saddam Hussein Hospital in Baghdad as recently as a year ago. A1

CHEMICAL WEAPONS BAN -- Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi, has notified diplomats in the Netherlands that after two decades of building a stockpile of chemical weapons he is ready to sign an international treaty banning them. B1

WARNING ON IRAQ -- The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, said that an expansion of the United States' war on terrorism into Iraq would only increase tensions in the Middle East. B4

NEW POWERS -- President Bush has granted the secretary of health and human services the power to classify information as secret, a step that shows how the battle against terrorism is drawing domestic agencies into the security apparatus. B6

Arrests and Charges

DIPLOMATS FRUSTRATED -- Foreign diplomats in New York whose job it is to monitor the welfare of their citizens say that as terrorism investigations reach a fourth month, they are frustrated by a dearth of information available on many cases and concerned by reports of mistreatment of some detainees. B5

DECIDING ON WALKER -- President Bush is nearing a decision about what to do with John Walker Lindh, the Californian-turned-Taliban fighter. The White House review came as CNN broadcast an interview with Mr. Walker, in which he said the jihad was "definitely" the right cause. B5

TERROR SUSPECT -- The Belgian police have arrested a Tunisian-born man they say had contacts with Muslim militants across Europe and recruited men for training in Al Qaeda camps. B5

Preventive Measures

VACCINE QUESTIONED -- As dozens of Congressional staff members prepared to be vaccinated against anthrax, critics questioned the safety of the vaccine and complained about the failure of federal health officials to take a stand on whether postal workers who might have been exposed should get the shots. B1

A RARE LETTER -- Donna Snyder, a grocery store employee in New Hampshire, has discovered that she has one of only two pieces of mail known to have been recovered from one of the planes that crashed into the World Trade Center. B6

SURPRISE FOR DONORS -- Since Sept. 11, many people have given blood for the first time, and some of them are finding out through Red Cross blood screening that they have diseases like hepatitis. B6

The Aftermath

DIESEL TANK WAS HAZARD -- Fire Department officials warned the city and the Port Authority in 1998 and 1999 that a giant diesel fuel tank for the mayor's command bunker in 7 World Trade Center, which collapsed on Sept. 11, posed a hazard. B1

AID TO FAMILIES -- The overseer of a federal compensation fund for victims of the Sept. 11 attacks has reportedly decided that the charity the families have received will not count against them in the calculation of awards from the fund. B7

COUNT OF DEAD FALLS -- The official count of the dead and missing from the World Trade Center attack dropped below 3,000, meaning that the Sept. 11 death toll in New York is now less than half as high as was once feared. B7

VOWS TO REBUILD -- John C. Whitehead, chairman of the downtown redevelopment commission, is assuring business and civic groups that he will lead an effort to rejuvenate the area and build a monument to rival the Lincoln or Vietnam Memorials. B7

DISPLACED NEIGHBORS -- The people who lived in a loft building directly opposite the World Trade Center are feeling the strain and sadness of dislocation. D1

The Arts

PATRIOTIC FILM -- "The Spirit of America," a three-minute montage of clips from 110 American movies, will be the first fruit of the post-Sept. 11 collaboration between Washington and Hollywood to appear in theaters. E1

PLAY ON AFGHANISTAN -- "Homebody/ Kabul," a play by Tony Kushner that is a meditation on Afghanistan, opened at the New York Theater Workshop. E1

TICKET PROGRAMS -- In a continued push to provide emotional solace to victims of the terror attacks as well as economic stimulus to New York cultural institutions, two new plans to give away thousands of free and discounted tickets to cultural events are beginning this week. E1

HEADLINE: Council Cuts $766 Million From Budget 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The City Council approved $766 million in spending reductions yesterday to help the city close an estimated $1.3 billion shortfall in the current year's budget. The reductions were approved after the Council negotiated an agreement with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to restore some cuts to cultural institutions, libraries and social services.
 As city officials moved to deal with fiscal fallout from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and a souring economy, they acknowledged that two planned tax cuts would not be taking effect, after all. A $100 million package of tax cuts that was put into this year's budget but never approved by the Legislature was declared dead for the year. Council officials also said that they would not extend the elimination of a personal income tax surcharge -- a move that would net the city an additional $181 million this year, and $362 million next year. 
 The Council voted unanimously to alter the budget for the fiscal year ending next June at its final scheduled meeting, just 12 days before more than two-thirds of its members will be forced by term limits to step down. Before they voted, the speaker of the council, Peter F. Vallone, praised them for taking action and not foisting the budget problem off on their successors. 
"They could have just said, 'It's your responsibility now; you do the cuts,' " Mr. Vallone told the outgoing Council members, and some of those who will replace them in January. "They didn't do that. And they're here today ready to vote on something that's not pleasant to do, but something our constituents know is necessary to do. There is no way this city will survive without making financial sacrifices."
The city typically modifies its budget in November to adjust for any changes that have occurred since the budget was adopted in June. But this year, faced with the attack on the World Trade Center and the recession in the rest of the nation, the adjustment took on new urgency.
The combination of the disaster and the sluggish economy led the city to collect $1.1 billion less than it had anticipated in taxes. That, combined with more than $200 million in other revenue that failed to materialize, had to be offset with spending cuts and additional revenue sources, including aid the city expects for the World Trade Center attacks, and money from the tax cuts that never took effect.
Many of the savings come from across-the-board cuts to city agencies, and some come from canceling plans to expand services, rather than from cutting existing services. But even with the $55 million in proposed cuts that council leaders were able to restore, and offset with other savings, the new budget plan will still hit cultural institutions, libraries and social services hard.
The plan also recognized $738 million in other sources of revenue, including $100 million in tax cuts that the Giuliani administration had put in the budget but which were not approved by the State Legislature.
One of the largest cutbacks in individual programs involved a $71 million plan to expand day care programs for 10,000 more children who are on a waiting list of 30,000. 
It will eliminate a $5.3 million program to pay for meals for elderly immigrants and a $6.5 million anti-smoking program. It will cut in half a $3.2 million public education program intended to reduce AIDS among minorities, and cut a third of a $3.2 million program to reduce infant mortality in the city. It drastically scales back a plan to put social workers in senior centers, and cuts all but $450,000 from a $5 million program called Promise, which was designed to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs.
The agreement calls for cutting $16 million in aid from libraries, $10 million less than the mayor had originally proposed. A further $12 million of that cut could be restored, though, through a program in which the city will agree to match private donations to the libraries. It calls for cutting $11.8 million in aid to cultural institutions, with the biggest cuts falling on the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the American Museum of Natural History and the Wildlife Conservation Society. 
Although officials said that the modification that was passed yesterday should help the city end the current fiscal year with a surplus of at least $375 million, they acknowledged that it did little to help the city with the fiscal problems that it will face next year.
When Michael R. Bloomberg is sworn in as mayor next month, along with the new Council members, their first order of business will be to close a budget gap for next year that has been estimated at $3.6 billion to $4.7 billion.
The budget modification recognizes that several tax cuts that were supposed to be part of this year's budget will not take effect, after all. 
The budget had called for cutting the city's hotel tax, as well as taxes for co-op and condominium owners, reductions for first-time home buyers and for parents who use child care. But the Legislature never approved a bill that would have enabled the cuts to take effect. The package would have cost the city an estimated $100 million this year -- money that can now be used to close the budget gap. 
Separately, Council officials said that they would allow a surcharge on the city's personal income tax to be reimposed. The surcharge -- which officials said varied but averaged 7 percent -- had been temporarily eliminated until Dec. 31. The re-imposition of the surcharge will yield an additional $181 million in the current fiscal year, which ends in July, and $362 million in 2003. 
The passage of the budget modification -- 48 to 0, with three members of the Council absent -- ended two weeks of feverish negotiations.
When the mayor handed in his first proposal to modify the budget on Dec. 4, Council leaders were dismayed that he called for eliminating many of their favorite projects. After negotiating, the Council got the mayor to restore roughly $55 million of those cuts, replacing them with other cuts. One Council official said that it was a fitting farewell -- a compressed version of the usual budget back-and-forth.
"It was the annual dance," the official said, "but done quickly."

OVERVIEW
Budget Agreement

The City Council and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed yesterday on a plan to close an estimated $1.3 billion gap in the current year's budget with spending cuts and new revenue sources.

NEW REVENUES: $738 million, including:

$428 million in federal and state reimbursements the city expects for the World Trade Center attack

$210 million from revenues generated in past years

$100 million from tax cuts included in this year's budget but never approved in Albany

SPENDING CUTS $766 million, including across-the-board cuts and:

$16 million cut from aid to libraries

$11.8 million cut from aid to cultural institutions

$5.3 million from elimination of a program to pay for meals for elderly immigrants

$1 million from elimination of rent subsidies for domestic violence victims who must leave shelters

$1.7 million from a 3 percent decrease in spending on contracts for homeless shelters

$4.5 million from reductions in a program to reimburse the elderly for prescription drugs

$2.75 million from reductions in a program to put social workers in senior centers

$6.5 million from elimination of an antismoking program

HEADLINE: His Term Ending, Giuliani Celebrates His Record 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
In the first of several farewell appearances yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani listed many of the benchmarks of his administration, like crime reduction, in what seemed an attempt to cement his legacy beyond his much-heralded leadership since Sept. 11.
 In addressing hundreds of civic and business leaders at the Regent Hotel on Wall Street, Mr. Giuliani reminded his audience that the city had improved tremendously in myriad ways since he took office eight years ago, and he suggested that many of his policies would survive the current damage, both psychic and financial, of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. 
 Last night, the mayor, who has less than two weeks left in office, attended his last town meeting, at a catering hall in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Instead of the series of requests to solve intractable problems that took up much of the 95 earlier such meetings, though, Mr. Giuliani last night faced a string of tributes from an adoring crowd. 
A student at John Jay College of Criminal Justice gushed, "My question is, you were the strength for the whole country. How will you continue this after you leave office, and can I have your autograph?"
The mayor dutifully signed a baseball the woman handed to him, and told her: "I thank you very much for saying that, but I'll tell you my secret: People of the City of New York were my strength. You really are incredible. I don't know if you realize how strong you are."
Earlier, at the Regent, Mr. Giuliani extolled the city's enduring nature in the face of falling tourism, pessimistic economic data and thousands of people burdened by unimaginable loss. He said that New Yorkers worried about the spirit of the city or its future "should just stop worrying."
"They should just get their heads up, instead of looking down at the ground and worrying and sweating and perspiring. They should just look up and they should look around and they should take a look at how the response the city had to Sept. 11 has made New York City, the capital of the world, now the most popular, the best regarded, the most wonderful city on the planet that everyone wants to come to and be a part of," the mayor said. "So build on the positive part and the optimistic part, and then the city's future is going to be even better than we produced."
Mr. Giuliani began his remarks by projecting on two giant screens a Time magazine cover from 11 years ago that featured the headline "The Rotting Big Apple."
From there, the mayor did a play-by-play from his management report, which was prepared before Sept. 11 and disseminated with little fanfare a few weeks later. Standing in front of a giant twinkling Christmas tree, surrounded by grand Corinthian columns, the mayor seemed to be speaking extemporaneously, perhaps because he knows his favorite statistics like his beloved Yankees know their batting averages.
Factoring out the World Trade Center attack, the mayor said that crime was at its lowest in 30 years, with the number of violent and other crimes falling 7.6 percent even this year.
Since he took office, personal income is up 49 percent, taxes are lower, the city's population has swelled to roughly eight million and private employment reached an all-time high, he said. More children have health insurance. Capital projects for arts groups have increased. And the city budget, in his opinion, was managed in a way that helped the city absorb the tremendous losses of revenues after the terrorist attack better than it would have, he said, had the city listened to those who encouraged it to pay down long-term debt.
Back before he took office, "New York City was seen as a place that was a failure," Mr. Giuliani said, adding that many cities have come to New York now to review Compstat, its program of tracking agency performances through computer statistics, which the mayor cites as the cornerstone of his mayoralty.
Aside from his extensive presentation on crime statistics -- a presentation that he has given several times in the last year -- Mr. Giuliani took extra time to stress what he seems to feel are his key successes.
For instance, he noted the 59 percent reduction in the number of people on welfare during his tenure, and reiterated how important the policy of reducing the rolls was to him and his administration. "The Human Resources Administration used to exist for the purpose of putting you on welfare," he said. "And now, instead of encouraging people to be on welfare, it tries to find a job for someone, so that we can do something real for someone."
And he lambasted the school board, one of the few important areas that is not, in spite of his prodigious desire, under his control. "The Board of Education has gotten tremendous support under this administration," he began, like a doctor at a medical conference winding up to describe an intractable disease. "I can't say, I wish I could say to you, that they have used the money as efficiently and as effectively" as numerous other departments. "Unfortunately, they continue to have a structure that is totally and absolutely inconsistent with the principles we espouse: accountability."
In many ways, the mayor's speech was a thank-you note to his former and current administration. Former and current members, in fresh blue suits and decorated uniforms, sat in the front row. They stood when he walked into the room, laughed at his jokes and gave him a standing ovation when he concluded his remarks. "After Sept. 11 the whole world found out about how talented you are," he told them. "I think you can be very, very proud about the condition in which you are leaving New York."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS GIVES UP ON DEAL THIS YEAR TO HELP ECONOMY 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Congress gave up hope today of reaching a deal this year to help the growing ranks of the unemployed and hasten a recovery from the recession and along with the Bush administration turned instead to partisan finger-pointing over who was to blame for the impasse.
 Stopped by reporters tonight as he left the Capitol, a bag of Christmas wrapping paper in his hand, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, was asked whether the economic stimulus package was dead. "Yeah," he replied as he went out the door. 
 Republicans did not dispute his characterization, even as they brought a new version of their plan to the floor of the House tonight to spotlight their proposals. And with neither side eager to be seen as walking away, mid-level administration officials negotiated into the night with senators from both parties on the off chance they could make a last-second breakthrough. 
Congress may tackle the issue again when it reconvenes next month. But the failure for now of the two parties and President Bush to agree on a legislative package to address the first recession in a decade led some economists to mark down their expectations for a comeback next year in business activity and job creation. 
Combined with the personal nature of the criticism that flew across partisan lines as negotiations ground to a halt, it also suggested that Democrats and Republicans in Congress would head into the 2002 election year more divided than ever over taxes, health care and other issues.
In many ways, Mr. Bush, the Republican-controlled House and the Democratic-controlled Senate were not far apart. They had agreed to give low-income workers a $300 per person check, and Democrats had signaled a willingness to go along with Republican insistence that the current 27 percent income tax rate be reduced to 25 or 26 percent. Both parties favored tax breaks that would give businesses an incentive to invest in new equipment. And Republicans had conceded that the package would have to include a substantial amount of money for unemployment benefits, including a 13-week extension of the current 26-week limit for unemployment payments.
But the talks failed to bring the parties together on what emerged as the most contentious issue, how to provide health insurance benefits to people who lose their jobs. 
With hopes fading for a deal, both parties engaged in some political gamesmanship.
During a visit to Capitol Hill this morning, Mr. Bush stunned Democrats by saying that "members of both political parties and both bodies of Congress have come to an agreement." 
But the deal Mr. Bush referred to was with three Democratic senators -- John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Zell Miller of Georgia -- who had previously signaled their support for a compromise floated by the White House last week. White House officials quickly acknowledged that Mr. Bush did not have an agreement that would bring along enough Democrats to overcome the 60-vote procedural hurdle needed to pass legislation in the closely divided Senate.
The president's assertion of having reached a deal was part of a broader effort by Republicans to cast Democrats -- particularly Mr. Daschle, a potential presidential candidate in 2004 -- as obstructionist.
To hammer home the point that the problem was with the Senate, House Republicans took up an amended version of the economic stimulus package they had passed in October. The bill contained $46 billion in tax cuts for businesses in the coming year. It also contained $13.5 billion in tax cuts for middle- and upper-income individuals, mainly through a reduction in the current 27 percent income tax rate to 25 percent, plus $13.7 billion for low-income workers in the form of one-time, $300 per person payments and $39 billion for increases in unemployment and health care benefits. The bill also contained tax breaks intended to help the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan and to help the families of victims of the terrorist attacks.
The bill significantly scaled back some provisions in the earlier House stimulus bill, passed in October, that Democrats had attacked as a giveaway to big companies at the expense of workers. Instead of calling for repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax at a cost of $25.4 billion next year, as the first bill had, the new version would cut the tax by $1.2 billion next year.
But Democrats said the Republican approach did not go far enough in expanding unemployment benefits for part-time workers and others who do not now qualify for benefits. And they said the Republican approach to providing health insurance subsidies to laid-off workers through tax credits would leave many people unable to afford coverage. 
The House bill passed its main procedural hurdle in a largely party-line vote of 219 to 198.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, defended the bill as a good-faith effort to find common ground with Democrats.
"As the Congressional session draws to a slow and difficult conclusion, the rhetoric has grown more heated and less reasoned," Mr. Thomas said.
Democrats said the bill was too expensive, especially given the likelihood of budget deficits for the next few years. In bringing up the bill, they said, Republicans were trying to score political points rather than advance a bipartisan compromise.
No Republican, said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, "is so naive that he or she believes that what they are doing tonight is going to become law."
Mr. Daschle said he would not bring the House bill before the Senate because its focus was on companies rather than workers.
"We regret very much that our Republican colleagues, at least so far, have refused to come to the table to negotiate seriously on health and unemployment benefits, in spite of the fact that millions of people are unemployed today," Mr. Daschle said at a news conference.
Economists said the lack of a compromise would not change the forecast for a recovery in the first half of next year.
"It will not affect the timing of the recovery, but it will affect the strength of the recovery during the second half of next year," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at Wells Fargo, the banking company.
On the assumption that Mr. Bush would sign into law a stimulus package valued at $75 billion to $100 billion in tax cuts and new spending for next year, Mr. Sohn had projected that the unemployment rate would rise to a peak of 6.3 percent in June from its current 5.7 percent.
Without a deal, he said, the rate will probably peak at about 7 percent, with 140,000 additional jobs lost.

Breaux joined President Bush and Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, yesterday in discussions on a stimulus package on Capitol Hill. The three Democrats had previously backed a compromise plan. (Associated Press)(pg. A34)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: LIBYA; 
In Changed World, Qadaffi Is Changing, Too

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi has notified diplomats in the Netherlands that after two decades of building one of the largest stockpiles of chemical weapons in the Middle East he is ready to sign an international treaty banning them.
 Colonel Qadaffi's decision -- which would open his extensive underground desert facilities to outside inspectors for the first time -- followed private consultations with intermediaries to the West. Among them were the former South African president, Nelson Mandela, who visited Colonel Qadaffi in October, and Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States, who traveled to Tripoli this month after earlier talks in London with Libya's chief of intelligence. 
 Diplomats who have been in recent contact with Colonel Qadaffi said that in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks he has accelerated his efforts to improve his standing in the West.
He was among the Arab leaders who denounced the Sept. 11 attacks as "horrible," and he publicly stated that the United States had a right to pursue the perpetrators. When anthrax attacks followed, Colonel Qadaffi said, "It is a cowardly, evil and irresponsible action putting in danger the whole of humanity."
With the lifting of United Nations sanctions against Libya in 1999 and a subsequent upsurge in European business, he seems eager to win the removal of the United States trade and arms embargo that has been in place for more than two decades.
Fifteen years ago, Colonel Qadaffi was at the center of America's campaign against terror. His intelligence organization was accused of planting the bomb that killed two American servicemen and a Turkish woman at a Berlin nightclub on April 5, 1986. Ten days later, President Ronald Reagan ordered the bombing of Libya, reportedly killing one of the colonel's daughters.
Then, in December 1988, a bomb aboard a Boeing 747 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland. The bombing killed 270 people and Libyan agents were suspected.
Now, as part of his consultations with intermediaries, Colonel Qadaffi was said to have offered intelligence information on members of Osama bin Laden's Qaeda terrorist organization, including a number of Libyans who are said to have served on Mr. bin Laden's personal protection force. 
Another possible reason for his willingness to cooperate with the campaign against Al Qaeda is that Colonel Qadaffi sees Mr. bin Laden as a threat, intelligence officials and diplomats say. A new French book, "Bin Laden: The Forbidden Truth," by Jean-Charles Brisard and Guillaume Dasquie, cites plots to kill Colonel Qadaffi by members of the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group, which has been linked to Mr. bin Laden and listed by the Bush administration as a terrorist group whose assets should be frozen worldwide.
The diplomats who related Colonel Qadaffi's conversations said that he had seen the benefit in cooperating. An earlier decision to provide Britain with intelligence information about members of the Irish Republican Army who had trained in Libyan camps and purchased Libyan weapons and explosives became a critical factor in Britain's decision to normalize relations with Libya.
That occurred in July 1999 after Libya accepted responsibility for the 1984 killing of a British policewoman by shots fired from the Libyan Embassy in London.
Britain restored full diplomatic relations without waiting for the outcome of the complex efforts to bring the suspected perpetrators of the Lockerbie bombing to trial. 
The United States appears to be awaiting the final outcome of appeals in that prosecution.
Last January, a Scottish court sitting in the Netherlands convicted a Libyan intelligence operative, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, for his role in planting the bomb. Another defendant, Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, was acquitted. 
An appeal is due to be heard in late January. The disposition of the case is expected to clear the way for a final compensation offer from Libya to the families of the passengers, crew and Lockerbie residents who died in the crash.
Jose M. Bustani, the Brazilian diplomat charged with implementing the Chemical Weapons Convention, said today from his headquarters at The Hague that he had received a private commitment from Libya that it would sign the accord in coming weeks. 
"I can confirm that this process has been cleared by Qadaffi, so it is a matter of time," Mr. Bustani said. "I believe the Libya development is very important, because by acceding to the convention and opening its chemical industry for inspection, that will have an impact all over the Middle East."
Mr. Bustani said that he had been trying to bring Libya "into the fold" for several years, if only to weaken the resistance of Arab states that say they will only join the 145 nations who have signed the chemical weapons pact once Israel signs the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
Sudan and Jordan have recently signed the chemical weapons convention, but Egypt, Syria and Lebanon continue to hold out.
Last month at the United Nations General Assembly meetings in New York, the Libyan envoy, Abdurrahman Mohamed Shalghem, caught delegates by surprise when he said, "My country is a party to most international agreements in the field of disarmament, and is in the process of acceding to the rest, including the Chemical Weapons Convention and the Nuclear Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty."
As recently as 1996, the United States publicly threatened to attack a chemical weapons production facility at Tarhuna, about 60 miles southeast of Tripoli, where Colonel Qadaffi had constructed a huge underground complex. 
In testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee in February of that year, the director of Central Intelligence at the time, John M. Deutch, called Libya's facility "the world's largest underground chemical weapons plant."
The secretary of defense at the time, William J. Perry, said Washington would not allow the plant to become operational, thus putting Mr. Qaddafi on notice that the facility would become subject to military strikes. 
Still, Libya is reported to have stockpiled 100 tons of chemical weapons agents at the Tarhuna facility and at a sister facility constructed with German assistance during the 1980's in Rabta, about 75 miles southwest of the Libyan capital.
"Libya's chemical weapons program is considered to be its most successful effort in weapons of mass destruction," said Joshua Sinai, a specialist on Libya with the Analytic Services consulting firm. He said that Libya's accession to the treaty would be a "significant and welcome development," but that Washington would have to insist on "complete access" to what he said was a complex system of underground tunnels big enough to accommodate vehicles and modeled after similar tunnels in North Korea.
The United States and Russia have the largest stockpiles of chemical weapons, about 70,000 tons in total, and both have committed to destroying them over the next decade.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CLASSIFIED INFORMATION; 
Bush Gives Secrecy Power To Public Health Secretary

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
President Bush has granted the secretary of health and human services the power to classify information as secret, a step that shows how the battle against terrorism is drawing domestic agencies into the national security apparatus.
 William A. Pierce, the spokesman for the Health and Human Services Department, called the new authority a recognition that the agency was now in the forefront of preparations to fight bioterrorism and is sitting in on White House sessions on domestic security. 
 "The bottom line is relatively simple," Mr. Pierce said. "We are now a homeland security agency, part of the homeland security council." 
He said he expected a "narrow subset" of agency documents to be classified, those relating to bioterrorism and the nation's preparedness to respond to it. 
Officials said the kind of information that might be classified would be storage sites for vaccine stockpiles, certain laboratory floor plans or some details about emergency medical stocks. Mr. Pierce said the secretary, Tommy G. Thompson, had not used his new authority.
Experts on government classification said they believed it was the first time in several years that a new agency had been given the right to stamp information as secret. The trend had been toward less secrecy.
In 1995 President Bill Clinton issued an executive order that overhauled government secrecy rules, reducing the number of documents made secret and shortening the time such documents were kept classified.
While the health department was the lone agency to get new classification powers, the government has generally been rethinking the balance between security and the right to know since Sept. 11.
Much of the federal government already has the power to classify information. The agencies with such powers include the pillars of national security, like the Pentagon, the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency, and agencies dealing with energy and nuclear plant regulation. Also on the list are agencies that deal with sensitive economic and trade issues, like the Treasury and Commerce Departments and the United States trade representative.
Officials said that until the Sept. 11 strikes and the subsequent anthrax attacks, it had not been widely assumed that the nation's public health department needed such authority, But that attitude has changed.
"They clearly are a national security agency," one White House official said. "They clearly are a homeland security agency." 
He added, "One of the things you do in the homeland security business is deal with classified information."
The president's designation of the department's new classification authority was printed in the Federal Register on Dec. 12 without further explanation from the White House. Mr. Bush cited President Clinton's 1995 executive order on classification, which said classification authority would be held by agency heads and officials designated by the president.
The secretary was granted the right to classify information as secret, but he was not given the power to brand information as top secret. The government defines information as top secret if its disclosure could cause "exceptionally grave damage to the national security."
Secret information is that which could be expected to "cause serious damage to the national security" if disclosed. In general, the higher level of classification means that fewer officials have access to it.
Until now, the department had to turn to other government agencies for assistance if it wanted information in its domain to be classified. 
Critics of secrecy policies called the change relatively modest. 
"One would have liked to see some explanation of why it was necessary," Steven Aftergood of the Federation of American Scientists said.
But Mr. Aftergood said he did not think the order would greatly expand the scope of government secrecy.
Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican and chairman of a House subcommittee on national security, said the department should use the power judiciously. But Mr. Shays said the classification authority was needed "to make sure we don't provide a road map to terrorists" of the nation's vulnerabilities.
Representative Jane Harman of California, the ranking Democrat on a House subcommittee on terrorism, cautioned that information sharing among agencies should be "the crux of any homeland security effort," and that classifying too many documents could hinder the transfer of information among agencies and levels of government.
Under the current secrecy rules, which were put in place by Mr. Clinton, agency heads are required to establish procedures under which employees can challenge classifications that they believe are improper.

HEADLINE: Japanese Budget Would Cut Spending, Even inRecession 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
At a time of mounting pressure to spend freely in hopes of stimulating a moribund economy, the Japanese government introduced a budget for the next fiscal year today that moves sharply in the opposite direction. It calls for unprecedentedly deep cuts in spending, in an effort to tame the country's already immense public debt.
 The government announced plans to spend 47.6 trillion yen ($370 billion) in the fiscal year starting April 1 -- 2.3 percent less than the initial budget it presented this year. If things go as planned, the government will hold its borrowing to 30 trillion yen, or about $233 billion, in new bonds, fulfilling a promise made by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi. 
 Even so, with the nation's long-term debt expected to swell to nearly 140 percent of the gross domestic product, interest payments are taking a growing share of the budget. At the same time, the economy will yield less tax revenue next year than it has in any year since 1987, the government forecast.
"We are not optimistic at all," said Masaki Omura, an economist at the Japanese finance ministry. "The situation is serious."
Recognizing the severity of the current downturn, Japan's fourth in the last decade, the government said it is basing its plans on the assumption that the economy will not grow next year and that prices will continue falling. Japan may get some help from a recovery in demand overseas, expected by officials late in 2002.
Mr. Koizumi appears willing to let the economy slide further into recession rather than risk pushing the national debt higher, a policy that has come under widespread attack. His critics say the prime minister's first priority now should be to spur growth, not impose austerity.
"Forecasting zero growth and making no attempt to stimulate the economy is worrying," said Richard Jerram, an economist at ING Baring Securities in Tokyo.
Under pressure from lawmakers in his own party who hold that view, Mr. Koizumi grudgingly assembled two supplementary budgets with extra spending after Sept. 11, at the risk of muddying his reputation as a reformer.
Having given that much ground, analysts said, he is likely to face pressure in coming months to set aside more of his reform agenda and assemble more spending packages.
The nation's central bank is also worried about the economy, but has little room left to maneuver. Today, for the seventh straight month, the bank lowered its assessment for the outlook of the economy, using unusually gloomy language not heard in three years. In this latest phase of the downturn, the bank said, consumers are now starting to acutely feel the pinch of wage cuts and layoffs.
In response, the bank took what steps it could to ease monetary policy, given that short-term interest rates are already effectively zero. The bank said it would pump more cash into the money markets to ensure that ample credit was available to banks and borrowers. And it said it would step up purchases of government bonds.

HEADLINE: Diagnosis of World's Health Focuses on Economic Benefit 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
For $101 billion a year in medical research and treatments, eight million lives could be saved annually in the developing world, and $186 billion a year in world income now lost to illness could be recovered. So concludes a report on economics and health released yesterday by the World Health Organization.
 The committee that drafted the report, led by Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard University, studied how a combination of foreign aid and impoverished governments' own funds could improve the health of people in emerging economies. The initiatives would tackle AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis and other diseases common in developing countries. 
 "There is no way these diseases can be addressed without international assistance," Professor Sachs said in an interview.
He said he hoped the United States would pledge about $10 billion a year, more than one-quarter of the amount the committee said would be needed from donor nations. Such a pledge would double foreign aid spending, to 1 percent of the federal budget.
"In Europe, this is no hard sell at all," Professor Sachs added. "The rest of the world gets this."
Most European nations spend proportionally more of their budgets on foreign aid than the United States does. So do Australia, Canada, Japan and New Zealand. In absolute terms, America dispenses more aid than any other nation, but only one dollar in 20 finances health programs.
In all, the report calls for wealthy donor countries to contribute $38 billion a year by 2015, with the developing countries that would benefit putting up $63 billion of their own. New international agencies would administer the donated funds.
Giving priority to health aid makes sense, according to David Dollar of the World Bank, because it is easier to deliver than other types of assistance. "There are certain types of health interventions that work even where other types of aid don't work," Mr. Dollar said.
Health aid need not be in the form of easily squandered cash, he said, and it can be applied effectively even where there is no infrastructure or stable government.
"In the case of vaccination, you can deliver the aid as physical vaccines, and it's a one-time intervention in many cases," Mr. Dollar explained. In the long term, vaccinations may help people more than projects like new roads, which soon fall apart if not maintained. 
Among the report's more disputed proposals is "a cooperative and voluntary arrangement" among the pharmaceutical industry, governments and the World Health Organization to cut prices on drugs and vaccines.
"We share the overriding goals of the report, but we have a lot of questions about specific strategies," said Rachel Cohen of Doctors Without Borders. "Relying on good will or charity is a very frightening way to move forward. Companies can have their priorities change overnight."
The plan will probably meet strong opposition in the United States, where foreign aid has many enemies in Congress and health aid, especially, is fraught with controversy.

HEADLINE: Protecting Steel: An Economic War That All Could Lose 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THE late 1990's boom was something like a great party. Not only did the party make people feel good, it made them forget their other troubles.
 But even great parties must end. On the morning after, the hangover arrives. Then the partygoers recall what was worrying them before the party became so much fun. 
 One thing that worried Americans in the early 1990's was the specter of overcapacity in a series of important industries, among them steel and cars. The fear was that the United States, as a relatively high-cost producer, would have a difficult time competing.
Now those issues are coming back. We've gotten used to the hangover -- the immense overcapacity left when the telecommunications and Internet bubbles burst -- and are starting to remember what we used to be unhappy about. Unfortunately, the solutions being proposed for the first economic crisis of this century have a 1930's ring to them.
Take steel. The simple solution, of letting markets weed out the least efficient producers, is not even being considered. The Bush administration, which seems to be a strong believer in free trade so long as it does not cost any votes in swing states, is pushing for an international deal to cut production and thus raise prices. In other words, it thinks an international cartel would be just fine.
It has gotten other countries to agree on some vague goals for cutting capacity that will probably not have much impact. So the administration may carry out its threat to impose tariffs of up to 40 percent on imported steel.
Which brings us to cars. "What happens to Ford, General Motors and Chrysler if the cost of steel goes up dramatically compared to what it costs elsewhere?" asked William Dudley, an economist with Goldman, Sachs. "Are you really making yourself better off?"
Of course not. Nor would the American auto industry be helped if Japan's recent successful efforts to drive down the value of the yen continue. If so, there will be demands for some kind of protection for automakers. Even before the recession was officially announced, numerous industries were calling for the dollar to be devalued to make their products more competitive.
Competitive currency devaluations and tariff barriers, collectively known as "beggar thy neighbor" policies, were tried during the Great Depression and made matters worse. That history is known to policy makers, but such steps are taken one at a time, often in retaliation for something another country has done, and are often popular.
The current recession remains a mild one. While demand has collapsed for those industries that expanded most in the bubble, overall industrial production is off just 7.4 percent from its peak. In part that is because of surprisingly strong auto sales, which reflect a combination of consumers who do not fear they will be laid off and automakers willing to battle for market share even if they lose money on every sale. No postwar recession, except for 1990-91, has ended with such a small decline in production.
Wall Street seems to be confident that the recession will soon end. The collapse of the latest economic stimulus bill was received with a yawn.
But even if the recession is almost over, there are few prospects for a surge in any sector. Cars and housing will be lucky to hold their own, and companies continue to announce cuts in capital spending. Without an engine of growth, the pressures for economic warfare, 1930's style, will intensify, and could make a bad situation much worse.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports 5-Month Low In New Claims From Jobless 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The number of United States workers filing new claims for unemployment insurance dipped to a five-month low, suggesting the worst of the layoffs seen after the terror attacks may be over.
 But economists warned that the country is still in for a period of rising unemployment because of lingering weakness from the recession. 
 For the work week ending Dec. 15, new claims for jobless benefits dipped by a seasonally adjusted 11,000, to 384,000. It marked the third consecutive weekly decline and pushed claims to their lowest level since July 28, the Labor Department reported today.
Jobless claims fell by a sharp 85,000 for the work week ending Dec. 8, and dropped by 13,000 the week before that. In fact, new claims have fallen in seven of the last eight weeks.
The more stable four-week moving average of claims, which smooths out week-to-week fluctuations, also declined last week to 438,000. 
Economists were encouraged by the declines, saying they may signal that the level of layoffs, which rocketed after the Sept. 11 attacks to a nine-year high, is stabilizing.
"It's starting to become more convincing that the drops in layoffs are for real and that the worst of the layoffs may be behind us," said one economist, Clifford Waldman of Waldman Associates.
To cope with the sour economy, which slid into recession in March, companies have cut production, trimmed hours and let workers go.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
The Postal Service, lightening up, sends a thoughtful holiday greeting by way of a TV spot.

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
MAIL volume and revenue were declining for the United States Postal Service even before the Sept. 11 attacks because of the economic slump; since then, of course, the post office has also been battered by anthrax scares and anthrax-related deaths among its workers.
 These woes have been reflected in recent advertising, most notably a television commercial, "Pride," which features real postal employees carrying out their duties with determination and enthusiasm, notwithstanding snow, gloom of night and, presumably, bioterrorism. That spot was introduced in November; at the time, Larry Speakes, the advertising manager for the Postal Service, said that it would probably be the only commercial the service would run until next year. 
 But times change. The anthrax threat seems to have eased. The national mood, while still subdued, seems less bleak. And postal officials have decided to lighten up, at least for the holidays. So they have introduced a 30-second spot called, appropriately, "Holiday." The ad, which began running on Wednesday night, is intended to remind viewers that the mail is about not just duty but also "bringing people together," Mr. Speakes said. 
"Holiday" was produced by Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group, the Postal Service's lead agency. "Pride" was created by Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, another agency used by the service. Like "Pride," "Holiday" shows real postal employees doing their jobs. As a piano tinkles "Auld Lang Syne," they recite fictitious names of the people and companies they are supposed to be connecting -- a cross section of the American populace, from the look and sound of it.
"From Claudia Rodriguez to her childhood friend," says an Asian clerk seen standing behind a post office counter, accepting a package. A male Hispanic letter carrier is then shown walking and talking about connecting a construction company and its "No. 1 supplier." His image is followed by one of an older, black male clerk who delivers a package while speaking about "Grandpa William and his grandson Billy."
A white male letter carrier is shown helping to unite the hearts of "Sgt. Peter Kozak" "and his fiancee, Deb." A black female employee makes the link between "Chang Lin and her great-great aunt." And, finally, another white male letter carrier brings together "Timmy Welsh and a Mr. S. Claus."
That is when the spot ends and a voice-over narrator is heard intoning: "To all the people who can't be together from all the people who bring you together. Happy Holidays." 
Lisa Bennett, executive vice president and executive creative director for Leo Burnett, explaining the rationale for the spot, said: "There are 800,000 employees in the Postal Service. We really wanted to represent the people who make up the Postal Service and, with the names of the senders and receivers we mentioned, to be inclusive of all kinds of people and relationships in the country." The spot was cast from a group of postal workers in the Chicago area who auditioned for the parts.
"Holiday" will run through early January on programs including "60 Minutes II," "E.R.," "Law and Order" and "Providence." It will be shown for football fans during the Independence Bowl on Thursday and the Holiday Bowl next Friday. "Pride" will continue to run, on a reduced schedule, on programs including "20/20," the network morning news programs and various end-of-the-year sports telecasts.
Mr. Speakes declined to disclose spending for either spot but said the Postal Service's total ad budget for fiscal year 2002, which ends in September, was about $112 million.
Will the spots work? The volume of standard mail -- formerly called third-class mail -- is down about 2 percent this year, as is first-class mail, Mr. Speakes said. Given current economic conditions, he does not expect "Holiday" or any other spot to able to remedy that problem immediately, or even at all, he said. Instead, the spots are meant more as a "branding message."
Which is?
"That the Postal Service really champions relationships," Ms. Bennett said. "And that it is the support system for all sorts of them."

HEADLINE: Bill Will Cut Fees to Regulators 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
A proposal to cut fees paid to federal regulators for corporate registrations, transactions, and mergers by an estimated $14 billion over the next decade was headed to the White House after lawmakers approved it today. 
 Overcoming a final obstacle before reaching President Bush, the Senate approved without debate the Investor and Capital Markets Fee Relief Act, which aims to reduce fees paid to the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 "This is it. It's off to the President now," said Craig Donner, a spokesman for Vito Fossella, a Republican representative from New York and one of the principle authors of the measure. "It's our understanding that the White House is supportive." 
The bill also includes a provision to raise salaries at the S.E.C., the investor protection agency, and bring them in line with other financial regulatory agencies. "With the passage of this legislation, and assuming its enactment into law as well as its full funding, we believe we will be able to continue to attract and retain outstanding staff," Harvey Pitt, the S.E.C.'s chairman, said. 
Wall Street's trade groups applauded the Senate, saying the bill would eliminate a hidden tax and focus on the main role of the fees, which is to finance the regulatory activities of the S.E.C. 
The Senate approved the measure by unanimous consent amid a flurry of proposed legislation Congress is trying to tackle before it leaves for the year. The bill intends to cut fees and other charges the S.E.C. collects through securities transactions, which amount to more than five times the agency needs to fund its operations. The measure also seeks to retain lawyers, accountants, and examiners the agency has been losing in recent years.

HEADLINE: ConAgra's Earnings Decline by 18% 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Profit at ConAgra Foods fell 18 percent in its most recent quarter as the company struggled with the recession and incurred additional marketing expenses. 
 However, strong sales of major brands like Butterball turkey, Hunt's tomato products and Banquet and Healthy Choice packaged dinners helped ConAgra Foods beat Wall Street's expectations. 
 ConAgra, the nation's second largest food company, said it earned $231.6 million, or 44 cents a share, down from $28.2 million, or 54 cents a share a year earlier. 
Its results beat Wall Street's expectations of 43 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
"Our company has weathered one of the most difficult quarters in history, marked by recession and war," ConAgra's chairman, Bruce Rohde said. "Our ability to perform well in this environment reflects momentum that is building for some of our key products." 
Sales in the period, which ended Nov. 25 and was the second quarter of ConAgra's fiscal year, grew to $7.36 billion from $7.23 billion in last year's second quarter. Four of the company's largest brands, Butterball, Hunt's, Banquet and Healthy Choice, posted sales gains of more than 5 percent. 
Sales of other brands, including Armour and Chef Boyardee, Swiss Miss, Peter Pan and Parkay also showed gains. One reason for improvement was bundling complementary products around specific themes, such as "back to school" and "holiday," the company said. 
Shares of ConAgra fell 7 cents to close at $24.24 in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Sept. 11 Keeps 8 Million Home for Holidays 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Government surveys show that about eight million adults decided not to travel during the Christmas and New Year holidays because of the Sept. 11 attacks.
 About 1.4 million changed the way they planned to travel. 
Two-thirds of those switched to car from plane. A few switched to car from train, and a small number switched to plane from car, perhaps drawn by bargain fares. 
 The figures are projections from a survey of 1,000 randomly selected households by the Bureau of Transportation Statistics, part of the Department of Transportation. The survey predicted that air travel would be down 20 percent. This is consistent with a survey by AAA.
Before Sept. 11, about 47 million adults planned to travel during the December holidays, the bureau said. After the terrorist attacks, the number was about 39 million, it said.
Both numbers are much smaller than those in December 2000, when, the bureau said, 62 million to 66 million adults traveled. Travel experts say the recession has cut travel even more than the fallout from Sept. 11.

HEADLINE: City's Unemployment Rate Jumps to 6.9%, the Highest in Nearly 3 Years 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Fewer people were flying to New York City, which meant fewer jobs at airlines. With less business being done, fewer people were needed to work as security guards and office temps. The decline in travelers meant that hotels and retailers did not hire as much seasonal help as in years past. 
 All of which contributed to another significant decline in jobs in New York City in November and a sharp jump in the city's unemployment rate. 
 Including adjustments for seasonal factors, the unemployment rate rose to 6.9 percent, the highest rate in nearly three years.
"In the New York City economy, it's clear these are difficult times," Stephen Kagann, the chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki, said yesterday. "The job losses are widespread in key industries," like finance, tourism and media.
Normally, total employment rises in November and December because of seasonal traffic in the retail and tourist industries, analysts said. And in fact retail and tourism jobs rose significantly in November. But other industries lost enough jobs that over all, private-sector employment was almost flat.
After adjusting for seasonal factors, private-sector jobs in New York City fell by 22,500. 
While that was not quite one-third as many private-sector jobs as the 72,200 lost in October, in the wake of the World Trade Center attack, the loss of jobs over the last two months was the largest two-month decline on record, according to City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi -- larger even than the 69,900 private-sector jobs lost during the recession in the first two months of 1991.
Some economists saw bright spots in the report. "I think some people were expecting the report to be as negative as last month's," said Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist for The New York Stat, a monthly newsletter covering the state economy. 
Among the few bright spots were industries that benefited from the aftermath of the attack, namely heavy construction and telecommunications, both of which added jobs. 
Government employment also surged last month. Including that sector, the total job loss in New York City last month was 18,800, compared with a revised total of 78,800 jobs lost in October. 
Financial companies recorded a net gain in November, with the securities industry alone adding about 700 jobs, seasonally adjusted. Most of the increase, however, could be traced to the return of some American Express and Merrill Lynch employees to their New York City offices from temporary space elsewhere.
Employment in New York in the securities industry remains 15,000 jobs below the level in September and 22,000 below its recent peak in March, Ms. Denham said.
While retail stores and hotels also added employees, the number of private-sector jobs fell for the seventh straight month. 
The city's unemployment rate, when adjusted for seasonal factors, was the highest since February 1999, rising to 6.9 percent from 6.2 percent in October. One year ago, the unemployment rate was 5.6 percent. Statewide, unemployment rose to 5.4 percent from 5 percent in October and 4.5 percent in November 2000.
Though the rate of decline in jobs slowed last month, that does not mean that the contraction in New York City employment is over, analysts warned.
In the airline industry, for example, 5,000 jobs were lost last month and 8,700 jobs disappeared over the last year. "But we still haven't reached the numbers that the airlines announced immediately after Sept. 11," said James P. Brown, an analyst with the New York State Department of Labor, which released the employment statistics yesterday. 
When large companies announce plans for layoffs, the actual jobs are often not eliminated for several months, as employees ponder their options in taking buyouts or early retirement packages, Mr. Brown said.
"The overall picture is one of weakness," Mr. Brown said. "We are not getting a lot of the seasonal hiring that we would expect." And after adjusting for seasonal factors, he said, "the picture is still of a continued weak economy."
Even with the recent increase, the unemployment rate is well below the rate experienced in the early 1990's, after the last recession. New York City's unemployment rate peaked at 11.6 percent in September 1992, about 18 months after the national recession ended. It fell to a low of 5 percent in July 2001.
And some economists note that the percentage of state jobs lost since March, when the latest recession began, was only about half the percentage lost in the first eight months of the 1990-91 recession.
Mr. Kagann, the governor's economist, noted that the state has lost 1.9 percent of its jobs since March. That compares with a 3.7 percent loss in private-sector employment in the 1990-91 recession.

HEADLINE: More Muted Talk About Help for Economy 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Nine months after the official beginning of the recession, the inability of Congress and the White House to agree on a stimulus package no longer has economists as worried that the economy will stumble without additional tax cuts or spending.
 "It's strange to be talking about stimulus at this point, because it's so late," said Edmund Phelps, an economist at Columbia University. "There are signs now that gross domestic product is about to turn around." 
 This week, for example, the Conference Board reported that its index of leading economic indicators rose for the second consecutive month, and by more than investors were expecting. New claims for unemployment benefits, the Labor Department said yesterday, dropped for the third consecutive week. 
Bruce Bartlett, an economist at the National Center for Policy Analysis, said that if the economy was already recovering, a stimulus package could do more harm than good. He warned that billions of dollars in tax cuts and spending could shorten the time before the Fed must again raise interest rates to fight inflation. 
"Anything that hastens that date," Mr. Bartlett said, "is bad news for the economy and worse news for the administration."
Do not forget, he said, that the Federal Reserve has cut interest rates 11 times this year and that Washington plans to spend billions of dollars to pay for disaster relief and to fight terrorism.
"It's important to remember," Mr. Bartlett said, "that there's already a lot of stimulus in the pipeline."
John Lipsky, the chief economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, said the best-timed stimulus may already be in place, somewhat unintentionally, thanks to the tax cuts and rebates enacted earlier this year. 
"They appeared at the exact right time," Mr. Lipsky said.
But he argued that Congress could still help the economy. "There are many reasons to believe that the recovery will be fairly muted," he said. "Fiscal action strikes me as potentially helpful in encouraging both the speed and vigor of the recovery."
But it may be too late, Mr. Lipsky said, to achieve those goals by expanding jobless benefits and health coverage for the unemployed. "If the idea is to provide potential fiscal stimulus that is fast-acting," he said, the government should focus on tax cuts rather than new spending.
The Republican-controlled House passed legislation yesterday that would have provided additional tax breaks, but Democrats -- led by Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader -- rejected the measure as too stingy to the unemployed. Moreover, most of the tax cuts in the House bill were aimed at spurring investment by businesses, a focus that was misplaced, Professor Phelps said. He added that spending by companies had declined to historically normal levels and was unlikely to rise soon.
"A huge part of the downturn is not the classical recession, in which you expect to retrace your steps a year or two later," Professor Phelps said. "Most of this downturn is simply the end of an unsustainable investment boom that got started in 1996 and ran out of gas in 2000."
Mr. Bartlett criticized the House's stimulus bill for being heavy with pork-barrel programs, influenced more by politics than economics. 
"There's a lot of stuff in the bill," he said, "that may or may not be good things to do as a matter of policy, but you really can't say that they're stimulative."
Despite these elements, several Wall Street analysts said that the stimulus package would have provided at least some spark for the economy. Yesterday, at least three said they would cut their forecasts for the economy's growth next year.
Though the stimulus plan has received the most attention in Washington, other bills stuck in Congress could be of equal importance to businesses.
Politicians seem to have given up until next year on a bill meant to set up a nationwide system of commercial insurance against terrorism, even though insurance policies for many companies will expire on Dec. 31.
John Berardi, the chief financial officer of Farmland Industries, said the failure to act on the stimulus plan, the new farm bill and an energy bill would slow recovery in the farming industry. 
Agriculture has been hit particularly hard this year because commodity prices have dropped at a time when credit became harder to obtain.
Mr. Berardi said he hoped a stimulus package would still be on the agenda when Congress returns in January. "There's still an opportunity," he said.
Professor Phelps said he hoped Congress would shift its attention to long-term strategies to improve the economy, like programs to create jobs.
"A lot of economists wish that there had been a debate about permanent changes in economic policy," he said. "We should be worried more about how high the normal unemployment rate is, especially for low wage workers."

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN ARGENTINA: ECONOMIC ASSISTANCE; 
U.S. Says It Favors Deferring Argentine Aid

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Despite Argentina's severe economic and political crisis, Bush administration officials said today that they were unlikely to support any new aid until the country adopted an economic course that had a chance of lifting it out of a four-year recession.
 What administration officials are not saying publicly is that Argentina will almost certainly have to devalue its currency and default on its debt before it has a chance of restarting the flow of loans from a $22 billion aid program administered by the International Monetary Fund. 
 In the eyes of many officials, the resignation of President Fernando de la Rua today increases the chances that a new government will adopt a better approach to managing the economy. 
"They're working through the difficult options that a sovereign nation has to look at to put itself on a sound financial footing," said Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill. "And that initiative has to come from the leadership of a country. It's not something that can be imposed from outside."
Asked if Argentina could expect any new aid to help grapple with unrest, Mr. O'Neill replied, "I think not."
Any new government in Buenos Aires is expected to abandon the policy of fixing the currency, the peso, to parity with the dollar, and to delay or cancel payments on its $132 billion foreign debt.
The United States and the monetary fund had supported Argentina's bid to defend its currency with several loans. But Mr. O'Neill has expressed skepticism about bailouts, and fund officials have been hinting in recent weeks that Argentina is unlikely to get any more support unless it takes a new approach. 
The fund rejected Argentina's urgent appeals to release a $1.24 billion installment of a loan arranged earlier this month, setting up the events that led to the fall of Mr. de la Rua's government. 
The fund generally allows member countries to decide how to manage their currencies, but Argentina's collapse appears to bolster the view -- already ascendant in the I.M.F. -- that it makes little sense to provide large aid packages to support fixed currencies. The preferred alternative is to let currencies float and adjust to market conditions. 
Riots in Argentina's major cities could also add momentum to a push within the monetary fund to find a more orderly way for governments to renegotiate their debts when their policies fail.
Some economists say the Bush administration and the monetary fund are partly to blame for Argentina's problems. 
Critics contend that an earlier aid cutoff might have forced the government to scrap damaging economic policies earlier. Instead, it imposed an austerity program and limited consumers' access to their bank accounts in a fruitless effort to meet financial goals set in conjunction with the monetary fund last summer.
"The fund gave them one too many bailouts," said Morris Goldstein, a former monetary fund official who is now at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The best hope is to get a new team there that has a credible plan, and then give them some money to help."

HEADLINE: Regents' Plan Would Alter Aid to Schools 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
The New York State Board of Regents yesterday proposed cutting state aid for education by 5 to 15 percent a year in some of the state's wealthiest districts and sending more money to school systems with high concentrations of poverty and poor performance.
 The plan was outlined yesterday by Carl T. Hayden, the Regents chancellor, and Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner. If passed by the Legislature, the measure would primarily benefit New York City and the other four big urban areas -- Yonkers, Rochester, Syracuse and Buffalo. Some rural school districts and small urban districts, like Roosevelt and Wyandanch on Long Island, would also benefit. 
 Mr. Hayden acknowledged that the plan would probably face resistance from upstate and suburban legislators who were likely to lose state aid. To blunt such opposition, the Regents, who set policy for schools statewide, called for lifting many restrictions on the way school districts can spend state aid, freeing them to shift money from one category to another. The plan would consolidate 18 of the biggest restricted categories into four more flexible ones: operating aid; gap aid, intended to close the achievement gap between districts; instructional materials aid, for textbooks, computers and libraries; and computer hardware aid. Some categories, like aid to special education, would remain unchanged.
This unrestricted approach to spending has been a perennial favorite of Republican lawmakers, and it was greeted positively yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki and Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, even as they chided the Regents for proposing what Mr. Pataki called a "major increase" in spending for education: $599 million, an increase that would constitute 4.7 percent of the current $12.7 billion budget. 
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bruno declined to comment on the proposal to reduce the share of aid going to wealthier districts. But Mr. Bruno said the Republican-dominated Senate was "wide open" to a more equitable way of distributing aid. "These things need to be negotiated out," he said. "Until we see the ramifications, it's hard to predict."
In defense of the plan, Mr. Hayden stressed that all districts would get some of the increase, even if not as large a share as in the past, and he noted that the increase in aid the Regents were asking for this year was about half what it was last year, a nod to the troubled economy. "This is not a Robin Hood scheme," Mr. Hayden said at a news conference in Albany to announce the plan. "More aid needs to flow to the children who need it most."
The Regents' drive to shift aid to poor and low-performing districts and to streamline the state aid formula comes as the state is under pressure to comply with a ruling in January by Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. He found that state aid to New York City schools was so deficient that the state was not meeting its constitutional requirement to provide a sound, basic education to all students.
Mr. Mills said yesterday that the Regents proposal was not a direct response to that court ruling, but Mr. Hayden interjected, "It certainly speaks to some of the observations contained in the decision." 
Steve Allinger, the Albany lobbyist for the New York City Board of Education, said yesterday that he saw the Regents' proposal as in the spirit of bipartisanship that President Bush used to win approval of his education plan in Washington. 
Harold O. Levy, the New York City schools chancellor, who harshly criticized last year's Regents plan for not directing enough money to the city, declined to comment in detail, though a spokeswoman said he liked this year's plan better than last year's.
Of the $599 million proposed increase to education, $388 million, or about 64 percent, would go to New York City, higher than the 40 percent proposed by the Regents in last year's plan. James A. Kadamus, a deputy state education commissioner, said, however, that that did not necessarily mean that New York City would get the most money per pupil, as other districts also have high needs. Over all, the proposal would give 87 percent of the increase to all so-called high-needs districts, 10 percent more than the share they received last year.
Mr. Kadamus said school districts in some wealthy suburbs, like parts of Westchester County, stood to lose little if any aid, because they already had extremely high education tax rates and their school populations were growing. The plan also recognizes the higher cost of doing business downstate, Mr. Kadamus said.
In contrast, he said, some upstate districts that are quite wealthy but shrinking have, under the existing state aid formula, been unfairly protected from reductions in aid.
Wealthy districts would lose as little as 5 percent of their present share of state aid if they are levying local taxes for education at or above the state average. The loss could grow to a maximum of 15 percent if their local contribution to education is below the average.
New York City, Mr. Kadamus said, has increased its local tax levy for education over the past two years so that it is now $16.14 per $1,000 of actual value, just below the state median of $17.58. Rochester is at $22.82, Yonkers at $18.09 and Buffalo at $11.24.
Noreen Connell, executive director for the Educational Priorities Panel, a budget watchdog group, said yesterday that while she supported the reallocation of resources to needy districts, the amount New York City would gain was not enough of a benefit to justify lifting some of the restrictions on state aid.
She said ending the restricted funding for the state's class size reduction program would encourage districts to make classes bigger once again and put money into other programs, like teacher training and remedial education. Studies have shown that smaller classes are more effective than teacher training in improving the achievement of poor children, Ms. Connell said, and with smaller classes, children would not need as much remediation.
"If overnight this proposal rectified all the underfunding in New York City, that would be different," Ms. Connell said. "But they're taking out something good at the school level that is going to be thrown into a pot which could go into any number of dysfunctional programs that are maintained year after year."
