HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN ARGENTINA: THE REGION; 
Despite Sneezes, No Cold Yet in Brazil

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
As a rising tide of popular frustration with the precarious state of the Argentine economy swept away the government of President Fernando de la Rua today, the financial markets of Brazil and neighboring nations took the turmoil in stride, suggesting that the damage may not spread much beyond Argentina.
 Analysts, investors and executives said that for today at least, the problems seemed largely limited to Argentina, in part because most lenders to the government are Argentines themselves rather than foreign banks. Moreover, the crisis had been developing for so long, they said, that most businesses with exposure in the region were prepared for trouble. 
 And while speculators bid down currencies in neighboring countries and in vulnerable nations as far away as South Africa and South Korea, there was little sign of the rapid financial contagion produced by currency crises in Asia and Mexico in the late 1990's and in Brazil last year. 
Investors were treated to the counterintuitive sight of Argentine stock prices shooting upward as the political situation crumbled. The most widely followed indicator, the Merval index, rose an unheard-of 17.49 percent today, and has gained 58 percent this month. 
Analysts said the market surged because investors saw blue-chip stocks as a safer place to keep their savings than the country's banking system, which is widely expected to be hurt badly by a devaluation of the peso and a default on government debt that many people in South America now see as all but inevitable. Stocks were also seen as a way to move money out of the country legally after the government imposed controls on cash withdrawals and transfers at the start of the month. 
"No foreign investors are going to be putting money into Argentina right now," said Bill Rudman, who is head of the Latin America group at WestAM, a money management company in London. "It's the Argentines who are looking for financial assets in anything other than a bank account."
The frantic stock trading today produced a gap of about 30 percent between the peso price of Argentine stocks and the dollar price of equivalents traded in the United States, known as American Depository Receipts. The gap suggested that investors expect the peso to be devalued by about 23 percent. Before resigning today, Mr. de la Rua said for the first time that the government was considering releasing the peso from its firm peg to the dollar.
Neighboring Brazil has the most to lose in an Argentine economic collapse. About one-seventh of its trade is with Argentina. Its weaker currency, the real, has given Brazilian goods price advantages over Argentine competitors in both countries, an advantage that will shrink or vanish if Argentina devalues.
With an eye on Buenos Aires, Brazil's central bank decided Wednesday not to change short-term interest rates for the coming month, despite improvements in Brazil's trade balance and external deficit that might otherwise allow a cut.
The credit markets have been factoring the growing risk of devaluation and default into the prices of Argentine government bonds for weeks. Bond trading today was thin and erratic, but generally headed lower. The benchmark Global 2008 bond's price fell 11.6 percent, to 24.75 cents per dollar of face value; the yield on government bonds rose to 44 percentage points over comparable United States Treasury securities.
With the economy stalled and little new financing available to Argentine companies, corporate debt defaults are rising. "We are seeing a trend of second-tier companies calling in the chips," said Laura Feinland Katz, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, the debt-rating agency.
Ms. Feinland Katz said most of Argentina's major corporate groups still have investment-grade ratings and sufficient cash on hand. But if the government tightens restrictions on capital outflow in an effort to shore up dollar reserves, companies might be unable to meet obligations.

HEADLINE: Meatpackers' Profits Hinge On Pool of Immigrant Labor 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The indictment of Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest meat processor, on charges that it conspired to smuggle illegal immigrants to work at its plants, is a sign of how dependent theAmerican food and agriculture system has become on foreign-born workers, many of them here illegally.
 Because of this heavy reliance, agriculture experts say, a major effort to crack down on the hiring of illegal workers could disrupt the nation's food industry. 
 "This would really cripple the system," said William Heffernan, professor of rural sociology at the University of Missouri who has studied immigrant labor. "In the communities where these plants are located there isn't an alternative work force. They'd have to raise wages and improve the conditions." 
Until 15 or 20 years ago, meatpacking plants in the United States were staffed by highly paid, unionized employees who earned about $18 an hour, adjusted for inflation. Today, the processing and packing plants are largely staffed by low-paid non-union workers from places like Mexico and Guatemala. Many of them start at $6 an hour. 
The shift in the economics of the food and agriculture industry has made such jobs unappealing to Americans, but highly enticing to immigrants.
Companies like Tyson, Smithfield Foods and Conagra have profited from paying low wages, pushing production lines faster and hiring workers who are much more willing to endure the hazardous conditions of a meat-processing plant, industry experts say.
"This is certainly not unique to Tyson," Professor Heffernan said. "This has been around for a long time in the meat-processing industry. And employers can take advantage of these people because they can threaten to send them back."
The companies can also benefit from high turnover, which means workers often do not qualify for insurance or vacation time.
But high turnover means the companies face constant pressure to find new workers. That pressure may have been at the heart of the actions Tyson is accused of in the indictment, which was unsealed on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Chattanooga, Tenn. 
The government charged the company and six of its employees with conspiring to transport illegal immigrants across the Mexican border and help them get counterfeit work papers for jobs at more than a dozen Tyson poultry plants. The indictment said that, to meet production and profit goals, Tyson officials would contact local smugglers near its plants to get more workers. 
Industry experts said it has long been believed that American food companies recruit in Mexico and knowingly hire illegal workers. Some said the companies advertise on the radio in Mexico, distribute leaflets, show videos and hire immigrant smugglers, or "coyotes."
Eric Schlosser, the author of "Fast Food Nation," which chronicled changes in the food industry, said that the recruiting and hiring of illegal workers had been widespread for some time, and that big companies had used it to their benefit.
"For me, I don't care if those workers are from Mars," Mr. Schlosser said in a telephone interview. "It's the way in which using illegals allows them to do all the other practices, like speeding up the production lines, not listening to workers and having a high turnover rate which reduces the power of the workers."
Professor Heffernan, at the University of Missouri, said it was simple: "It's the race to the bottom; it's just the race to the bottom. Companies started breaking the unions, moving the plants to rural areas and hiring immigrants a long time ago."
The same foreign-born workers harvest fruits and vegetables in Florida and California, they milk cows on giant dairy farms in Wisconsin and Oregon and process and pack potatoes in Idaho.
"Immigrant labor, whether it's legal or illegal, is critical," said Keith Esplin, president of the Potato Growers of Idaho. "Most Mexicans here will have papers, but the farmers won't have any idea. There is real good counterfeit stuff out there." 
Of course, because of the widespread use of counterfeit documents, no one knows for sure how many of them are working illegally. But industry and government officials say that, for better or worse, foreign-born workers are now one of the most vital elements in the American food and agriculture system.
About one million farm laborers are on the job at any one time, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. And a government study estimated that nearly 40 percent are illegal. A few years ago, the Immigration and Naturalization Service estimated that about 25 percent of meatpacking workers in the Midwest were probably illegal.
"We have enormous segments of agriculture that are critically dependent on hired farm labor," said Keith Collins, the chief economist at the Agriculture Department. "They are needed, particularly for harvesting perishables, like fruits and vegetables in Florida and California." 
Asked whether many of the foreign-born migrant laborers were illegal, Mr. Collins said, Absolutely.
"It's in the hundreds of thousands," he said. "No doubt."
The government, though, has had little success in stemming the flow of illegal immigrants to food and agriculture companies. Federal raids on meatpacking plants sent many illegal workers back to their countries. But it outraged food companies, who complained of disruptions. Civil rights officials accused the government of harassing Mexicans and others from Central America. And Midwestern politicians sometimes complained that slowing down the work at meatpacking plants increased the supply of livestock and thereby harmed hog and cattle farmers, who had already been suffering from low prices for their goods.
The big meatpacking companies said today that they would work to ensure that they were not hiring illegal workers. But they have long maintained that it is a difficult thing to achieve. There is a complicated network of smugglers and a huge trade in the trafficking of fraudulent work documents.
Janet Riley of the American Meat Institute, which represents the big meat processors, said it would be hard to root out illegal immigrants because it was difficult to know how many were working at plants. The institute does not even have estimates on foreign-born workers.
"We don't know the number," Ms. Riley said. "But we do know it's significant." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: ANIMAL SLAUGHTERING & PROCESSING (95%); IMMIGRATION (92%); FOOD INDUSTRY (92%); FOOD & BEVERAGE (91%); EMPLOYMENT (90%); SMUGGLING (90%); ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); FOOD MFG (90%); MEAT PROCESSING & PRODUCTS (90%); RECRUITMENT & HIRING (89%); INDUSTRY ANALYSTS (89%); INDICTMENTS (89%); ALIEN SMUGGLING (89%); FOREIGN LABOR (89%); POULTRY PROCESSING (89%); REFUGEES (78%); POULTRY (78%); TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT SERVICES (78%); LABOR UNIONS (77%); LABOR FORCE (77%); SOCIOLOGY (75%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (70%) MEAT; LABOR; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; ILLEGAL ALIENS; WAGES AND SALARIES 

COMPANY: TYSON FOODS INC (91%); SMITHFIELD FOODS INC (55%)

HEADLINE: South Korea Reports a Widening Income Advantage Over North 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The people of South Korea are more than 12 times richer on average than those of North Korea and are steadily widening the gap, according to statistics released today by the South Korean government.
 The statistics provided startling evidence of how far the South has advanced since the Korean War compared with the North. 
 They were released in the midst of efforts by the South to persuade North Korea to return to negotiations aimed at reconciliation that were broken off last month. 
North Korea's economic troubles, as dramatized by some of the statistics, were expected to persuade North Korean leaders of the need to resume talks. 
Negotiations halted when South Korea refused to yield to the North's demand to call off a military alert that was ordered after American forces began operations in Afghanistan.
The South has promised to send 300,000 tons of food aid provided the North agrees to another round of visits by members of families divided by the Korean War. 
One factor that may influence the North's position was an event not included in the report -- preparations for the 60th birthday in February of North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il. 
South Korean officials believe the North will need an extra supply of food to distribute in connection with observances of an occasion that Koreans view as the most significant birthday in a person's life.
The income disparity, now 12.7 to 1, has increased significantly since 1995, when the statistics showed the average South Korean earning 10.5 times as much as the average North Korean.
Although the gap decreased slightly in 1998, the height of the South Korean economic crisis, it has widened since then, said Chon Sin Ae, director of economic management at the National Statistics Office, which released the report.
Overall, the report said, North Korea showed signs of a slight recovery floods and famines that have devastated its economy for the past six years. North Korea's economy grew by 1.3 percent last year after having fallen steadily through the previous decade.
That figure, however, was still far less than South Korea's 8.8 percent growth rate in 2000. The gap was expected to grow this year even though South Korea's economy is estimated to have increased by only 2.8 percent since last Jan. 1. 
The report found that the average South Korean's income was $9,629 in the year 2000, compared with an average income of $757 in North Korea. South Korea's overall gross national income last year was $455 billion compared with $17 billion in the North. 
The North, at the end of Japanese colonial rule over the Korean peninsula in 1945, was ahead of the South industrially and maintained that lead after the Korean War ended in 1953. Then in the 1960's, the South entered an era of rapid industrial expansion.
South Korea, for instance, produced 3,115,000 motor vehicles in 2000 while the North produced only 6,600 vehicles, almost all of them trucks that were largely for military use. All told, more than 12 million motor vehicles ply South Korea's often crowded streets and highways. By comparison, only 262,000 vehicles operate on the North's largely empty roads.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers in New Jersey Move on Tax Amnesty Plan 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
As they approach a deadline for addressing New Jersey's growing fiscal problems, state legislators are backing a tax amnesty that they say will bring in millions of dollars in back taxes next spring.
 At the same time, however, a proposed change in the corporate tax formula, which even its supporters concede would cut into next year's revenues, is also moving quickly through the lame-duck Legislature. 
 The amnesty plan, extending to the end of June, would forgive all interest and penalties and would apply to individual income, corporate and sales taxes. 
The last time New Jersey offered amnesty to delinquent taxpayers, in 1996, the results exceeded the best projections. The Treasury Department projected then that the state would collect $80 million in delinquent taxes; the plan netted about $250 million altogether. 
This year the proposal arose quickly, as its sponsors said it had to, to make sure that people did not put off paying taxes. The Assembly Appropriations Committee approved the measure today, and its sponsors say they believe that it can be passed by both chambers before the Legislature adjourns on Jan. 7.
As the legislators fight over spending in their final days, with Democratic leaders trying to stop new expenditures and Democratic and Republican legislators angling for favorite projects, this unexpected source of revenue has bipartisan appeal.
The amnesty plan is also appealing to those who dismissed it earlier this year. "Nine months ago I didn't believe it was wise," said Assemblywoman Barbara Buono, a Democrat and a sponsor of the measure. "But much has happened in the last nine months."
Treasury officials have yet to calculate the damage from the recession and the Sept. 11 attacks, but most estimates of the shortfall in this fiscal year exceed $1.4 billion. Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, who had maintained for many weeks that he would leave office next month with a surplus, has concurred in predictions of a shortfall. 
Several Democrats expressed reservations about an amnesty, arguing that it would chiefly benefit high-income taxpayers, or at least those able to pay their full bills, and that it would effectively reward them while other delinquent taxpayers would have to negotiate payment plans not exempt from interest or penalties.
Leonard Lance, the committee chairman and the other sponsor of the bill, said he was also concerned about possible inequities, but added, "Very few people would come forward except through amnesty."
Mr. Lance was sanguine, too, about the prospect of collecting back taxes from the late 1990's, when the state was enjoying a surge in personal incomes. 
The committee also approved a bill today to change the way corporate taxes are calculated, to base the charges only on sales. That would cut taxes for corporations with headquarters in New Jersey and the bulk of their sales in other states. 
Business representatives have estimated the cost to the treasury in the first year at $12 million, but contend that the money saved by large employers will result in many new jobs. They also say that other states are adopting similar "single sales" formulas, and that New Jersey must follow suit to attract new employers and investment. 
Opponents of the measure say the revenue losses would be much higher. In testimony before the committee, Jon Shure, the president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, a liberal research group, said the losses could reach $250 million a year.
Opponents also argued that of the eight states -- including Connecticut -- that have adopted the same kind of formula, few have seen the employment gains predicted, and some have lost manufacturing jobs. 
But the proposal has been approved by comfortable margins in both the Senate and Assembly Budget and Appropriations Committees.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The New Jersey Assembly Appropriations Committee approved two new tax measures yesterday. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: FUND-RAISING; 
Striving to Fill Stockings in Hard-Hit Town

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: NEVADA, Mo., Dec. 20 

 BODY:
James McKenzie's Christmas list this year is as long as ever: 17 10-year-old girls, 16 7-year-old boys, 20 infants, 49 toddlers -- 314 children and counting. But his budget hardly matches: Days before the deadline, the toy drive that Mr. McKenzie runs here in this haggard town of 8,500 had collected only half its $5,000 goal.
 "People are thinking the same, 'I am tapped out,' giving 5 bucks where it may have been 10," Mr. McKenzie, director of the county ambulance service, shrugged as he sorted stuffed animals in the room he calls Santa's little workshop. "The only people that we rely on -- that we can rely on -- is our own community. If their revenues are falling short, it's going to affect us." 
 Call it charity fatigue. With widespread layoffs and a spiraling recession after the national outpouring of more than $1 billion in donations after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Christmas do-gooders across the nation are struggling to stretch scarce resources for an ever-growing number of applicants, many of them fresh out of work and asking for help for the first time. 
The United Way and Salvation Army do not tally donations until their holiday campaigns are over. But Maj. Bill Grein of the Marine Corps' Toys for Tots program, which collected 15 million toys last year, said donations were "significantly down" in 40 percent of the 380 divisions. In a recent survey, one in four people said their contributions to Sept. 11 charities would hamper their holiday giving, and half said the economic downturn meant they would cut back on their charitable giving.
Donations to Watershed Inc., which provides food, clothing and toys to poor people in central Arkansas, are about 60 percent off from last year. The "Angel Trees" in Marysville, Calif., north of Sacramento, have yielded only about 1,500 presents this season, less than half of last December's total. Near Daytona Beach, Fla., volunteers are as rare as cash: The Salvation Army found only enough bell-ringers for 26 spots instead of its usual 42. 
Here in Nevada (pronounced nuh-VAY-da), a 150-year-old railroad town 100 miles south of Kansas City, Mr. McKenzie's "Share the joy, give a toy" banner went up at precisely the wrong time. Honeywell International announced in November that it was moving its Nevada operation to Mexico, taking 200 jobs. Key Industries, a manufacturer of work clothing, just closed its 50-worker plant. The payroll at FirstStar Bank's loan processing center in town has gone from 200 employees to about 50 this year, the bulk of the cuts in recent weeks. 
"It all came down pretty hard last month," said Craig Hubler, the city administrator.
But you cannot reschedule Christmas. So Mr. McKenzie and his emergency-services crew made the annual siren-free ambulance run to Wal-Mart, filling eight shopping carts with Hot Wheels Hyper Cycles and Tonka trucks, Fashion Polly purses and Diva Starz dolls. All eyes were on price tags.
"When you're buying one or two, you don't think so much about it," said Tina Werner, a paramedic, surveying Playskool's Mr. and Mrs. Potato Head Silly Suitcase with 3-year-olds in mind. "Add $14.88 up 13 times, the money doesn't go very far."
Mr. McKenzie, who has spent all but one of his 37 years in Nevada, the last 12 as one of five elected members of the Town Council, lacks a paunch, and only a handful of whiskers in his trim beard are white. But for the last decade, he has played Santa Claus to poor children scattered around Nevada and surrounding Vernon County. 
Children from families with incomes up to 150 percent of the federal poverty guidelines -- $25,575 for a family of four -- qualify for the toy giveaway, as well as a food basket prepared by Community Outreach, a pantry that was handing out dried milk and donated venison this morning. Barbara Long, director of the program, spent $3,519.29 on apples, oranges, carrots, potatoes, bread, milk and hams, though she has only $3,000 to pay for it.
What is worse, Key Industries said it could not provide excess clothing as it had in the past. Instead, a local church ran "undie Sunday," collecting $250 "to buy all the underwear left in Nevada," Ms. Long said. 
The toy drive also lost a sponsor. Last year, Mr. McKenzie drove to Springfield, about 70 miles away, to pick up bicycles and basketball hoops from Toys for Tots to add to the locally collected loot. But this month, the program sent a letter saying that "donations of funds are way down this year," meaning "we have less and less to divide between too many areas." Nevada's toy drive was on its own.
The middle school came through as it had before, collecting $520 at its fall dance. The ambulance service added a dessert auction to its annual Christmas party, netting $244. (Mr. McKenzie's apple pie drew only $4, but Tricia Baldwin, an emergency medical technician, baked $22 cinnamon rolls.) A local businessman gave 18 scooters.
On Wednesday night, Nancy Kerbs and her daughter Katherine, 10, stopped by the office with a Barbie and a Matchbox Splash 'n' Dash Car Wash. Ms. Kerbs's husband was just laid off at Honeywell, but she is giving instead of getting.
"We're O.K., but we know that there are people who aren't," said Ms. Kerbs, who does statistical research for a nearby college. "We've always had good intentions, but we thought this year we better do it."
After Sept. 11, Mr. McKenzie and his crew, whose five ambulances average eight calls a day, collected nearly $5,000 in the historic town square and at the high school's homecoming football game. Now he is asking again.
The goal is to give each child a sack of at least three items, starting with the stacks of Monopoly and Peek-a-Boo Peggy that donors dropped off in recent days. Then on to Wal-Mart, where each medic adopts kids from a certain age group and storms the aisles with them for items under $10. Mr. McKenzie is partial to the search and rescue figurines, miniature fire engines and, of course, ambulances.
He charged up $2,282.03 on the first shopping spree, and that does not include diapers, wipes and rattles for the youngest children. If he runs out of money, Mr. McKenzie said he would borrow from the ambulance employees' fund. Or make a last-minute appeal to his neighbors.
"It's a small town," he explained. "I can call up the owner of the radio station and say we are desperately short, we need $1,000 by tomorrow. They'll crank it up."

HEADLINE: KILLINGS INCREASE IN MANY BIG CITIES 

BYLINE:  By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
Homicides have increased sharply this year in many large cities, a development that troubles law enforcement officials and experts who fear it may signal a return to rising crime rates after a large decline in the 1990's.
 The rise in homicides was led by Boston and Phoenix, which had increases of more than 60 percent through Dec. 18, compared with the same period last year, according to police figures in a survey of 18 major cities. 
 Homicides jumped 22 percent in St. Louis, 17.5 percent in Houston, 15 percent in San Antonio, 11.6 percent in Atlanta, 9.2 percent in Los Angeles and 5.2 percent in Chicago, the police departments in those cities said. 
However, even the sharp increases this year leave the big cities far below the peak in homicide in 1991.
The rise in Chicago, which has had 644 homicides this year, compared with 612 in the same period last year, means that it will probably pass New York for the first time as the city with the most homicides, though Chicago has 2.9 million people and New York has 8 million.
New York is an exception to the big cities with rising homicides, with 617 through Dec. 16, compared with 651 in the same period last year -- a drop of 5.2 percent.
Several other cities also had small decreases, including Washington, with a decline of 6 percent. But in most cities with fewer homicides, the decrease was so slight that experts said it was not statistically significant.
Homicide has long been considered the bellwether crime, the one that most worries the public and therefore the one that police chiefs watch most carefully.
A jump in homicides in the big cities led the crime wave of the late 1980's, and a homicide decrease in the big cities started an eight-year decline in overall crime beginning in 1992.
Charles H. Ramsey, Washington's police chief, pointed to two possible explanations for the increases this year: the downturn in the economy and an increase in family killings after years of declines driven by greater attention to domestic violence. 
The economy is the best indicator of whether crime will continue to increase, Chief Ramsey said. 
"More pink slips mean more crimes," he said. "It doesn't take long before you start seeing that impact at street level."
Chief Ramsey said he was especially concerned about the impact that a prolonged recession would have on poorer neighborhoods and low-income workers. "It reaches everyone; it just reaches them first," he said. "If this becomes long term, believe me, you will see the difference." 
Another factor in the increase in homicides, police officials said, is the rising number of prison inmates being released, the flip side of the prison building boom of the last two decades. The number of inmates released from state and federal prisons is projected to reach 635,000 this year, up from 474,300 in 1995, Alan Beck of the Bureau of Justice Statistics said. 
Newly released prisoners are a particular problem in Los Angeles, because California, with the biggest prison system, accounts for one in five of all released inmates, the majority of whom return to Los Angeles.
"Prison is basically a place to learn crime," Sgt. John Pasquarello of the Los Angeles Police Department said, "so when these guys come out, we see many of them getting back into drug operations, and this leads to fights and killings."
James Alan Fox, the Lipman family professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University, pointed to another likely cause -- the cyclical nature of crime. "To some extent, these cities were victims of their own success," Professor Fox said. "The levels of homicides that some of these cities had at the turn of the millennium were unusually low and unlikely to be sustained." 
In addition, the number of teenagers, the age group most prone to crime, is growing by 1 percent a year after years of shrinking. But the homicides now do not seem as connected to the combination of young people with drugs, gangs and guns as they were in the crime wave of the late 1980's, police executives in several cities said.
In Boston, for example, the city with the largest percentage increase this year, 67 percent, the average age of those arrested on homicide charges is 25 and the average age of the victims is 30, far higher than average ages a decade ago in the crack cocaine epidemic.
"I don't think there is any one particular reason for the jump in homicides," said Paul Farrahar, Boston's deputy police commissioner in charge of homicides. "Where we know the motivation for the killings, they have been kind of across the board this year. I wish there was one single motive we could see, so we could address it and go back to a lower figure." 
But, Mr. Farrahar said, the most surprising increase in Boston this year has been killings involving family members.
Another possible factor in the increase this year, officials said, is the impact of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, as the police in many cities were diverted to other duties like guarding bridges and water supplies, and people suffering from depression may have turned to alcohol or drugs to medicate themselves.
But of the 16 cities surveyed, only New York, Baltimore and Washington reported a jump in crime after Sept. 11. Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University, said most of the increase in homicides, in those cities with upturns, occurred in the first half of the year.
In New York, crime dropped sharply after Sept. 11, followed in October and November by a surge in violence, as many police officers were deployed to other duties, Bernard B. Kerik, the police commissioner, said.
After he spotted the sudden rise, Mr. Kerik said, he ordered several of his special units back to their crime-fighting jobs, including narcotics detectives, the gang intelligence unit and the warrant squad that tracks down parolees who commit offenses. As a result, shootings and homicides dropped last week to levels below what they were in the same period last year.
Professors Fox and Blumstein said Mr. Kerik deserved credit for introducing policies to help bring New York's crimes down again this year, about 12 percent over all, in the face of the upturn elsewhere, showing that it could be done through innovation and good management. 
In Washington, Chief Ramsey said the 6 percent drop in homicides for the year would have been larger if not for the Sept. 11 attacks. "We were doing much better than that before Sept. 11," he said, "but we've had a spike since then and we're trying to figure out if that's related."
"I don't know if anxiety has anything to do with it or whether there's the impression out there that the police are busy doing other things," he said. But Washington has had a marked increase in domestic killings and others traceable to "plain old arguments." 
"That motive category is always significant, but it seems like, from Sept. 11 on, the majority seems to be that," Chief Ramsey said. "I don't know if people have shorter fuses or what; it's just too early to tell."
In one city, San Diego, the events of Sept. 11 may have led to a sharp drop in homicides. Before the terrorist attacks, the police were projecting that San Diego would have 70 homicides this year, a 40 percent increase from the 50 homicides the city had in 2000. But since Sept. 11, there have been only 5 killings, and San Diego is now likely to have no increase for the year, Lt. Jim Duncan of the homicide division said. Because San Diego is a military town, with large Navy and Marine bases, Lieutenant Duncan said, people have been focused on the war and their family members overseas, and this has helped reduce crime. 

CORRECTION-DATE: December 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about an increase in homicides in several United States cities referred incorrectly to the comparison between Chicago's number and New York's. If Chicago, as expected, finishes the year as the city with the most homicides, this will be the second time it has surpassed New York City's total. The first occurred in 1998.

HEADLINE: Two Ways to Defy a Recession 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
"Ma'am, you're on the wrong side of the glass," Ben Carter-Allen said to the woman in the leather jacket who was peering through the yellow-framed window. "Come on in and squeeze the bears."
 A divinity school student moonlighting at the Teddy Crafters store here in the brand-new Polaris Fashion Place indoor mall, Mr. Carter-Allen, 24, catcalls to young couples in the corridor, "She needs a bear." And it works. The Happy Hugger ($36), the Lucky Dog ($23) and the Wise Old Bear (on sale for $16, from $22) seem recession-proof as they move out the door in crowds of 200 to 300 a day, many wearing $10.95 fatigues or firefighter's uniforms. 
 While the National Retail Federation is reporting the worst holiday shopping season in a decade, and the International Council of Shopping Centers says sales are down 3 percent from last year, there are few signs of the troubled economy or any threat of terrorism amid the shopping bags here at Polaris. From its Oct. 25 opening through 10 a.m. on Monday, 1,286,935 shoppers had strolled the mall's 1.5 million square feet, and several of the 150 stores and kiosks say they are leading their national chains in sales this season.
"You build it and they'll come," said Vicki Peppard, manager of Teddy Crafters, where the sales clerks ask customers to make a wish and then drop a satin heart -- symbolizing love or happiness or courage -- into the toy animal's belly before it is pumped up with fluff.
Still, many merchants are worried that Polaris's popularity will not stretch past New Year. They fear a fading of the novelty here at the first mall in the nation with seven anchor stores -- big department stores that serve as a foundation of a mall's business -- and the first in central Ohio with Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor. Even as older malls die, Polaris is among 11 large shopping malls that have opened around the country this year, up from six in 2000, and one of three to have opened since the Sept. 11 attacks. 
Though many worry that Columbus, the nation's 15th-largest city, is "overstored" -- Easton Town Center just doubled in size, to 1.6 million square feet, and there are four additional malls nearby -- other people are banking on the city's becoming a regional shopping destination. Polaris, which cost nearly $300 million and was built in a warp-speed 388 days (most malls take two years), has drawn 20 to 40 percent of its traffic from outside Columbus, its managers say, with shoppers crossing state lines from Pennsylvania, Indiana, West Virginia and Kentucky. (Hotels across the street have been booked on weekends.)
The mall offers $4 valet parking with electronic retrieval from any of Polaris's four exits, as well as rooms, complete with glider chairs, where mothers can nurse their babies. Huge kilim ottomans and leather love seats placed around the mall make it feel like a living room.
The only reminders of the trouble beyond its parking lots are the American flags painted on the few yet-to-open storefronts. Sure, some workers called in sick on Halloween, when rumors that terrorists would attack a mall somewhere in the United States were rampant, and others were scared last week when a nearby construction crew caused an hourlong loss of power. But mostly, Polaris offers an escape. 
This morning the mall's managers stalked its halls, straightening chairs as if expecting guests for a house party. By walkie-talkie, they reported lights out on the awning at Sole Outdoors, dust on the sign of Gymboree, cigarette butts outside the California Pizza Kitchen.
"Every day at 10 o'clock is like a Broadway opening for us," said Linda Wardell, assistant general manager. "I can't go over to Afghanistan. What I can do is make sure that we have the best Santa in town."
How it's going depends on whom you ask.
Kristi Burns, whose Victoria's Attic kiosk offers scented candles, rag dolls and ornaments in the image of polar bears, says she expected Polaris to yield four or five times the sales of her other location, in Lancaster, 30 miles southeast. Instead, it is barely keeping pace.
"There's been a lot of people in this mall disappointed," said Ms. Burns, 33, a hairstylist who used her savings to pay for the $12,000 seasonal lease on the kiosk. "The good news is I was able to cancel merchandise."
Rodney Wilson, a salesman at Curio a Go-Go, said the $72.95 photo album had been a hard sell, but people were grabbing at the peculiar $3.99 greeting cards adorned with other people's castoff snapshots.
Dave Lewison, chairman of the marketing department at the University of Akron and author of a retailing textbook, says new malls typically enjoy a honeymoon of at least six months, particularly when they open, as Polaris did, on the eve of the Christmas shopping season.
"The question isn't whether they're going to do well," Mr. Lewison said of Polaris. "It's if they do well, who's going to pay the price for that?"
The answer seems to lie eight miles away, at the Northland Mall, vintage 1964, which appears to be taking its last breaths. Some 300 malls around the country have died since the mid-1990's, and experts say that up to 500 more may be on the verge. 
At noon today, Northland's concourse was as quiet as a library, save for a bleating siren from the empty miniature ride-on fire engine. The gates were down at Trends, lights out at Claire's Accessories. Santa was gossiping with a janitor because no one was in line to sit on his lap. A visiting student choir sang to mostly empty folding chairs.
All three of Northland's anchor stores -- Sears, J. C. Penney and Lazarus -- are shuttered. And all three chains have glittering new outlets over at Polaris.
In addition to its seven department stores, Polaris has such mall staples as the Gap, Stride Rite and Starbucks, along with some Ohio originals. Among the more surprising storefronts is In Your Image, where six digital cameras scan your head, creating a three-dimensional blueprint for a personalized bronze or wax bust.
"It's a keepsake, it's something you might want to wait to buy until you had more money," Bryan Taylor, the manager, admitted, though 60 to 70 people a day have been purchasing the merchandise, priced at $29.99 to $899.99. "I haven't had one person come in and say this is too expensive."
At Teddy Crafters, which has five other stores and opened here in Polaris on Nov. 17, customers have bought bears for children who lost parents in the terrorist attacks, and bears to send overseas to American soldiers. An extra $4.95 puts an electronic "I love you" in with the stuffing. (Personal messages can be recorded for $8.95.) 
"Now I'm going to put him in a bag," Ms. Peppard, the manager, cooed to a customer. "But when you get home, you get him out of there."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: COMPENSATION; 
Victims' Fund Likely to Pay Average of $1.6 Million Each

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES and DAVID BARSTOW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The overseer of the federal fund set up for the families of those killed or injured in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks estimated today that the fund could cost taxpayers as much as $6 billion and would provide tax-free awards, on average, of approximately $1.65 million for the families of those who died in the attacks.
 Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master of the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, offered the estimates as he unveiled the regulations that would guide the fund's work when it opens for business on Friday. Those rules allow Mr. Feinberg to grant larger awards if evidence shows they are justified by "extraordinary circumstances." 
 The likely awards by the fund, based on the economic assumptions Mr. Feinberg has adopted, range from $300,000 for an unmarried 65-year-old who earned $10,000 a year to $4.35 million for a 30-year-old who had a spouse and two children and who made $175,000 a year. 
The estimated price of the no-fault compensation fund, the first of its kind ever created in the aftermath of an American disaster, is considerably lower than early, unofficial legislative forecasts, in part because the number of victims has shrunk to roughly half the number first feared lost in the attacks. Moreover, Mr. Feinberg has clearly put limits on how much the families of very high-income victims will be able to recover from the fund.
By law, the fund's awards must be reduced by whatever life insurance, pension payments, death benefits or government assistance victims' families have received -- a step that could pare the public cost to roughly $4.8 billion. Charitable contributions received by the families will not be deducted from the awards, however. To seek an award from the fund, claimants must waive their right to sue over the disaster, a requirement intended to limit airline liability for the attacks.
"I have met with hundreds of claimants, families who have suffered, and I am absolutely of one mind on this," Mr. Feinberg said at a news conference at the Department of Justice. "Whatever we do is of small comfort, and I realize that. We do, however, aim to provide some appropriate compensation, some limited measure of comfort."
The fund, he said, would pay the awards within four months and would spare families the need to "revisit the tragic events of Sept. 11 over and over again during the pendency of a lawsuit in our courts." 
Victims' families, lawyers and public officials, who have been waiting for months for some indication of how the fund will operate, gave the new rules and the projected payouts a widely mixed reception.
The president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, which is providing free legal help for families that file a claim with the fund, applauded the program, noting that the procedures allowed families unsatisfied with a potential award to argue for more.
But some victim representatives said the estimated awards were far lower than they had hoped for, particularly with regard to the compensation for pain and suffering, which they say is much lower than they might have won in court. Mr. Feinberg, whose awards are not reviewable by any court, determined that an unmarried victim without children should get $250,000 for pain and suffering. He decided that an additional $50,000 each would be awarded for any surviving spouse or child.
"It's an absolute disgrace, and as I read it, it only gets worse," said Michael Cartier, who lost a brother in the disaster and who is a member of Give Your Voice, which represents some families of civilians killed in the attacks.
The fund, which makes its awards based largely on the lost earning power of those who died, is also likely to be of little satisfaction to the families of the uniformed rescuers, about 400 of whom died at the Trade Center. Because the families of firefighters and police officers who die in the line of duty receive generous lifetime pensions and a $250,000 federal award, it will be difficult for them to argue that they have suffered great economic damage. Mr. Feinberg acknowledged that the fund's treatment of the families of some uniformed services personnel "is a big question mark" but said he would take a fresh look at the rules if it appeared that such families were "walking away with nothing."
The fund's new rules also drew strong criticism from Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York State Attorney General, who said they were "unduly restrictive and subvert the intent of Congress, which was to fully compensate all victims of the tragedy." Mr. Spitzer said he was particularly concerned about the limits the rules put on who was eligible to file a claim for physical injury.
Mr. Feinberg yesterday defended his efforts, saying that the fund was a much more attractive option for families than the uncertainties of costly, protracted litigation.
Even for wealthy people, the awards contemplated here are substantial and far better than going to court, he said. "I am hard pressed to accept the argument that these awards are too low," he added. "This is a classic trade-off between administrative speed and efficiency and rolling the dice in court and going for the proverbial pot of gold."
Although the federal statute that created the fund did not explicitly require him to do so, Mr. Feinberg has clearly tried to address the disparities between the awards made to the families of the wealthiest victims and those made to families whose lost breadwinner earned far less.
The awards increase steadily as the victim's income increases from $10,000 a year to $225,000 a year -- but after that, substantial increases in income do not produce substantially larger awards. Thus, the award for a victim who earned $2 million a year is not appreciably more than the one for a victim who earned $225,000 a year.
Although Mr. Feinberg insisted that he had not set a limit on the awards the fund would make, he warned that awards of more than $3 million "will rarely be appropriate." Similarly, although he said that there was no official minimum award, the rules are aimed at ensuring that -- between the fund's award, life insurance, death benefits and other noncharitable compensation -- no victim's family would get less than $300,000 for those without dependents, or $500,000 for those who were married with children.
The most contentious issue Mr. Feinberg faced was the task of putting a dollar figure on the "pain and suffering" and other noneconomic losses sustained by the victims and their families. Some victims' advocates had argued that this component of the awards should vary depending on how each had died -- instantly and without warning, or after nearly an hour of choking smoke and fear. Such factors usually play a significant role in the determination of jury awards in court cases over wrongful deaths.
Mr. Feinberg acknowledged that "each person experienced the unspeakable events of that day in a unique way." But, he said: "I will not play Solomon. I cannot make those distinctions, and I will not make those distinctions. Every life is valuable." Instead, he said, "the most rational and just way" to deal with these variations in personal tragedy was to establish a single, uniform amount of compensation for everyone -- in this case, $250,000, plus $50,000 for a spouse and for each minor child left behind.
He said he was willing to listen to arguments that this element of the awards should be higher, but he noted that this figure conformed roughly to the amounts paid under existing federal programs that compensate the families of police officers and military personnel who are killed in the line of duty.
Mr. Feinberg has clarified some uncertainties that stemmed from the hastily drafted airline bailout legislation that created the fund.
The fund is open to claims filed on behalf of anyone -- other than the terrorists -- who died on the hijacked jets, at the Pentagon, or at the World Trade Center, including illegal aliens. But Mr. Feinberg has now defined who can file a claim for "physical harm."
Such claims may be filed only by those who were "present at the site" -- defined as any area where Mr. Feinberg concludes "there was a demonstrable risk of physical harm" -- during the "immediate aftermath" of the attacks. For civilians, the immediate aftermath means within 12 hours of the attacks. But for rescue workers, that period is extended to 96 hours.
However, Mr. Feinberg defines physical harm to mean an injury that was "treated by a medical professional within 24 hours" and "either required hospitalization as an in-patient for at least 24 hours or caused, either temporarily or permanently, partial or total physical disability, incapacity or disfigurement."
Mr. Spitzer, the New York Attorney General, argues that this definition would bar claims by those who continued to work despite severe pain, by those who deferred medical treatment for more than 24 hours so that they could reunite with their families, and by those who were treated, without documentation, at the emergency triage centers that sprang up the day of the attacks.
Families seeking to file a claim have two options under the rules. They can submit documentation supporting their claim, await a decision, and then seek a hearing to argue for a higher figure. Or they can seek a hearing first, make their arguments, and then await a decision, which would be final.
Moreover, anyone eligible to file a claim can immediately apply for emergency awards of $50,000 for death or $25,000 for serious injury.
The rules permit a single claim per victim, but Mr. Feinberg declined to determine who should file that claim, deferring instead to state probate and inheritance laws. Thus, he did not specifically invite claims filed by same-sex partners, fiances or fiancees, and others lacking a clear, documented relationship to the victims, although he did not rule out such claims.

HEADLINE: Argentina Unraveling 

 BODY:
With severe economic troubles, weak leadership and a restive population, Argentina has been courting trouble for months. It arrived with the collapse of the elected government and a second day of deadly rioting yesterday in the streets of Buenos Aires and other cities. Whether Argentina comes out of this crisis as a stable democracy will depend on the restraint of its army, the patience of its people and steady leadership by the successor to President Fernando de la Rua, who resigned yesterday. 
 The sight of a democratically selected Latin American leader, however unpopular, departing so hastily from office is troubling for a country still trying to build democratic institutions and practices. Instability and dashed hopes have haunted Argentina since military rule ended in 1983. Raul Alfonsin, who oversaw the transition, did not finish his presidential term, resigning in 1989 during another economic crisis. His successor, Carlos Saul Menem, steadied the economy for a time but never addressed the country's fundamental problems. 
 Mr. de la Rua was an ineffectual leader. Given Argentina's chronic instability, however, the country might have been better served if the Peronist opposition had entertained his offer yesterday to create a national unity government to confront the economic crisis. Domingo Cavallo, the powerful economy minister, who was responsible for imposing a punishing austerity program and a currency board that maintained an artificial one-to-one rate of exchange between the peso and the American dollar, resigned late Wednesday. The Peronists, who control Congress, could have helped to construct a new bipartisan consensus on how to proceed. 
Instead they chose to take advantage of the crisis, forcing Mr. de la Rua to resign. In the absence of a sitting vice president, Ramon Puerta, the Peronist leader in the Senate, will become president. It is not yet clear whether he intends to complete the last two years of Mr. de la Rua's term or call for an earlier vote. He should schedule elections as soon as possible.
Argentina is beset by a 20 percent unemployment rate, growing poverty and a bankrupt financial system. The Argentine economic miracle of the 1990's was a mirage created by foreign creditors enamored of the country's monetary policy. The currency board allowed foreigners to invest without having to fear devaluation or inflation. 
This allowed Argentina to go on a $130 billion borrowing binge without addressing longstanding shortcomings, especially the corruption of its public finances and the nation's uncompetitiveness as an exporter. Predictably, the time has now come when Argentina can no longer make its debt payments, and foreign investors have lost confidence in the country. The usual stern prescriptions from the International Monetary Fund for greater austerity to weather the storm only made matters worse. 
Like other nations that have reached this crisis point, Argentina will most likely have to devalue its currency and pass through even rougher economic times before it can begin a recovery. It is a painful process, and one that can be managed only if political stability is restored and maintained, and if the army stays out of politics.

HEADLINE: Police and Firefighters Win Court Victory in Seeking Raises 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES 

 BODY:
The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the city's police and firefighter unions may ask a state panel to help resolve contract disputes. Union leaders had long sought that change in the hope that they would win significant raises that would make their pay comparable to that in suburban departments.
 The Giuliani administration, arguing that its labor costs would skyrocket and bankrupt the city government, had challenged a state law giving the unions that right. The state's highest court unanimously turned back that challenge yesterday. 
 The law, passed in 1998, allows unions representing police officers and firefighters -- like the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the Uniformed Firefighters Association -- to appeal to the state's Public Employee Relations Board to step in on stalled negotiations. It effectively takes arbitration of contract disputes out of the hands of the city's Office of Collective Bargaining.
While that office tries to resolve disputes by comparing police and fire contracts to those of other city unions, the state's Public Employees Relations Board uses the contracts of police and fire unions in neighboring communities as a standard. Police officers in some counties near New York City are paid as much as 35 percent more than those in the city.
The court ruling could also have a significant effect on negotiations with other city unions.
Because it allows the city's fire unions to appeal to the state board, a spokesman for the firefighters union said, many firefighters might re-examine a contract tentatively agreed to this summer that is awaiting a formal ratification vote.
Furthermore, the police contract often sets the upper standard against which other city union contracts are measured. Any substantial increase granted by the state board would be likely to lead other unions to seek comparable raises. While a 1 percent raise for police officers would cost the city about $15 million a year, city officials have estimated that a 1 percent raise for all city unions would cost $100 million.
Since the city faces budget problems as a result of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, it was unclear how much latitude the state panel might have in granting a raise to officers, who have been working without a contract since July. Since the the attacks, the police union has argued that its members' heroics should be rewarded with sharply higher pay.
"Before Sept. 11 or after Sept. 11, it didn't make sense for New York City police officers to be paid substantially less than their counterparts," said Robert Linn, the union's chief negotiator. "What Sept. 11 did was show that New York City has a real need to have and retain highly trained police officers."
The union, which represents about 26,000 of the department's rank-and-file officers, has long argued for a "market adjustment" raise to bring city officer's salaries closer to suburban pay. In the early stages of negotiations, the union requested a 39 percent increase over two years, which it has lowered to 23 percent. The city has offered a raise of 10 percent over two years. 
Mr. Linn said he hoped the court's decision would lead to a timely resolution of the negotiations. "Having an external board that looks at police salaries all over the state really gives an opportunity for a full and fair hearing, and I don't think that was possible before," he said.
The court's ruling alters more than three decades of city contract negotiations with its Fire and Police Departments. Under the 1967 Taylor Law, police officers, firefighters and other essential government employees are prohibited from striking. In return, they can seek binding arbitration from the state board, or from local labor boards created by municipalities, including the Office of Collective Bargaining.
In 1996, after heavy lobbying by the police union, the State Legislature overrode a veto by Gov. George E. Pataki to pass a law giving the state board jurisdiction over city contract disputes. After a judge struck that law down because it focused solely on New York City, the Legislature passed a new version, extending the state board's jurisdiction to contract disputes between all local governments and their unions.
In a statement, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani continued to defend the Taylor Law and expressed concern that the ruling might further dampen the city's budget outlook. "The law that created the Office of Collective Bargaining was written by, with and for all of the unions in the city," he said. "It is a law that has worked well for both sides for more than 30 years. The court did not agree."
The mayor also said the city's offer to the police union was fair. "We hope that the arbitrators will recognize the generous nature of the offer and appreciate the fiscal constraints now facing the city in light of the events of Sept. 11th,' he said.
In its court challenges, the city argued that extending the labor board's jurisdiction was a violation of home rule, the city's right to govern itself. But in upholding lower court decisions yesterday, the Court of Appeals ruled that because the 1998 law was a "special law" that serves a substantial state concern, the state panel has jurisdiction.
"We conclude that under the present statutory scheme, once a police or fire union pursues impasse resolution assistance" from the board and the board "declares an impasse, it has jurisdiction over scope of bargaining issues" with the city, the court wrote.
Labor experts said the ruling could significantly alter the landscape for contract negotiations in the city.
"It's a breakthrough for the union," said Eli B. Silverman, a professor of police studies at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, who has studied labor relations in the department. "You've got to keep in mind that since '93, '94, they feel they've been unrewarded. You can get all the pats on the back you want, but you've got to pay the mortgage."
He added, "Inherently, they felt it was unfair, because if you believe the mayor's own claims that the police were the main propellant that has driven crime down, why not reward them more?" 
Some, however, said it was premature to assume that the state board would do just that.
Daniel G. Collins, a professor at New York University who serves on the Board of Collective Bargaining, cautioned against any higher hopes for the new police pact because of the decision yesterday. He said he did not believe there would be any difference in rulings between the city and the state boards. 
Mr. Linn, the police union negotiator, acknowledged that the state board might also consider the city's current economic woes, especially a projected $1 billion budget deficit. "The city's current budget does not make hard choices easier," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
DOLLAR THRIFTY TO CUTSALARIES OF 40 TOP EXECUTIVES

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group plans to reduce salaries for executives and suspend 401(k) contributions and pay raises in 2002 after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks reduced demand for rental cars. 
Wages for the top 40 executives at Dollar Thrifty, the owner of Dollar Rent a Car Systems and Thrifty Inc., will be pared as much as 22 percent, a spokeswoman said. Dollar Thrifty said in October that it would eliminate 1,200 jobs and reduce its rental-car fleet about 20 percent. Dollar Thrifty, based in Tulsa, Okla., had an 83 percent decline in third-quarter profit, and said the attacks deepened a slide in travel and rental-car demand caused by the recession.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Japan: Auto Sales To Fall 

BYLINE:  By Ken Belson (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Japanese automobile sales will probably decline for the second consecutive year in 2002 as fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States continues to hurt the global economy, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said. 
The industry group expects sales to fall 0.7 percent next year, to 5.9 million cars. Sales of passenger cars are expected to fall 4.6 percent while sales of minicars, which have engines of less than 660 cubic centimeters, are expected to rise 1.6 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Red Sox Accept Bid From Group Headed by Marlins' Owner

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
A group led by John Henry, owner of the Florida Marlins, won the Boston Red Sox yesterday in a unanimous vote of the team's majority owner and limited partners.
 The vote came during a meeting of the limited partners at Fenway Park that lasted longer than a doubleheader. When the nine-hour session ended, John Harrington, the Red Sox' chief executive, said he was confident the Henry group would continue the "tradition of fielding a competitive team and contributing to the community" established under the Yawkey family's ownership, which began in 1933. 
 The Henry group bid $660 million for the team, Fenway and 80 percent of the New England Sports Network. No baseball team and its assets have sold for even half that amount. 
Justin Morreale, the lawyer who handled the sale for the Red Sox ownership, said the winning bid also assumed debt that took the value of the sale to approximately $700 million.
Others apparently submitted higher bids, but Morreale said no bid was higher "that was not subject to very significant contingencies that ranged from impractical to one which violated Major League Baseball rules."
The winning group includes The New York Times Company, which owns The Times and The Boston Globe.
Russell T. Lewis, president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, said in a statement: "We are extraordinarily pleased with the outcome. John Henry and all the other members of our group care deeply about the Red Sox and Boston and will proudly continue the stewardship of the Yawkeys."
One of the losing bidders was Charles Dolan of Cablevision, who has made unsuccessful efforts to buy the Yankees, the Mets and the Jets. There had been speculation that the other owners would not approve Dolan because his brother, Larry, owns the Cleveland Indians.
Perhaps with that concern in mind, Charles Dolan flew to Milwaukee on Wednesday to meet with Commissioner Bud Selig, a person familiar with the meeting said. Selig, the person said, told Dolan he saw no reason that Major League Baseball would not approve him.
But the Henry group had been considered the leading contender for the Red Sox because of its baseball connections. It is expected to have no trouble gaining the three-fourths approval it needs from owners of the other teams.
Harrington, the Red Sox chief executive, said the goal was to have the new owners in place by the start of next season.
Henry has owned the Marlins for three years. The winning bid group also includes Tom Werner, who was once the managing partner of the San Diego Padres; George Mitchell, the former United States senator from Maine, who was a member of the commissioner's blue ribbon panel on the game's economics; and Larry Lucchino, who has had vast experience as president of the Baltimore Orioles and the Padres and has recently worked closely with Selig on economic matters. Lucchino is expected to become president of the Red Sox.
The groups bidding for the team were initially supposed to be buying only the 53 percent owned by the Jean R. Yawkey Trust, but the limited partners indicated a willingness to sell once they saw the money that was being offered.
The sale of the Yawkey share was subject to approval of the limited partners. Twelve of the 23 limited partnership shares were needed to accept Harrington's recommendation, but all shares were voted for the Henry group.
Henry, who is expected to be the managing partner of the Red Sox, was part of the bidding group with Selig's permission. 
"The commissioner has a great deal of respect for John as an owner," Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief lawyer, said. "To force him to sell on an off chance that he might get the Red Sox wouldn't be fair."
Werner, who was also close to Selig when he operated the Padres, was initially the lead member of that bidding group, but Henry recently assumed that role. A baseball official said Werner would be active with Henry.
Henry is believed to have a contingency deal to sell the Marlins to Jeffrey Loria, owner of the Montreal Expos, one of the teams believed to be a target for elimination. If baseball is unable to eliminate two teams before next season and Loria buys the Marlins, Selig is expected to appoint someone to operate the Expos.
Subsequent to the submission of bids last Monday, the Henry group, with the Red Sox' permission, joined forces with one led by two Boston entrepreneurs, Joseph O'Donnell and Stephen Karp. But problems over control of the merged group arose, and the two camps did not pursue the Red Sox jointly.

HEADLINE: Cadillac, Too, Shifting Focus To Trucks 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Cadillac has built a pickup truck the Cadillac of pickups, nearly three tons worth, available in sable black, white diamond or silver sand, with the familiar Cadillac coat of arms stretched across its hulking grill.
 By rolling out an 18-foot-long Cadillac Escalade EXT pickup last month, with a sticker price of $50,000, General Motors is acknowledging, to some degree, that the Cadillac sedan's place in popular culture and its long hold on the aspirations of the affluent has been lost. It is also sanctifying America's love affair with trucks. 
 On the basis of present trends, sales of light trucks -- the category including sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickups -- will exceed sales of passenger cars this year for the first time. Two decades ago, fewer than one in five vehicles purchased was a truck. Through November, automakers sold 7,963,427 light trucks compared with 7,848,180 passenger cars, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank of Southfield, Mich. 
This bulking up of the American fleet has reversed the gains made in automotive fuel economy since the oil supply crises of the 1970's while reshaping patterns of auto accidents and injuries. And from Detroit's perspective, it has turned the passenger car into an ugly stepchild, with some saying there is little money to be made in cars and few resources to spare for them.
These days, when American cars appear on television or in movies, they are often classics, like the vintage Camaro in last summer's "Charlie's Angels" film or the 1971 Plymouth Barracuda driven by Don Johnson in the recent CBS program "Nash Bridges."
As General Motors is painfully aware, no car seems to have lost so much of its cool as the Cadillac sedan, which once held popular culture in its thrall. Jimmy Durante, Bing Crosby, John Wayne and Roy Rogers drove Cadillacs. For Elvis, buying them seemed something of an addiction. Long ago, the Sedan de Ville and its cousins were supplanted in drivers' psyches by imports. The most popular luxury import brands -- BMW, Lexus, Mercedes -- helped lead the way in developing luxury S.U.V.'s.
After many false starts at reviving Cadillac -- like the ads for the Catera with Cindy Crawford in a short, skintight skirt and knee-high boots -- Cadillac has lately regained a measure of chic by taking the same route.
First, in 1998, came the Escalade, a giant sport utility vehicle that is the forerunner of the new Escalade EXT pickup. An Escalade, for instance, fills much of the TV driveway of Bernie Mac, the comedian with a popular new Fox sitcom; the vehicle figures in songs by artists like Jennifer Lopez, Outkast, Jay-Z and Jermaine Dupri, who included the lyric "gotta have me an Escalade," on one song.
"Cadillac was frozen in time," said Ilsa Schumacher, an anthropologist whose Westport, Conn., consulting firm, Cultural Dynamics, helps G.M. get in touch with cultural trends. "It was in a huge time warp from the 50's. It was like an embryo in a time capsule."
"The S.U.V.," she added, "has been able to cross a lot of boundaries that the sedan has not." 
G.M. hopes that some of Escalade's cachet will extend to the EXT pickup; the company said that Brian Jordan, the Atlanta Braves outfielder, was among the first 160 buyers.
Cadillac is not alone in stretching boundaries. Automakers now talk about a whole new category of S.U.V. progeny that some call the S.U.T., for sport utility truck, and others term the S.U.P., for sport utility pickup. There are middle-brow versions, like the Chevrolet Avalanche, and Grey Poupon ones, like the Lincoln Blackwood. 
With its 345-horsepower engine, leather interior and Bose sound system, the Escalade EXT embodies the crossover quality of these trucks, filling a sort of restoration hardware-meets-big gulp niche. 
Susan Docherty, who manages the Cadillac brand for G.M., described the target customer for luxury pickups as a slightly earthier version of the likely buyer of a luxury S.U.V.
"They both have $2 million homes next door to each other," she said. But the prototype luxury S.U.V. driver is about 50, "has an M.B.A. from Harvard, has the golf club membership. He's the person keeping up with the Joneses."
General Motors sees the luxury pickup driver as roughly five years younger. He "might have inherited his father's construction business," Ms. Docherty said, "and has been in the construction business since he was 18, 19 years old." He may or may not have attended college, and he "is absolutely still connected to his high school friends, whereas the S.U.V. buyer is connected to his college friends."
The company expects that about 80 percent of luxury pickup buyers will be men, compared with 55 percent for luxury sport utilities.
Next month, Cadillac will roll out a reinvented luxury sedan, to be called the CTS, that it has high hopes for. Still, like the rest of the industry, it also plans to keep reinventing the truck. In 2003, Cadillac will introduce a cross between an S.U.V. and a station wagon that is tentatively called the SRX and is considered still something else -- an L.A.V. To the uninitiated, that's a luxury activity vehicle.
"The 90's were about minivans and S.U.V.'s," Ms. Docherty said. "This decade is definitely a truck decade that is about S.U.V.'s and crossovers."
Last year, truck sales pushed the fuel economy of the average new vehicle to the lowest point in two decades, according to the Environmental Protection Agency, and environmentalists want an immediate toughening of federal fuel economy standards.
All the major automakers, except Honda, openly oppose that. While they are working on technologies to improve mileage, like hybrid gas and electric engines, they argue that pushing for too much too fast will be costly and slow the development of breakthroughs, like hydrogen-powered fuel cells.
The EXT averages about 13.5 miles per gallon of gas, according to Cadillac.
Auto executives say they make what people want to buy. A recent test drive of the Escalade EXT demonstrated its capacity for head turning, whether in envy or horror. On a highway, a police officer cruised alongside just to take a long, longing look.
Cadillac has sold trucks before. Founded in 1902, it made ambulances and paddy wagons in its early days, emblazoned with the family crest of Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac, the Frenchman who founded Detroit. 
The latest Cadillac crest, however, is rendered without six tiny ducks that it included until recently. Though Cadillac now is trusting its image to a pair of off-road vehicles equipped for the discerning sportsman, the ducks seem to have left the roost.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall on Lower Forecasts for Telecommunications

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday after Juniper Networks Inc. and Jabil Circuit Inc. lowered profit forecasts, tempering optimism for a rebound in demand for telecommunications gear that helped drive the Nasdaq composite index up 35 percent the last three months.
 "Whatever kind of rebound we have will be farther out and not as strong as the majority of people were expecting," said Howard Kornblue, who helps oversee $20 billion at ING Pilgrim Investments in Scottsdale, Ariz. 
 The Nasdaq declined 64.35 points, or 3.2 percent, to close at 1,918.54, led by Microsoft and Cisco Systems. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.63 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,139.93. 
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 85.31 points, or 0.9 percent, to 9,985.18, with financial shares, including J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, declining. It was the first drop in five days for the Dow and S.& P. 500.
Some investors said the Nasdaq's three-month advance has left stocks expensive given the outlook for profit growth. Companies ranging from Ciena to Lucent Technologies have reduced earnings forecasts, and the Nasdaq has slid 5.1 percent in the last two weeks.
Analysts expect companies to report falling earnings this quarter and next, extending the string of declining profits to five quarters. For the year, the Nasdaq has lost 22.3 percent, the S.& P. 500 has fallen 13.7 percent and the Dow has dropped 7.4 percent.
While corporate profits are dropping, evidence is mounting that the economy is not deteriorating further. A government report showed the number of workers filing new claims for unemployment unexpectedly fell last week to the lowest level in five months and a separate report indicated a slowdown in manufacturing in the Philadelphia region is abating.
Juniper plunged $4.08, or 18 percent, to $18.85. The company, the second-largest maker of gear for Internet traffic, halved its fourth-quarter revenue forecast as sales declined more than expected. The company projected earnings of 5 cents a share on sales of $150 million to $155 million, below its previous estimates of 10 cents a share and $200 million.
Telecommunications companies such as WorldCom Inc. and Qwest Communications International Inc. are spending less on networking gear to save money during the recession.
"The thing that bothered people is they didn't miss by a little bit, they missed by a lot," said Andrew Abrams, who manages $100 million at CWH Associates Inc. "When you are off by that much it says, 'I really don't know what my business is,' and that means a lot of other guys don't know what their business is and that scares people."
Cisco, the largest maker of computer-networking gear, lost $1.06, to $18.29. Foundry Networks Inc., which makes computer-networking switches, dropped 29 cents, to $7.69. 
Jabil Circuit slumped $3.50, to $21.25. The maker of electronic equipment for brand-name companies reduced its 2002 earnings forecast as it reported that its first-quarter profit plunged 82 percent. The company cited declining demand for its manufacturing services as reasons for the shortfall. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
(By Reuters)
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after reports showing a drop in jobless claims and a big improvement in mid-Atlantic manufacturing activity raised hopes the recession-bound economy is laying the groundwork for a rebound next year.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 2/32, to a price of 99 23/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.04 percent from 5.05 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to 99 11/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.42 percent from 5.45 percent on Wednesday.
