HEADLINE: A No-Win Outcome 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Conventional wisdom asserted that in the end Congress would pass an economic stimulus bill. I was one of the few skeptics. Why was my skepticism vindicated?
 It helps to recall an observation that Gail Sheehy made last year: "The blind drive to win," she wrote, "is a hallmark of the Bush family clan. One thing that G. W.'s childhood friends told me repeatedly was that he has to win, he absolutely has to win and if he thinks he's going to lose, he will change the rules or extend the play. Or if it really is bad he'll take his bat and ball and go home." 
 Now consider this: More than two months ago George W. Bush endorsed a "stimulus" bill so tilted toward corporate interests that even many conservatives were startled. This left only two ways a bill could pass the Senate: Either the Democratic leadership would collapse, or Mr. Bush would accept something that didn't look like a personal win. It didn't, and he wouldn't. 
 The struggle really began less than 48 hours after the terrorist attack, when Bill Thomas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, tried to ram through a sharp cut in the capital gains tax. Even opponents of the capital gains tax generally acknowledge that cutting it does little to stimulate the economy in the short run; furthermore, 80 percent of the benefits would go to the wealthiest 2 percent of taxpayers. So Mr. Thomas signaled, literally before the dust had settled, that he was determined to use terrorism as an excuse to pursue a radical right-wing agenda.
 A month later the House narrowly passed a bill that even The Wall Street Journal admitted "mainly padded corporate bottom lines." It was so extreme that when political consultants tried to get reactions from voter focus groups, the voters refused to believe that they were describing the bill accurately. Mr. Bush, according to Ari Fleischer, was "very pleased" with the bill.
 Wednesday Mr. Thomas finally offered what he considered major concessions. "Republicans have given a lot," he declared. And Mr. Bush urged the Senate to pass this new, "bipartisan" bill.
 What, exactly, did Mr. Thomas concede? Here's a comparison that may help you feel his pain.
 The original bill, though sold as a short-run stimulus package, was actually a long-term tax cut in disguise; it would pump less than $100 billion into the economy in its first year, but would cost about $250 billion over the next five years. By contrast, the new bill -- well, actually the numbers for the new bill are just about identical. 
 The original bill consisted almost entirely of tax cuts -- 95 percent of the total cost -- with virtually nothing for the unemployed. The new bill offers slightly more to the unemployed, enough to reduce the share of tax cuts in the bill's total cost to a measly 92 percent. 
 In the original bill 69 percent of those tax cuts were for corporations; in the new bill this is reduced to a mere 63 percent.
 In its most controversial provision, the original bill retroactively eliminated the alternative minimum tax on corporations, refunding $24 billion in past corporate taxes. The new bill doesn't entirely eliminate the alternative minimum tax -- but it still offers corporations about $16 billion in refunds, spread out over time instead of all at once.
 To console himself for all these compromises, Mr. Thomas added a new individual tax break, useful only to very affluent families. 
 Strangely, these awesome sacrifices didn't impress the Democratic leadership. And so we have no stimulus bill.
 The question the American people ought to ask is why the Bush administration, given the deadlock in Congress, didn't push for a minimalist package -- rebate checks for those who didn't get them last summer, plus extended unemployment benefits, and a temporary investment tax credit. This would have disappointed Democrats who also wanted medical coverage for the unemployed, but it would surely have passed, and it would have been better than no deal at all.
 But such a package would not have lived up to the hopes of administration strategists, who thought they could use Sept. 11 to advance their long-run domestic agenda. It therefore would not have counted as a personal win for Mr. Bush. And so he took his bat and ball and went home.

HEADLINE: Both Parties Deflect Blame For Stalemate On Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Acknowledging the risks of their failure to settle on a recession-fighting package, leaders of the two parties in Congress said today that they would take up the issue again next month when they return from their holiday recess.
 Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, said he would like President Bush to call Congress back into session on Jan. 2, three weeks earlier than scheduled, to deal with the economic recovery plan. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, said he, too, was willing to get right back to work on the issue. 
 "Our hope is that it can be revived early next year," Mr. Daschle said. 
But there was no indication that the two sides were any closer to a deal. After the House passed a revised version of a Republican stimulus plan in the pre-dawn hours on a largely party line 224-to-193 vote, Republicans tried unsuccessfully to bring the bill up as part of a last-minute flurry of legislating in the Senate this afternoon, officially burying it for the year.
The collapse of the effort to reach a compromise reduced the chances that Congress and the administration could inject $75 billion to $100 billion of tax cuts and new spending into the economy next year, as most economic forecasters had assumed they would. But continued paralysis would also leave that $100 billion in the government's coffers for other purposes when tax revenues are drying up and analysts are predicting a return to budget deficits.
Intent on deflecting blame for the deadlock, Democrats and Republicans exchanged another round of accusations about which side was responsible for the inability of Congress to address the needs of laid-off workers and give the economy a lift.
Administration officials and Republicans in the House and Senate stuck to their line that the problem was intransigence on the part of the Democratic majority in the Senate, particularly Mr. Daschle.
"There's a line in a country western song that says you've got to know when to hold them and when to fold them," said Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas. "It is time for Tom Daschle to fold them. We are talking about people who cannot wait until the end of January to get the help that they are looking for."
Democrats said that for all the talk from Republicans about helping the unemployed, the main thrust of the House Republican bill was to cut taxes for businesses and for middle- and upper-income people.
Democrats said the Republican plan was too expensive, bloated by special interest provisions, unfair to laid-off workers and likely to be ineffectual in pulling the economy out of the first recession in a decade.
"We've looked at the compromise one last time and have concluded that it's wrong on all counts," Mr. Daschle said.
Democrats said that they would like to move quickly next month on one element of the stimulus package, extending the current 26-week limit on unemployment benefits by 13 weeks. Hinting without subtlety at his party's political strategy, Mr. Daschle said, "We extended those benefits three times during the last Bush recession, in the early 1990's, and I think it's important for us to extend them this time."
But it was not clear that Republicans would be willing to separate an extension of unemployment benefits from their tax-cutting proposals, a step that might give them less negotiating leverage.
In abandoning negotiation for confrontation this week, the two parties were in effect treating their differences as the kickoff to the 2002 mid-term Congressional elections. 
With new budget projections next month likely to show the government running deficits for the next few years, Democrats are hoping to deny Republicans a chance to enact another round of tax cuts. Determined to keep domestic spending in check to help pay for the war on terrorism and modernizing the military, Republicans do not want the recession to become an excuse for the Democrats to create entitlements like a right to health insurance subsidies for the unemployed.
"They believe there has to be a tax cut for the common cold," Mr. Daschle said. "Our view is that tax cuts have merit and ought to be examined, but there's a lot more to economic and fiscal policy than tax cuts, and that we have to take into account the budget and other needs."
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, said his party had made many concessions to the Democrats in trying to negotiate a bill, including more money for unemployment benefits and health insurance subsidies. But Mr. Nickles said there continued to be fundamental differences in approach.
"We're not just interested in just paying more people not to work," he said. "We want to create jobs and put people back to work."

HEADLINE: Thwarted Hopes in Congress 

 BODY:
In a disappointing conclusion to its 2001 session, Congress has adjourned in a blaze of partisan recrimination over the failure to pass a measure to stimulate the economy. Though President Bush and Republican leaders made some last-minute concessions on the bill, their final offer was too costly, too unlikely to help the economy and too unfairly weighted toward corporations and rich taxpayers to be acceptable. On a separate issue, Congress passed a spending bill to provide significant help for Lower Manhattan. But in a last-minute setback that was discouraging, a bipartisan agreement to provide tax incentives to help rebuild the area was blocked by two Republican senators. 
 In the closing hours of work yesterday, Mr. Bush accused the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, of blocking the stimulus bill by using a parliamentary rule that required 60 votes for passage. But it was Mr. Bush who failed to reach across the aisle and negotiate a bill that could be acceptable to more than three conservative Democratic senators. Genuine bipartisanship means working with the Democratic leadership and caucus as a whole, not trying to lure a few members with individual deals. 
 Mr. Daschle went far to try to make a deal with the White House. He even signaled a willingness to consider additional cuts in corporation taxes and income taxes for the wealthy, in return for Republican concessions on the structure of health benefits for unemployed workers. He was rebuffed. Mr. Bush and the Republicans insisted on enacting an ideologically driven measure on health benefits geared to individual tax credits rather than subsidies to health insurance programs. The Democrats were right to reject that approach, which would put older and less healthy people at risk.
The failure to pass a $100 billion stimulus bill is not likely to have much impact on the $10 trillion economy. But it was disheartening to see Congress leave town without extending unemployment and health benefits for those thrown out of work in the recession. 
Before adjourning, Congress approved an emergency spending measure that brought aid to New York to a total of $11.1 billion this year, only a little more than half the $20 billion that Mr. Bush promised after Sept. 11. The same bill also increased the amount that the administration had initially sought for so-called homeland defense, including the effort to combat bioterrorism. There is every reason to hope that Congress will add spending in these two vital areas next year. 
There was a breakthrough yesterday on one important measure for New York, providing tax relief for victims of the World Trade Center attacks. A welcome concession by Representative Bill Thomas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, extended the tax relief to lower-income victims, not just those with higher incomes as originally called for in his bill. The victims' measure passed in the closing hours of the session.
Unfortunately, a separate bill pushed by Senators Charles Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York to provide $5 billion in tax benefits for Lower Manhattan businesses was derailed in the Senate. The two senators who blocked it, Phil Gramm of Texas and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, objected to learning about its provisions at the last minute. In coming weeks the measure should be revised so that it helps large as well as small businesses. Mr. Gramm and Mr. Nickles should understand that it is consistent with their philosophy and help move the bill quickly to passage.

 BODY:
Argentine Financial Crisis Leads to Resignations
President Fernando de la Rua of Argentina resigned, a casualty of a deepening four-year-old recession that has brought the country to the brink of financial collapse and a social explosion rooted in unemployment and desperation.
 Demonstrations and looting also prompted the resignation of the economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, above. The coffers are empty and the country is on the verge of a halt of payments on its $132 billion debt and a devaluation that could bankrupt much of the private sector. Page A1.

Public health and law enforcement officials have long argued that drug-tracking programs can save lives by identifying doctors who overprescribe narcotics as well as patients who forge prescriptions or con unsuspecting doctors. Juniper Networks, the second-biggest maker of networking equipment that directs Internet traffic, cut its fourth-quarter profit forecast in half and lowered its sales estimate as customers like WorldCom and Qwest pared spending. Nine months after the beginning of the recession, the failure of Congress and the White House to agree on a stimulus package no longer has economists so worried that the economy will stumble without the extra boost. C2.

Leaders of the parties in Congress said that they would take up a stimulus package again when they return from their recess. A36.

Tyson Case Highlights Work Force
The indictment of Tyson Foods on charges it conspired to smuggle illegal immigrants to work at its plants is a sign of how dependent the American food and agriculture system has become on foreign-born workers. A26.

Morgan Lifts Figure on Enron Loans
J. P. Morgan Chase is owed $2.6 billion -- $1.7 billion greater than previously thought -- linked to the bankrupt Enron. C4.

Profit Falls at Securities Firms
Net income fell 67 percent at Lehman Brothers, 17 percent at Goldman Sachs and 21 percent at Bear Stearns. C4.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SUBSIDIES; 
Insurers Fail To Gain Help In Terror Costs

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Congress abandoned efforts today to protect the insurance industry from losses in any future terrorist attacks when the Senate failed to bring a measure to the floor in the final hours of the session.
 Bush administration officials, industry executives and analysts predicted that the refusal by Congress to act would prompt insurers and business lenders to increase their rates sharply as terrorism coverage was reduced or eliminated. Over time, they argue, economic harm would result. 
 "This won't cause bank runs or panics in the street, but it will cause something much more insidious, an added cost and slowing down of the economy at the worst possible time," said Under Secretary of the Treasury Peter R. Fisher, a former senior official at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who has overseen crises including the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management. 
Insurers, administration officials say, will not extend adequate coverage to building owners, developers, manufacturers and energy companies, among others. They add that lenders will be reluctant to provide financing for new and existing projects, or will do so only at substantially higher rates.
While the insurers hope that Congress will act next year, the prospects for this remain highly uncertain. A consensus emerged in the weeks after the September attacks that the insurance industry needed assistance, having lost $50 billion from the attacks. But the measure stalled over a number of matters including regional politics, financing methods and proposed changes in the nation's tort-law system. 
Legislators from the Northeast and big cities elsewhere, areas considered the most vulnerable to terrorism, generally supported aid for the insurers more strongly than those from other areas. House Republicans wanted big government payouts in future attacks to be repaid by either the industry or policyholders instead of by taxpayers.
At White House urging, the Republicans tried to limit lawsuits over damage from terrorist attacks, but the Democrats refused to go along with this.
American military advances in the war in Afghanistan and the absence of new, widespread terrorism also made the legislation appear less urgent.
And while his top aides worked on the legislation, President Bush did virtually nothing to push for it in Congress.
The legislation that died today would have done nothing to compensate insurers for their losses from Sept. 11. Those losses, while steep, still left the industry in a relatively healthy condition. 
Three weeks ago, the House, voting largely along party lines, adopted a measure to provide as much as $100 billion in government loans to the insurance industry to cover losses from future large-scale terrorist attacks. The money was to be repaid by insurers, policyholders and, if the administration wanted, taxpayers.
But comparable measures repeatedly stalled in the Senate. Late attempts by Democrats to revive the legislation were blocked this afternoon by an objection from Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky.
A growing number of state insurance regulators have said in recent days that if Congress did not adopt a financial assistance package by the end of the year, they would permit property and casualty insurers to exclude coverage for terrorist attacks. But the Consumer Federation of America has asked the state regulators to continue requiring insurers to provide this coverage. 
Mr. Fisher, the Treasury Department official, said that as terrorism coverage declines, people ranging from real estate developers to utility plant owners will begin to see their lenders charging more because their property, which serves as collateral for loans, will face greater risks. He also said the costs of insurance coverage would continue to rise, even as coverage shrank.
"Exclusions will be out there, and price shocks are going to happen," he said. "I've talked to people who have already seen a threefold increase in their premiums without the exclusions. They anticipate they will now see this in their costs of borrowing."
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, agreed and said that the failure of Congress to adopt legislation "will hurt the financial markets, particularly since bonds and bond covenants require adequate insurance, and it is not going to be there."
"The problems that will occur are going to be insidious," he said, adding that "they will be real and they will be deep."
Reinsurance companies -- which enable primary insurers to spread their risks by taking out their own insurance policies -- have warned that they no longer intend to offer coverage for losses from future terrorist attacks. About 70 percent of the contracts for property and casualty coverage expire at the end of this month.
With the bulk of commercial insurance policies expiring then, negotiations for coverage have been going on for several weeks. Not knowing whether Congress would provide help, most insurers have agreed to provide a wide range of coverage for everything but losses from terrorism.
Steve Wechsler, chief executive of the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts, said that his 200 members would see the effects as their policies come up for renewal next year. "Congress will increasingly be hearing from people with problems as the new year begins," he said.
The matter is most pressing in about a dozen major cities, like New York, Washington, Chicago and Los Angeles, that are considered prime terrorist targets. In these cities, the demand for terrorism coverage is greatest and insurers are refusing to provide it.
In much of the country, including small towns and rural areas, some insurers have agreed to sell terrorism coverage. But many business owners seem to feel little need to buy it. 
The insurers maintain that since they have no way to calculate how often or how forcefully terrorists may strike, they have no way to calculate how much to charge. 
"What we have here is an emergency in slow motion," said Steve Bartlett, the president of the Financial Services Roundtable, a group of the 100 largest banks, insurance companies, investment banks and brokerage firms in the country. "The economy won't fall off a cliff in January. But what we will see is a slow, extraordinarily powerful avalanche."
Mr. Bartlett, saying that the lack of terrorism coverage would be felt outside the big cities as well, cited the case of a trucking company owner in North Carolina, who had been turned down for a loan to buy more trucks because he could not obtain this coverage.
"He has a profitable company and an existing relationship with a lender," Mr. Bartlett said. "But he couldn't get a loan because some terrorist might decide he was a target."

Argentine President Quits As Deadly Violence Rises

HEADLINE: Our Friends the Terrorists 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Just to puncture our hypocrisy for a moment: We've been battling terrorism by bolstering backers of terrorism in Pakistan.
 Pakistan, our new ally in the war on terrorism, has a long history of supporting indiscriminate attacks in India and especially the disputed territory of Kashmir. The latest, headline-grabbing attack was the assault on the Parliament building in New Delhi that now threatens war between two nuclear powers, but many thousands of civilians have been killed over the years by Pakistani-financed terrorist organizations. 
 All in all, Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence Agency, or I.S.I., is responsible for many more killings than Osama bin Laden. 
But however hypocritical it may be to bolster one government that harbors terrorists while overthrowing another, there is no good alternative. The Bush administration is exactly right to be simultaneously supporting Gen. Pervez Musharraf and twisting his arm to fight terrorism, for he may be Pakistan's last hope to rescue his country.
Pakistan today is not only a catastrophe for Pakistanis but a threat to the entire region. Its economy is quasi-feudal, some 55 percent of adults are illiterate and more than 10 percent of children die by the age of 5. Pakistan now has more drug addicts than college graduates.
In the last 20 years public schooling has been partly replaced by madrasas that preach extremism, the pursuit of nuclear weapons has isolated the government, and foolish policies have crippled the economy. The I.S.I.'s installation of the Taliban in Afghanistan has backfired, and now there is a risk of the "Talibanization" of Pakistan, as religious extremists return from their "crusades" in Afghanistan and Pashtuns perhaps revive their quest for an independent Pashtunistan.
In Pakistan earlier this month, I flinched whenever I read the newspapers. Guerrillas in Kashmir were "freedom-fighters" if they lived, "martyrs" if they died. And on The Nation's editorial page appeared this rant: "The Christian world has not accepted us Muslims as human beings even. These nations are determined to exterminate the Muslims." 
General Musharraf is in charge of this morass, and -- under strong pressure from President Bush, and less visible nudging from China -- he has acted decisively to pull his country toward reality. He ousted the head of the I.S.I., permitted the entry of U.S. troops to oust the Taliban, and sent troops for the first time into tribal areas to capture Taliban escapees. He has moved to sideline the religious fanatics, close the extremist madrasas and deport foreign religious students. Next he must clamp down on the Kashmiri fighters.
Over the last two years General Musharraf has shown himself capable of brutally tough decisions, and there is some reason to think that he can regain control of the I.S.I. (which may have run the latest Indian attack as a rogue operation), cut off state support for Kashmiri terrorists, nurture a growing market economy -- and prepare for democratic elections. The religious parties get less than 5 percent of the vote in Pakistan, and so democracy can delegitimize extremism as well.
When I first traveled around Pakistan as a student backpacker two decades ago, I sneaked into closed tribal areas and visited a village that was a center for heroin and gun-running. One gunsmith tried to sell me a pen that could not only write but also shoot a .22 bullet out the end. Not even a Palm Pilot can do that, and it was only $7! This incredibly nifty gadget enthralled me as a symbol of Pakistani ingenuity -- and it's also apt because Pakistan has squandered its considerable potential and excelled far more at things destructive than constructive.
Now Pakistan is at a moment of maximum danger, threatened by the instability caused by returning Taliban fighters on the west and by the risk of war with India on the east. Similarly, it was at a time when India was near economic collapse, in the summer of 1991, that New Delhi moved decisively toward a path of economic reform -- and toward more sensible domestic and international policies across the board.
Pakistan, after so many wrong turns in its history, has tentatively taken a right one in the last few months. Now it must build on that by clamping down on its own terrorists. And, whatever the stench of blood in Islamabad, we Americans must hold our noses and do all we can to help General Musharraf hold his course.

HEADLINE: A Private Fortune to Further a Public Agenda 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
He will be sworn in by the departing mayor on New Year's Eve in Times Square. That is free. The next day, Michael R. Bloomberg will foot the bill for the inaugural reception, a modest affair of wine and cheese at the renovated Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan.
 The festivities will be just the latest example of the mayor-elect's beneficence toward municipal government. Since he was elected two months ago, Mr. Bloomberg has been willing to draw on his personal fortune to help him begin to build the broad base of support he will need in the face of a looming economic crisis, much as he did to get himself elected. 
 Last week, he held a cocktail reception for incoming City Council members in his Upper East Side town house, complete with fine wines and a humble speech, and held a sit-down dinner for borough presidents. A few weeks ago, he took an official trip to the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico, taking along newly elected officials on his private plane, and paying for their stay at one of the most expensive hotels in the commonwealth. His private plane also ushered elected officials and others to Israel to meet with government officials. 
Not since the early 1970's, when New York State was governed by Nelson A. Rockefeller, has there been an elected official in the state who has been able to tap into his own wealth in ways that benefit his political and policy agendas. 
Mr. Bloomberg, who spent $69 million on his mayoral campaign, bristles at suggestions that he spend portions of his own fortune to shore up the Parks Department or plug the city's enormous budget gap. But he has, as mayor-elect, been able to draw on that fortune to build good will among elected officials with whom he has had little or no contact in his life as a private businessman. His aides suggest that dinners with everyone from rank-and-file workers to foreign dignitaries will be the norm in his administration. 
The unusual juxtaposition of Mr. Bloomberg's wealth and public service has forced the city to examine ethical areas that have not been explored since Mr. Rockefeller was supplementing the salaries of his subordinates, political experts said. That practice came under fierce scrutiny by the Senate when Gerald R. Ford chose him as vice president. The Conflicts of Interest Board has privately been considering new recommendations, which are likely to be issued sometime over the next few weeks, said people with knowledge of the discussions. By law, the board cannot reveal what it is reviewing until it publicly releases an opinion.
"The notion that you can't have people you work with over for dinner seems odd," said Wayne Hawley, a lawyer with the board. "Though possibly at some extreme it would raise the sorts of issues that expensive gifts would. These things are, perhaps unavoidably, pretty fact-specific."
People close to Mr. Bloomberg say that they expect his personal style, which relies heavily on relationship-building and personal salesmanship, to extend into his mayoralty, during which he will continue to entertain public officials much the way he used to play host to socialites and television personalities. Much of the wining and dining, however, will probably take place at Gracie Mansion, which he plans to use as a clubhouse rather than as his home.
"It is more and more likely that his social life will be entertaining City Council members and the borough president and the district attorney and corporate C.E.O.'s who we are trying to woo and legislators from Buffalo," one aide said. "His social life will be aggressively business. Not unlike Rockefeller, where you use your wealth to benefit the agenda of the city."
And like Mr. Rockefeller, who also had a private plane which in fact he used to usher officials to Israel, Mr. Bloomberg may find the approach has its merits. "On one level, his wealth is a measure of his past leadership," said Bill de Blasio, an incoming council member from Brooklyn who served in the Dinkins administration and managed Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign last year. He was one of the guests who enjoyed tartar rolls, wine and museum-quality art at Mr. Bloomberg's Upper East Side home. 
"But he has to be careful about being sensitive about it," Mr. de Blasio added. "It was a smart move to invite us over, because there is a lot of mystique surrounding him, and for most of us, they don't have a lot of experience with people on his economic level."
Joel Rivera, an incoming council member from the Bronx who benefited from a free plane ride and a room at the Ritz-Carlton in Puerto Rico, said he found that the time spent with Mr. Bloomberg in the air was very useful because they were able to talk about higher education. And the gesture made an impression. "We've all been waiting for quite some time for a hand to be extended," he said. "I think there will now be two sides to City Hall."
Mr. Bloomberg seems to be somewhat aware that he must avoid creating uncomfortable class gaps or seeming impervious to the city's troubled times. He has taken pains to say that his inauguration will be low-key. One of the few foods served will be peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. He even decided against live music, and except for the last-minute addition of a stereo in the corner, the event may be soundless save the voices of revelers. 
But like Mr. Rockefeller, Mr. Bloomberg brings more than a large bank account as one of the city's wealthiest residents. Wealth and social power inevitably lead to business and social connections that can be useful, particularly when the city needs to press the private sector to help with its recovery. 
"Rockefeller had the trappings to make him useful," said Ronald Maiorana, who was the governor's press secretary his entire term. "He had his own helicopter to go back and forth to New York and Albany. It was a matter of convenience, and he was being magnanimous and generous when the elected official would ask for a ride."
Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, said that Mr. Rockefeller's prior relationships, which were like the ones Mr. Bloomberg has had with business leaders, medical experts and philanthropists, served the state well. "He came with all sorts of social relationships already formed," Mr. Carroll said. "Mike Bloomberg is also plugged in. He can talk to bankers, appoint business people who will help and things like that."
But he and others added that money alone was not the lure, a view echoed by others who knew Mr. Rockefeller. "His was an incredible personality," Mr. Maiorana said. "People were drawn to that as much as his wealth. You hear the term that someone really loves people. In his case it was not a cliche; it was a fact."
Aides to Mr. Bloomberg constantly say that he is also a man who likes to negotiate hard deals and troubles over bread and wine, and that people will be charmed by this as well. 
But no matter what the city's fiscal shape, no matter that he will hold the most modest inauguration in decades, Mr. Bloomberg will remain a very wealthy man, and the city will probably continue to see him through the prism of his planes, homes and the accouterments of a life well led. Former Mayor Edward I Koch said, "I think he is going to keep drinking expensive wines."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 16, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 21 about wealthy politicians who have used their fortunes to advance a public agenda misstated the period in which Ronald Maiorana worked as press secretary to one such figure, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York. It was 1970 to 1973, not the governor's entire term.

But ethical questions follow the cocktail parties in his town house and flights on his jet. (Bill Cunningham/The New York Times); (United Press International/Corbis)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: IN BEIJING; 
Pakistan's Leader Reassures China of Their Special Bond

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Friday, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan received an unusually lavish welcome here on Thursday, as the two countries sought to reaffirm their longstanding friendship amid the shifting Asian alliances brought about by the United States-led war on terrorism in Afghanistan.
 "The cornerstone of Pakistan's foreign policy is its close association and relationship with China," General Musharraf told China's president, Jiang Zemin, after arriving at the Great Hall of the People in an immense motorcade. 
 Mr. Jiang called Pakistan an "old friend," adding, "I trust that your visit will serve to vigorously advance our comprehensive partnership or collaboration." 
The five-day state visit was one of a series of events to commemorate 50 years of diplomatic relations between China and Pakistan. In that time, China has become an important source of both economic aid and military technology for Pakistan. China's support of Pakistan in part has been as a counterweight against India, which fought a war against China in 1962.
But the friendship between Pakistan and China has recently been shaken a bit by the introduction of a third party -- the United States -- which has adopted Pakistan as its closest ally in the region in its war against Afghanistan's former Taliban rulers and Osama bin Laden's Qaeda terrorism network.
While China has generally supported the American war effort, the new cooperation between a nation it views as its primary global competitor, the United States, and its old friend, Pakistan, was bound to raise concerns.
In general, China wants to make sure that it remains the power to be reckoned with in the region. Beijing has nurtured economic and security relations with the new Central Asian states that ring its western frontier, and it does not want to see an American military buildup there.
A second Chinese concern is maintaining stability in South Asia, especially avoiding a war between Pakistan and India over Kashmir, which abuts China. Chinese officials have stressed the importance of reaching a diplomatic solution.
"Pakistan's political stability is not only in the interests of the Pakistani people, it also concerns regional peace and stability," Mr. Jiang told the Pakistani leader, according to China's Xinhua News Agency. 
General Musharraf reassured his hosts that an old friendship would be given priority. 
"China has been our trusted friend and our relationship has remained time-tested, and we are very positive that in the future also this relationship, this strategic association and relationship, will continue," he said.

HEADLINE: Budget Battle Ends in Congress Without the Usual Brouhaha 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The often contentious process of deciding how much to spend on activities of the federal government came to a close today on Capitol Hill, with few of the fireworks and none of the presidential vetoes that had become common in recent years.
 Congress cleared the last three of the 13 annual appropriations bills, for the Defense Department, health and education programs and foreign aid. The Defense bill included $8.2 billion for disaster relief in New York and $8.3 billion to tighten domestic security. 
 The first session of the 107th Congress ended when the Senate adjourned today at 10:06 p.m., five hours after the House wrapped up its business. Congress is scheduled to reconvene on Jan. 23.
Lawmakers had many disagreements over priorities, but none deep enough to force a shutdown of federal agencies, as in 1995-96. Congress did not resort to the messy device of a catchall spending bill, as it had often done when it failed to pass separate bills for major operations of the government.
But agreements may be more elusive in 2002, an election year. The political environment will be more partisan as lawmakers use the budget to contrast the positions of the two parties. Moreover, the budget will be extremely tight. Congress will face the prospect of deficits because of the recession and the tax cuts enacted this year. And the government will need more money to fight terrorism.
Congress was late in finishing its work this year. The spending bills provide money for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. But the appropriations process generally followed the civics textbooks.
Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said the process worked well.
"We stayed within the budget numbers, but we still reacted and responded to the terrorist attacks," Mr. Young said in an interview. "Most of the 13 bills passed with huge majorities."
The spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services and Education, often the most contentious, won broad bipartisan support. The House approved it on Wednesday, 393 to 30, and the Senate followed today, voting 90 to 7.
Mr. Young, a Florida Republican, said he and the senior Democrat on the committee, David R. Obey of Wisconsin, "set out early in the year to make sure that the bill did not become a political football."
Democrats said they were extremely pleased with the increases in spending for education and biomedical research. The National Institutes of Health is getting an increase of $3 billion, or nearly 15 percent, to $23.3 billion.
Education programs will receive $48.9 billion. That is $6.7 billion (16 percent) more than last year and $4.4 billion (10 percent) more than President Bush requested.
The spending bills are among the few measures that Congress must pass each year, because under the Constitution, "no money shall be drawn from the Treasury but in consequence of appropriations made by law."
Representative Norm Dicks, Democrat of Washington, said he regretted Mr. Bush's insistence on "an arbitrary number" -- $686 billion -- as the limit on spending subject to annual appropriations, known as discretionary spending. Because of that insistence, Mr. Dicks said, "lots of domestic security needs will go unmet," and the Pentagon will get much less than it needs to buy weapons and equipment.

HEADLINE: United Airlines Mechanics' Strike Is Blocked by Bush 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
President Bush blocked a strike yesterday at United Airlines, the second time this year that the White House has intervened to prevent a walkout at a large carrier. 
 Mr. Bush signed an executive order creating a three-member emergency board responsible for studying the contract dispute between United Airlines and its mechanics and making a settlement recommendation. 
 The appointment of the board bars a strike for 60 days by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 13,000 mechanics at United, the nation's second-largest carrier after American Airlines. Had the White House not acted, United workers would have been free to walk out beginning today, effectively shutting down the airline right before the Christmas and New Year's holidays. 
The move had been expected for weeks because of the precarious financial condition of the airline industry and the weak economy and because of the prospect of a serious disruption during a peak travel period.
The machinists union, which is a member of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., lashed out at the White House, accusing the Bush administration of "declaring war" on American workers. 
"The right to win better wages and working conditions came at great cost to workers in this country and will not be given up or taken away without a fight," R. Thomas Buffenbarger, the president of the union, said in a statement.
United said that it had met with union leaders in Washington yesterday and agreed to continue negotiations. "We all recognize that the very unusual circumstances in our industry have made contract negotiations much more challenging than usual," the airline said in a statement. 
They are especially challenging at United, where a majority of the parent company, the UAL Corporation, is owned by employees, including a large stake held by the machinists. 
The union agreed to wage concessions in 1994 in exchange for its stake in the company. After returning to 1994 wage levels, the mechanics were poised to receive a large pay increase in line with a generous new contracts signed earlier this year by mechanics at American Airlines. 
But United lost nearly $2 billion so far this year because of the weak economy and the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 that crashed two of its jets.
John W. Creighton Jr., the former paper company executive who took over as chief executive in October after his predecessor was forced to resign, is now seeking concessions from all employees to stem the losses. 
The airline acknowledges that United mechanics are now paid roughly one-third less an hour than their counterparts at American. The union is also upset because United's pilots succeeded in negotiating a generous new contract last August. 
But giving mechanics any pay increase is difficult at a time when United is receiving $800 million in direct government assistance and may have to apply for a federally backed loan. 
The airline and the union are struggling to come up with a formula that would somehow satisfy the workers' demand for a raise without raising United's costs. "To date, we are not asking for concessions from the '94 rates," William P. Hobgood, UAL's senior vice president for people, said in an interview. 
The discussions are further complicated by the fact that a rival union hoping to win the right to represent United's mechanics is waiting to seize on any perceived failure by the machinists.
Mr. Bush's appointees to the emergency board are three experienced labor arbitrators. Under the Railway Labor Act, which governs labor relations in the airline industry, Congress has the right to intervene if a settlement is not reached in 60 days. It could extend the strike moratorium or impose the emergency board's proposed settlement. 
Mr. Bush has been more aggressive about blocking airline strikes than any president since Lyndon B. Johnson. In March, he appointed an emergency board to prevent a walkout by mechanics at Northwest Airlines. The two sides reached a settlement before the board made its recommendation. 
The White House was poised to intervene again in April, when pilots at Delta Air Lines were threatening to shut down the airline. But the two sides reached an agreement before the strike deadline. 
Unions accuse the White House of removing the pressure on management to settle. But airline executives say that government intervention only rights the balance because airline strikes are so expensive that management has no choice but to give in to the workers' demands.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Pushes to Make Daschle Appear a National Villain 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
When President Bush's push for an economic stimulus package collapsed in a partisan heap early this morning, Republicans from the White House down left no doubt about where they thought the blame lay.
 "Fundamentally, it still remains the job of the Senate leadership to complete their business," the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, solemnly intoned. 
 Speaker J. Dennis Hastert was blunter: "The Senate has turned its back."
The object of their ire was Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, who has emerged as the Republicans' devil du jour. 
Senator Daschle, 54, is the most powerful elected Democrat in the country, but he speaks so softly that reporters strain to hear him. He is as partisan as anyone in Washington, but manages to disguise it beneath his mild manners.
Republicans contend that Mr. Daschle is the man most responsible for blocking major elements of President Bush's domestic agenda, from the stimulus package to Republican appointments.
One conservative group ran newspaper advertisements in South Dakota last month picturing Mr. Daschle side by side with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, accusing the senator of helping keep Mr. Hussein in power by opposing oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Vice President Dick Cheney called him "an obstructionist" and declined to criticize the advertisement.
Another conservative group has run radio advertisements in Mr. Daschle's hometown, Aberdeen, S.D. -- with a media buy so heavy that typical listeners hear them two dozen times a week -- blaming him for blocking the president's plan to "extend unemployment benefits to those most affected by the Sept. 11 tragedy." Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, likened Mr. Daschle to a "rabid dog."
"I keep finding amusement in their imagination, in the different references they're making to me," Mr. Daschle said, allowing himself a faint smile in an interview on Wednesday, sandwiched between procedural wrangles on the farm bill and the collapse of negotiations on a stimulus bill. "Who knows what tomorrow brings, but they seem to have an unlimited supply."
If Mr. Daschle can shrug off the attacks, it may be because it is far from clear they have hurt him, among fellow Democrats or the public at large. In June, just after Democrats took control of the Senate when Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont switched from Republican to independent, a New York Times/CBS News poll found that 68 percent of Americans had not heard enough about him to even have an opinion. 
Now, just weeks after Mr. Daschle became a household name and face in the trauma of a deadly anthrax-laced letter sent to his office, the political attacks have increased his prominence even more. 
"This makes Tom Daschle the man to see," said Jennifer Palmieri, the spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee. "His life was threatened. The American people know who he is because of the anthrax letter. They're not going to buy that he's a firebrand."
But Grover Norquist, an influential Republican strategist and president of Americans for Tax Reform, which is helping sponsor the radio advertisements against Mr. Daschle, said: "He is not going to be a senator from South Dakota in 2005. He will either run for president and give up his seat, or if he tries to run again having been the leader of the left wing of the Democratic Party, we'll beat him."
Indeed, Republicans leave little doubt about their strategy, or its antecedents.
"It's time for someone, everyone, to start using the phrase 'Daschle Democrats' and the word 'obstructionist' in the same sentence," the Republican strategist Frank Luntz wrote in a memorandum of suggested talking points to the Senate Republican caucus on Wednesday.
"It's time for Congressional Republicans to personalize the individual that is standing directly in the way of economic security, and even national security," the memorandum added. "Remember what the Democrats did to Gingrich? We need to do exactly the same thing to Daschle."
Republicans and Democrats alike acknowledge, however, that the low-key Mr. Daschle can hardly be compared to Newt Gingrich, the former Republican Speaker and theorist who often seemed to go out of his way to be provocative, even polarizing.
By contrast, Mr. Daschle has offered virtually unstinting support to the White House in its war on terrorism abroad and at home, ignoring the objections of some liberal senators who raised questions about the administration's requests for sweeping new law enforcement tools. Only on domestic economic questions where polls suggest Democrats have an advantage has Mr. Daschle challenged the White House.
"Newt was a lot easier" to caricature, said Senator John B. Breaux, a moderate Democrat from Louisiana whom the White House has tried to co-opt in its search for a compromise stimulus plan. "It was not a lot of heavy lifting. Tom is not a good target. He's not someone you can put up on a wall like Osama bin Laden. He's nice, he's likable, he's genuine."
To Republicans, Mr. Daschle's calm demeanor masks a partisan determination that reminds them of the former Senate Democratic leader George J. Mitchell, the former senator from Maine, who was one of Mr. Daschle's mentors. Bush partisans still blame Mr. Mitchell for forcing President George Bush to abandon his "no new taxes" pledge in the 1990 budget deal.
"He's so nice, so unassuming, that you'll never see the knife until it's in your back," Mr. Luntz said in an interview.
Addressing the future of an economic package, Mr. Daschle insisted he was not trying to block passage, only "redirect" priorities away from the president's proposed tax breaks for businesses to greater medical insurance coverage for unemployed workers, and said he hoped a deal might still be worked out in January.
"We want to pass something," he told reporters today, "but we don't want to pass anything."
Mr. Daschle, who is in his third term and up for re-election in 2004, said he would not make any decisions about a presidential race until after next year's midterm elections, though some people close to him seem to think he may be seriously considering it. He said he thought Democrats would be well advised not to try to pick a nominee too early.
"I don't think that we know who will be a strong candidate in 2004 in part because we don't know what the circumstances are going to be," he said. "I think it is too early."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Aides Lay Plans To Repair a Battered Image 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Even after Bill Clinton was elected president, his campaigning never seemed to stop. In the White House, he was always keenly attentive to polls and political calculations and presided over what became known as a "permanent campaign."
 Now, Mr. Clinton is trying to extend the permanent campaign even beyond his presidency. 
 Frustrated that his image has been battered since he left office, Mr. Clinton summoned several of his aides and advisers on Wednesday to devise ways to remind the public of his accomplishments and defend his legacy against criticism on matters including his role in the current recession and his failure to strike a fatal blow against Osama bin Laden or his terrorist network after the embassy bombings in East Africa in 1998.
Several participants at the meeting in Mr. Clinton's Harlem office said in interviews that they had agreed to compile a list of the Clinton administration's achievements that his supporters could have handy when defending the president. They hope to build a staff that will coordinate efforts to enlist former cabinet secretaries and other Clinton surrogates to appear on television talk shows and deliver speeches. And they are making plans to raise Mr. Clinton's profile on the lecture circuit, particularly before college audiences, which are most receptive.
Participants in the session said Mr. Clinton was concerned that Democratic leaders had not sufficiently spoken up for his administration, especially his centrist policies on health care, welfare, crime and education. As part of the campaign to refurbish his image, Mr. Clinton wants to play a central role in setting an issue agenda for the Democrats and for the party's aspiring Congressional and presidential candidates, his advisers said.
No modern president has ever mounted such an aggressive and organized drive to affect the agenda after leaving the White House.
"It's important that the president's legacy not be squandered because his own people remain silent and scattered," said Bill Richardson, Mr. Clinton's energy secretary, who like many others took part through a telephone hookup. "It's important that the Democratic Party not turn away from Clinton's centrist legacy that brought us economic prosperity."
Several participants said they did not want to discuss the meeting out of respect for Mr. Clinton's privacy. Others also acknowledged that they were worried that Mr. Clinton could be portrayed as preoccupied with his reputation and not conducting himself appropriately for a former president.
"I feel very uncomfortable talking about these meetings," said Sandy Berger, Mr. Clinton's former national security adviser.
"As far as I'm concerned, it was a private meeting, so I'm not going to say anything," said Al From, the executive director of the Democratic Leadership Council.
Others, insisting they had nothing to hide, were not so reluctant.
Rodney Slater, Mr. Clinton's transportation secretary, said an impetus for the meeting was to make sure that the former president's policies were still in the public discourse.
"As much as anything, it was to recognize that we were part of something special," Mr. Slater said, "that there were still opportunities out there for us to express opinions about things and professional judgments."
Douglas Sosnik, who was Mr. Clinton's political director and later one of his most senior aides, put it this way: "Under President Clinton's leadership, we accomplished a remarkable amount in the last eight years, and his friends feel we should be doing a better job of getting that out proactively. Since he left office, we've spent too much time on the defensive, reacting to stories."
Gene Sperling, who was Mr. Clinton's top economic aide, said, "Most of the conversation was really about what kind of things he should be doing with his time, what his long-term service contributions should be."
Julia Payne, Mr. Clinton's spokeswoman, said she would have no comment about "a private meeting."
While Mr. Clinton had held meetings with advisers before, participants described this one as having a special urgency.
Mr. Clinton dominated the session, which lasted nearly two hours, participants said. They said he was careful not to criticize President Bush. And they said that while he expressed concern that he was being blamed for not catching Osama bin Laden, most of the discussion was about how to raise his profile and press his case on domestic matters.
Even during his presidency, Mr. Clinton was deeply interested in how he would be perceived by history. Now, the efforts to deploy surrogates to speak out for him are reminiscent of his vaunted war rooms in the White House, which were established for him to seize the political offensive on matters that included Whitewater and health care.
"He basically said our legacy is being pummeled and we have to find ways to revive it," said one participant, who described it as if it were a meeting of the top lieutenants of a political campaign. "We concluded that the Clinton hard core were not on message, and we had to develop a center of gravity. We have to remind people of what we did on the economy, what we did with the crime bill, what we did with terrorism." He added, "They're trying to pin the bin Laden thing on us."
Participants said that while some nice things were said about the Democratic leaders in Congress, Senator Tom Daschle and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, there was a view that they would only do so much to press the Clinton agenda. "The view was that House and Senate Democrats were too preoccupied with their own re-elections and their own deals," one participant said.
Other participants included Maggie Williams, Mr. Clinton's current chief of staff; John D. Podesta, Mr. Clinton's former chief of staff; Bruce Lindsey, Mr. Clinton confidant; Eli J. Segal, the former head of Mr. Clinton's national service organization; Steve Richetti, who was a deputy chief of staff; Maria Echavesta, a former deputy chief of staff; and Cheryl Mills, a deputy White House counsel. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York did not take part, nor did former Vice President Al Gore or any of his advisers.
Mr. Clinton's advisers said part of the discussion was over how active the former president should be in stumping for Democratic candidates next year. They said they had not reached a determination.
"He does not want to appear to be upstaging Bush," said one participant. "But the alternative to that is to continue to see his legacy vanish. Clinton said he was getting more of a positive response about his legacy with younger people."
Mr. Richardson, for one, said it was appropriate for Mr. Clinton to have a more public role.
"I'm pleased that the president will be more active in ensuring his legacy," he said.

HEADLINE: A Fairer Sort of Harvard 

BYLINE:  By Richard Freeman; Richard Freeman is a professor of economics at Harvard and co-director of the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. Frank Rich is on vacation.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Last spring protesting students at Harvard demanded that the university pay all of its workers at least a living wage and that it stop contracting with outside companies for low-wage work. Faced with unflattering national publicity, Harvard set up a committee of faculty members, administrators, students and employees to look at the situation of its low-wage workers and make recommendations. The protests had raised a fundamental question: Does a major employer like Harvard have a responsibility to be a good employer to workers, or should it seek to get by with the least it can in the labor market?
 The last time Harvard faced this question was in December 1929, when the State of Massachusetts ordered it to pay female building cleaners the state minimum wage of 37 cents an hour, 2 cents above what the university had been paying. Choosing to get by with the least it could, Harvard fired the cleaning women and directed other workers to do their jobs. 
 This time Harvard is going in a very different direction. Its committee's report, which came out this week, documents the substantial decline in the real wages of custodians and other low-paid employees. It describes how the threat that work would be contracted out has put pressure on unionized workers to accede to low pay. If the committee's recommendations are adopted next month by Harvard's president, Lawrence Summers -- as is likely, given his positive reaction to the report -- the university will be committed to treating its lower-wage workers as full members of the university community and to giving them decent wages, respect for their work and opportunities for further training.
The committee also recommends pay increases that would take the lowest wages to between $10.83 and $11.30 an hour from $8.50. These rates are based on what the committee felt collective bargaining would have produced absent the threat of outsourcing to lower-wage contractors. The recommended pay levels exceed the levels in the living wage law that the City of Cambridge applies to municipal employees and city contractors.
Contrary to the fears of some alumni, students and administrators, the committee did not cave in to student demands for setting low-level pay according to a living wage formula, about which there could be considerable controversy, or to end outsourcing. Though it recommends a wage floor for the present, the heart of its proposal is something else: a parity wage and benefits policy for contractors, based on collective bargaining. Companies under contract to provide workers at Harvard would have to pay wages equivalent to the wages for Harvard's unionized employees doing comparable work. The Harvard unions would be bargaining, in effect, for minimum wages and benefits for the employees of contractors as well as for themselves, even though those outside workers might not be union members.
This policy has greater applicability to other major employers than a living wage would. And it does not lead the university into the difficult task of regularly evaluating living standards for workers with different family structures.
Falling real wages for low-paid workers are not unique to Harvard or to universities. Failure to spread prosperity widely has been the major failure in America's economic success. Treating low-wage workers as hired hands rather than as part of the work community is also not unique to Harvard. Many employers use contractors for low-wage work to avoid being responsible for what they know are abysmal wages, benefits and working conditions.
The Harvard committee's response of parity in compensation and working conditions between union and nonunion workers shows one way to deal with this problem. Other major employers, particularly those without unions, might find different ways, like committing to a definition of a living wage and paying accordingly.
For the United States to come together in the face of economic disparity, it is important to recognize that there is virtue as well as economic sense in being a good employer. Harvard December 2001, not Harvard December 1929, should be a model for the American economy.

HEADLINE: Spending Rate Is Pointing To a Rebound 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
Consumer optimism rose to a four-month high this month, and Americans have been spending at a pace that suggests they will help the economy rebound during the next three months, reports released today showed.
 The University of Michigan's final index for December jumped to 88.8 from 83.9 in November. The preliminary December figure was 85.8, and the revision exceeded analysts' expectations. 
 The index marks "a significant shift in consumer attitudes," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York. "This is further support for a first-quarter recovery."
A rebound in stocks, low oil prices, fewer job cuts and American military success in Afghanistan are helping restore optimism after Sept. 11.
The Michigan survey helps predict spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the economy, and a report from the Commerce Department today suggests that consumers passed more time in malls and auto showrooms during the final three months of this year.
While personal spending fell 0.7 percent in November, that came after a record 2.9 percent jump in October, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline was slightly smaller than economists had expected.
The two months combined suggest that spending may grow at a 4.7 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, which ends this month. That contrasts with a 1 percent rate, the lowest in eight and a half years, that the Commerce Department reported today for the third quarter.
Gross domestic product, the sum of goods and services produced in the United States, shrank at a 1.3 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the department said today in its final estimate. The third quarter's performance was the weakest in more than a decade.
The pace is slower than the 1.1 percent rate of decline reported last month. The revision largely reflected new construction data and new export information.
A third report showed that personal incomes fell 0.1 percent in November, matching decreases of the prior two months. Analysts had expected a 0.2 percent increase.
Consumers have adjusted by shopping at discounters and taking advantage of no-interest financing at auto dealers. Recent numbers from the Labor Department also suggest that the worst layoffs have passed.
The personal savings rate was 0.9 percent after registering 0.2 percent in October. The indicator weighs current income from wages, salaries, businesses and government payments against spending. It does not account for borrowed money, income from investments or withdrawals from prior savings.
The report on gross domestic product showed that businesses reduced inventories at an even faster pace than previously estimated. The lower number subtracts from G.D.P. At the same time, the depletion of stockpiles may lead to increased factory orders and production next year, which would help drive growth.
Investors are growing more optimistic that corporate profits may rebound. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 10 percent since the beginning of October after falling 21 percent in the first nine months of the year. The Nasdaq composite index is up about 30 percent.
Oil prices have fallen more than 25 percent this year, contributing to gasoline prices at the pump that have fallen below $1 a gallon in some regions of the country.
The latest employment figures offer reason for optimism. The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits fell unexpectedly last week, to the lowest level in almost five months, government figures showed on Thursday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Rise in Consumer Sentiment Sends Share Prices Higher

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rallied yesterday as an unanticipated rise in consumer sentiment and heartening forecast by the telecommunications equipment maker Nortel Networks put investors in a buying mood.
 "The consumer confidence data are heartening," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. "That is one positive sign that 2002 will be a recovery year. Combined with other indicators, it makes for an easier decision-making process." 
 The University of Michigan's key gauge of consumer sentiment rose for the third consecutive month in December, as buyers demonstrated confidence in the economy's prospects, even as personal income declined during October. Consumer spending accounts for nearly two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Better-than-expected outlooks from Nortel and Nike lifted hopes that the economy and corporate profits would turn around next year. Wall Street was hit by a string of corporate earnings warnings this week, but investors are betting the market hit bottom in September and is poised to rise further.
"The market is looking forward," said Peter Gottlieb, portfolio manager at First Albany Asset Management. "We're looking forward to a recovery in the first or second quarter of next year, and we need numbers that are going to confirm that idea."
The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 50.16 points, or 0.5 percent, at 10,035.34. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.96 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,144.89. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index added 27.29 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,945.83.
For the week, most major indexes advanced solidly. The blue-chip Dow gained more than 2.3 percent, while the broader market rose by 2 percent. Technology stocks faltered after a promising start, finishing the week 0.4 percent lower.
Wall Street was watchful of fallout stemming from Argentina's deepening political and economic morass. The nation's president, Fernando de la Rua, stepped down amid the worst civil unrest in a decade, prompted by anger over Argentina's worsening financial problems and efforts to avoid the biggest debt default in history.
But traders focused on positive news from several companies that either met or beat analysts' forecasts in spite of the halting economy.
Canada's Nortel warned it would post a quarterly loss because of weaker sales, but its stock rallied nonetheless on relief that the loss was lower than Wall Street analysts had expected.
Nortel gained 77 cents, to $7.13, dragging many networking stocks up in its wake. Ciena, for instance, rose 42 cents, to $14.43.
Nike, the maker of athletic shoes and clothing, announced that it expected modest earnings and revenue growth for the balance of its 2002 fiscal year. Nike surged by $2.51 on the news, to $56.30.
Weakness in the financial and pharmaceutical sectors helped constrain share price gains. J. P. Morgan Chase declined 77 cents, to $35.75, on continued problems stemming from its loan exposure to the bankrupt energy trader Enron.
Pfizer fell 40 cents, to $41, after a Texas jury awarded plaintiffs $43 million in compensatory damages from injuries arising from the company's recalled diabetes drug Rezulin. Pfizer rival Eli Lilly dropped $1.63, to $78.40.
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday. The 10-year Treasury note lost 11/32 , to a price of 99 12/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.08 percent from 5.04 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32 , to 98 30/32 . The bond's yield rose to 5.45 percent from 5.42 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Rich and Poor, by Race 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Grounded by an Income Gap" (Arts & Ideas pages, Dec. 15):
 It astounded me that almost nobody quoted in the debate over income disparity cited the degree to which institutionalized racism accounts for this disparity. 
This is true worldwide, in terms of rich and poor countries, as well as within our own society. And the disparity is all the more potent when it comes to wealth, as distinct from income. 
 The economists you quote, as well as society as a whole, simply fail to consistently understand the role of racial hierarchy and subjugation as explanatory factors for so much of our economic, political and social life. Until we can come to grips with this reality, we will forever fall short of our democratic ideals -- and possibly forever face angry, degraded people in the rest of the world.

CHESTER HARTMAN
Executive Director, Poverty and Race Research Action Council
Washington, Dec. 19, 2001

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Japan and China in Pact On 8-Month Trade Dispute

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
Japan and China said today that they had settled an eight-month dispute that threatened to seriously disrupt trade between them, an $85 billion relationship fraught with an unusual degree of political testiness.
 China agreed to withdraw 100 percent tariffs it had imposed on Japanese automobiles, mobile phones and air-conditioners. Japan backed down from threats to impose very low ceilings on imports of Chinese agricultural goods. 
 It took a high-level face-to-face meeting to complete the deal. Takeo Hiranuma, the Japanese trade minister, met in Beijing today with his Chinese counterpart, Shi Guangsheng. 
"Both governments will work together to strengthen orderly trade between our two countries," the Japanese Trade Ministry said today in announcing the deal. It mentioned plans for future talks and for a joint crackdown on smuggling.
Powerful domestic political sensitivities were at play on both sides. Resentment of Japan's conquest and occupation of much of the country in World War II remains alive in China, and though it is modernizing and growing fairly rapidly, China's economy is still much the smaller and more backward of the two. In Japan, the inefficient but politically powerful farm sector whips up nationalist sentiment to win protection from cheaper foreign competition. 
At the farm lobby's behest, Japanese lawmakers set off the dispute by imposing high duties on Chinese-grown mushrooms and leeks. 
Contributing to friction in the trade relationship has been Japan's direct loss of manufacturing jobs to China as companies shift production to take advantage of lower wages there. In part because Chinese factory workers are paid as little as 5 percent of what Japanese workers earn, Japanese companies now own more manufacturing capacity in China than they do in the United States. 
But there is little that lawmakers can do to stop the manufacturing exodus to China, analysts said, noting that the two economies will become increasingly intertwined in the coming years. 
"Concluding the trade argument is very positive for both sides," said Mamoru Yamazaki, an economist at Barclays Capital Markets in Tokyo. "Japan needs China as an export market and a manufacturing base."

HEADLINE: Thomas Gulotta's Irresponsible Exit 

 BODY:
In his last major act before leaving office, Nassau County's departing Republican county executive, Thomas Gulotta, extended his record of fiscal mismanagement and made the job facing his Democratic successor, Thomas Suozzi, a lot harder. Making last-minute changes to the budget approved by the County Legislature's narrow Democratic majority, Mr. Gulotta rejected its core idea of accelerating three planned 5 percent tax increases into a single 15 percent increase next year. Instead Mr. Gulotta lowered next year's tax increase to 9 percent, relying for superficial balance on the same sort of phony assumptions and gimmicks that led the populous suburban county -- one of the nation's wealthiest -- to pile up huge public deficits in the midst of an economic boom. 
 Among other things, Mr. Gulotta optimistically recalibrated the county's sales tax projections to forecast a 3 percent increase in sales tax receipts over the coming year. Westchester County is predicting that sales tax revenues will remain essentially flat, and in New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has projected a 5 percent decline. 
 The Nassau Interim Finance Authority, the state oversight board that monitors Nassau County's finances, hurt its own credibility as an independent watchdog by approving Mr. Gulotta's revisions instead of demanding another round of tweaking by county officials. The board itself acknowledged that the budget contains big risks that will have to be closely monitored. But having rejected several previous versions, the board decided to accept the large remaining flaws, and put its faith in Mr. Suozzi to straighten things out once he takes office on Jan. 1.
Mr. Suozzi was on firm ground in complaining that saddling him with such a precarious budget will make it more difficult to achieve the fundamental reforms of county government he promised voters. For his future effectiveness, though, Mr. Suozzi needs to ditch his immature habit of venting disagreement by tossing off intemperate remarks that risk alienating people whose cooperation he badly needs.
The oversight board has given Mr. Suozzi a deadline of April 1 to come up with a responsible four-year fiscal plan that will lift Nassau out of the red. That is a very short time to accomplish the required top-to-bottom restructuring of Nassau's bloated government bureaucracy, flush out patronage and waste and achieve realistic labor agreements that allow for overdue personnel reductions and improved productivity. But the severity of Nassau's financial problems makes prompt action mandatory. Mr. Gulotta's mendacious final budget only adds to those problems.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
I.M.F. and U.S. Are Blamed For Argentina's Collapse
With riots in the streets, the collapse of a government and another multibillion-dollar bailout deemed a dismal failure, Argentina's woes have raised fresh questions about the effectiveness of the International Monetary Fund and the financial policy of the United States, the fund's leading shareholder.
 Latin American and European government leaders joined protesters in Buenos Aires, Wall Street traders and financial experts in putting at least part of the blame for Argentina's problems on the I.M.F. and the Clinton and Bush administrations. Page A1. 

Microsoft Asks for a 4-Month Delay
Microsoft asked a federal judge to delay by at least four months hearings on the proposed remedies of its antitrust case, pushing the proceeding to August at the earliest. The company also announced that one of its witnesses in the hearing might be its chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, left. The scheduling request was the latest in a series of motions and legal jockeying over the final phase of the case. C2.

Microsoft plans to acquire as much as 3 percent of the equity in Korea Telecom, a South Korean telephone company and Internet service provider. C3.

Stocks Increase on Positive News
An unanticipated rise in consumer sentiment and heartening forecasts by Nortel and Nike put investors in a buying mood. The Dow Jones industrial average finished 50.16 points higher, or 0.5 percent, at 10,035.34. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.96 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,144.89. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index added 27.29 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,945.83. C4.

A Fare to Remember From Delta
Delta Air Lines acknowledged that it had a problem with its Web site after a customer tried to buy a ticket online to Hamburg with a return three weeks later from Munich and was quoted a fare of $21,469,423.27. C14.

Tyson Cracks Down on Immigrants
They came by the thousands from Mexico and Central America in the mid-1990's to work at the Tyson Foods chicken plant in Shelbyville, Tenn., where they were all but guaranteed a job, often without legal working papers, current and former workers said. Tyson, now embroiled in the largest immigrant-smuggling case in American history, has been cracking down on illegal workers. A12.

Economy Contracts at 1.3% Pace
Gross domestic product shrank at a 1.3 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said in its final estimate, its weakest pace in more than a decade. Two other reports showed that consumer optimism rose to a four-month high this month, and that Americans have been spending at a pace that suggests they will help the economy rebound in the next three months. C4.

Honeywell Settles With Northrop
Honeywell International has agreed to pay $440 million to Northrop Grumman to settle antitrust and patent lawsuits filed more than a decade ago. C4.

AOL Discontinues Goodwill Games
AOL Time Warner discontinued the Goodwill Games, which were conceived by Ted Turner in the 1980's as an alternative to the boycott-plagued Olympics. In recent years, the games have lost millions of dollars as well as political relevancy after the fall of Communism. S5.

Ted Turner, the vice chairman of AOL Time Warner, signed a two-year contract. C14.

Japan and China End Trade Dispute
Japan and China settled an eight-month dispute that threatened to disrupt trade between them, an $85 billion relationship fraught with an unusual degree of political testiness. C3.
