HEADLINE: Median Income Drops Are Tied to Immigrants 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Median household income dropped between 1989 and 1998 in Queens, Brooklyn, Suffolk, Fairfield and many other counties across the nation that experienced a large influx of immigrants, according to new census data.
 The data indicate that even as the economy in the New York region and the nation rebounded after the recession of the early 90's, figures for median household income, adjusted for inflation, failed to climb in many counties because of the increase in low-income immigrant workers. 
 The new data show that in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx -- counties with a major increase of immigrants -- median income fell sharply. More surprising, though, was the marked income drop in some of the region's wealthiest suburbs, including Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties in New York and Fairfield County in Connecticut. 
"Immigrants are jumping immediately into these inner-ring suburbs, which is a change from the past 300 years, when the first generation lived in inner-city neighborhoods," said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a civic group that works to improve the economy of the New York region. "This new phenomenon is reducing household incomes in some of the well-to-do suburbs as immigrants move into Bridgeport, Stamford and Norwalk. It's consistent with the national phenomenon of the suburbanization of poverty."
The new data show that median income also fell in many counties in other states attractive to immigrants, including Los Angeles County and Miami-Dade County.
In Queens, according to the data, the median household income fell to $36,480 in 1998 from $44,938 in 1989, a drop of nearly 19 percent, while in Brooklyn it fell by 18 percent, to $27,556 from $33,762.
In Los Angeles County, where there has been a surge of immigrants from Mexico, median income fell in constant dollars to $37,655 in 1998 from $45,962, a decline of 18 percent, according to the census data.
Andrew A. Beveridge, a professor of sociology at Queens College, prepared the analysis that compared the Census Bureau's median income estimates for 1989 and 1998.
Many economists view the median as the best figure for assessing income trends since half the incomes are above it and half below. 
Several economists and sociologists, however, argued that the new census data exaggerated the income drop from 1989 to 1998. They said that although median household income might have fallen in many counties, it did not fall as much as the new data suggested. 
These economists questioned the new computer model developed by the Census Bureau, and they noted that there was a higher margin of error in analyzing small areas like counties. In addition, critics argued that the way inflation was adjusted might have exaggerated the drop in median income.
Stephen Kagann, chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki, said the estimated declines were not credible.
"They use an inappropriate starting point, 1989, which was a cyclical peak, thereby ignoring the deep recession that occurred afterwards," Mr. Kagann said. "And they use an inappropriate inflation adjustment that overestimates inflation and thereby underestimates the growth in income."
He said that if the analysis had taken 1993 as its starting point, when New York's economy was near the bottom, the study would have shown a 7.9 percent increase in median household income statewide.
Jared Bernstein, an economist with the liberal Economic Policy Institute, also said that the new census data painted too gloomy a picture. Pointing to another census study, from last March, he noted that median household income for New York State dropped by 7 percent from 1989 to 1998. He added that a 5 percent increase in income in the two boom years, 1999 and 2000, meant a decline of just 2 percent from 1989 to 2000.
Still, he saw economic problems in the state. "In New York, you've had an amplified version of the expanded income gap we've seen nationally," he said. "Folks in the high end -- in law, high tech, financial markets -- were in a good place to ride the boom. Meanwhile, the huge supply of low-wage workers who were serving these upper-end workers during the boom didn't do nearly as well."
Mr. Beveridge's analysis estimated that median income in Nassau County fell by 14 percent ($61,096 in 1998 from $71,202 in 1989), 16 percent in Suffolk ($54,008 from $64,580), 11 percent in Westchester ($56,865 from $63,629), 12 percent in Fairfield ($57,389 from 65,583), 12 percent in Hudson County ($35,743 from $40,641), 17 percent in Passaic County ($40,923 from $49,421) and by 10 percent in Essex County ($40,595 from $45,375).
While critics derided the numbers, Mr. Beveridge defended them, saying the arrival of immigrants in Bridgeport, Yonkers, Paterson, Hempstead and other communities could have caused a double-digit decrease in income.
In the preponderance of counties nationwide, median household income rose from 1989 to 1998. The counties with declines were often in metropolitan areas with the greatest surges in immigration, including New York, Miami, Los Angeles, San Diego and Washington.
Roger Waldinger, an immigration expert at the University of California at Los Angeles, said the decline in household income could have been fueled by factors having nothing to do with immigration, like the increase in one-member and single-parent households. 
Economists have pointed to other reasons for stagnant or declining incomes, including pressure from import competition, the declining power of labor unions, automation that pushes workers out of jobs and poor schools that churn out students who lack job skills.
Dr. Waldinger has conducted studies showing that in many communities, immigration affects income levels and the gap between rich and poor. He said income levels were dragged down by unemployment, not immigrants, who he said usually worked long hours. But many economists say limited skills and inadequate English relegated many immigrants to low-paying jobs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An influx of immigrants to neighborhoods like Flushing has helped to push median household income down in Queens, census data indicate. Brooklyn, Suffolk, Fairfield and many other counties have also seen a drop. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: As the Travel Rush Begins, Patience Is a Must-Have 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
On a stage, Mariachi Allende, a Mexican-style band in colorful charro outfits, set the crowd dancing and clapping with its rendition of "Feliz Navidad."
 The band was among a string of performers that included an Elvis impersonator and country-and-western bands. 
 Muganza Nyota was watching the show, in the international terminal at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport as it slipped into the busiest season of the year.
"This is the first time I've flown since before September," said Ms. Nyota, who was changing planes en route to Paris from Phoenix. "Seeing this band and hearing their music makes me much more confident and relaxed about it all." 
Mariachi performers and Elvis impersonators were among the novel reminders that the Christmas travel rush at airports, bus terminals and train stations around the country this year was different from the rush in years past.
Air traffic is expected to be down 15 percent to 20 percent compared with last year, partly because of fear after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and partly because of the weaker economy.
But the waits to check in at airports are significantly longer this year -- up to three hours in Los Angeles, for example -- because of tighter security. Travelers were warned, for example, not to carry wrapped gifts, because security officers might want to inspect them.
But air, road and rail traffic moved relatively smoothly, and when problems arose, people tried to make the best of them.
At the American Airlines terminal at La Guardia Airport in New York, some passengers had to wait four hours or longer to check in, causing scores to miss their flights. The airline said passengers not prepared for the heightened security caused the delays.
"It's terrible, because I've been standing on line for more than four hours, and I'm tired," said Wesley Jean-Louis, who was trying to rebook a flight to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after missing one because of the long wait. "I didn't expect it; I thought everything would go smoothly."
Nearby, Richmond Punch, 21, a student at the Juilliard School, tried to lighten the mood by playing the violin. That earned Mr. Punch some change and a cookie from a happy father for playing the theme song from the television show "Barney" for the man's son.
Concerns about delays prompted airport officials to make extra efforts to keep tempers from flaring. In Denver, for example, after drivers approaching the terminal endured random car searches, an airport employee dressed as Santa Claus handed out candy canes and maps of the airport.
But most passengers seemed to come armed with the best ammunition against the long waits, patience.
"This is the longest queue I've ever been in," said Rod Mabin, 31, who works for an advertising agency in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, as he looked at a line of at least 300 people at Los Angeles International Airport. But Mr. Mabin said he was very patient, adding, "Nothing bothers me anymore."
The concerns about safety and airport lines led many people to take to the highways, although traffic was expected to be slightly less than the record of last year because of the weaker economy. The plunge in gasoline prices has also encouraged some people to travel by car.
"A lot of people are saying, 'Let's just drive rather than take a plane,' " said Don Furlong, a division manager for AAA South, in Georgia. "I think the fear of flying is gone, but the fear of hassle at the airport is still causing trepidation."
Some bus companies said ticket sales for long trips were up this year, in part because of concern about the safety of air travel, but sales for short trips were down.
Kajal Jhaveri, a spokeswoman for Amtrak, said that the decline in the economy was hurting business over all but that premium train service and sleeper cars were selling out.
Even train passengers were encouraged to prepare for the worst at stations.
"Anecdotally, you can see the crowds, and we're advising travelers to purchase tickets in advance to avoid a last minute rush," Ms. Jhaveri said. "And we recommend that they get to the station an hour early."
Officials of Greyhound Lines said they had increased security at 33 major transfer points, checking bus passengers with metal-detector wands. All drivers have cellphones for use in emergencies, the officials said.
Myron Watkins, a district manager for Greyhound in Atlanta, said traffic was down before the holiday but was picking up. Mr. Watkins said he anticipated a brisk but smooth flow about equal to traffic last year.
The specter of Sept. 11 influenced the travel plans of some people who decided to stick with air travel.
David Vaillancourt, 23, who was on his way from Los Angeles to visit his family in Providence, R.I., said he would normally change planes in Boston, the airport used by some of the terrorists, but he was going through Pittsburgh this year.
"My parents thought it would be easier for me to fly in and out of Providence than Boston, what with all the security there," said Mr. Vaillancourt, an actor who has lived in Los Angeles for three years. "But it means I have a three-hour layover in Pittsburgh. It'll take me all day to get home -- so I brought a good book."

HEADLINE: The Economy May Be Facing More Hurdles 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
At first glance, the economy seems primed for a speedy revival from recession.
 Since the beginning of the year, the Federal Reserve has slashed short-term interest rates more aggressively than ever before. Oil prices have fallen to under $20 a barrel. The stock market has rebounded, companies have slimmed down their bulging warehouses and consumers can look forward to lower tax rates next year. 
 So it's clear sailing ahead, right? Not necessarily. As it turns out, some of these signs are not as favorable as they sound, and lurking behind them are financial imbalances that threaten to retard the recovery. 
Indeed, while many on Wall Street are counting on a solid rebound next year, Main Street is still looking for signs of improvement. Take Rodney McMullen, an executive vice president at Kroger, the nation's biggest grocer-retailer. He said purchases of discretionary items, like flowers and jewelry, had stopped sliding but showed no hint of a revival. Because those items are not necessities, their sales tend to be the most sensitive to buyers' finances.
Consumers, it appears, have not felt the full impact of all those supposedly positive factors.
For starters, the deterioration of the federal budget outlook may have neutralized much of the Fed's rate-cutting. "On net, those two wash out," said David Romer, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
The cushy surpluses once projected for the next few years have virtually disappeared, thanks to income-tax cuts, depressed tax revenues and billions in unexpected spending on disaster relief, domestic security and the war in Afghanistan. If the government issues more debt to pay for these things, businesses will have to offer higher interest rates to compete for investors' financing.
"Long-term rates have not fallen, even though short-term rates have come way down," Professor Romer said. In past recessions, the two have tracked more closely. This time long-term rates took a while to respond, then fell, but have since begun to climb again. Since the Fed began cutting rates in January, its key short-term rate has fallen from 6.5 percent to 1.75 percent. Meanwhile, 10-year bond yields, which closed at 5.08 percent yesterday, are little changed from January levels. Long-term interest rates generally have to fall to convince businesses to ramp up investments.
That is not to say that the Fed's actions had no effect. "Monetary policy is a powerful tool, and that's still true," Professor Romer said. "If we hadn't had the monetary policy, long-term rates might be a lot higher than they are."
Cheaper oil may also offer a disappointingly small jolt to the economy. "Certainly it's good news," said James Hamilton, an economist at the University of California in San Diego. But he warned that oil prices' capacity to spur growth had little to do with how much they had apparently stifled it in the past. "Oil prices have much more potential to disrupt the economy when they go bad," he said.
An even deeper problem for the economy, however, could arise as businesses and households come to grips with their balance sheets.
"Businesses are not wanting to take on some more debt even though the rates are lower, unless they're refinancing something they already have," said Patricia Marquez, a business banker at Wells Fargo in El Paso, Tex. 
Since April, for example, El Paso has been battling a cash shortage among new businesses with a federally supported program that injects low-interest seed money to back up commercial loans. Ms. Marquez said that without the program, several businesses would not have been able to get loans.
And the full force of a credit crunch may be about to hit small businesses in the next few months, said Cap Willey, who owns an accounting firm in Rhode Island and chairs the economic development committee of National Small Business United, a lobby with more than 65,000 members. Mr. Willey said banks were likely to clamp down on lending after receiving their borrowers' annual financial statements, which are typically due 90 or 120 days after the year ends. A sudden tightening would be a nasty surprise for those who expect the economy to recover in March or April.
The retrenchment comes less than a year after corporate borrowing reached its highest level in two decades. "After 1995, there was an expectation of ever-higher growth," said Bill Martin, an economist with UBS Warburg. When the rosy future turned bleaker late last year, and companies seemed likely to have trouble meeting earnings expectations, the rationale for easy credit disappeared.
But it will still take a while before the gap between corporate spending and cash flow narrows enough to lay the foundation for revival, said John Youngdahl, an economist with Goldman Sachs. He says the gap has already dropped to $170 billion from about $250 billion. "Progress has been made by the sharp cut in capital spending," Mr. Youngdahl said, "but we still think there's a way to go in 2002."
In previous recessions, Mr. Youngdahl said, the gap typically closed to a level that would be equivalent to roughly $100 billion today before the economy revived.
To lay the groundwork for sustainable economic growth, households may also have to move away from borrowing to rebuild their savings. Like companies, consumers added about $250 billion to their debts in the last year. The trend away from saving has been going strong since the last recession ended in 1991. Back then, the situation was reversed: private saving exceeded borrowing by about $360 billion.
Saving could already be on the rise. In El Paso, Ms. Marquez said business had dropped in local restaurants. "People are staying home, they're saving their money," she said.
The behavior of Americans who received tax rebates also hints at more saving. "The fact that such a low percentage of those rebates were spent in the short term was a collateral signal that the saving rate was going up," Mr. Youngdahl said.
At least initially, however, all that could be bad news for the recovery. Mr. McMullen of Kroger said he could not recall a recession when sales of durable goods -- cars, refrigerators and the like -- had not led the recovery. But Christopher D. Carroll, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, said the rise in saving virtually always went along with a fall in purchases of durables. "It seems very unlikely to me that we'll see a big surge in durable goods spending to help pull the economy out of recession robustly," he said.
Bill Dunkelberg, who conducts a monthly survey of small-business owners for the National Federation of Independent Business, which has about 600,000 members, was more hopeful. "To stop growth, you really need the consumer to give up the ship, and I don't see that happening," he said.
Hiding in the shadows of corporate balance sheets is another potential drag on the economy: the crippling of corporate pension funds by the stock market's fall.
"The last time we had such a major dip in the stock market was 1973 and 1974," said Ethan Kra, the chief retirement actuary at William M. Mercer. In the 1970's, Mr. Kra said, holding half a portfolio in stocks was considered aggressive. "Today there are pension funds that are 70, 80, 90 percent equities," he said.
The losses are severe. "We're talking tens and tens of billions in the economy," Mr. Kra said. "It's hitting companies of all sizes."
Disappointing returns spell danger for companies whose pension funds pay a fixed benefit to retirees. The companies will have to top off their pension funds using earnings.
Mr. Kra predicted that these unanticipated contributions would continue for years. That means the worst pension expenses might not surface until late in 2003.
Will these hindrances keep the economy from recovering on time? According to the National Bureau of Economic Research, the unofficial arbiter of the business cycle, an average recession lasts about 11 months. On that schedule, the recession could end sometime in February. Yet this has been no average recession.
Professor Romer pointed out that unlike most recent recessions, this one had not resulted from the Fed's efforts to head off inflation. "You would expect a different set of patterns in a recession that's got a different cause," he said.
"We know this is a very unusual recession," Mr. Martin agreed. Since forecasters did a poor job of predicting the recession's onset, he said, they should not necessarily be trusted to predict the timing or strength of a recovery.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN ARGENTINA: INTERNATIONAL FINANCE; 
ARGENTINA'S CHAOS RAISES NEW DOUBTS ON MONETARY FUND

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
The deadly riots in Argentina, the collapse of its government and another multibillion dollar bailout gone awry have raised fresh questions about the effectiveness of the International Monetary Fund and the financial policies of the United States, the fund's leading shareholder.
 Latin American and European government leaders today joined protesters in Buenos Aires, Wall Street traders and financial experts in putting at least part of the blame for Argentina's problems on the lending agency and the Clinton and Bush administrations. 
 Some say the monetary fund showed callousness by failing to give new aid to Argentina early this month, as the country's economic program, designed with I.M.F. approval, was forcing painful austerity measures on its citizens. Others say the fund made the opposite mistake, repeatedly offering loans to Argentina despite indications that the country's policies had become unworkable, delaying the day of reckoning. 
These criticisms, even if contradictory, increase pressure on the I.M.F. and the Bush administration to articulate a clear policy toward financial rescue efforts, which often come under fire even when they are judged successful.
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill came into office publicly denouncing multibillion dollar bailouts, saying that either they fail outright or they allow foreign governments to get away with bad policymaking and investors to get away with bad bets.
In practice, however, the Bush administration has yet to take a clear stance on such bailouts and has made international financial policy a low priority.
Peru's finance minister, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, complained today that the fund bungled its dealings with Argentina by adopting inconsistent policies that were at turns passive and inflexible. "The fund is partly to blame for this because the fund did not sound the alarm in time and then took a very hard line when things were incredibly difficult," he told Peruvian radio.
Hubert Vedrine, the French foreign minister, assailed the I.M.F. for abandoning a longtime client and imposing "demands that have been excessive or at the wrong time." The French, who like the United States are significant fund shareholders, have called on the lending agency to step up its involvement to help Argentina recover.
After some hand-wringing about jeopardizing the money of American "plumbers and carpenters," Mr. O'Neill supported a multibillion loan for Argentina in August. He has also backed two large rescue packages for Turkey, a strategic ally that has faced tough financial problems.
When Argentina's crisis worsened in recent weeks, Bush administration officials did not take a firm position, allowing the I.M.F. to make the call on withholding additional loans, people involved in the fund's deliberations said.
Even the harshest critics of the I.M.F. put most of the blame for Argentina's current plight on a succession of governments in Buenos Aires. But many say the monetary fund should have called government officials to account sooner.
Argentina adopted a strict fixed-currency regime and overhauled its banks in the early 1990's. It tamed inflation and became, for a spell, a glowing economic success story.
But subsequent governments allowed spending to grow out of control, building up a foreign debt that became impossible to maintain. Argentina also fell into a deep recession four years ago. The government beseeched the I.M.F. for help to stay solvent as it tried to work through its problems.
Backed by both the Clinton and Bush administrations, the I.M.F. twice came to the rescue, beginning late last year.
The idea was to help the country defend its fixed currency, which had become a political touchstone, while avoiding default on $132 billion in foreign debt, allowing it to continue good relations with foreign investors.
The terms of the aid program were wrenching. The government agreed to slash spending during a deep recession to increase the chances of making debt payments on schedule.
"If Argentina got its core economic policies right, it would have avoided this problem," said Charles Calomiris, a finance and economics professor at Columbia University who has been sounding the alarm about Argentina for months. "But the I.M.F. and both the Clinton and Bush administrations let them stay in denial. They all wanted the problem to fall on someone else's watch."
It is always a tough call to cut off aid, Mr. Calomiris said. But he argued that by delaying, the fund helped Argentina dig itself into a deeper hole.
"If you do not show leadership and make it happen early, then you face a catastrophe," he said.
Michael Mussa, the I.M.F.'s chief economist until last spring, said the fund was justified in providing aid to Argentina late last year.
But he said that he disagreed with the decision by the fund and the Bush administration to continue the aid program in August, when he said the situation in Argentina had likely deteriorated beyond repair.
"The fund made a mistake in not saying no in August," Mr. Mussa said. "The situation might have been more controllable then."
The difficulty, of course, is that such calls are much easier to make in hindsight. Mr. Mussa acknowledged that even when the political and economic situation in Argentina was more stable, a move to delay debt payments or devalue the currency ran the risk of rattling financial markets and even causing a financial implosion in the region.
In contrast, by watching Argentina wrestle with its finances over a period of months, financial markets anticipated the possibility of a default. The chances of contagion are now viewed as minimal.
Moreover, it is difficult to place blame for Argentina's economic program squarely on the fund when much of the policy was designed by Argentina itself, sometimes over the objections of the fund's economists.
At an August meeting at I.M.F. headquarters, fund officials told Domingo Cavallo, Argentina's economy minister, that the country would be better off delaying debt payments.
Argentina, however, was determined to pay its debts in full and keep its fixed currency in place, fulfilling what it viewed as a promise to its citizens and creditors who had been told for years that pesos were as good as dollars. It outlined strict fiscal policies that it claimed would allow it to meet its obligations.
But by December, as Mr. Cavallo resorted to freezing bank accounts and raiding pension funds to find enough hard currency to make debt payments, collapse looked imminent. The fund decided to suspend aid for a program that appeared to have little chance of success.
Though there were unique elements, Argentina's demise seems certain to add to the doubts about the wisdom of bailouts, doubts that have grown in recent years. Nearly every major financial rescue effort, including those in Mexico, Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea, Russia and Brazil, has come under intense scrutiny from the left and the right, albeit for widely varying reasons.
Fund officials say privately that they cannot avoid financial bailouts altogether. The lesson of Argentina, they say, is that they need to find a way to say no before the people they are supposed to be helping take to the streets.

HEADLINE: Tennessee Town Loses Allure for Immigrants 

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

DATELINE: SHELBYVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 21 

 BODY:
In the 1990's, they came here by the thousands from Mexico and Central America, making their way across the border and traveling by van to this rural town in horse country. 
 They found jobs easily at the Tyson Foods chicken-processing factory on the edge of town, often without working papers or, perhaps, using counterfeit Social Security cards, current and former workers say. 
 Shelbyville, 60 miles south of Nashville, became a magnet for Mexicans and Guatemalans who found shelter at the trailer parks that sprang up near the plant and in cottages and shanties not far from the town square. 
The immigrant community and the Mexican grocery stores and taco stands that have opened helped transform Shelbyville's identity. 
But now this town of 16,000 people is at the center of the largest immigrant-smuggling case that involves a major American company, government prosecutors said. 
An investigation that started four years ago here, when the Police Department heard about immigrant smuggling that prosecutors said involved a Mexican grocer and Tyson executives, has led to the indictment of Tyson and six managers.
The company and the executives are charged with arranging to transport illegal immigrants across the border and helping them obtain counterfeit work papers for jobs in Shelbyville and more than 12 other poultry plants in nine states. 
The company said the case involved a handful of employees who were acting against policy.
Since the investigation began, Tyson, the largest poultry and meat processor in the nation, has cracked down on illegal workers at its plant in Shelbyville, the largest factory in town, former and current workers said. 
With the national economy in a slump and the local economy reeling from layoffs at other companies in the region, many of the Mexicans and Guatemalans are leaving.
"There's no work here," said Rene Gaspar, 23, a Guatemalan who arrived six months ago with no working papers and no money and is sharing a heatless shanty with three other unemployed Guatemalans. "We were looking for work and looking for a life here. But what we are is poor and ashamed."
Among those who were dismissed from the factory that drew them in the first place, some have found seasonal work in the nearby tobacco fields. 
Others have taken the few jobs available at factories that are not too strict about working papers, and a few are working as grooms for the stables of walking horses for which the region is known.
For those who want to go back home, the Mexican grocery stores display signs that advertise van trips to the border. 
In 1990, according to Census figures, Shelbyville had 92 Hispanic residents. 
A decade later, in 2000, it had 2,343, although those figures are considered low because they are unlikely to reflect many of the illegal workers. 
For those who remember Shelbyville from long ago -- who might have seen Mexicans arriving in town as grooms for the annual Tennessee Walking Horse Celebration over the years but never expected a large enclave -- the influx has required an adjustment. 
"It is quite a different place," said the city manager, Ed Craig, who grew up here, left for 35 years and returned three years ago. 
The schools have enrolled thousands of Spanish-speaking children over the last few years, starting programs in English as a Second Language. A Hispanic church, Iglesia de Cristo, opened on Madison Street, a main road, a few years ago. Bank tellers are taking Spanish courses, and drugstores sell Glamour magazine in Spanish.
Last year, The Shelbyville Times-Gazette added two pages in Spanish, which are published on Fridays. The editor, Mark McGee, said some readers called to cancel their subscriptions in protest.
At the trailer park near the Tyson plant, which was crammed with factory workers until last year and now has several vacancies, residents said, there are still a few residents who work for Tyson. But those who do not have legal papers said they expected to have to leave at any time. 
None said they knew of Tyson's involvement in smuggling workers, and all the workers interviewed said they had made their way to Tennessee on their own. 
But they said that starting about a year ago their supervisors began selecting employees whom they knew were working illegally and firing them. 
"I don't know if I'll lose my job this week or next week," said a man who identified himself only as Alfonso, who traveled to Shelbyville in 1998 to work for Tyson after having paid a man $1,000 to help him across the Mexican border into Arizona. 
Alfonso, 35, who has no working papers, shares his trailer with Jesus Gonzalez, 19, who was discharged from Tyson last year because he was working there illegally. Mr. Gonzalez now works a few days here and there for a company that delivers the live chickens to the Tyson plant, he said.
Alfonso said he would probably leave if he were caught for working illegally at Tyson and, perhaps, go to South Carolina, where he heard that there was farm work.
"I don't think it will be long," he said. "And there are no more jobs here for me."

Latin American and European government leaders partly blamed the International Monetary Fund and the Clinton and Bush administrations for Argentina's problems: deadly riots, the collapse of its government and a multibillion-dollar bailout gone awry. A1

Senator Ramon Puerta was named acting president for two days; today, a governor, Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, is to be designated interim president, to serve until a successor can be elected in a national vote expected to be held on March 3. HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN ARGENTINA: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Argentina's New Chapter In an Epic of Frustration

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
Argentina has some of the world's richest agricultural and cattle lands and a good deal of oil, an educated and cultured population, and a mere 36 million people sprinkled over a land mass nearly the size of India. At the turn of the last century, its economy was comparable to that of the United States.
 So why is the country today in such a mess? And why has it met similar crises at so many points in its modern history? 
 Most of Argentina's presidents in the past seven decades have either resigned or have been overthrown in military coups. Their demises have often come in the midst of economic crises, and after the discontented filled Buenos Aires' broad, Parisian-style boulevards to battle the police. 
When President Fernando de la Rua resigned this week halfway through a four-year term, he followed a script written by a long string of failed predecessors, leaving a country lacking political consensus, a government on the brink of bankruptcy, an economy in a nosedive. 
Indeed, Mr. De la Rua seemed to be revisiting an article published in the British magazine The New Statesman in 1978 that commented: "The failure of Argentina as a nation is the biggest political mystery of this century." 
The unfulfilled promise of this New World country with European aspirations is rooted deep in its history of civil wars, military and guerrilla uprisings, and dishonest government. But there are many other reasons, too, why the present situation is so unsurprising and the future so uncertain. 
Forty percent of Argentines do not pay their taxes, penalizing those who do and leaving the government perpetually short of cash. The economy is led by a business class that has trouble competing in international markets and has traditionally shielded itself through tariffs and depended on handouts from the government. The political system is characterized by corrupt, machine-led parties whose loyalties shift carelessly among ideas and agendas. The electorate is fickle, and tends to look for quick fixes without sacrifice. 
The dominant political organization, the Justicialist Party, was set up by Gen. Juan Domingo Peron in the 1940's as a populist quasi-fascist party that took from the rich and gave to the poor and big unions. The party today has no guiding ideology and is deeply divided. 
Some members want to open the economy, and others would set up high tariff walls and reject the globalization that neighboring Chile has thrived on for much of the last decade. 
The demonstrations of the last few days had no leaders and few slogans beyond a desire to throw all politicians out of office. "They are pigs and prostitutes who have failed," chanted a crowd that gathered outside the presidential palace in the Plaza de Mayo on Thursday.
This sorry panorama has inspired a series of new best-selling books by Argentine writers who launch the most withering criticisms of their own country. 
"I don't remember a single moment in my life when you could say we were not in a crisis," wrote Mariano Grondona, a veteran journalist, in a new best seller. "Ever since the 1930 coup, when the state lost its legitimacy," he added, "the Argentine state has declined to the point of impotence." 
He had little better to say about business or labor. Mr. Grondona noted that Argentina's productivity is exactly the same today as it was in 1970, while the United States is 80 percent more productive than it was 31 years ago. Argentina exports only 8 percent of what it produces, he said, while neighboring Chile and Mexico export 30 percent.
"We don't have the quality of life that we want, nor the efficiency, nor the decency, nor the security that we require because we Argentines have failed," wrote Marcos Aguinis, a literary critic in a book published early this year. "Only if the society develops a decisive diagnosis can we come closer to selecting good leaders and create a climate of rationality, strength and hope."
But the diagnosis of the present -- the unsustainable debts, the hobbling economy, the unstable government -- can only begin with a look at the past. 
Argentina was a colonial backwater in the 16th through the 18th centuries, when all legal regional commerce with the Spanish motherland passed through distant Lima, Peru, the colonial capital for southern South America. That left Argentines far from the main trade routes, and Buenos Aires, the capital, got its start as a smuggler's port. 
Making get-rich-quick deals, evading taxes and paying off corrupt customs officials became standard operating procedure, and remain so.
Even today, few Argentine companies have gone public because executives are reluctant to open their books to regulators who might question their tax receipts.
The Buenos Aires stock exchange rarely does more than $15 million in stock trading volume a day, limiting foreign capital flow into local companies. This was true even in recent years, when the last government of President Carlos Saul Menem sold off much of the state to foreign, particularly Spanish, enterprises. 
Much of that money ended up in the pockets of government officials rather than going toward social services, as a series of recent corruption investigations have shown.
Paltry tax revenues have expanded government deficits and debts. So have free spending and an inefficient government that divides overlapping responsibilities between Buenos Aires and the 24 provinces.
The cumbersome division of powers is the product of a series of indecisive 19th civil wars, and it has contributed to the creation of more than $152 billion in central government and provincial debts. 
Mr. De la Rua's predecessor, Mr. Menem, said he would change all that. He privatized, deregulated and pegged the value of the peso to the dollar.
For a while the strategy worked spectacularly. Annual inflation dropped from the thousands of percent to nearly zero. Between 1991 and 1997, the gross domestic product grew by 52 percent, as $13 billion in foreign investment poured in.
But Mr. Menem and Mr. De la Rua after him used the currency peg as a crutch. With no inflation, there was no need to balance budgets to keep interest rates down, and government deficits skyrocketed. Meanwhile, as the dollar grew stronger, Argentine products became even more uncompetitive on world markets. 
Now unemployment has risen to one in five workers. The current recession is nearly four years old, and it is deepening. If the government defaults on its debts and devalues its currency, as most economists expect, things probably will only get worse and the national decay of the last seven decades will continue.

HEADLINE: After Twists Of a Novel, Congress Goes Home 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
Congress snarled its way out of town today, after a session as remarkable for its mood swings as the laws it passed but ending with dramatic inaction on the economy.
 Although the first midsession switch of control of the Senate in history slowed legislative action, the first session of the 107th Congress passed more legislation than first sessions usually do. That record was spurred by a rare month of bipartisanship after the Sept. 11 attacks. 
 But the mood evaporated, and now lawmakers look toward a second session dominated by tight spending decisions, as looming deficits replace the land of plenty they thought they had in 2001. Next year will also be colored by midterm Congressional elections, bound to be bitter since control of each house is shaky. 
But it is unlikely that things will change as often as they did in 2001. Ross Baker, a Congressional scholar at Rutgers University, said that observing Congress this year was like "watching a play in which they are constantly replacing the leads with understudies."
"You don't know if you're watching Shakespeare or Strindberg -- or sometimes the Marx Brothers," Mr. Baker said.
This session could be measured in four chapters. At the outset, Republicans basked in controlling the presidency and both houses of Congress for the first time since Dwight D. Eisenhower was president. 
Their major accomplishment was a $1.3 trillion tax cut, President Bush's first priority, which they passed in May, and they seemed poised to do much more, confident that budget surpluses could pay the bills. Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the majority whip, called on Republicans to push their own agenda, not compromise.
But time ran out suddenly. Republican control of a Senate divided 50-50 was tenuous, and in June Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont startled his colleagues by leaving the Republican Party to become an independent, caucusing with the Democrats and giving them control. 
From June to September Congress buzzed with talk of a Democratic agenda, and the Senate passed a strong patients' bill of rights. In the House a campaign finance measure banning the unrestricted donations known as soft money seemed close to final passage in July.
The terrorist attacks ended that chapter and dashed Democratic hopes, while opening a third phase, as the parties worked together to a degree unseen for decades. Congress passed a use-of-force resolution, an airline bailout, a vast increase in federal criminal powers against terrorism and money-laundering, and after weeks of squabbling, a bill enhancing airport security. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, called that period of cooperation "the pinnacle of our legislative achievement."
But for politicians used to condemning each other over basic economic differences, bipartisan cooperation proved an unnatural act, and it dissolved in October. The basic party differences overcame efforts to adopt an economic stimulus bill and a measure to protect insurance companies against potentially enormous bills for terrorist attacks.
Oct. 10 probably marks the end of the honeymoon. That was when Representative Bill Thomas of California, the combative chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, announced that he was abandoning bipartisan talks on a stimulus and would draft a Republican bill. 
In this last chapter, the only major measure salvaged was an overhaul of federal aid to education, which involved billions more for poor children and annual testing to see if the money was doing any good. 
The bill, Mr. Bush's other top priority, was nurtured yearlong with a degree of bipartisanship and compromise seen nowhere else but in the legislation that followed the terrorist attacks. The president made allies of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Representative George Miller of California, the leading Democrats on education. Hailing the cooperation that brought agreement as the bill was passed last week, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, chairman of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, said the process was "marked by the courage of legislators on both sides of the aisle to challenge conventional thinking and party orthodoxy for the sake of meaningful change."
Because of the coup that brought Mr. Jeffords into a Democratic majority, and even the 50-50 party split beforehand, the Senate attracted more attention than the House. 
But the reality was that the steadiness and effectiveness of House Republicans was even more notable. With a slim majority that meant six defections could bring defeat, House Republicans lost only one vote all year -- a July procedural vote on campaign finance that they were perfectly willing to lose since that meant the bill could be put off.
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, outgeneraled the Democrats at every battle and boasted that he never lost a vote that he tried to win. And while Democrats had no trouble breaking with President Bill Clinton in his first year, Republicans stuck with Mr. Bush in 2001. He lobbied effectively when asked but also had good will behind him.
Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, said in May, "It's very important to us to make him succeed."
When Congress returns next month, it will inevitably start a fifth chapter, conditioned less by the strength of the parties than by the weakness of the economy. Where last spring's budget resolution found lots of money for tax cuts, farm aid, education and even an expansion of federally aided health care, next year's will see a return to the deficit financing that posed hard choices for Congress in the 80's and 90's. 
Mr. Daschle said on Thursday, "All of the domestic priorities that we care a great deal about are usually the first to be put on the table when cuts need to be made."
On their way out of town, House Republicans joined in a chorus of complaint about Senate inaction, not just on the economic stimulus and insurance protection, but on President Bush's religion-based initiative, farm legislation and a ban on human cloning. While some of his colleagues personalized the issue by calling Mr. Daschle names, most commonly an obstructionist, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said on Thursday, "The biggest disappointment I have has been the lack of being able to see our bills taken up and passed by the Senate."
That is a two-party street, of course. It takes 60 votes, not 51, to get most bills passed in the Senate these days, and if Democrats stalled the cloning ban, Republicans blocked the farm bill. President Bush and his House backers contended this week that if only the Senate would vote, a stimulus bill they backed would get a majority. Perhaps, but the only stimulus bill the Senate voted on had 50 backers and 48 opponents, and that was not enough to get it through procedural thickets that would also have confronted the president's bill.
But second sessions are usually more productive. When elections loom, incumbents usually want to be able to say they have accomplished something. Big-money items like a prescription drug benefit for the elderly are unlikely, but the patients' bill of rights, which languished in a House-Senate conference this fall, could re-emerge if President Bush seeks action. An increase in the minimum wage could become a priority for Senate Democrats, and voting against it is hard in an election year. 
Still, as Senator Nickles noted, once-cooperative Senate committees like Finance and Agriculture are now passing major bills on party-line votes, which means they are instantly in trouble on the floor.

(Associated Press) Chart: "AGENDA -- To Bipartisanship And Back Again"A look at what the first session of the 107th Congress passed and what awaits further action. PASSEDTAX CUT: Lowers taxes by $1.3 trillion over the next decade by cutting tax rates, doubling the child credit, reducing the estate tax and providing relief to married couples. EDUCATION: Sharply increases federal aid to schools with large numbers of poor students and requires annual testing in reading and math. RELATED TO SEPT. 11 ATTACKSUSE OF FORCE: Authorizes President Bush to use "all necessary and appropriate force" against nations, organizations or individuals who were involved in acts of terrorism or harbored people who were involved. DOMESTIC DEFENSE: Provides $40 billion in emergency spending, earmarking $8.3 billion for domestic security and $8.2 billion to help recovery in New York. ANTITERROR BILL: Expands the government's surveillance and detention powers and its ability to penetrate money-laundering banks. AIRLINE BAILOUT: Provides $15 billion to compensate airlines for grounding of flights and drop in passengers after terrorist attacks and provides that victims may collect benefits from the federal government without going to court. AIRPORT SECURITY: Requires the government to hire about 30,000 airport screeners and to inspect all checked baggage. UNFINISHEDSTIMULUS: The two parties could not agree on a recession fighting package, with Republicans pushing tax cuts for businesses and middle- and upper-income people and Democrats insisting on extending unemployment insurance and providing health insurance for those laid off their jobs. INSURANCE: Legislation to provide billions in government loans to the insurance industry to cover potential losses from future terrorist attacks passed the House, but the Senate version did not come to the floor for a vote. ENERGY: The House approved a plan to encourage energy production that included allowing drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge; the Senate did not act on a bill. FARM: The House passed a $170 billion 10-year farm bill that added billions to current crop subsidies, but Republicans effectively killed the Democratic version of the bill in the Senate, which gave more money to conservation and environmental programs. PATIENTS' RIGHTS: The House and Senate both passed versions of a patients' bill of rights, guaranteeing certain medical services, but did not compromise on a final measure. CAMPAIGN FINANCE: The Senate approved a bill to overhaul the nation's campaign finance law, including a ban on the large unrestricted political contributions known as soft money, but the House did not act. RELIGIOUS CHARITIES: The House passed a bill that expanded federal social service funds to religious groups, but the Senate did not act.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: France: Economic Standstill Expected 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Economic growth in France is expected to slow nearly to a standstill as the new year begins, the government statistics institute said. 
In its latest economic report, the institute projected growth of 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 2001 followed by an identical rise in the first quarter of 2002. The institute said the slowdown was because of the global downturn, with recessions under way in the United States and Japan. But it forecast the French economy will grow 0.5 percent in the second quarter of 2002.

HEADLINE: Here's a Big Surprise for Boss Tweed, Wherever He May Be 

BYLINE:  By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
The newly renovated former New York County Courthouse -- generally referred to as the Tweed Courthouse -- opened its doors yesterday for a celebratory ceremony, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani welcomed the building's new tenant, the Museum of the City of New York. 
 The museum is not scheduled to move from its home at 1220 Fifth Avenue to the new space, on Chambers Street just north of City Hall, until the spring of 2004. By then another $40 million will probably be spent to adapt the building to its new purposes, above the estimated $85 million that the current renovation has already cost. 
 Robert R. Macdonald, the museum's director, said there was a possibility that beginning next April there would be a special temporary exhibition in the courthouse dealing with the attack on the World Trade Center. 
From the outside, with its broad granite steps and Corinthian columns, the palatial structure brightens Chambers Street. Inside there is a soaring skylighted rotunda looking down on broad open spaces. Mr. Macdonald said that when he first visited the site, "it was a rabbit warren of city offices." Now, it is a series of vast, high-ceilinged rooms, a basilica silently awaiting exhibitions.
The courthouse is a monumental structure built between 1862 and 1878 for more than $13 million paid by the city of New York. In a fraudulent scheme, a great deal of the money was rechanneled back to Boss Tweed, the notorious politician, and his friends in the Democratic machine at Tammany Hall. Among the many charges, $133,187 was paid to Tweed's plasterer for two days' work and $400,000 for safes.
Throughout its history, the site has been plagued by ghosts of its various incarnations. In the early 1800's it was the location of the city almshouse, converted in 1816 to the city's first cultural center. Through the latter half of the 19th century the land was occupied by the Tweed Courthouse. After 1916 the building housed government offices. In recent years it had fallen into disrepair and has been considered a white elephant adjacent to City Hall. Several speakers at the ceremony yesterday referred to the renovation as "an exorcism," finding a certain irony in the fact that such "a cursed building" would now be a museum honoring the city of New York.
Attending the breakfast ceremony were city officials, museum trustees and guests including the writers Louis Auchincloss and Frank McCourt.
After depicting the courthouse's history as an icon of Tammany Hall, Mayor Giuliani said that the renovation would "purify the building and remove the stench of Boss Tweed and corruption." He said "nobody hated Tammany Hall more than Fiorello LaGuardia," and added that he was sure LaGuardia thought about tearing down the courthouse. He indicated that it had been partly exorcised by the fact that Derek Jeter of the New York Yankees had visited it for meetings on four occasions in recent years.
The Mayor remembered walking through the structure in 1993, soon after his inauguration. "The building was in terrible, terrible shape," he said. "We met two rats, my first acquaintance with anyone from city government." 
Calling the Museum of the City of New York "a truly historic museum," he said that among other things, in its new location it would house tapes and interviews dealing with the attack on the twin towers. He said that the museum would now "take on dramatic and vital significance: it has become part of how we memorialize the World Trade Center." 
He added that on Sept. 11, before the attack occurred, he was headed toward the courthouse for a meeting about the renovation.
The renovation began in 1999. When it was announced last year that the museum was going to be the new occupant, there was some criticism that the shift would have a debilitating economic effect on East Harlem and other neighborhoods near the Fifth Avenue location. It is at the northern end of the city's Museum Mile, on the corner of East 103rd Street. In defense of the move, officials of the museum said the courthouse location was more accessible to mass transit and would double the exhibition space. Both buildings are owned by the city.
Mayor Giuliani and Mr. Macdonald both emphasized the fact that the move would now help to revitalize Lower Manhattan. Mr. Macdonald said that in City Hall Park the museum would continue to carry out its role as "a center of learning and a quality cultural attraction" and would now have a new role at the core of the city's civic center.
Renovations included repairing the columns and cornices, replacing the roof, replicating chandeliers and sconces and restoring courtrooms to their original shape.
Leading a tour of the building, Mr. Macdonald said that the ground floor would have a restaurant, a visitors' center, an auditorium for the museum's various literary and musical programs and a retail shop. Moving up the cast-iron staircase, he said that the second floor would have the main exhibition rooms, with a chronological historical portrait of the city from Dutch days to what he referred to as "the city of tomorrow." 
On the third floor will be the historical research library and special exhibitions, like the one currently at the Fifth Avenue location: "Al Hirschfeld's New York," a major show of the artist's drawings of the city and its cultural life. Next month, there will also be an exhibition on Manhattan skylines from the late 19th century through Sept. 11.
The Museum of the City of New York was founded in 1923 and was first situated in Gracie Mansion. In 1932 it moved to Fifth Avenue. There are 1.5 million items in its collection spanning 400 years of New York City history: theatrical memorabilia, documents, photographs, prints and drawings. These and other treasures will presumably be more easily available to the public when the institution moves downtown.

HEADLINE: Black Leaders Are Pleased To Be Courted By Bloomberg 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Assemblyman Carl E. Heastie, a Democrat from the Bronx, tells the story about having called Michael R. Bloomberg within a week of the election that made the billionaire businessman the successor to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Heastie said he had called only to leave a message with a secretary congratulating Mr. Bloomberg on his victory. 
 But, Mr. Heastie said, he was stunned when the mayor-elect, overhearing his secretary taking the message, picked up the phone himself and began chatting with the first-term assemblyman. 
 "We had a very nice, cordial conversation," Mr. Heastie said. "He told me that he would like to get together sometime and talk about the issues that are of the most importance to the people in my district."
He said he was flabbergasted by the mayor-elect's overture, especially in light of the fact, Mr. Heastie said, that he had not had a face-to-face meeting with Mr. Giuliani since being elected to the Assembly a year ago. "I was surprised and pleased. I never got the impression that Giuliani paid that much attention to my community."
It is a refrain spoken frequently these days by many black elected officials -- all of them Democrats -- who, like Mr. Heastie, are finding themselves consulted and courted by the Republican mayor-elect. While Mr. Giuliani was highly popular in some sectors of New York City, he has not had a particularly warm relationship with the city's black elected officials. 
And black elected officials say that Mr. Bloomberg's demeanor is a refreshing change of pace from their experiences with Mr. Giuliani, who, they contend, seldom if ever met with black elected officials.
"The mayor-elect and I have had a lengthy one-on-one meeting since the election," said Representative Gregory W. Meeks, a Democrat from Queens who is also the chairman of the Council of Black Elected Democrats in New York. "And we've had several conversations on the phone already."
Mr. Meeks said that he and Mr. Bloomberg have spoken at great length about the need for further economic development in Queens and problems in education in his Congressional district.
When asked how many times he had met with Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Meeks said, "Well let me think for a minute. Try zero." Then he added, "if you want to know how many I've talked to Giuliani on the phone, let's see. Try zero."
Conversations with several black elected officials reveal similar stories of how Mr. Bloomberg either called them or intercepted their calls to him. In each case, the mayor-elect has asked for meetings with the various officials. 
And many say it is an almost shocking contrast with the tenure of Mr. Giuliani, who made headlines two years ago by announcing that he would meet with the state's highest-ranking black elected official, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, after shunning the comptroller's requests for meetings for five years.
Several officials explain that Mr. Bloomberg is riding into office in the aftermath of a highly charged election in which many black and Latino elected officials felt alienated from the Democratic candidate, Mark Green, the public advocate. In that election, Mr. Bloomberg received about a quarter of the black vote, compared with the less than 10 percent of the black vote Mr. Giuliani received in 1993.
Moreover, Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, came to office after an election in 1993 that was very much divided along racial lines, in which he defeated the city's first black mayor, David N. Dinkins.
Furthermore, Mr. Bloomberg's aides contend that there is no down side to being more aggressive in meeting with black elected officials, pointing out that as a businessman without a great deal of political experience or baggage, Mr. Bloomberg has little to lose, and everything to gain, by reaching out more assertively than Mr. Giuliani. 
So far, it seems the strategy is yielding dividends. 
Mr. Meeks said that he and the Council of Black Elected Democrats are planning a reception within weeks of the inauguration at which Mr. Bloomberg would be the guest of honor. They hope to help him become better acquainted with various officials. 
That Mr. Bloomberg is already receiving high marks from black elected officials is clear not only from those with whom he has met in the last few weeks. He has also been praised for his selection of Dennis Walcott, longtime leader of the New York Urban League, who is widely described as being a respected figure among black New Yorkers.
Even the Rev. Al Sharpton, the one-time mayoral candidate and frequent Giuliani critic, said that he has been impressed with the mayor-elect's performance, a function in part of Mr. Bloomberg's having agreed to be photographed with Mr. Sharpton.
"The signal so far is that there is going to be access," Mr. Sharpton said. "Now, whether access leads to action remains to be seen."
"But clearly, in a transition period of one month, there has been more outreach to the black community than in eight years under Giuliani."

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 The Transfer of Power

A FRESH START -- Some 100 days after the terror attacks on America turned the world's attention to Afghanistan and launched a bombing campaign to topple the Taliban, Afghans prepared to install an interim government they hope will prove historic by ending 22 years of war. A1

STATUS QUO -- Despite the fall of the Taliban, no woman in the southern Afghan city of Karzis is likely to leave her house without a head-to-toe burka and no girl is likely to go to school. Representative of the deeply conservative Pashtun culture, the city is also home of the Karzai family and of Hamid Karzai, who becomes the leader of the interim government today. B1

The Hunt for Al Qaeda

THE MARINES -- The United States marines in Afghanistan have not directly engaged the enemy force on force. Instead, they have been used for quick, stealthy reconnaissance and raids. Now, at a time when nimbleness may count as much as firepower, the marines are being asked to prepare to root out the last pockets of Al Qaeda fighters, said to number between 300 and 1,000, in the ravines and caves outside of Tora Bora. B1

MORE TROOPS -- Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said he was ordering more American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora, and described the effort as critically important for capturing die-hard Al Qaeda members, seizing their weapons and uncovering intelligence on terror attacks now being planned. B2

IN MOGADISHU -- The Somali police arrested four Iraqi Kurds and one Palestinian for questioning over possible links to Al Qaeda or other extremist groups. The police said the men appeared to have entered Somalia without permission. B3

Threats, Home and Abroad

THE WALKER CASE -- President Bush directly linked John Walker, the American who was captured in Afghanistan, with Al Qaeda, as administration officials said Mr. Walker would probably face at least one charge that carries the death penalty. That would give the government more leverage to negotiate with Mr. Walker's lawyers. A1

A WARNING -- An instructor at a Minnesota flight school warned the F.B.I. in August of his suspicion that a student might be planning to use a commercial plane loaded with fuel as a weapon, a member of Congress and other officials said. The officials, who were briefed by the flight school, said the instructor had warned the F.B.I. in urgent tones about the threat posed by the student, Zacarias Moussaoui, a French citizen of Morrocan descent who was indicted last week on charges of conspiring in the terror attacks. B1

CONGRESS -- In the final hours before adjourning for the year, Congress took action on measures to combat bioterrorism, to protect the food supply and to increase security at seaports and nuclear power plants and along the nation's borders. B4

THE INTERVIEWS -- As the Justice Department's deadline for interviewing thousands of young foreign men about the terror attacks passed, officials said about half of the 5,146 visitors wanted for questioning had provided information, and that the controversial canvass had turned up at least two leads in the investigation. It appears that hundreds of the people on the list have not been found, in some cases because they have returned home. B4

BAIL DENIED -- A Pakistani man who prosecutors say may have links to the hijackers was denied bond pending his sentencing for voter fraud. A federal magistrate in Winston-Salem, N.C., ordered that the man, Imtiaz Ahmed Siddiqui, be held until his sentencing in March. B4

The Anthrax Investigation

WASHINGTON AND BAGHDAD -- Shortly after the first anthrax victim died in October, the Bush administration began an intense effort to link Iraq to the attacks and continued to do so even after scientists determined that the lethal germ was an American strain. But scientists and government officials said the largely secret work had found no evidence to back up the initial suspicions, which is one reason administration officials have said recently that the source of the anthrax was most likely domestic. A1

HOAXES AND THREATS -- A postal worker accused of scrawling a note about anthrax on a package as a joke was one of 58 people arrested nationwide and charged with anthrax hoaxes or threats since the anthrax scare began. B5

IMMUNIZATIONS -- Many postal workers at the New Jersey center where at least four anthrax-tainted letters were processed are not interested in being vaccinated, despite a suggestion from federal health officials that those at a high risk of exposure to the bacteria consider being immunized. B5

Relations in Asia

INDIA AND PAKISTAN -- India recalled its ambassador to Pakistan and ended bus and train service between the two nations to protest what it called Pakistan's failure to shut down two Pakistan-based groups that India has accused of carrying out a suicide attack on Parliament last week. Pakistan said it would not recall its ambassador to New Delhi and again denied any role in sponsoring terrorism against India. A1

THE KOREAS -- The South Korean government said it had canceled the alert placed on its troops at the outset of the war in Afghanistan, removing a prime obstacle to dialogue with North Korea. A5

ISLAMABAD ACTS -- Pakistan intends to follow Washington's lead and freeze the assets of two Islamic charities that were added to the United States' list of foreign terrorist organizations on Thursday. B3

Aftermath of the Attack

A GIFT -- Four firefighters and two police officers from New York City -- including one who lost his brother in the trade center attack -- delivered 90,000 pounds of food and blankets to an orphanage in Kabul. The expedition was intended to show Afghans the humane side of America, but also to raise the morale of United States soldiers there. B3

THE MEMORIAL -- A city still in shock has managed to create a quiet, dignified approach to what is now historic ground, as construction begins on the first of four public viewing platforms proposed for the perimeter of ground zero. B8

VICTIMS COMPENSATION -- Faced with widespread protests that he has been stingy, Kenneth R. Feinberg, who is in charge of the federal fund for victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, urged disappointed families to seek a hearing before the fund to argue for larger compensation awards. B8

HATE CRIMES -- Complaints to the New York Police Department of hate crimes against Arab-Americans and Muslims have dropped sharply since the trade center attack, falling to less than one incident a week in the last month compared with 39 in the week ending Sept. 22. B8

HOLIDAY TRAVEL -- Air traffic this Christmas season is expected to be down 15 percent to 20 percent from last year, partly because of safety concerns after the terror attacks, and partly because of the weak economy. But the check-in lines are significantly longer -- up to three hours in Los Angeles, for example -- because of new security regimens. A12

HEADLINE: APPEARANCES; 
Selling Indulgences

BYLINE:  By Mary Tannen 

 BODY:
Along with everyone else this fall, I was unable to shop. Seeing thousand-dollar hand-painted mink-trimmed jeans in a store window made me cross the street. Planning Christmas gifts, I couldn't get past sturdy sneakers with Velcro straps.
 Buyers were not buying; sellers were not selling. The press offices of the beauty industry, normally all bubble and hum, were silent, as if everyone had suddenly lost sight of the importance of styling mousse and lip gloss. 
 Into this vacuum slid a narrow volume bound in black watered silk embossed in gold letters: "Clive Christian, the World's Most Expensive Perfume." I stared at the marbled endpapers, the etchings of women in Grecian attire, the glossy close-up of a crystal bottle. Obviously this book had fallen through a space-time wormhole and was coming to me from a parallel universe. Or, if not another universe, just another country. There was a letter from a publicist in England: Clive Christian would be in New York for a few days; would I like to meet him?
The meeting, at Cipriani in the Sherry Netherland Hotel, was breakfast, at my request. The publicist back in London had been perfectly happy with the hour; Clive Christian, drinking black coffee in the dim reaches of the restaurant, was less so. He wasn't used to talking this early in the morning, let alone to the press. In fact, he wasn't convinced that he should be talking to the press at all. "This might be one of the very few times that I surface," he offered.
Athletic and slender, he was dressed in black and evenly tanned with a two-day beard, and he made me think more of a Riviera cat burglar than the name behind the World's Most Expensive Perfume. Allowing only that he was from a "design background," Christian said that his ambition was to make his name "a generic for fabulous British products." Like Hermes in France. His first product was ornate cabinetry, which he displays from a showroom on Madison Avenue, where model kitchens are so embellished with cornices and balustrades that you can hardly find the sink, but when you do, the drain is gold-plated. 
"Two or more years ago," Christian said, he bought two old English perfume houses that had been supplying "the royals for yonks." Although his bottles are topped with replicas of Queen Victoria's crown, the formulas are new -- the old scents were terrible," he said -- and contain only natural ingredients: "You don't get a great waft of chemical perfume." The fragrances are available in perfume only, no cologne -- the Rolls-Royce but not the town car."
It must be difficult, I said, to establish a luxury brand when even the giants are reporting sales dips. Christian waved away my concerns. "Recessions come and go, but if you're the best in your field, you walk past that. Our sales are remarkable."
Soon after, I had lunch at the Four Seasons Hotel with Lyn Leigh, a publicist for Creme de la Mer. She had sent me -- just to look at -- a 16.5-ounce jar of the cream, complete with a sterling-silver tray and spoon selling exclusively at Neiman Marcus, this Christmas, for $1,200. Creme de la Mer is a fluffy, white cream invented, literally, by a rocket scientist, Max Huber, who cooked it up out of seaweed to treat his own face, scarred by a chemical explosion. Estee Lauder bought the formula from his heirs in 1996 and put the cream into select distribution for what was a stunning price then: $150. (It is now $165 for a two-ounce jar.)
Leigh, who is English, has the preternaturally clear, unlined and deeply moisturized complexion that is the trademark of every Lauder employee. When I mentioned the $1,200 jar, she gave a delicate wince. It was in production last summer, and initially she didn't have the heart to promote it. The big jar sans tray is more widely available for $1,000 and does very well, she told me. "Women buy it for themselves."
Afterward, I stopped in at Bergdorf's cosmetics department. The place was jumping. At Creme de la Mer, sales were good; ditto at Cle de Peau Beaute, a luxury division of Shiseido. Its face cream, called La Creme, was selling briskly for $450 an ounce. There were no spritzers at Clive Christian's counter. A saleswoman came out with scent strips -- three for men, three for women -- that were indeed subtle, not like the heady, complex mixes I associate with fine perfume. 1872 and X are $595 for an ounce and a half; No. 1, with a real diamond set into the bottle's neck, is $1,820. There was no scent strip for the $12,000 special edition, which has even more diamonds. No matter. The perfumes had sold out.
Looking around at the scores of platinum credit cards flashing in the light, I concluded that Clive Christian's vision had extended further and deeper than mine. He had been able to see beyond the epiphenomenal shopper's malaise to the enduring human capacity for self-indulgence. I wonder if it's too late to place an order with Neiman Marcus. . . .
