HEADLINE: The Cult 

BYLINE:  By Jim Nelson; Jim Nelson is a writer and editor for GQ.

 BODY:
In Northern California this September, wine lovers and merchants were speaking secretively and longingly about a new wine -- said to be sublime but impossible to find in stores -- called Merus Cabernet Sauvignon. Some described Merus as "the next cult wine." Cult wines, I knew, were serious things, highly sought after beverages of unquestionable quality and rarity. So, hoping to see a state-of-the-art wine production facility, I drove out to Napa to find this Merus vineyards.
 Well, there were no vineyards. There were only the suburbs. The directions led not to Napa Valley but to the town of Napa. Instead of rolling hills and idyllic trellises, there were middle-class houses and fenced yards, Volvos and Nissans parked neatly out front. 
 Then I spotted it: in front of one perfectly ordinary house sat an unhitched trailer bed that had gone blotchy and purple with grape stains. I parked, got out and snooped around. In the backyard, where other families might put a small basketball hoop, sat an industrial grape-destemming machine, looking like some alien forklift. Behind it, the garage was taken over by a clutter of barrels and tubes, with jugs of wine on the shelves -- remnants, it seemed, of some illicit Prohibitionist activity. 
I went around and knocked on the front door, and a woman answered and said, yes, I had found my way. She opened her arms, motioned me into the living room and said, "Welcome to the winery."
Erika Gottl and Mark Herold are trying to make the next cult wine. They are assisted in this endeavor by their dog, Calypso, a wolf hybrid that paces the house as if she were quietly looking for the moon. Otherwise, they are on their own. Just the two of them, married to themselves and their grapes.
They do not own a vineyard. They do not have any ranch hands here in suburbia. But somehow they are managing -- brilliantly. In its very first vintage, Merus has become a hit. The 1998 cabernet sauvignon, released this year, won rave reviews from wine critics, especially the critic who matters most, Robert Parker Jr. Merus is already on the wine lists of exclusive restaurants like the French Laundry in Napa Valley and Charlie Trotter's in Chicago. Like every cult wine, it can't be found in your corner liquor store. Gottl and Herold sell most of their wine through a mailing list. And though Merus goes for $85 a bottle, there is no more of the '98 cabernet to speak of. 
"It's gone," Gottl says. "Sold out really quickly."
Gottl and Herold run a streamlined operation. He's more the grape man -- a trained oenologist who still consults at the venerable Joseph Phelps winery. She's more the business side. She licensed and bonded the house as a winery and ships the wine herself. She is superfriendly with her U.P.S. man. "This is mom and pop, O.K.?" she says, pointing to her husband and herself. "However, nobody really knows that, and we try and compete with the big boys."
Gottl and Herold made only 230 cases or so of the first vintage of Merus. They get their grapes from local vineyard owners, mostly retirees who have an acre or two of prime grape-growing land. They are fixated on quality, and their work ethic seems to know no limits or time constraints. Both often wake up at 5:30 in the morning just to go out in the backyard and "punch down," or stir up, a giant vat of fermenting grapes.
"Everything," Gottl says, "has to be perfect all the time."
Cult wines are a curious window on the wine world. They are both fetish objects and works of genuine hard-bitten labor. They are wonderful to drink and impossible to have. They are a measure of the giant leaps in quality that American winemaking has made in recent years and a gauge of how overblown the wine market has become.
Though they have inspired imitators in other countries, cult wines are uniquely American -- or, more precisely, Californian. The trend centers on an obsessive group of winemakers who produce picayune quantities of very high quality wine, usually cabernet sauvignon. The cult club is small: people in the wine business say, variously, that there are only 7 or 9 or 10 or 11 established cult producers. But all admit that they have an influence beyond their size -- thanks in large part to Parker, who has lavished them with high ratings. (The names of the major culties that get floated about usually include Harlan Estate, Screaming Eagle, Bryant Family, Grace Family, Colgin Cellars, Dalla Valle, Araujo Estate, Abreu and, to a lesser degree, Marcassin, Williams Selyem and Behrens & Hitchcock.)
All fetch what used to be considered outrageous prices. Most of the wines are sold, like Merus, only through mailing lists, and though high, the prices are actually in the neighborhood of the finest French Bordeaux, even a little less expensive. It's the secondary market where the prices really get out of hand. Until the economy started to soften, bottles of Harlan and Screaming Eagle were routinely selling for $1,000 to $1,500 at Internet auction sites. Now these wines can be had for a more "reasonable" $400 to $600.
What has survived from the boom times is an ever growing appreciation of wine. Americans are, more than ever, into wine -- into the swirl and smell of it, into wine bars and "29 wines by the glass." The numbers reflect the infatuation: sales of wine in the United States have increased steadily for the last decade, rising to $19 billion in 2000 from $10.9 billion in 1991. Interestingly, Americans aren't drinking more -- unit sales have remained relatively stable -- but they are spending more on wine. The only sector of the market that is tanking is the cheap stuff, all those jugs of Gallo that sit, unloved, in supermarket aisles. Meanwhile the high end is flourishing. 
California's emergence as a world-class wine producer has a lot to do with it. The state got its first real international recognition way back in 1976 when a bottle of Stag's Leap cabernet won a blind tasting at a wine competition in Paris. But it is only in the last decade that California producers fully shook off their inferiority complex and started to remake the business in their own way, investing in new technology and making ever more premium wines. Cult wines are the leading edge of this phenomenon.
The most striking aspect of the big cult wines is how similar they are. Nearly all are made in a very specific style. They're big, assertive, highly fruit-extracted, the very sort that American wine critics and enthusiasts have come to look for over the years. This is now known variously as the California style or, in a nod to the critic, the Parker style, and it has actually spread back to France. Small-scale vintners there known as garagistes (a reference to the dusty, romantic garages they presumably work out of) have begun to make big, assertive American-style wines -- and to earn high ratings from critics, particularly Parker. Some of the garagistes don't work out of garages at all but out of the west wings of chateaus. It hardly matters. Like the culties, they make highly extracted red wines in small batches, and like the culties, their wines can cost you $200 or more.
For both the garagistes and the cult winemakers, limited production is the vital factor: something they can brag about, but not a mere gesture. Limiting the yields of vineyards allows vintners to concentrate their fruit, which brings more flavor to the table -- that California style.
There is no better place to see this in action, indeed to see the full realization of an American cult wine, than where the original one was created, Harlan Estate, all 240 acres (36 of them cultivated) staring benevolently down at Napa Valley like Corcovado in Rio. Everything about the place suggests a Big Plan, a group of ideas set in motion years ago and only now being harvested.
Bill Harlan, 61-year-old dreamer who used to spend his money on racing cars and yachts, bought these hills with the fortune he made in land speculation in the 1970's and 80's. Back in the 80's, hilly property in California was not widely used for grape growing. But Harlan and his team studied the traits of the great wines of the world -- he is that type, the kind of guy who bungee-jumps but studies the rope first -- and found that slopes make the best wine. It's just harder to get to the grapes.
Harlan and his winemaker, Bob Levy, knew they needed to make a splash with their first vintage. So they held back the first three they produced; that is, they made wines every year from 1987 to 1989 but never released them. "They just weren't of the caliber that we felt we could come out with and make a statement," Levy says.
The statement they wanted to make, he says, involved putting out wines with intensity, with concentration, as well as a supple finish. The trick -- and it is a trick that winemakers have learned all over the globe in recent years, in part inspired by Parker's love of "fruit bombs" -- is to first limit the yield. This is counterintuitive, since the traditional goal of agriculture is to eke ever more out of the land. But the new thinking is that if you have four grape clusters feeding off the same cane, or shoot, of a vine, getting rid of two clusters will produce more flavor in the others. This is the brutal quandary of modern winemaking: deciding which grapes get to live and which get sacrificed to the greater good. When I walked through the fields that had yet to be picked at Harlan, I noticed that in some places Levy and his team left only one cluster where other winemakers would have allowed three or four.
The other trick is one that may seem obvious but hasn't been clear to winemakers until recently: picking the grapes when they are fully ripe. Harvest day is the most significant day of the year for a winemaker. After that, he's stuck with what he has -- whatever qualities and flavors the fruit evinces. In the early days of California winemaking up through the 1980's, grapes were picked automatically if they reached a certain sugar level -- gauged with an instrument called a refractometer -- but that didn't necessarily guarantee ripeness. It could result in underripe, unimpressive wines that couldn't stand up by themselves. Of course, most people didn't really notice. The wines seemed to fit the taste of the time. "In the 80's," Levy says, "a lot of the wines were made with the concept that Mondavi" -- the winemaker Robert Mondavi -- proposed as 'food wines,' which were really picked early, underripe, too low in maturity."
It has been only recently that winemakers, prodded by Parker, have realized that sugar levels don't tell the whole story. Even after reaching a certain sweetness, grapes need "hang time," their moment in the sun. Much of their flavor is sealed in the last waning days of summer sunlight. Winemakers have realized that to make bigger, more expressive wines, they need to let the grapes hang in the ripening sun longer (but not so long that they become overripe or, if the rains get to them, soggy and vegetal). California, where the growing season is long and the sun plentiful, is perfect for this. In France, by contrast, the wine-growing regions are situated at more northern latitudes than in California, and some vintages never attain full ripeness.
Levy expends a great deal of energy on the ripeness question, going out into the fields and tasting grapes by rows. Levy touches them, smells them, searches for signs of veraision (color change) and pops them into his mouth.
Harlan grapes, like the grapes at almost all wineries, are hand-sorted and go through a destemming machine on their way to the fermenting tanks. But Levy adds his own unique step. He sets up a conveyor belt between the two operations and instructs his fieldworkers to sift through the grapes one more time. The grapes get flung out onto the moving belt, allowing the workers to nab any stems the machine didn't catch. Does it make a difference? Who knows. Levy says that catching those few errant stems might remove a whiff of bitterness in the final product. "Anything we can do to make the wine a little bit better," he says, "I'm committed to doing." 
And what of the final wines? Parker gave both the 1994 and 1997 Harlan Estate a whopping 100 points, two of the dozen or so in his career that he has awarded a perfect score. Once a wine is anointed like that by Parker, collectors and wine lovers scramble to purchase whatever they can get their hands on. They seek out the gray market, driving up prices at auction. The wine sells out before it even hits the shelves. (Harlan Estate, like a classic first-growth Bordeaux, now sells its wine as "futures," meaning people on the mailing list buy it a year before it is even available.)
When I asked Harlan what would happen if Parker suddenly gave him a mediocre score, like, say, 87, he blanched -- what kind of madness was I speaking? -- then said, "Well, I wouldn't like it." Would he change the way Harlan Estate makes its wine? He and Levy would go back and taste the wines, try to figure out why they didn't please Parker. But, no, he said, he would go on making wines the way he feels is right.
The truth of the matter is that the cult wineries have Parker figured out. They are absolutely making better wines than they used to -- it isn't a mere paint-by-numbers game -- but they wouldn't be able to sell these wines with the same ease, or the same price tag, if Parker didn't like them. 
Parker admits that his ratings have tremendous influence on the game and professes to be unhappy about it. He laments the phenomenon of collectors "chasing the trophy wines," but he doesn't see a solution. "What do you do about it?" he says with a sigh. "I mean, I'm just not going to refrain my enthusiasm for a wine because I know the impact is going to be significant."
With all the clamor for these cult products, you have to wonder about the potential for abuse -- whether winemakers might be tempted, say, to hold back some of the precious supply for themselves, then sell it on the gray market and take the profit. So far, no one has been caught doing that. But the owner of one prominent, semicult winery says he suspects that some wannabe cult producers lie about how much they make. "A lot of people will tell you they make a tiny amount," the vintner says. "You'll read in the Wine Spectator, 'Only 500 cases made,' but then it's in grocery stores a year later. Sooner or later that's going to backfire."
Rather than play such games, most cult winemakers do things the old-fashioned way: they raise prices. This year, Jean Phillips, proprietor of Screaming Eagle, sent a letter to everyone on her mailing list bemoaning the fact that gray marketeers kept reaping fortunes from her wines. She promptly raised the price of a bottle from $150 to $250. I asked someone on her mailing list, a Sacramento doctor named David Schneider, if that made him rethink his annual purchase. Schneider said the price hike hurt, but he didn't want to lose his chance to buy the wines. "If I don't buy this year," he figured, "I'll probably be taken off the list, and it'll be impossible for me to get on again in the future."
This year, too, Harlan Estate made the jump from $150 to $200 a bottle -- and didn't suffer any attrition.
I had to taste such a thing, so I asked Bill Harlan to oblige me. Standing in his tasting room (it's more like a tasting suite, with a grand piano, a fireplace and a table for 16), I was nervous that I might knock something over: I had the figure $780 burned into my head -- the price for a bottle of Harlan I saw on a wine list at a restaurant in New York. Harlan poured the winery's two great vintages, the '94 and '97. The wines were bold and beautiful, more instantly accessible than a Bordeaux and yet more balanced than the "fruit bomb" I expected. I won't bother to say whether I detected "hints of chocolate" or "vanilla notes," as the argot has it, but I will say that the wines were delicious and that, despite my pleasure, I couldn't help wondering how much each sip cost. Was that a $20 sip? How much would a quaff run me?
These days things can happen fast in California. If a new winemaker sets his mind to it, if he is blessed of good resources, acts accordingly and wins high ratings, he can be an overnight sensation. The crucial step, says Michael Unger, a German importer of Harlan and Merus, is playing to Parker. "I name Parker as an instrument because if you know how to use it, then it works perfectly," he says. "Because if you're doing it right, you can be a superstar in five years."
Harlan Estate, after all, got a perfect score with its '94, its fifth released vintage. But Harlan says it isn't that simple. "We've been doing this for 20 years," he says, speaking of the decades of back work it took him, including acquiring the land for Harlan Estate.
And there is a lot of uncertainty looming ahead. At this point, it is not clear whether many cult wines will last long enough in the cellar to remain superstars. Since it is a new phenomenon, no one knows whether these wines will continue to improve for 15 or 20 years in the bottle, as most collectible Bordeaux will.
For now, most prudent wine producers are taking it one vintage at a time. Over at Merus, Gottl and Herold can use all the help they can get. To my taste, their wines are every bit as good as Harlan's -- similarly balanced, with a bit more spice. Parker gave their 1998 a score of 93 points, an incredible coup for a first vintage. The word arrived just in time. "It was great news," Gottl says, "just a tremendous relief.
"We're still running on a shoestring," she says, since they have to carry the costs of vintages that have yet to be released. "We still have to go beg at the bank. It's very hard, because we don't have deep pockets."
Here's a novel and just idea: perhaps they can take a loan out on a few more Parker points.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Occupancy and Rates Sag at New York Hotels

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
New York's hotel industry, along with the national economy, showed signs of weakness even before the terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. But those attacks plunged New York and large parts of the tristate area into an economic tailspin almost overnight and had a drastic impact on tourism. 
 A record 37.4 million people visited New York in 2000, but 5.4 million fewer will have visited the city by the end of this year, according to projections this month by NYC & Company, New York City's official tourism organization. As a result, New York hotel occupancy this year is expected to plummet to 72.5 percent from last year's record 84.6 percent, according to John Fox, the hotel industry analyst for PKF Consulting. And with at least five major hotels preparing to open next year -- adding a total of more than 2,000 rooms -- Mr. Fox projected that occupancy would fall to 68.5 percent next year. 
 To add to the industry's woes, next year's room rates -- which averaged $237 in 2000 and are expected to average $206 this year -- are forecast by Mr. Fox to tumble to $181 in 2002. If so, it would be the first time since 1997 that average rates were below $200. 
Whether so many out-of-towners are staying away because of the recession, because they fear flying, or because they are reluctant to visit the city that suffered the most from the terrorist attacks, the effect has been devastating not only to hotels but also to such other pillars of New York's tourism industry (projected at $14.9 billion this year) as restaurants, theaters, museums and scores of retail shops, big and small.
The latest statistics available for New York hotels are nothing to cheer about, but they are better than most travel industry officials were expecting just after Sept. 11. Still, while occupancy averaged 70.7 percent in October and is estimated to be about 73 percent for November, that is well below the 86.5 and 86 percent occupancy levels of those months last year. 
Most of the visitors now are Americans because as tourism statistics almost everywhere attest, vacationers on both sides of the Atlantic and Pacific are wary of flying and therefore are hewing closer to home than at any time in recent memory. That is why much of New York's recent tourism marketing has been directed at people within driving distance of the city, although with the added hope of enticing them to stay overnight. They are the focus of the Paint the Town Red, White and Blue campaign that began last month.
Priced from $157 to $324 a person, the packages, on sale through March, include a night at a Manhattan hotel, hotel tax, dinner, and a Broadway show. As of last Monday, 9,675 packages were sold. The tourist office is also offering to visitors and residents alike a brochure with discounts for hotels, museums, other attractions, shops and restaurants. (For more information, call 800-692-4843 or see www.nycvisit.com.)
One hotel without vacancies is the Sheraton Manhattan Hotel at Seventh Avenue at 51st Street. In an unusual twist, all 650 rooms have been sold out since soon after the terrorist attacks. They are not filled with tourists but with employees of Lehman Brothers, the investment banking company, which set up offices in the hotel after its offices in the World Financial Center were damaged in the attacks on the nearby World Trade Center.
Similarly, the Marriott Marquis hotel, on Broadway between 45th and 46th Streets in Times Square, set aside 250 of its 1,946 rooms for Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, which also had offices in the World Financial Center. It was not clear early last week how long Deloitte & Touche would occupy those rooms; Lehman Brothers said it would start moving workers out of the Sheraton in February. 
Tourism officials generally regard hotel performance as a reliable indicator of the health of the industry. Those figures not only track visitors' spending, as well as the taxes that their spending generates, but they also help tourism officials market a destination to out-of-towners. 
But not even the most reliable figures can prepare New York for the unexpected -- for example, the arrival in early October of about 1,000 residents of Oregon, who came to show solidarity with New Yorkers. They reserved 600 rooms at the Waldorf-Astoria (owned by Hilton) for $110 a night, instead of the pre-Sept. 11 rate of about $300. 
Then on Nov. 30, more than 3,500 Canadians arrived in New York by plane and bus for a three-day visit to shop, dine, attend Broadway shows and hold a solidarity rally at Roseland Ballroom. Their visit accounted for a total of 1,400 room nights (at $199 a night) for Starwood's Sheraton, Westin and W hotels in Manhattan.
Besides contributing to the hotels' bottom lines, the Canadians and Oregonians made another valuable contribution. The arrival of the Oregonians, said Pamela Graber, the executive director of the Waldorf Towers, also lifted the morale of Waldorf employees, who "until then had been rattling around in a hotel that had seemed almost empty."

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-23-01: ON LANGUAGE; 
Roll's Roles

BYLINE:  By William Safire 

 BODY:
Todd Beamer was a passenger on the doomed Flight 93, taken over on Sept. 11 by terrorists who intended to use the aircraft as a missile to destroy the White House or the Capitol. He had a telephone line open to an operator in Chicago, who reported hearing him recite the Lord's Prayer before leading a group of heroic passengers to rush the suicidal hijackers. Then Beamer said: "Are you guys ready? Let's roll."
 President Bush recalled that moment in the eloquent peroration of a speech in Atlanta last month. "We will always remember the words of that brave man expressing the spirit of a great country," he said. "We will no doubt face new challenges, but we have our marching orders. My fellow Americans, let's roll." 
 A song with that title was promptly distributed to radio disc jockeys. In a Philadelphia football stadium, a fan called "the sign man" unfurled a banner with the words "Let's roll . . . out" to tumultuous applause. "The words are everywhere," reported Britain's Guardian. "They have become America's favorite, bittersweet and articulate bumper sticker."
The phrase in its currently popular sense means "let's get going; let's move." The original sense of get rolling had to do with the wheels of conveyances, horseless and otherwise, and dates back to the 16th century. The crapshooter's roll 'em was introduced early in the 20th century, and the moviemakers' command to cameramen, "roll 'em," (answered in an old joke by "anytime you're ready, C.B.!") was first recorded in 1939. Five years later, in his novel "The Man With the Lumpy Nose," Lawrence Lariar wrote: " 'Do me a favor and go home and write it!' McEmons stood over the reporter menacingly. 'Get rolling!' " (I have an editor like that.) But the specific phrase let's roll in its current meaning was first cited in the 1952 novel "The Tightrope," by Stanley Jules Kauffman: " 'Let's roll, dreamer,' said Perry."
In 1950 and 1951, the blues artist Cecil Gant (aka Private Gant, the G.I. sing-sation) came out with two songs that brought roll onto the music scene. "We're Gonna Rock" was a remake of a lesser-known 1947 song by Wild Bill Moore, which repeated the words "We're gonna rock, we're gonna roll" for most of the song. The second was "Rock Little Baby" (the title bottoms on "rockabye your baby"), which included the line "Rock little daddy, send me with a rock and a roll." By June 1951, the disc jockey Alan Freed promoted the revolution in popular music that became known as rock 'n' roll. The phrase "Let's rock and roll" was an excited call to dance to that music. Later -- and this is the etymological conjecture of a confirmed fox-trotter -- with the rock clipped out, the phrase became a more general exhortation to nonmusical movement or action.
In a related development, as transition-hungry writers like to put it, a new sense of to roll up wheeled into the lexicon. It was expressed this month by ABC's Sam Donaldson: "It looks like the Taliban is being rolled up." The verb phrase roll up, which might have begun in the showroom of a carpet salesman, later became the action of arriving in a carriage or automobile, and now has the meaning of "to defeat" or "to conclude" (expressed by film directors in a noun form as "that's a wrap"), akin to the military meaning of "to mop up" (though no soldiers say "that's a mop"). 
Roll out, remembered not so fondly by former military recruits as the command to get out of bed, has also gained a new meaning as a noun: "a type of release in which a film gradually plays in an expanding number of theaters." This method of distribution differs from the usual nationwide release. Ira Konigsberg, author of the 1997 Complete Film Dictionary, informs me of the metaphoric origin: "The growing appearance of the film is much like the expansion of a carpet when it is rolled out. A synonym is platforming."
The old verb roll -- from the Latin rota, "wheel" -- like Ol' Man River, is unstoppable, creating new meanings as it goes, recently elevating itself by association with a historic moment. With the poet Byron, we can wish it ever more power: "Roll on, thou deep and dark blue Ocean -- Roll!"

PERILS OF PARLOUS
These are parlous times. Make that observation in a speech, and each member of your audience will frown and nod, joining in the general worriment. One or two misfits will be wondering, "Does the speaker mean parlous or perilous?"
In The International Herald Tribune, the historian Roger Buckley writes darkly about "the parlous prospects for the economy." Bloomberg News was told by a spokesman for Cathay Pacific Airways that the airline industry "is in a parlous state worldwide." The ABC anchor Peter Jennings was quoted by Mark Jurkowitz of The Boston Globe as saying, "We are in parlous economic times."
The word is not related to parley; it has nothing to do with the French parler, "to talk." Parlous has the same meaning as the word it sounds like: perilous. The Latin periculum, akin to peritus, "experiment," means "risk." But perilous is beyond "risky," scarier than the general "dangerous" or the unavoidable "hazardous"; it is "fraught" (meaning "full of, laden") "with peril."
If parlous means "perilous," who needs both? The two forms of the same word have been battling it out for seven centuries, and today we're going to declare a winner.
Parlous is a delicious example of linguistic syncopation. Every ragtime or jazz enthusiast knows that when you syncopate (from the Greek for "cut short"), you begin a note on a weak beat in the bar, sustaining it into the accented part, thereby shifting the accent. In grammar, you syncopate by snipping a word short or by skipping one or two syllables in the middle. Examples: fo'c'sle for forecastle, and Chumley for Cholmondelay. They don't order Worcestershire sauce in Wooster, Mass.
Usually the shorter and easier forms win, and extrality is likely to overtake extraterritoriality. However, parlous has an arch, archaic ring and carries a touch of the pompously bookish (like fraught), while perilous has a straightforward, sailor-take-warning feel. You won't be incorrect if you try to impress your friends with the syncopated form of perilous, but if you do, it's at your parl.

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
Buyers Beware of Pleather and 19-Cent Sweaters

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT

 BODY:
IF you haven't purchased all your holiday presents yet, too bad.
 There is nothing left. At least at Macy's, where I've taken up temporary residence since just before Thanksgiving. 
 It all started innocently enough when I dropped into my local Macy's at Essex Green to return a pair of pants I'd bought for my son. As it happened, the day I walked in was one of their legendary one-day sales. There were markdowns on markdowns. It was like an economics lesson in deflation. Sweaters that looked and felt like cashmere (but were made out of some petroleum derivative) were going for $10. I bought three. 
Employees were taking down signs that said 40 percent off and replacing them with signs that said 50 percent off. If you had a Macy's charge card, another discount. If you opened a Macy's charge account, another discount still.
Cash register magic: one sweater rung up at $4.50.
It was like finding an amazing fishing hole, or a tree that actually grew money. It didn't matter if I didn't really need all those new sweaters. Macy's was practically giving them away.
My mother-in-law, who hates shopping, got caught up in the same one-day-sale frenzy. Watching in disbelief as the prices dropped, she told the cashier wryly, "What, are you going to pay me to take this?"
Thus began a new tradition in the suburbs: trading Macy's stories. I was sure I had everyone beat with my $4.50 sweater, until I found out that a cousin of mine in Fairlawn had bought one for 19 cents.
I discovered that the world was divided into two kinds of people: those whose hearts race at the thought of a 19-cent sweater, and everybody else.
My friend Julia vowed she would never set foot in a department store from October through January because of the crowds. Others expressed pity.
"They're not making any money," Liza said sadly."
Barbara of the socialist bent asked, "Is all this stuff made by slaves?"
Then there were those who confessed that they preferred paying retail. Odd creatures.
"I grew up clipping coupons my whole life," said one, whose identity I will protect. "I'd rather pay full price."
At lunches and holiday parties, we analyzed the issue of the 19-cent sweater like Samuelson or Keynes. Still the coupons kept arriving with each day's mail.
But then one day, coupons and charge card ready, I found the fishing hole had dried up. The 50 percent off signs -- vanished. I paid $20 for a sweater. Ripoff.
Macy's was playing games with me, taking advantage of my greed and gullibility. "You sound like a gambler in Atlantic City," Liza said. "Your eyes are all shiny and you're talking about coupons."
She was right.
I talked to Elina Kazan, publicity director for Macy's East, who told me that New Jersey had more Macy's stores than any other state but California. She insisted that the markdowns weren't any steeper than usual -- though she had just bought a $435 leather jacket for $106. 
"I'm the consummate shopper," she said. "It has to do with timing, luck, your shopping skills. I know when to strike."
Strike?
The day after speaking to Ms. Kazan, I saw the TV commercial -- Macy's One-Day Sale. My instincts took over. Never mind that I'd already cleaned my closet out twice to make room for all my new sweaters. I hadn't even started on accessories. I had one hour. I wound up with two handbags, a hat, a scarf, another sweater, two watches, two pins and a bracelet: $140.
The next day I was out with friends, breathlessly recounting the sale. I got this, I said, holding up a brown Liz Claiborne handbag.
"Nice," my friends murmured. "Beautiful." 
"Is it leather?" one asked.
My shopping skills were on the line. "I think it's leather," I said.
The purse was passed around.
"It looks like leather," said one. The next nodded.
Then it got to Molly. She shook her head.
"Pleather," she announced.
Pleather? 
Later I looked at the label inside: 100 percent polyvinyl chloride.

LENGTH: 2619 words

HEADLINE: Leaping From One Void Into Others 

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
WE are looking for substance or, failing that, for traction against the natural desire to seize on the meaning of things too soon. New York is far from absorbing the piece of world history that crashed into it in September. But the pressures to make sense of Ground Zero are great. Some of the pressure arises from the desire to help survivors of the terrorist attacks deal with the burden of grief. Some of it also arises from the tendency of bureaucracies to take on momentum with a logic all their own. This pressure can easily result in the burial of meaning rather than the discovery of it.
 A bureaucracy is now in place for the rebuilding of New York's financial district. The Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Authority, as the organization is called, is a division of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency led by Charles A. Gargano, an appointee of Gov. George E. Pataki. With one exception, the authority's board of directors is a line-up of captains of industry, including top executives from financial services and communications companies and from public agencies for construction and economic development. Madelyn Wills, the authority's sole female director, represents Community Board 1, the local planning unit for lower Manhattan. 
 John C. Whitehead, a former Goldman, Sachs president who heads the new Redevelopment Authority, has said that the group's top priority is the design and construction of a memorial to the terrorists' victims. Ideas for this project have been taking shape since September. Pressure to proceed swiftly toward a design have been escalating, with the rationale that the design process is also a healing process. This thinking is sound.
There is a serious danger, however, that the scope of the design process will be too narrowly defined. The wounds in need of healing go deeper than Ground Zero and spread wider than the suffering of victims and survivors. The attack was an assault on a great city and its relationship to the rest of the world. It was an assault on history and on the American withdrawal from history in the post-cold war era. We should be skeptical of the desire for closure, one of our nation's pet chimeras, until we have faced its opposite: opening the civic imagination to the accelerating globalization of the urban realm. This opening, too, should be part of the design development.
The formation of the redevelopment authority signified the end of a process as well as the beginning of one. Actions taken and not taken between mid-September and late November are now part of the permanent record of 21st-century New York architecture. Historians will be analyzing them for decades. Meanwhile, this phase of recovery clarified some useful information for planners now working toward short-term and medium-range goals.
There are immediate needs to repair the transportation system into and out of Lower Manhattan. These should be linked to long-range planning for regional transportation. Such plans are contingent on the effectiveness of our Congressional delegation in securing federal support.
There are plans to construct public viewing platforms around the perimeter of the World Trade Center site. Two towers of high-beam light, depicted on the cover of The New York Times Magazine on Sept. 23, should be piercing the night sky by the end of the month. Many of us who live downtown never knew or admitted how attached we had become to the retail infrastructure, including stores like Century 21, Borders, Staples, Lenscrafters, Brooks Brothers and the Gap.
THERE is, however, no current need for office space, and hence no rationale for granting developers emergency concessions, like the suspension of zoning and environmental regulations. Questions that initially seemed pressing -- taller towers versus lower ones; modernist plazas versus Ye Olde Towne Squares -- are moot. Even if Larry Silverstein, the leaseholder on the twin towers, feels compelled to produce designs to satisfy his insurers, no one else need think about new buildings yet.
In general, however, this phase was notable for the lack of substantial ideas it produced. Efforts to rally the city's architects resulted in rounds of meetings, organizational strategies, motivational pep talks and general scurrying. Eventually, those efforts could be pivotal in reframing architectural discourse in this country around issues of cultural weight. If so, it will be because of the monumental vacuum that this hyperactivity exposed.
What we face now, in fact, are twin voids, one local, the other global. The first arises from the abdication of the public sector in the area of city planning. The second comes from New York's isolation from the rest of the urbanizing globe. Both stem from the collapse of historical perspective under the pressures of privatization.
The aggressive response of corporate architecture firms and their developer clients to the terrorist attacks was not New York architecture's finest hour. Nonetheless, much of this behavior can be diagnosed as a symptom of the privatization of city planning over the last two decades. Never has this surrender of civic responsibility been more starkly illustrated than in recent weeks.
"We should think like capitalists, not like Communists," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said in his budget address earlier this year. The implied equation of the commonweal with the Cominterm sums up a role reversal that began during the Koch administration and is now nearly complete. City officials scurry about like Mickey Mouse entrepreneurs, plotting their next career moves. Corporate architects, despite clear conflicts of interest, try to act like public servants, with evident sincerity in a few cases. Nobody, meanwhile, bothers to look to the City Planning Commission for leadership. That demoralized, dysfunctional agency represents the power void in which all were operating before the state's redevelopment agency was set up.
Will the public sector reclaim it? For an extended period or for emergency use only? These questions deserve protracted debate. There will be efforts to neutralize the discussion, however. Municipal politics and real estate development have become, in effect, two divisions of the same industry: the City Hall-Development Complex, we might call it.
Politicians depend on real estate developers to finance their campaigns. Developers need politicians to help keep things all in the family when private contracts are awarded or special permits are sought. Architects may or may not like this status quo, but few of them are suicidal enough or courageous enough to demand reform. Our mayor-elect, Michael R. Bloomberg, is less beholden to the Complex. He is better placed to encourage developers to aim higher. But he is also taking office at a time when budgets for public services must be drastically curtailed. Privatization is likely to accelerate.
If faith in the City Planning Commission can't be restored, why bother keeping this agency around? We already have the city's Economic Development Corporation to expedite private development. In my scheme of things, City Planning would be retained, but recast within a more cultural, less legalistic framework. The agency should operate as a cosmopolitan think tank. Its primary mission should be to coordinate local growth with broader developments in global urbanization. Mayor Bloomberg can run it from his private jet.
A planning agency for contemporary New York should be guided by an overarching set of ideas that looks beyond municipal boundaries: great cities always have more in common with one another than with the nations in which they are located. Technology has drawn into close proximity great cities from the past as well as today's urban centers. Urban policy is now inseparable from foreign policy, at least on the cultural plane. The city is global.
Such an agency could create something substantial out of Void 2. In the last 14 weeks, we have witnessed the shocking culmination of a crisis that has been building for more than a decade. The war on terrorism illuminates, among other things, the widening gap between our advanced technology and the world that technology has enabled us to dominate.
This "culture gap" began with the dismantling of the Berlin Wall in 1989. For 28 years, that structure symbolized the polarization of history into a global binary structure reinforced by nuclear arms. A new phase of world history began with the wall's collapse. The United States has yet to work itself free from the wreckage. It hasn't calculated the degree to which its place in the postwar era depends on historical awareness.
In October I was persuaded to cancel a trip to Syria. I had thought of the trip as an act of personal healing. My perspective on the contemporary city was shattered by the attack on the twin towers, and I didn't feel I could regain it without making a pilgrimage to the part of the world where cities were first imagined.
Aleppo, my destination, has been a cosmopolitan center for more than 4,000 years. Over the millennia, Aleppo has been destroyed and rebuilt often. They have a saying there: every civilized person has two homes, his own and Syria. New York could benefit now from the knowledge that civilization includes the destruction as well as the creation and re-creation of great things. Aleppo was in the news again recently. Mohamed Atta, the Egyptian who studied engineering and city planning and is believed to have led the Sept. 11 attack, wrote his thesis on the destruction of Aleppo's historic fabric by modern design.
On its Web site, the Aleppo hotel I was booked into appears to be a plain modern slab, floating in the usual modern void. It has a trio of penthouse restaurants, serving Chinese, Italian and American cuisine. There are good mountain views from the upper floors, along with the attraction of not being able to see the hotel when you are inside it. But Aleppo has survived Hittites, Mongols, Persians, Greeks, Romans, Crusaders, Venetians and Ottomans. It may even survive modern technology, and tourists like me.
But could our technology survive without Aleppo? Possibly not. Our machines are too dependent on the fragile network of relationships within the Near and Middle East that protects our access to oil. Those machines include the planes that enable us to fly around the world for peaceful or military purposes. They have been underused for peaceful purposes, if by that we mean not only activities undertaken without arms, but also actions that explicitly promote peace by enlarging our cultural awareness of the world that our machines control.
George Bush Sr. described the Persian Gulf War of 1991 as a defense of the American way of life. His son has defined the current conflict as a defense of civilization itself. We would like to think that those two objectives are compatible. But the increasing divergence between them has been the overarching story of the post-cold war period.
This gap has expanded even further since Sept. 11. Hot war is not the ideal way to build bridges. The appearance on best-seller lists of books on Islam is one sign that the gap may eventually be narrowed. It may take more than a generation before this cultural perspective penetrates foreign policy. But the work we do now at Ground Zero could help move the process forward.
Television. Skyscrapers. Jet planes. Mr. Atta took three examples of modern technology and combined them into a single weapon of mass destruction and terror. The result was a cultural statement as well as an act of murderous aggression. One can't unpack the meaning of Ground Zero without understanding its historical dimensions. We might start by recognizing that one third of the world's population embraces Islam. We could also recall the number of nations convinced of their destiny to lead.
Anyone can create his or her own authority for the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan. Mine includes two thinkers who have expanded my framework for historical awareness: the neuroscientist Gerald Edelman and the historian Fernand Braudel. Braudel, author of the recent posthumously published "Memory and the Mediterranean" (Knopf), used "la longue duree" to describe the framework I am looking for. The term is imperfectly translated as "the long perspective."
Perspective involves more than placing ourselves in illuminating relationships with historical artifacts. It also requires the process of illumination itself: perspectival adjustments in our interior landscapes, our private worlds of memories, learning and concepts. Mr. Edelman has described this process as "building a bridge toward consciousness."
The first task of my redevelopment authority would be to build a bridge toward a more complex consciousness of the urbanizing world. If you enjoy traveling -- around the globe and within the mind -- you have much to contribute to this work. You're carrying around a superior technology, a bunch of neurons in your head ideally suited to mapping modernity and your place within it.
My postponed Syrian trip was motivated by impulse. I wanted to touch some old stones, and memorize the experience in relationship to other stones I have stroked on the road. For example, I was looking forward to visiting one building, completed in 1325, that originally housed the Venetian Embassy. The word embassy is euphemistic: in those days the Near Eastern region lay within the Venetian maritime empire. I've spent many hours looking at contemporary art in the Arsenale, the shipyard from which the Venetian fleet set forth, and not enough time walking around the navy's far-flung destinations.
Stones are dots. Minds connect them. It is hard to understand Venice if you approach it from the West. But when you look back at Europe from the Asian side of the Bosporus, the pieces start falling into place. By pieces I mean stones: the actual materials from which Venice is made. In 1023 a law was passed compelling Venetian merchants to return from their Eastern voyages with treasures suitable for adorning the basilica of St. Mark. More than 500 of these precious objects, including marble columns from Syria, now decorate the church's facade.
VENETIANS saw themselves as "the third Rome," after Constantinople. That is one reason that Venetian Gothic, with its heavy reliance on perforated screens, resembles an Oriental style. For Ruskin, the Doge's Palace was "the central building of the world" because its design fused Romanesque, Byzantine and northern Gothic motifs. Through Ruskin and the 19th-century Venetian Gothic Revival, the stone trail leads to Great Britain and the United States. Its most recent incarnation is the Venetian Hotel in Las Vegas.
Touch enough stones, and you are on your way to developing your own longue duree. Think of it as a cultural radar system. Its antennas must be periodically readjusted, not only in response to current events, but also to receive memories of past adjustments. When the system is down, the causes and effects of events cannot be detected. Those linkages go the way of old radio waves, out into the ether.
The system is down. There is little coherent relationshjp between foreign policy and historical awareness. Our foreign policy is for machines. We have not found ways to integrate into policy the global civilization that technology is creating. This task should be performed by cities, starting with New York.
One feature great cities have in common is the capacity to recreate themselves after an assault. Under traumatic circumstances, New York has joined an ancient and illustrious roster. The dialogue about cities is synonymous with history. This discussion is now global. Young as we are, history is calling on New York to lead it.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA DELATINER

 BODY:
Best Bet
When he was 5 and a Cub Scout growing up in Sea Cliff, James Foote visited Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt's home in neighboring Oyster Bay. Impressed by what he saw, he became interested in the man and his times and started reading about both.
 But it was not until he entered the Navy in 1968, grew a mustache, put on weight and acquired eye glasses that the casual interest turned to something more. 
 "Guys started saying, 'Hey, you look like Teddy Roosevelt,' and I realized they were right and started to really read up on him," Mr. Foote recalled. 
By the time he left the Navy 20 years ago and returned to Long Island to work as a machinist, Mr. Foote, now 53 and still a resident of Sea Cliff, had his future mapped out. He decided to parlay his physical resemblance to and intellectual fascination with Roosevelt into a career.
Clad in appropriate attire, Mr. Foote has created a "living portrait" of the man, using quotes culled from Roosevelt's speeches and writings, facts found in biographies and histories of his era, and even a 1915 recording cylinder made during a Roosevelt speech at the Young Man's Progressive League to emulate his hero's voice better.
Starting small and part time with just a few appearances a year, eight years ago Mr. Foote left his full-time job to be Teddy Roosevelt whenever and wherever the 26th president was needed. Last year he logged more than 10,000 miles, bringing Teddy four or five times a month to classrooms, historic sites, fairs, conventions and conferences throughout the United States.
On Friday he will be at the Port Washington Library at 12:10 p.m. Information: (516) 883-4400.
On Jan. 4 at 9 p.m., he will appear in a PBS special, "America 360." Next fall he will lead his Rough Riders, a group of re-enactors, up San Juan Hill in a four-hour documentary for the History Channel to be filmed at the Muttontown Preserve.
"I'll never get the villa I wanted," Mr. Foote said, discussing the economics of being Theodore Roosevelt.
"But," and here Mr. Foote, as he frequently does in conversation, slipped into his Teddy mode, quoting him, voice and all, "life is a great adventure and I want to say to you, accept it in such a spirit."

Spiritual Carols
The Bethel A.M.E. Church Choir appears at 3 p.m. today at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages on Route 25A in Stony Brook. The ensemble, from the church in Setauket, one of the oldest African-American churches in continuous use on the Island, will add spirituals to the customary array of carols and holiday tunes. Information: (631) 751-0066.

For the Birds
With the weather so peculiar lately, birders are not sure of what they will find when they take to the Island's woods, beaches and meadows.
"Orioles and catbirds are still around when they shouldn't be," said Lucy Nash of Stony Brook of the Four Harbors Audubon Society. "Unless there's a northern push soon, who knows what we'll see on Thursday."
That is when Ms. Nash's group does the Smithtown Christmas Bird Count, going from Sunken Meadow State Park to Mount Sinai Harbor. Information: (631) 751-7333.
Two other local birding counts will take place this year. One is on Saturday in Orient Point, which covers the North Fork. Information: (631) 722-5542. The other is next Sunday in South Nassau. Information: (631) 666-7624.

Still Funny
The Cinema Arts Center in Huntington will be showing "Funny Girl," the 1968 musical about the legendary singer-comedian Fanny Brice that won Barbra Streisand an Oscar in her first movie role. Directed by William Wyler with music by Jule Styne, the film will be shown in a new 35mm print on Wednesday and Thursday at the center on Park Avenue. Information: (631) 423-7610.

Free Choices
TODAY -- The Long Island Greenbelt Trail Conference is holding a hike, "Cookies and Carols," at 2:30 p.m., going from the Great River Long Island Rail Road station to Connetquot River State Park in Oakdale and back. Participants are asked to bring flashlights, a warm drink and baked goods to share. Information: (631) 567-9484. BARBARA DELATINER

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
New Year's Resolutions For Financial Health

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino 

 BODY:
For many Americans, 2001 has been a difficult year financially, with continued stock market volatility, rising unemployment and recession.
 No one knows what the new year will bring, but experts recommend a few moves -- call them financial resolutions -- that may improve the outlook. Though most are basic, they seem more important than ever these days. 
 * Organize financial records. This provides a snapshot of your financial health and net worth -- and a framework for future investing and budgeting decisions. Review and file loan, investment, bank and tax statements. Permanent records, like birth certificates, property deeds and insurance policies, should also be stored in a safe place.
* Build an emergency fund. A cash cushion can get you through a layoff or other financial emergencies; it will also help you avoid selling stocks in a down market. Experts recommend having enough to cover living expenses for three to six months. Consider using any extra income, like a year-end bonus, to get a jump-start.
* Minimize debt. That means paying off or refinancing high-interest debt. If you have money sitting in a bank or money market account earning only 2 percent interest, you can improve your overall return by using some of that money to pay off a credit card balance.
* Keep investing. Stock market declines are not a reason to stop investing, especially for long-term goals like retirement -- historically, markets eventually rebound. But stick with companies that are fundamentally sound and keep your portfolio diversified. Now may be a good time to rebalance your portfolio, by reallocating your mix of stocks, bonds and cash. Experts recommend avoiding risky investments if your financial goals are short term.
* Review your insurance. That includes life insurance, disability and long-term care policies, as well as your homeowner's and business coverage. To ensure proper coverage, assess your risk exposure and personal circumstances. At certain times in your life, you may require more or less insurance -- for example, once your home mortgage is paid and your children are on their own, you may need less.
* Update your estate planning. If you don't have a will, draw one up; if you do, update it to reflect any changes in your personal or financial situation. To limit their tax liabilities, people with substantial assets should seek the help of a professional estate planner. Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: The View From/Storrs; 
Finally, Rooms in the Inn, And They're on Campus

BYLINE:  By HARLAN J. LEVY 

 BODY:
TWO months after opening with great fanfare as the only on-campus hotel in the state, the University of Connecticut's new 100-room Nathan Hale Inn and Conference Center, has logged 2,000 occupancies, been host to about 30 conferences and brought in $135,000 in revenue.
 Not only has the plum-and-sand-colored, five-story hotel filled up rapidly since its Oct. 15 debut, it has also finally begun to satisfy an aching, longstanding demand at UConn, which has a four percent ownership stake. 
 Other than the few rooms available at the Best Western in Mansfield Center, the old-fashioned Tolland Inn on the Tolland Green, and various bed-and-breakfasts, all miles away and scattered throughout the rural hills, UConn has never before had a suitable facility up close to house parents, alumni, and conference guests. And that has hurt. 
"The need was dire," said Philip E. Austin, president of UConn. "There was no immediately accessible hotel that had food and beverage service and that was an upscale facility."
All that has changed.
David Kornfeld, manager of the new hotel, has already booked 100 conferences for next year averaging two to three days each. The conferences to date have included three weeklong events.
"We are on pace to do our plan, which is a 63 percent occupancy for the first year," Mr. Kornfeld said. "Annually we expect to do $3.5 million in revenue. The profit should be 30 percent, and that's good for a full-service hotel, especially after the first year of operation."
Meanwhile, parents and alumni have flocked to the $10 million inn.
"On campus there's great excitement that at long last here's a place where prospective students and their families and families of current students can have high-quality, geographically contiguous accommodations," Mr. Austin said, "not to mention the advantages for our faculty, now we're able to host regional academic conferences and professional meetings."
For homecoming weekend at the end of October, the hotel was totally booked and will be again at commencement in mid-May, Mr. Kornfeld said.
The hotel rooms have high-speed Internet access, with king- or queen-size beds in 82 single rooms, 17 mini-suites, and a presidential suite. The rates range from $89 to $149 a night. 
There is also a complete business center, laundry, and University shuttle bus service.
For conferences, the Nathan Hale can accommodate up to 750 people, with an executive board room, four meeting rooms, and a ballroom to complement the large conference space in the adjacent South Campus residence complex. 
Abigail's, a lounge and bar, abuts the 20-table Blue Oak Cafe. Room service and catering are also available. A small fitness center, a hot tub and a 40-foot-long indoor swimming pool seem to be popular, especially the pool.
"Anybody who has kids, that s what they ask for," said Elaine Olsen, the front-desk clerk.
But parents and alumni represent only a small portion of the business the hotel expects to bring in, Mr. Kornfeld said.
"We re hoping for about 10 percent of the business to come from alumni," Mr. Kornfeld said. "About 70 percent is going to come from the university from various conferences, guest speakers and other functions, anything from a holiday party to a staff meeting, and 20 percent is where we want our corporate and social business."
The hotel makes a "huge difference," said Karen Grava, a UConn spokeswoman. "In the past we did not have a suitable place for guests, and many times we ended up putting people up in Hartford, which was not convenient."
An example was the visit by the president of Senegal. "When the president of a nation travels," Ms. Grava said, "he has a huge entourage. It required many hotel rooms in Hartford and trying to get the people back and forth was very difficult."
The hotel finally puts UConn on an equal footing with other schools, said Dawn Bradway, a graduate school psychology student from Batavia, N.Y., who was having lunch with her adviser at the Blue Oak Cafe on a recent Saturday, on their first visits to the hotel.
"All the other major universities have had hotels and banquet facilities on site for years and we haven't," Ms. Bradway said, "so I'm finally glad to see we've got something on site."
The hotel has solved a longtime problem for Ms. Bradway, who has been at UConn since 1994 and who has had to house her visiting parents at distant hotels once or twice a year over the past couple of years.
"They've wanted to visit and stay," Ms. Bradway said, "and a really nice hotel is a good 30- or 40-minute drive, and if you're out at a late dinner and you wrap things up, to go that far for a night's stay is pretty inconvenient."
Benson Ginsburg, a biobehavioral sciences professor and Ms. Bradway's graduate school adviser, said the hotel is long overdue. "Having witnessed the need over the years," he said, "I'm very happy to see it." Mr. Ginsburg said a major international conference in his field is schedule at the hotel in July.
The hotel was a timely convenience for Susan Entwistle, her husband Gary, a Canadian accounting professor on sabbatical at UConn, and their two children Joel, 11, and Megan, 9, who had to find a place to stay when their four-month lease on a home ran out Dec. 15.
"We just came from Disney World," Ms. Entwistle said, "and this is a nicer hotel than where we were staying."
MeriStar Hotels and Resorts, a Washington, D.C.-based firm, manages the facility. Students make up more than half the hotel's 70 employees. The developer was Campus Associates, owned by Robert B. Friedman, also owner of the Norwich Navigators minor league baseball team.
Mr. Friedman paid $10.1 million to build and furnish the hotel. He signed a 50-year lease with the university and will pay it $5,000 a year for the first five years and $25,000 in the sixth year. After that, the rent will increase by the same amount as the rise in the previous year's Consumer Price Index, the federal inflation measure.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Putting His Nightclub Experience to Good Use

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
NED DOUGHERTY'S account of his fast-track life as a Hamptons nightclub owner, punctuated by his near-death experiences and subsequent apocalyptic visions, was published in March, initially to limited interest. "Fast Lane to Heaven: Celestial Encounters That Changed My Life" (Hampton Roads Publishing Company, $21.95) was merely another title in a crowded category of books about faith and spirituality.
 Sept. 11 changed all that. Mr. Dougherty, who was an owner of Club Marakesh in Westhampton Beach from 1976 to 1996, has recently lectured at Harvard University and the Baylor College of Medicine, as well as at bookstores, cafes and religious retreats across the country. This weekend he was booked twice on the East End, at a Hampton Bays church and at a community center in Bridgehampton. 
 The reason behind the sudden interest in Mr. Dougherty appears on page 252 of his book: "A major terrorist attack may befall New York City or Washington, D.C., severely impacting the way we live in the United States." 
That prediction has audiences interested in hearing what else he foresees. In his chapter called "The Future," Mr. Dougherty recounts 11 other visions foretelling war and natural disasters. There are warnings about the Middle East and China, predictions of economic collapse in the United States, tidal flooding and a terrorist attack in Rome. 
But the book is less about prophecies than about his spiritual odyssey. Having created Long Island's answer to Studio 54, Mr. Dougherty became the king of Long Island night life in the 1970's and remained so for an astonishing 20 years. He also built a real estate business, which he ran from an office next to the club. 
"When I came to the Hamptons, my motto was, 'He who dies with the most toys wins,' " Mr. Dougherty, now 55, said in an interview. "I certainly had my share of toys. Now I have a different motto: 'He who dies with the most toys is in for a terrible surprise.' "
In the process of amassing those toys, Mr. Dougherty made his share of enemies. The mayor of Westhampton Beach used to call Club Marakesh a jungle. "It was a jungle to some people," Mr. Dougherty said, "but to others, it was a paradise."
Lon Sabella, an owner of Lon Sabella et Daniel, a clothing and jewelry shop in Westhampton Beach, butted heads with Mr. Dougherty in the past. "He lured the wrong people to Main Street, from Brooklyn and Queens," Mr. Sabella said. "His club became passe, and he had to reach further to keep it filled. There were so many fights we had to put on extra police."
Mr. Dougherty said he paid little attention to how others felt during those years. Things began to change for him on the night of July 2, 1984, when he and a business partner he had been feuding with got into a fight in the upstairs V.I.P. lounge at the club.
Afterward, Mr. Dougherty stumbled down the stairs and out the door, collapsing on the sidewalk. Such was the reputation of Club Marakesh that the medics who came to his rescue presumed he was using drugs, he says in his book, and so did the emergency-room doctors who wanted to pump his stomach a few moments later. Mr. Dougherty said that he sometimes used cocaine but that he had not that night nor in the previous months.
During the ambulance ride, the medics reported that his heart stopped for about eight minutes. Mr. Dougherty writes that at that point, he experienced many of the sensations, sights and sounds he has since learned characterize a near-death experience. 
In his account, Mr. Dougherty describes looking down at his own form lying in the ambulance. He writes of a tunnel and of feeling a warm light, of hearing melodious chiming. He describes a parade of memories as he encountered friends and relatives long dead. A celestial motivational seminar is held in an ethereal stadium; the spirits all cheer. He encounters the Archangel Michael and a figure much like the Virgin Mary. Both communicate what Mr. Dougherty calls End Time visions to him, which he recounts in his book's last chapter, about the future.
When he got out of the hospital after a few days, Mr. Dougherty started delving into parapsychology, reading the work of Elisabeth Kubler-Ross and others on death and dying. He began to rediscover the Roman Catholic faith of his childhood, and he became a spokesman for the International Association for Near-Death Studies in East Windsor Hill, Conn. After 20 years of drinking -- several bottles of Dom Perignon a night were the norm, he said -- he lost his taste for alcohol.
"I realized I had a new agenda to follow," Mr. Dougherty said, but his transformation took years. He wanted to get out of the nightclub business, he said, but remained involved because a former girlfriend had bought a share of the business and asked him to stay.
Then, on May 26, 1996, a young patron named Shane Daniels was badly beaten as he left Club Marakesh. Mr. Daniels is black, his assailants white, and the police described the attack as racially motivated. Television cameras, newspaper photographers and national publicity, all of it bad, followed; the Rev. Al Sharpton held a march through Westhampton Beach to protest the way the case was being handled.
"I had already found a buyer for the club," Mr. Dougherty said. "I was going to sell it. When Shane Daniels was attacked in the municipal parking lot, I was less than 24 hours away from signing over the club."
He added quietly, "When you're trying to sell your business, you don't want Al Sharpton protesting in front of it."
The deal to sell the club fell through when the State Liquor Authority blocked the transfer of the liquor license to the prospective buyers, and the club closed. Mr. Dougherty said he lost a couple of million dollars. He subsequently sold his real estate business to a local competitor and devoted himself full time to writing and building a nonprofit foundation called the Mission of Angels (www.missionofangels.org), which is currently raising money to provide vacations for children who lost a parent on Sept. 11. The group does not yet have a board of directors, but Mr. Dougherty said he was recruiting members and hoped to build a headquarters in Hazleton, Pa., where he was born.
"In building the Mission of Angels, I find myself relying on some of my earlier business skills," he said, "but I also realize I am relying more on other people than I did before. I am much more aware of the need for teamwork today."
In June 1998, Mr. Dougherty filed for personal bankruptcy. He currently earns a subsistence living, he said, selling copies of his book. He does not charge for his personal appearances, he said, but he sells the book at them.
Even with his personal financial problems, Mr. Dougherty said he had no regrets: "I believe we are primarily spiritual beings. I believe we are here to learn and grow, and I believe we all have a mission in life. The message, to put it simply, is that everyone's mission is to be of service to mankind and to love one's neighbor."
On Main Street, the local pharmacist who bought the Club Marakesh building is trying open a health club there. The space is still strewn with chairs, sectional furniture and old bar fixtures from the club's last days and nights.
Mr. Dougherty said he took one souvenir when he left, the velvet rope he used every weekend, and donated it to the Shrine of Our Lady of the Island in Eastport. There, it's used to preserve orderly lines among the hundreds of people waiting for a healing touch during a prayer service.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT; 
Top-Flight Preparations in Historic Spot

BYLINE:  By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
SOUTHERN Suffolk's newest culinary star is also one of its oldest. The Bayport House, then called the Fiat Inn Hotel, opened in 1869. During its 132-year history, the landmark building has been a stagecoach stop, waiting room for the train, speakeasy and restaurant. The food has roamed from American to German to Italian. Today, everything is new at this historic spot: owners, chef, staff, food and ambience.
 When I last visited the Bayport House, about a decade ago, ristorante was part of its name. It served very good Northern Italian food but was equally renowned for its Christmas decorations. Garlands, wreaths, trees, boughs, lights, snowflakes and balls started appearing the day after Halloween. In a starring role was a plethora of santas, from the jolly fellow in his sleigh on the lawn to a regiment of moving santas and Mrs. Clauses within. 
 The 2001 version of the Bayport House also makes a holiday statement, albeit a more restrained one. Decorations include wreaths and garlands entwined with pristine white lights, a display of miniature houses and an occasional santa or two. At other times of the year patrons will be taken with the overall ambience of the old building: the charming, multi-windowed dining porches and the snug tap room with its impressive, hand-carved bar.
Bill and Leda Sukow, the new owners, are a presence in the well-run dining room. Their staff of amiable, hardworking professionals could not be faulted. Those all-seeing servers notice any drop in the fullness of the bread basket and offer more focaccia. Resist. That warm, onion-topped bread is so terrific that many a diner has found himself too full for the meal.
That would be a shame because Joseph Felicetta is in the kitchen. Long Islanders may be acquainted with the food of this highly regarded chef form his stints at places like Metropolis in East Setauket and Octopus Garden in Port Washington.
At the Bayport House the food is contemporary American -- a salad bowl of influences. The menu includes dishes as diverse as Laotian prawns steamed in banana leaves, a French Quarter seafood bisque, chicken in a Mexican mole sauce, calamari with a Thai dipping sauce, ancho chili-rubbed rib-eye steak, a German-style tenderloin of pork with potato pancake and baked apple, and a New England fish chowder.
That creamy chowder, full of briny goodies, was the top appetizer one night. Another time, the pink-hued seafood bisque, with its lashings of cayenne and sherry, was its equal. If the mixed seafood salad is a special, go for it. This was not the familiar Italian starter but a mound of greens dressed with a miso vinaigrette and topped with bean sprouts, crab meat, a few large shrimp and big chunks of meat from half a lobster. Wasabi and seaweed salad ringed the plate. (That very tasty seaweed salad is also listed with the vegetable side dishes and at $5 would make an economical opener.)
Other appetizers that more than made the grade were the very tender fried calamari, the classic Caesar and the rough-hewn pate served with cornichons, pickled onions and grainy Dijon mustard.
I encountered no failures on this menu. Among the headliners were sauteed skate in a brown butter sauce, grilled swordfish topped with tiny, thumbnail-size tomatoes in a tomato-basil salsa; a succulent grilled chicken breast crusted with rosemary and garlic and paired with a creamy wild mushroom risotto, and a velvety filet mignon sporting a Gorgonzola crown with red wine sauce, basil mashed potato and grilled vegetable accompaniments.
The best pasta sampled was an angel-hair blessed with leeks and littleneck clams steamed with fermented black beans, garlic, ginger, chilis and white wine. It was a lip-smacking treat. For those looking for something more straightforward, a two-pound lobster has been a frequent special.
Desserts were as scrumptious as the rest of the meal. All were worth the calories; two were show-stoppers. The sampler of homemade ice creams and sorbets was an eye-popper. Four mini (homemade) cones held assorted flavors. The plate also included ice cream-filled bonbons and a frozen banana ice cream pop covered in decadently rich chocolate. The same adjectives also also describe the bittersweet chocolate terrine. It's a don't-miss finale for chocolate lovers. The Bayport House itself is a don't-miss treat for Long Island foodies.

The Bayport House
291 Bayport Avenue, Bayport
(631) 472-2444.
