HEADLINE: Before the Textbooks, The Address Book 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
WITH local N.A.A.C.P. leaders leading the way, it was anything but an ordinary return to school for Alexander and Jacques Pittman last month when the brothers walked back into the West Shore Middle School in Milford after being barred for nearly two months.
 In the glare of flashing cameras, Alexander, 12 and Jacques, 11, were escorted back into school by their mother, Debbie Pittman, and leaders of the Greater New Haven N.A.A.C.P. with a throng of news media following closely behind. 
 "It's great to be back," said Jacques. "It was getting pretty boring being home every day, and I can't wait to see my friends." 
The brothers were returning to school after a two-month battle with the city's school system. They had been barred from the school they had both been attending since kindergarten when both the city's Board of Education and a state hearing officer determined they did not live in the Milford home of their grandmother, but rather in the Bridgeport home of their father. 
The boys' mother, Ms. Pittman, who said she and her children lived with her mother in Milford, refused to enroll them in Bridgeport and instead kept them out of school while she battled with Milford and the state. She said she and her sons, as well as an older daughter who graduated from the Milford school system last year, had been living in Milford since 1993 when the brothers started attending school there. The private investigator hired by Milford, however, said the boys lived in Bridgeport with their father, who is divorced from Ms. Pittman.
The brothers were allowed back in school after the local Probate Court determined that temporary custodial guardianship, which Ms. Smith transferred to her mother, Dorothy Smith of Milford, in October, was not based solely on a motivation for the boys to attend the city's schools.
"It is against state law to transfer guardianship just because you want your children to attend a particular school system and we had to be certain that was not happening here," said Mary Jo Kramer, Milford's superintendent of schools who this month was named superintendent of the Darien school system. She said she was most concerned that the children had missed so much school.
Pupil residency is a major problem in school systems across Connecticut. School officials said hundreds of students were accused each year of illegally attending suburban schools, especially in districts near the state's largest cities. With many suburban schools already overcrowded and the cost of educating children so high, towns said they can't look the other way when a nonresident is attending their schools, although officials said they understand the motivation.
"As educators, these situations really do put us in a very awkward position because we do hear some very moving stories from parents pleading with us to let their children stay," said Marjorie Anctil, assistant superintendent of schools in Trumbull. "It's never easy to turn children away, but when we determine they do not live here we have no choice."
The rise in divorces, more frequent moves and shared custody among parents and other relatives have all contributed to the difficulties school systems face in trying to determine where students actually reside. Some school districts, in fact, such as the Hartford suburbs like West Hartford, Bloomfield and Newington, consider the problem so severe they have hired former police and law enforcement officers to work full-time on residency cases.
"We investigate between 200 to 250 residency cases every year and about half the time we are able to establish that a student is not actually residing in West Hartford," said Richard Gable, the school system's director of registration and student residency.
Mr. Gable, a 34-year law enforcement veteran who worked in the West Hartford and Newington police departments and has been employed in his current post since 1994, said his job has actually become more challenging over the past decade.
"More and more people are trying to illegally place their children in our school system, but we're getting better at detecting when it happens," said Mr. Gable. "Of course we don't catch everybody and I'm sure there are students who manage to even graduate without being caught. But it's something we devote a lot of time and energy to because it saves considerable money."
That's why the Newington Board of Education recently decided to hire the town's police chief, Richard Klett, who is retiring, to be the school system's first director of safety and residency. Mr. Klett will assume his new post Jan. 1, said Ernest Perlini, the superintendent of schools.
Mr. Perlini said that because the town is between Hartford and New Britain, he is certain there are far more students attending the district illegally than the 10 to 15 cases that are investigated annually.
"We believe employing an expert in local law enforcement full-time is going to save us a considerable amount of money over the long run," said Mr. Perlini. "While we would like to accommodate everyone who wants to attend our schools, the reality is that it is impossible."
While there are no statewide statistics on the number of students investigated annually by local school districts for fraudulently attending suburban districts, school officials in numerous communities said the problem has worsened considerably in recent years.
"Pupil residency has always been a concern of school districts, but because education has become so much more expensive and with enrollment in some districts actually bursting at the seams, there is no question this has become a much more urgent issue," said Thomas Murphy, a spokesman for the State Department of Education.
Mr. Murphy said there were programs like Project Open Choice, which makes it possible for more than 1,700 students in the state's three largest cities, Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven, to attend other school systems. But, he said, parents often try illegal measures because "there are clearly far more people who want their children to attend school systems outside their districts than what the current capacity allows."
With annual per pupil expenditures now more than $8,000 on average, some as high as $11,000, and with soaring enrollments as well, districts across the state said they were scrambling to find ways to insure that all students attending their schools actually reside in their towns and cities -- including hiring full-time investigators. 
"It's not a pleasant reality, but it is something we have to do, given the current economic system in which school systems have to pay themselves for the lion's share of our budgets," said Ms. Anctil, the assistant superintendent of schools in Trumbull, a town that borders Bridgeport.
"We feel terrible we can't allow everyone to attend who wants to," said Mr. Perlini of Newington, recalling a family last year who desperately wanted their children to continue attending the school system even though they were moving to another town.
"It was very, very difficult to turn them down because their children had been attending our schools for years and they were all good students," said Mr. Perlini. "It doesn't matter whether they're already attending or not, once they aren't living here anymore we cannot allow them to attend."
Both local and state educators conceded that at times the issue of actual residency is not easy to determine because of shared custody or divorces in which children split time between different homes. According to state statute, "a child residing in a dwelling located in more than one town shall be considered a resident of each town in which the dwelling is located and may attend school in any one of such towns."
In the recent Milford case, however, school officials said they were convinced after a six-month investigation that the Pittman brothers were living in Bridgeport. Milford's conclusion, upheld by the state, prompted Bridgeport school officials to send truant officers to the home of the boys' father on four occasions, but never found the boys or their mother there.
"We never found any evidence they lived in Bridgeport," said Richard Huydic, spokesman for the Bridgeport school district, which over the past two years has had 40 students placed in the district after they were illegally attending suburban schools like Milford, Trumbull, Stratford and Fairfield. "We were prepared to have them attend our schools, but we also needed validation they lived here and the family continued to maintain they resided in Milford."
Because she and her children are African Americans, Ms. Pittman said she believed there were "racial overtones" to Milford's investigation and decision, which included hiring private investigators to follow her sons. She said they were allowed back in school only after she enlisted the help of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
"I said all along we lived in Milford and my only concern was that my children receive the education they are entitled to," Ms. Pittman said. "What hurts the most is that my sons have missed two months of learning they will never get back. But I could not justify sending them to the Bridgeport schools when I knew that's not where they lived."
School officials denied that race played any role in their decision, insisting the use of private detectives is a routine part of their dozen residency investigations each year, most of which, they said, involved white families.
"This was always about residency, not race," said Ms. Kramer, Milford superintendent. "I can't say that emphatically enough."
Mr. Huydic, as well as spokespeople for the New Haven and Hartford school districts, said they cooperated with suburban towns when informed that students attending those schools actually live in the larger cities.
"When we are provided with an address by the towns we always send a truant officer to investigate as part of our efforts to determine residency," said Mr. Huydic. "Other than that, there's really not much more we can do."
Ed Linehan, New Haven's supervisor for magnet schools and district registration, said while there are only about a half dozen students each year enrolled after illegally attending suburban school districts such as Hamden, East Haven, West Haven and Milford, "one would assume it happens a lot more often that we will never know about."
Mr. Linehan said there are about 450 city students attending schools legally in surrounding school districts, but added that the numbers of students who attend illegally shows "there is clearly far more demand than there is available space."

HEADLINE: Weather Spells Relief From Fuel Costs 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
DARREL GROCE, an owner of Wayne Fuel Service in Lynbrook, hasn't quite resorted to leaning back with his feet on the desk. But neither has the phone been ringing off the hook.
 "We're just sitting here waiting for people to call," Mr. Groce said. "And waiting for the weather to get colder." 
 Unseasonably balmy weather in the Northeast, including the warmest November on Long Island in 132 years and sweater weather for much of December, has sent demand for home heating oil plummeting along with its price, now about 30 cents less a gallon than a year ago.
Prices for gasoline and natural gas are also down sharply for reasons that have less to do with the weather but are adding just as greatly to the savings for Long Island consumers.
For Mr. Groce, all the warm weather has meant time on his hands in a season when he is usually making deliveries nonstop. In November alone, he said, business was down 40 percent and a driver who usually worked full time was hardly working at all.
But for others it was good news in a shaky time: money not spent on oil and gas was remaining in people's pockets or getting spent instead on holiday shopping.
Economists said lower energy costs were bringing huge savings to Long Island. The region consumes 20 percent of petroleum products used in New York, which is the fourth largest per capita consumer of petroleum after Texas, California and Florida, according to federal estimates.
"There is a little extra bit of a twist because the reduction in the oil and gas prices is coupled with the reduction in heating fuel consumption because of the weather," said Thomas Conoscenti, a Long Island regional economist in Nesconset. "It has helped keep the economy a lot stronger than it would have been."
Dr. Conoscenti said savings on heating oil were probably exceeded by motorists' savings on gasoline, down an average of about 30 cents a gallon from a year ago.
Gary E. Huth, the principal Long Island economist for the state Department of Labor regional office in Hicksville, said there were also intangible benefits.
"If people are not spending as much, it gives a certain amount of the feeling of a buffer, a cushion, and that's important in these times when people are feeling stressed in other areas," he said.
Savings were most easily quantified for heating oil, still the dominant fuel for home heating on Long Island.
For the estimated 615,000 residential heating oil customers in Nassau and Suffolk, the convergence of warmer-than-normal temperatures, lower prices, lower demand and large inventories of heating oil is the exact opposite of market conditions a year ago.
Kevin Rooney, the chief executive officer of the Oil Heat Institute of Long Island, a heating oil trade group, said that from Sept. 1 through Dec. 17 of last year temperatures were 7 percent below normal and an average customer used 264 gallons with an average retail price of $1.74 a gallon for a cost of $459.36.
For the same period this year, Mr. Rooney said, temperatures were 25 percent above normal and an average customer used 185 gallons at an average retail price of $1.42 a gallon for a cost of $262.70, a saving of $196.66 per customer and more than $120 million for all Long Island customers.
Mr. Conoscenti said that when a 2.1 retail multiplier was taken into account, the total boost to the regional economy was $254 million.
Mr. Rooney said industrial and commercial users of oil and natural gas had also saved large amounts of money.
"It's wonderful news for consumers, but absolutely awful for the heating oil industry," he said.
Residents who use natural gas for cooking, heat or hot water were also paying and using less.
Bonnie Habyan, a KeySpan spokeswoman, said the company estimated that bills for its 442,000 residential customers in Nassau, Suffolk and the Rockaway Peninsula would be 15 percent below a year ago for November through March, the period the company regards as the heating season.
Natural gas costs plunged by 27 percent in December. For a full-service gas customer with an average bill of $1,200, savings would be $180 for the season, she estimated.
At gasoline stations, the average price for midgrade gasoline was $1.311 at midweek, down from $1.729 a year ago, according to the Automobile Club of New York. Regular and premium grades declined by similar amounts. 
"It's always better for the retailers when prices are lower," said Kathryn Pollane, executive director of the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association in Melville. "People go out more, and they will buy things in the stations' retail stores."
Some retailers outside the gasoline trade said warmer weather had brought out more shoppers.
"By this time last year we had already spent $100,000 removing ice and snow," said Janine Nebons, general manager of the Tanger Outlet Center in Riverhead. She said shopping at the center's 170 manufacturer's outlet stores was running 12 to 15 percent ahead of a year ago.
"We're having a fabulous year," Ms. Nebons said. "What analysts and the media said about the discount scene being very strong fits right in with what we are seeing this year.
"A lot of people who would have traveled to New Jersey are coming here," she added. "The East End is a straight shot with no bridges or tunnels." Suffolk also exempts county sales taxes on clothing and shoes priced at under $110.
While the lower cost of natural gas and oil has also cut the cost to generate and import electricity, the savings will not be reflected on bills of the Long Island Power Authority until next year. LIPA makes adjustments for fuel costs once annually for the preceding year and is currently adding a 5.8 percent surcharge to electric bills to cover high fuel costs in 2000.
Richard M. Kessel, the authority chairman, said last week that the 5.8 percent surcharge might be reduced or eliminated when the authority reviews costs for this year. "I do not anticipate it will be increased," Mr. Kessel said. 
Heating fuel savings from unseasonably warm weather may be drawing to a close.
Tim Morrin, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service forecast office in Upton, said Long Island temperatures for the fall season had been two degrees above normal. But Mr. Morrin said the weather service was predicting temperatures colder than normal to set in late this month and through January and February.
He added, however, that a study by forecasters in Upton found a correlation between the 10 warmest autumns and significantly less snowfall in the winters that followed.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Motorists, above, take advantage of lower gasoline prices at a Mobil station in Hewlett. Darrel Croce, left, makes a home heating oil delivery in Lynbrook.; Kevin Rooney, head of the Oil Heat Institute of Long Island. (Photographs by Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Westchester; 
Leasing Former General Foods Site Is Behind Target

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
SLUGGISH leasing activity and construction delays at the sprawling 39-acre former Kraft Foods headquarters in White Plains -- now called 333 Westchester Avenue -- have caused the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation of Manhattan, the current developers, to secure an extension on its deadline for finding tenants as spelled out in its financial agreement with the Westchester County Industrial Development Agency.
 In response to a request by the developer, the county agreed late last month to give the company an additional 20 months to meet the occupancy goal, which had been set for next spring. 
 Charles Steven Cohen, president and chief executive of Cohen Brothers, which is renovating and marketing the 600,000-square-foot complex -- which was vacated by Kraft in 1997 and is still mostly empty -- attributed the current problems to a number of "costly delays and unexpected conditions." 
"All this has taken more time than expected, which is not unusual with a project of this scope," Mr. Cohen said. The company, which serves as owner, developer and leasing agent, has been renovating 333 Westchester since it acquired the property in 1998 for $25 million. 
So far, it has poured $15 million into the four-building campus, which was originally constructed for the General Foods Corporation in the 1950's. Its first task was to redesign and remarket it as four distinct buildings, and it hired the architectural firm of Philip Johnson. Under the new design, each building is now entered through a towering sculpturelike entry with its own distinctive color. In all, the project, which also includes upgrading the buildings and surrounding campus, is expected to cost $90 million.
In large part, the current slow economy is the main cause of Cohen Brothers' problems, according to company spokesmen and economic development specialists. 
"The once favorable conditions existing in the leasing market are not the same as when C.B.R.C. undertook the project," Joseph P. Carlucci, a lawyer for Cohen Brothers, said in a letter to the Industrial Development Agency seeking an extension in dates on its agreement with the county. 
"The market has flattened, and there is considerably more sublease space on the market today, which makes lease-up of the site more difficult," Mr. Carlucci of Cuddy & Feder & Worby in White Plains, wrote. The request was granted late in November.
The vacancy rate for the eastern part of Westchester that includes all of Westchester Avenue in White Plains as well as Harrison, Purchase, Rye, Rye Brook and Port Chester was 18 percent at the end of the third quarter, up from about 11.6 percent a year earlier, according to figures from Insignia/ESG Inc., the commercial real estate services provider.
COHEN BROTHERS -- which owns 11 million square feet of Class A commercial real estate in New York City, Los Angeles and Houston -- requested that the lease achievement date be revised to reflect the time each of the remaining three vacant buildings would be ready for tenants.
When the agency provides benefits to a company, it often takes ownership of the project and leases it back to the firm. Cohen Brothers in effect acts as an agent of the development agency and gets the tax exemptions to which the I.D.A. is entitled. "We hold their feet to the fire by retaining an ability to recapture benefits," said Teri Waivada, executive director of the Industrial Development Agency.
The I.D.A. board extended the 1998 arrangement under which Cohen Brothers agreed to sell the campus to the agency and lease it back in return for receiving economic development incentives -- in particular, sales and usage tax breaks on the redevelopment work and on purchases by tenants -- from Westchester County. As a condition of receiving county assistance, Cohen Brothers must fill certain percentages of its space by certain target dates.
To date, Cohen Brothers has leased about 100,000 square feet of the 193,000-square-foot south building, but none of the other three buildings.
"Cohen Brothers said they needed more time, and we extended the lease-up date to December 2003 from April 2002," Ms. Waivada said. On Dec. 31, 2003, Cohen Brothers must have 67 percent of the space leased out.
Cohen Brothers said it needed the amendment of the timetable in its agreement with the county agency to satisfy its lenders -- the Union Labor Life Insurance Company and Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce -- and give itself more time to renovate the property's north, east and west buildings. Once the buildings are ready, Cohen Brothers said, it can obtain temporary certificates of occupancy from White Plains, allowing for the space inside to be leased to business tenants.
The future of the entire complex as viable office space is critical to the county, Ms. Waivada explained, because the 430,205 square feet of space that remains to be leased out represents a sizable chunk -- 21.69 percent -- of the 1.98 million square feet of office space in the eastern market segment.
"Buildings that are full generate jobs, disposable income and sales tax revenues," she said.
But the weak economy is not the only reason that Cohen Brothers has fallen behind schedule. The complex has not been an easy one to market, according to Mr. Cohen, in large part because it was designed for a single tenant almost 50 years ago, when General Foods moved from 250 Park Avenue in Manhattan to White Plains.
TODAY, Mr. Cohen is marketing the complex -- his first suburban office venture -- to small- to medium-sized tenants requiring anywhere from 2,500 to 500,000 square feet. The current tenant list in the south building includes Allied Irish Bank; Macsteel Asoma, a steel trading company; America Online; and Nexus Computing Solutions, among others. 
Although asking rents range from $28 to $30 per square foot -- which places 333 Westchester at the high end of Westchester office market, where rents have averaged in the mid-$20's per square foot -- Mr. Cohen said actual rents charged will be competitive with the rest of the county.
The company is requiring, though, that tenants agree to a minimum lease period. "Our mantra is to do business with people who are staying in business," Mr. Cohen said. "We want them to drop anchor with us five or more years."
Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of economic development, said that requirement was "more than reasonable," especially since the cost of the work necessary to prepare the space for a particular tenant must be amortized over time.
In his letter to the county agency, Mr. Carlucci, the lawyer, attributed some of Cohen Brothers' current problems to delays caused by unexpected site conditions, not the least of which were boulders at the bottom of new elevator shafts that are being installed as part of the rehabilitation of the buildings.
"For obvious reasons, we couldn't blast in the building," Mr. Cohen said during a recent interview, explaining that workmen had no alternative but to chip away at the stones with pneumatic drills. As a result, the process took far longer than expected, he said.
The company expects to complete lobby and elevator work at the buildings and receive the temporary certificates of occupancy by next April.
It has already renovated the cafeteria and private dining rooms in the south building, which altogether seat 800. And it has rehabbed the 15,000-square-foot fitness area, also in the south building, which has a small basketball court. 
Economic and construction setbacks aside, Mr. Carrera speculated that the most likely reason for the slowness in leasing out the building may be that potential tenants have not been able to visualize the completed space and have chosen to move into quarters that are available immediately -- of which there are plenty available in the county.
"Timing is everything," the director of economic development said. "That and finding the right user for the space. It's like buying a home -- you have to have the right match."
"If a tenant is looking for easy access to Interstate 287," Mr. Carrera said, "this building has that. If they need plenty of parking, they have that too. It's a great office building, and there is no way that this project is a lost cause."

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
Celebration in Stamford
Kwanzaa, the seven-day observance of the African-American heritage of family and community spirit was founded in 1966 by Dr. Maulana Karenga, head of the Black Studies Department at California State University in Long Beach. It has become a nationwide celebration that starts Dec. 26. 
 Josephine Fulcher-Anderson, co-founder of the Stamford Kwanzaa Association, said, "Now more than ever it's important to gather in celebration of life, heritage and family -- for all races to come together in support of our community and nation." 
 The second annual Kwanzaa Celebration in Stamford will be held Wednesday at 6:30 p.m. at the Rich Forum of the Stamford Center for the Arts on 307 Atlantic Street. The celebration is open to the public free of charge.
During the evening, the first of Kwanzaa's seven principles, Umoja (unity), will be celebrated. Also, the meaning of the remaining principles -- self-determination, collective work and responsibility, economic cooperation, purpose, creativity and faith -- will be explored.
Story-telling, poetry, music, African drumming, dance, and audience participation, usually reserved for the close of Kwanzaa, will instead be presented in Wednesday's program.
For free reservations: (203) 325-4466.

Latin Mass on Christmas
The Saint Gregory Society of New Haven has preserved a custom of offering the traditional Latin Mass, or Tridentine Missal, every Christmas Day for the last several decades. The group will do so once again on Tuesday at 8 a.m. at Sacred Heart Church on Columbus Avenue and Liberty Street.
The music will feature the Gregorian chants for the Third Mass of Christmas, "Puer natus est nobis," performed by the Schola Cantorum of the Society, a choral ensemble of 20 professional church musicians. The group has acquired an international reputation for its concerts, radio broadcasts and recordings of sacred choral masterworks.
Music lovers who find an 8 a.m. concert on Christmas morning a bit daunting can hear additional High Masses with Gregorian chant scheduled by the Schola Cantorum on New Year's Day at noon; Jan. 6 (The Feast of the Epiphany) at 2 p.m.; and Jan. 13 (The Feast of the Holy Family) also at 2 p.m.
For information: (203) 624-2751 or (203) 432-9996.

Singing Cowboys
If once-popular songs of the West such as "Cool Water" and "Riders in the Sky" come around again, two New England cowboys could be the catalysts: Gil Dube from Maine and Dave Downs from Connecticut.
Ten years ago they formed a May-September duo (Mr. Dube is 71; Mr. Downs is 40-ish) calling themselves Old Paint and focusing on songs of lonely cattle drives, tough hobo tunes, coal miner's laments and love ballads for all ages.
They have sung and played acoustic guitars and harmonicas in more than 35 sites in Connecticut alone, including the Common Ground Bar in Bristol, where they met; the Center Squeeze Cafe in West Hartford; the Portland Historical Society; the Mattatuck Museum, the Apple Valley Folk Festival, the University of Hartford Folk Festival, the Soup Kitchen Concert Series in Middletown, the Veteran's Home in Rocky Hill, and at several motorcycle rallies.
They will perform at It's Only Natural at 386 Main Street in Middletown on Thursday at 7 p.m. No cover charge.
For information: (860) 346-9210. 
 ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Monastery Reopens as Housing Complex for Elderly

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: BORDENTOWN 

 BODY:
FROM some angles, the four-story red-brick monastery, part of its nine-acre grounds enclosed by a wall, looks much the same as it did when the building was constructed in 1885.
 But closer inspection reveals a modern two-story addition behind the Romanesque-style monastery, attached to it by a glass atrium, as well as a cluster of smaller structures just beyond the brick wall. Here, new and old have been fused in converting the monastery and its grounds -- previously home to the Sisters of Poor Clare, a Roman Catholic order of cloistered nuns -- into a 137-unit housing complex for the elderly called Clare Estate. 
 The $18 million project, which opened this month, provides three levels of residences, social services and personal care so residents can age in place, according to its developer, CIS & Associates of New Brunswick, a partnership of Christiana Foglio and Dov Gluck, two New Jersey developers.
The complex is in Bordentown's nationally designated historic district, which has more than 700 structures, nearly half built between 1851 and 1900, giving the one-square-mile city a 19th-century look. 
Clare Estate has 50 assisted-living units in the new building, where residents, as part of their monthly rent, receive such services as three meals a day, housekeeping and health care, including medication monitoring. Tenants in the 51 units carved from the old monastery get some services but no health care.
There are also 36 independent-living units in nine two-story buildings dotting the grounds. These units are reserved for people with annual incomes of $21,500 to $28,860, and they rent for $600 to $700 a month. Rents for the assisted units are $2,600 to $2,800 and for the residences in the monastery, $1,700. Five units scattered among the buildings are for lower-income residents and rent for $526 to $600 a month.
"The monastery site," said John W. Collom III, Bordentown's mayor, "had the potential to become an eyesore, but it didn't happen." There had been "a high degree of acceptance" among residents to the idea of recycling the building, he said, adding that its reuse as housing for the elderly was much more attractive than other options for a nine-acre site.
As a project aimed in part at the elderly with modest incomes, Clare Estate is an anomaly. In recent years, all types of housing for the elderly, especially assisted-living units, have sprouted like daisies in response to the state's growing elderly population. Most were built for affluent residents. 
But the high-end market has suffered in the last 18 months from overbuilding and a slackening economy, said Barbara Kleger, president of Senior Living Consultants in Philadelphia, a firm that advises developers but was not involved in Clare Estate. Meanwhile, she added, investors are putting money into projects that fill underserved niches, and the elderly "are shopping for value," not just upscale surroundings. 
Rents for the units at Clare Estate are kept below what they would otherwise be in part because of a $14 million below-market-rate loan from the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, one of three state agencies providing financial assistance to such projects. The rest of the financing includes developer equity and proceeds from the sale of federal historic preservation tax credits. The city also granted a 30-year real estate tax abatement.
Deborah DeSantis, executive director of the finance agency, said that in the five years her agency has offered such loans, it has provided $165 million in financing for 1,400 units in 11 projects, either built or under way. At least 20 percent of the units are for people earning below an area's median income.
"There is nowhere near an oversaturation of affordable units," Ms. DeSantis said. Also in favor of Clare Estate, she added, is that it offers a historic campuslike setting and a continuum of care.
Those factors, along with a convenient location, are what drew Pearl E. Howe, 78, to an independent-living unit at the project. Mrs. Howe, a widow, moved in September from a rental in Bordentown Township.
"I don't have to use my car every time to go shopping," she said. "It is also peaceful here, like the country, but with the city just outside." Knowing that other levels of services and care are available also makes her "a little bit more secure," she said. 
Like others in the community, Mrs. Howe said she is happy the project preserved the monastery. It is "something of an monument," she added. 
FOR as long as old-time residents can remember, the monastery has been a part of the neighborhood's character. It started life as a parochial boarding school, and in 1909 it became home to the Poor Clare Sisters. 
So it came as a blow when the sisters announced several years ago that they could no longer afford to maintain the aging building, which was too large for their shrinking population. Originally, 45 sisters lived at the monastery, and as a self-governing, self-supporting order, they used some of the grounds to grow vegetables. At one time they also baked communion wafers for use in Masses.
There were various proposals to save the building, including a plan by the Bordentown Board of Education to reuse it as a school. But none were realized, mainly because it was too costly to renovate the building.
That worried city officials, who feared the monastery would suffer the same fate as the Bordentown Military Academy. Because it had been difficult to find new uses for the school's main building, it crumbled into an eyesore and ultimately was ravaged by fire and razed. Condominiums now stand on the site. 
But in 1998 CIS & Associates bought the monastery for $1.4 million, with visions of turning it into housing for the elderly. The sisters have since moved to a smaller newly built monastery in nearby Chesterfield.
The developers bought the site because "the building really moved us, and we saw in it something others didn't see -- its potential as more than a cookie-cutter senior housing project," said Mr. Gluck. Among its attractive features are its open land as well as its location close to Routes 130 and 295 and to the New Jersey Turnpike. 
But there were challenges, including piecing together the financing, which took a year. Because the federal government changed its requirements during the application phase, the project was redesigned and the total number of units dropped to 137 from 150. 
Under the design by Parsons + Fernandez-Casteleiro Architects of Manhattan, the old monastery's facade, with its rows of windows with brick arches, like eyebrows, has been restored. Inside, the main building has been transformed to residences as well as public spaces that include a main dining area carved from two former chapels. Such details as stained glass windows, arches and woodwork have been preserved and other features have been given a new uses; a confessional has been turned into a phone booth.
Rather than mimic the monastery," the new building is modern, said Jeff Parsons, a principal, adding that the glass atrium connects the structures and provides views of the monastery's bell tower and the site's 100-year-old oak tree. A barn on the property, which is being retained, offered the inspiration for the simple design of the smaller buildings.
State Assemblyman Joseph R. Malone III of Bordentown said Clare Estate "is the largest and one of the first assisted-living projects in the northern part of Burlington County, where "there is a crying need" for such housing. "It gives seniors a place to stay that is close to family," he added. 
Ms. Foglio said the lack of other comparable developments in the county and the graying of the population would enable Clare Estate "to weather the tightening economy." 
Mayor Collom said the project "is uplifting for the city," which has waxed and waned over the decades and is now on an upswing, and it put a tax-exempt property onto the tax rolls. Mr. Malone added that it also "saves not only a landmark but memories."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clare Estate has 137 units for the elderly, including 51 units that are in the 116-year-old monastery building. (Dith Pran/The New York Times) Map of New Jersey highlighting Bordentown.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Warmer and Fuzzier Scrooges and Grinches?

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS

 BODY:
IF the corporate world is dull, colored in premature grays, then why is Stanley Bing laughing? Could it be the holiday season? Certainly not this year, with its sad undertones and economic malaise. 
 Despite all that's happened, though, Mr. Bing and his co-workers are doing their best to spend the season in the usual way. "We are commuting with friends," he said, "having lunch with friends, going out for drinks with friends and seeing our friends get fired." Because budget-writing time coincides with Christmas, the corporate world, Mr. Bing added, "celebrates the season with layoffs as reliably as the English do with roast goose." 
 As this year of tragic loss, shaken confidence and waves of layoffs draws to an end, it seemed a good time to seek some perspective from a sage veteran of the corporate world, a Westchester resident who slogs to Manhattan on Metro-North each day as thousands of others do. 
Stanley Bing is the pen name of a best-selling author and Fortune magazine columnist named Gil D. Schwartz, a New Rochelle resident who writes with telltale insight and humor about the inner workings of corporations, while trying to keep his identity secret because he also works for an enormous multinational conglomerate. 
"In a craven and cowardly fashion," Mr. Schwartz said, "I hide behind a pen name, disguising the people I work with while I report on life on the inside. I'm a spy and I report on the inside of the world I move around in, at the same time staying true to my country -- my company." 
How well does the disguise work? 
"It is a horrendously kept secret," he said. 
Before entering corporate America more than two decades ago, Mr. Schwartz worked as an actor. "But always in a theater company," he said. "I have a love for organization and structure. The beehive." 
He left the theater and went to work for a large "gigantic multinational, industrial behemoth based in Pittsburgh." At first, he hated having to wear a suit and shave every day. "Now I'm not really comfortable unless I'm shaved and in a suit," he said. "I have Stockholm Syndrome." 
Mr. Schwartz loved that first job. He remembers wistfully going to corporate headquarters where he had be among "two dozen steer-fed executives, none of them under 240 pounds, all with white helmet hair, sitting around a steel gray table."
"I heard them talk about turbines and power plants in this big building that was filled with these industrial people and I was moved."
Mr. Schwartz is fascinated by the ways people organize themselves for work and the ways those organizations bring out the best -- and worst -- in people.
"The public doesn't understand that the corporate world is really like a dysfunctional family," said Mr. Schwartz. "Of course this," he said, motioning around his large corner office at CBS in Midtown Manhattan where he is executive vice president of communications, "is actually the only family from which you can get fired." 
Bosses, he said, are receptors of filial feelings, even when they're younger than employees. "You rage at them, you want to kill them, supplant them. I mean, how much more Greek drama can you get? "As a writer," Mr. Schwartz confirmed, "I have a lot to feast on." 
It was soon after entering corporate America that Mr. Schwartz let his pen loose, capitalizing on his two talents, as a good writer and good bureaucrat. He began to write a monthly column for Esquire magazine, centered upon business advice, like "how to give good phone," as Mr. Schwartz put it. It was proscriptive advice, but "so hostile," Mr. Schwartz admitted, "that if it wasn't funny, it would have been obnoxious." 
For the last seven years, Mr. Schwartz has been writing a biweekly column for Fortune magazine, about his own corporate life and those of others he knew. He has written books, including a novel and the best-selling "What Would Machiavelli Do? The Ends Justify the Meanness" (Harper Business, 2000), which preaches rank meanness as a career tool. 
The book's acknowledgments page begins with Mr. Schwartz (uh, Bing) thanking "Leonard, my first boss, who kept me waiting in his anteroom for three hours one Friday night in 1982 until I realized that he had left by a separate exit without having the courtesy to tell me he was doing so. He is now a multibillionaire who works about six hours a week." 
Mr. Schwartz, 50, who grew up in New Rochelle, has been married to Sue Mittenthal, for 24 years. They have two children.
A book coming out in the spring of 2002 describes how you can use Zen to manage your manager. 
Mr. Schwartz has not relied upon Zen to succeed. "There were times when I kept my position only because I never left my chair," he said. "I just sat in my chair. My bosses would go, 'What are we going to do with him?' But I always had a chair and looked busy and they'd say, 'We'll get him later.' And then those people would be gone and I'd just keep going." 
The corporate world has changed since Sept. 11. The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were attacks on workplaces and people who worked together died together. Anthrax, too, was sent to offices. There was concern and paranoia about everything from planes flying into the office to envelopes to the unknown. 
"It didn't help that so many demented people were phoning in bomb scares," said Mr. Schwartz. "I would walk down Sixth Avenue and see so many workers standing out of their buildings. Nor did Mr. Ridge's maddeningly vague warnings help." 
But as a result of the experience, noted Mr. Schwartz, there has been "a lot more holding onto each other, a lot more sharing of feelings." For a time afterward, every interaction at work was even prefaced with a mention of its inconsequence. 
"People were saying to me 'I know this isn't important, but I want a raise.' " And while Mr. Schwartz noted that corporate Christmas parties this year are for the most part more sober and calmer than usual ("the corporate lampshade allotment is down,") he did draw the line at how far change would ultimately go: "We're not going to sing Cumba-Ya and hug and sway."
In fact, recently, since the question of economic collapse is off the table and the only thing left to answer is exactly when the recovery will come, there has been a sense of relief. With it, said Mr. Schwartz, "the more superficial and idiotic stuff" has seeped back into corporate life.
"We had perspective," he said, "but pretty soon we'll be screaming when the 10 o'clock mail comes at 10:05." And that's not an altogether bad thing. "Life asserts itself in the inconsequential, a drink after work and other irrelevancies," he said. . 
In the end, by returning to such corporate conventions, "We are putting a thumb to our nose" at our attackers.
"It's still pretty cold in here," Mr. Schwartz confirmed from his corner office, "and we like it that way. It's the real world and we're glad to be alive in it."

HEADLINE: On Brighton Beach, a Tide of Immigrants 

BYLINE:  By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
ON oceanfront land in Brooklyn once occupied by the Brighton Beach Baths, the Muss Organization of Queens is moving into the third year of construction on a condominium project that is reversing the symbolism of the site -- from one linked with the past to one reflecting the possibilities the city holds for its recent immigrants and their children.
 The project is called Oceana, a large-scale development that began in 1999 and will have 15 buildings with 850 apartments when it is finished in about four years. So far five buildings are completed and fully or partially occupied. A sixth is in construction. 
 The Brighton Beach Baths were a sentimental symbol of Brooklyn family life as older people remember it. Starting in 1907, families came on weekends and in the summertime to change clothes in cabanas and take up the favored activities of the era -- swimming, handball, group exercising, sunbathing and mah-jongg. But by the mid-80's it became clear that the Baths' days were numbered. The developer who had purchased the site in 1954 closed the Baths and proposed a large-scale residential development. After many hearings the city approved a plan for 1,600 apartments in the recession year of 1993. It never went forward. 
Years passed. Then Muss went into contract to buy the property and won city approval for a more modest development: 850 apartments along with a 16,000-square-foot clubhouse. Site preparation started in the fall of 1999. 
The large number of immigrant families that Oceana has attracted makes it possible to think of it as a symbol of the future in housing quality that successful immigrants or their children can aspire to in America. Between 50 and 60 percent of the heads of household among the 305 buyers so far were born abroad, the management says. Many of them immigrated only within the last 20 years, often from the former Soviet Union but from other countries as well. Many grew up in America after arrival at a young age and early education in American schools.
All have used savings accumulated in business or the professions to buy housing that has all the elements of luxury living -- spacious apartments with grand views; a gated entrance to a 15-acre site; underground parking and some reserved street-level spaces; attention to design and decor in public spaces; a community building with a health club and a pool. Eventually, if the city can be persuaded, residents will have direct private access to the beach.
Current sales are mainly in a price range of $350,000 to $800,000 and rise as high as $1.2 million for penthouses with direct ocean views. Prices exceed $500,000 for 40 percent of apartments currently on the market. 
The Oceana condominium is not the only new housing in Brooklyn in which recent immigrants evidence their financial achievement. Nor is its housing the most expensive to be found. In Manhattan Beach and Mill Basin and parts of Bergen Beach, immigrant families have been prominent among the recent buyers of new or totally renovated houses selling for upward of $700,000, and as high as $2 million or more. A broker in many of these sales, Jon Sobel, said that in about a dozen sales at more than $1 million over the last two years, five of the buyers were Russian-born. The rest were American-born.
"All these people were well-to-do, and they were self-made too," Mr. Sobel said.
But, as interviews with new buyers at Oceana showed, there is remarkable variety in the twisting paths that led them all to reach their current economic status and then choose to settle in the same Brighton Beach condominium. Few of them appear to have come from a background of poverty. On the contrary, most had successful careers in their homelands, but had the ability to take on and succeed at new careers in America -- or to enable their children to succeed.
The newer immigrants may speak English hesitatingly, but their young children already speak as fluently as natives. As sales proceed, the variety in the ethnic background of buyers is also increasing. And more and more of them are coming from outside Brooklyn.
Steve Maksin and his wife, Natalie, a couple in their 30's who bought at Oceana, are perhaps representative of this newer type of buyer -- younger, Americanized, fluently English-speaking and lacking even shallow roots in Brooklyn. Mr. Maksin arrived -- alone -- from Kiev, Ukraine, only 13 years ago as a high-school graduate. He lived at first with his grandmother, who had immigrated in 1979. Two years later his mother arrived. He met Natalie when they were both undergraduates at the Stern School of Business of New York University. 
"My wife told me that her parents were planning to buy in Brighton Beach and I should go to look at apartments in the same development," said Mr. Maksin, a 34-year-old tax lawyer and accountant working for PricewaterhouseCoopers in Manhattan. "I thought that that would be the last place people would be likely to buy. But when I went to see the place, I was sold." The Maksins paid $285,000 for a two-bedroom second-floor apartment, buying from plans in the fall of 1999. They closed and moved in last February. 
ACCORDING to an analysis of the city's 1999 housing and vacancy survey done by the sociology department at Queens College, an estimated 85,500 households headed by immigrants had incomes of $100,000 or more at that time. Of that total, 7,700 of the households came from the former Soviet Union. The total number of immigrant-headed households in 1999 is calculated by the department to have been 1.14 million. 
In Brighton Beach near the entrance to Oceana -- on Brighton Beach Avenue, half a block from Coney Island Avenue -- the mark of Russian immigration is heavy on local commercial life. A small high-end supermarket called Gourmet Plaza opened a year ago. The women operating the many specialty-food counters in most cases speak Russian only. A small cafe, clothing shops and furriers selling high-priced goods have opened nearby. Yet prices generally seem much lower than in Manhattan. One condominium owner estimated that prices for specialty foods are 30 to 40 percent lower than they are in Manhattan.
The personal tales of the routes that Oceana's buyers traveled to condominium ownership establish the development's claim to be a leading magnet for the successful immigrant in New York City.
Tina Orsini, for example, was born in the Abruzzo region of Italy, on the Adriatic Sea. Her father arrived in the United States in 1955, when she was 7. Her husband, Alfonso, is a third-generation American, with Irish, Italian and Hungarian roots. Mrs. Orsini is an English teacher, currently working on her doctorate at Teachers College of Columbia University. Her husband spends most of the year in the ski-resort town of Leysin, Switzerland, as headmaster of a private school.
The Orsinis both came from middle-class families, but neither had been living in Brooklyn when they bought at Oceana. "We sold our house in Summit, N.J., when Al got an appointment in Switzerland, and when I came back a year and a half later when everything was in storage, I thought we had to re-establish a nest somewhere. My brother was living in Brooklyn, and he said, 'You really have to come and see this place in Brighton Beach.' "
Mrs. Orsini bought a two-bedroom apartment on the second floor of an oceanfront building for $330,000. Her husband had not even seen it when she went into contract, she said. "The community is highly multicultural but with a large Russian population, which I think has brought flavor and beauty to the area," she said. "To me it feels like a place abroad. It's nice to live in a luxurious way in a very local but global community." 
Another Oceana resident is Dr. Pavel Yutsis, 54, who bought a four-bedroom second-floor apartment from plans for $675,000 in May 2000. Born in Odessa, Ukraine, and a graduate of medical school in Voronezh, Russia, Dr. Yutsis arrived in the United States in 1980 with his wife, Lilia, and his son, Max, now 26. Their daughter, Francine, 13, was born in the United States. 
At first the family stayed with in-laws in Newark. While working as a nursing assistant at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., Dr. Yutsis prepared to take the medical board examinations, which he passed two years later. In 1986 he opened a pediatric practice in Brooklyn and later bought a house in Bensonhurst. Fluent now in English, he is the host of two weekly medical call-in shows: one in English called "From Allergies to Aging" on WWRL and the other in Russian called "The People's Wave" on WPAT.
"There are very few Russians who would not like to live near the beach, especially if they're from Odessa," Dr. Yutsis said. "I could have bought a mansion with 40 rooms, but what would I do with all those rooms?"
Another buyer, Ernesto Custodio, 30, came to the United States from the Dominican Republic at the age of 10. He graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo and now works, mostly at home, as a computer-network consultant. He and his wife, Lisa, were renting on 105th Street near Central Park West when they started house hunting throughout the metropolitan area on the Internet. They found Oceana on a real-estate Web site.
"We drove around in Brooklyn, and we liked the look of Bay Ridge," Mr. Custodio said, "but they just had regular apartments there that didn't seem to justify the commute." The couple bought a 1,200-square-foot one-bedroom apartment at Oceana on the first floor, selling at the time for $310,000. 
"I had never been to this place before," Mr. Custodio said. "But we like the beach and we take advantage of the club, and it's not a bad commute." Using the Q line express train, called the Q-diamond, the commute to Midtown takes about 45 minutes.
THE Muss Organization's purchaser-profile data on the first 200 sales last February showed that 73 percent of those buyers had incomes over $100,000 a year. Almost half the buyers were former renters, and the rest had owned a home.
Sixty percent of the buyers formerly lived in Brooklyn, and most of the rest came from other boroughs of the city. The information on occupations showed that 84 were self-employed and 30 were in computer-related businesses. The next-largest category was doctors -- 17. Forty of the first 200 buyers were retirees, and about a third had not yet turned 30.
Most of the early buyers were local people, largely Russian or of Russian extraction, who had been waiting for years for the redevelopment of the Baths site to succeed. But more recently, as Oceana has become better known, the buying pool has widened geographically. One attraction has been its on-site parking capacity, for 1,200 cars, a ratio of 1.5 cars per apartment. About 90 percent of the parking is underground. The typical ratio of parking in those mid-density Brooklyn projects that have parking at all is 0.6, or 6 spaces for every 10 apartments. About three-quarters of Oceana buyers own at least one car.
The Muss Organization acquired the property in 1999 after spending two years winning city approval for its proposed revision of a higher-density plan that had been approved six years earlier for the previous owner, the Miami Beach firm of Alexander Muss & Sons. Its principal, Stephen Muss, is Joshua's cousin. His view-oriented plan called for four tall towers with a total of 1,600 apartments, with many studios and one-bedrooms.
Joshua Muss, steeped in more conventional New York City midrise development, was unenthusiastic about that plan aesthetically, but faced two practical impediments that led him to abandon it and start over. The first was that it was extremely costly to build. The second was that it would have been nearly impossible to finance. "We would have had to finance 400 apartments at a time," he said. "Can you imagine finding yourself in a terrible market when you're building 400 apartments?"
Instead, Muss Development turned to the San Francisco firm of Sandy & Babcock International, working with the Manhattan architectural firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron, to redesign the project. Stanley Krebushevsky was the zoning consultant. 
The site plan is intended to create a "parklike neighborhood feeling," Muss says, with a circular road and 15 midrise buildings of 7 to 12 stories surrounding the central clubhouse. The carousel that was a notable feature of the Brighton Beach Baths was disassembled and donated to the New York Aquarium in Coney Island, which plans to restore it as a grand entrance and visitors center.
The Carlyle Group of Washington is a financial partner in the Oceana project. Construction financing is obtained on a building-by-building basis from the Bank of New York.
One fundamental change brought by Muss Development has been in the apartment mix. Instead of many smaller apartments in what was to have been a rental development, Oceana's for-sale apartments are all two bedrooms or larger, and 90 percent are either three bedrooms or convertible into three bedrooms in space built as a den or dining area.
Generous apartment size was one of the attractions for Phyllis and Irwin Shanes, an American-born couple who bought a 1,900-square-foot four-bedroom apartment with three baths and an ocean view for $685,000 a year ago. The Shanes, both retired, had been living in the Seacoast middle-income co-op next door to the Baths property for the last 15 years. 
"Most of our friends have moved to retirement communities in New Jersey, or they went to Florida," said Mrs. Shanes, whose husband was the administrator of a union health and welfare fund. "But I was happy here. I like the underground parking, and the closets. We bought a surface parking spot at our door too, so we can give a place to anyone who comes to visit us." Outdoor parking sells for an average of $35,000 a space, with a monthly maintenance fee of $35. Indoor space rents for $200 a month plus tax. 
THE development is not without Asian representation. Winnie Cheng and her husband, Lee Fong, a lawyer, arrived with their families about 30 years ago as teenagers, she from mainland China and he from Hong Kong. They met through friends, married in the 70's and later bought a house in Oyster Bay, N.Y. Their two sons are in college. A month ago they closed on a $400,000 two-bedroom apartment at Oceana, but are keeping their Long Island house, mainly for weekend use.
"We needed a place closer to the city for commuting," Ms. Cheng said. It matters little to them that there are so few Asian-born Americans in Brighton Beach. "We are from New York City, and today we do business with people of all ethnic backgrounds," she said. 
But Luba Dubrova's family is perhaps more representative of the early buyers. Ms. Dubrova, a 21-year-old senior at Brooklyn College, spoke no English at all when she arrived with her family from Minsk in 1989. She lives with her parents, Elvira Dubrova and Lev Klaynberg, and her grandmother, Marya Dubrova, in a 1,770-square-foot penthouse purchased for $625,000. 
Her parents, reluctant about giving an interview in English, sent their daughter on that mission. Her father worked for a printing company in Minsk, but now he works as a manager at his brother Joseph's company in Manhattan, Wonder Works Construction. The family rented apartments in Bensonhurst and at Trump Village on Ocean Parkway before buying their Oceana apartment.
"I went to P.S. 247 after we arrived in Bensonhurst," Ms. Dubrova said in accentless English. "One day I didn't speak, and the next day I couldn't stop talking."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: Thriving on a World in Crisis; 
Life at the Woodrow Wilson School, a Training Ground for Policy Wonks, After Sept. 11

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
LIKE a ghost, a stark, white reminder of the fallen World Trade Center stands over a corner of Princeton University.
 Aptly, Robertson Hall -- home to the university's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs and designed by the same architect responsible for the twin towers -- has a similar soaring lobby set behind arching columns. 
 These days, the resemblance is a reflection of the building's purpose, since the world finds itself turning to the Woodrow Wilson School and a handful of institutions like it that serve as training grounds for those whose job it will be to make sense of the world in the aftermath of Sept. 11.
Unfortunately, the Woodrow Wilson School finds itself in something of a bind. At a time when the United States is embroiled in a war against terrorism and needs experienced operatives on the ground, the Woodrow Wilson School -- by its own admission as well as those of academics at other schools -- is heavy on traditional scholarship and teaching. 
Richard Falk, who retired from Princeton last year after teaching international affairs for 40 years, said that the school had lost some of its strength in international relations over the years and had become "dominated by economists and by an economistic view."
"It has been a period in which, due to retirements and resignations, it has not sustained its strength in international relations," Mr. Falk said. "It used to be very strong, perhaps the strongest, in international relations."
And for his part, Joseph J. McCarthy, associate dean at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University -- which often competes with the Wilson school for the best students -- said he thought his institution was more real-world oriented. 
"If you were going to distinguish between the schools," said Mr. McCarthy, "our faculty, while it includes many people trained in the disciplines of economics and political science, also includes -- more so than the Woodrow Wilson School -- individuals from the world of policy, former senators, members of congress and the foreign service."
Indeed, before the economy began to cool the well-crammed heads of Woodrow Wilson students were being turned by lucrative salaries at consulting firms and investment banks.
Now, said Fred Hitz, the school's director of the Project on International Intelligence and a former inspector general of the Central Intelligence Agency, students are approaching him for help in starting careers at the agency.
"For a long time the C.I.A. and the government was really persona non grata on campus," said Mr. Hitz. "Students have awakened to the possibility of being of service, and that's music to my ears."
Shirley Tilghman, who was installed as Princeton's president in May and baptized by fire during the week of Sept. 11 -- which also was the first week of classes in her new tenure -- put it this way:
"What all of us are very conscious of since Sept. 11 is the importance of the school of public policy. We have seen a rekindling of student interest in public service. Students are interested in everything from R.O.T.C. to the C.I.A., and I think that's a very good and healthy sign that students see public service as a lofty goal."
That was echoed by Robert L. Hutchings, the assistant dean, who said he expected that the events of Sept. 11 would renew interest in government service.
"There's been a shift away from government to the nonprofit sector," said Dr. Hutchings, a former member of the National Security Agency and an ambassador at large to Eastern Europe. "Many students were averse to the unappealing bureaucracy in the U.S. government or the World Bank or the U.N. One effect of Sept. 11 was to show that if you want to be where the action is, if you want to influence big policy, then it's better to be in government than at a small nonprofit."
Founded in 1930, the school has produced thousands of influential alumni and has a reputation for offering a strong academic footing for those interested in careers in Washington or around the world.
Little more than a decade ago, Nicholas Rasmussen was a student at the Woodrow Wilson School working on simulations of a war between the United States and Russia; today he is a director of the National Security Council's office of combating terrorism.
"As I have gone through my career, I am continually running into alumni I know -- and people I didn't know were alumni -- at all levels of the government," said Mr. Rasmussen.
Anthony Lake, former assistant to President Bill Clinton for national security affairs and currently a professor at the Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University, had been a foreign service officer in Vietnam before enrolling at the Woodrow Wilson School.
Once there, he helped a professor write a book about the sociology of Vietnam that he said "helped me understand still more about the underlying reasons for what we were experiencing in Vietnam."
The school has 90 juniors and 90 seniors in the undergraduate program, while 65 students -- of the 600 who applied this semester alone -- are in each of its two-year master's of public administration classes. In addition, there are 30 students in a Ph.D. program and 20 in a new one-year mid-career program for public servants who have been in the field for at least seven years. That group includes a state legislator from Guadalajara, Mexico, a doctor from the Food and Drug Administration and a United Nations peacekeeping officer who had served in Ethiopia and Eritrea.
The school currently has 2,463 alumni working -- 8 percent work for foreign governments, 12 percent in the field of education, 18 percent work for the federal government and 19 percent work for nongovernmental organizations or multilateral agencies. The remainder -- about 43 percent -- were in such fields as law, urban planning, consulting, communications and finance. 
For now, James Trussell, the school's associate dean, said it was too soon to know if the terrorist attacks would generate more applications for next fall or a shift in student concentration from domestic to international affairs.
"There are trends in student interest over time," said Dr. Trussell, who has been at the school for 29 years. "As the country becomes more isolationist so do our students, and they shift away from international affairs. Sometimes there is a boom in students interested in domestic, and other times a boom in students interested in international. These are all cycles that wax and wane."
From 1902 to 1910, when Woodrow Wilson was president of the university, he envisioned the creation of a law school to specialize in training students for public service. But a special committee made up of lawyers felt a law school would defeat Wilson's idea of a broader education, according to a history of the school written by an alumnus, William K. Selden.
In 1930, the university decided to create a school as a memorial to Wilson, but did not name it for him until 1946, when its endowment was firmly established.
The school received a huge boost in 1961 when Charles Robertson -- a member of the Princeton class of 1926 who managed the investments of his wife, Marie, an heiress to the A&P grocery fortune -- donated $35 million. The endowment has since grown to $550 million.
"My parents wanted to make a significant gesture of philanthropy, and I think they wanted to address the current state of world affairs, which included the cold war and the threat from the Soviet Union," said their son, Bill Robertson. 
With the Robertsons' money, the school more than doubled the size of its graduate program to 40 students for each class, hired additional faculty members and built Robertson Hall, designed by Minoru Yamasaki. In 1979, Princeton's board allowed the endowment to be handled independent of the university's finances, and the younger Mr. Robertson, a 1972 Princeton graduate, manages the fund with a board trustees.
Of course, the endowment allows the school to lure top professors to Princeton, where many have joint appointments with the Wilson school.
To be sure, Stephen W. Bosworth, dean of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University in Boston said the Woodrow Wilson School was set apart from the other major public policy schools in two distinct ways: it was smaller, and it was very rich.
"They are affluent, to put it mildly," said Mr. Bosworth.
The institution's endowment also allows it to offer full scholarships to attract the best applicants. This year, students in the first year of the master's program -- who are paying $26,530 in tuition -- will receive a stipend of up to $13,000 for living expenses. Indeed, median financial aid to first-year master's students this year is $38,530.
That can make a difference in the shape of a career. Without a large burden of education loans, students can resist the more lucrative jobs in the private sector and instead accept a job in public service that could later grow into an influential policy position.
Kavita Ramdas, director of the Global Fund for Women, grew up in India and came to the Woodrow Wilson School on full scholarship.
"That's something the Woodrow Wilson School is well-known for," said Ms. Ramdas. "It makes it one of the more diverse graduate schools in public affairs because people who wouldn't be able to afford Princeton get a full scholarship."
Yet Mr. Bosworth, a former United States Ambassador to South Korea, said that having a faculty independent of the rest of the school had its advantages.
"We are in a position to set our own academic agenda and professional agenda in a way we could not if we did not have our own faculty," he said.
Sometimes the school's faculty -- by definition trained to look at events through a more cosmic prism -- can find itself at odds with the world around it.
For instance, Michael Rothschild, the dean of the school, was recently among three faculty members singled out in a report entitled "Defending Civilization: How Our Universities Are Failing American and What Can Be Done About It," prepared by the American Council of Trustees and Alumni in Washington -- a conservative nonprofit group devoted to curbing liberal tendencies in academia.
Mr. Rothschild was quoted at a town meeting on campus on Sept. 11 as saying: "There is a terrible and understandable desire to find and punish whoever was responsible for this. But as we think about it, it's very important for Americans to think about our own history, what we did in World War II to Japanese citizens by interning them."
Although the words of Mr. Rothschild -- one of 117 professors accused of unpatriotic behavior after Sept. 11 -- were held up by conservatives as proof that academia was out of step with the rest of the country, he said he had no regrets.
"I am a liberal," he said. "I am a card-carrying member of the A.C.L.U.
Zia U. Mian, a Pakistani lecturer at the school and a leader of the Princeton Peace Network, which has been critical of the American war in Afghanistan, tried to sum up the peace movement not only on the Princeton campus but at many leading universities around the country.
While Mr. Mian said it was "hard to be critical in a time of war and when thousands of innocent Americans have died," he did not hesitate to offer that "well-meaning mistakes" on the part of Americans might have contributed to the Islamic rage.
"Nobody really wants to talk about the fact that this is tied to the politics of oil in Saudi Arabia," he said.
Nonetheless, Mr. Rothschild said the school reflected all views, then quickly named off three left-leaning economists and three on the right.
"Is there a tilt?" he said. "I can't find it."
Defending the school's position in the universe of public policy institutions, Mr. Rothschild said it had a strong reputation as a feeder to national security and such multilateral agencies as the United Nations and the World Bank. In addition, he noted that it had been adding new centers to expand its policy expertise in other areas. 
For example, he said, "You just can't be a serious public policy school without an ability to understand health care."
Consequently Lee Silver, who taught microbiology for 17 years at Princeton, is now teaching at the Woodrow Wilson School's program in science, technology and environmental policy.
"I'm having the time of my life," said Dr. Silver. "It's been a whole new perspective on the world."
He said the disconnect was most evident in the early days of the recent anthrax scare.
"The Bush administration made a huge mistake when they did not contact scientists right away," Dr. Silver said. "They had no idea what they were talking about. It's a classic example."
Then there is Christina Paxson, director of the Wilson School's two-year-old Center for Health and Wellbeing, an economist who is trying to nurture interdisciplinary projects that go beyond the traditional health-policy work.
"The focus is on human wellbeing instead of looking at causes of specific diseases," Dr. Paxson said. "We're trying to look more broadly at determinants of emotional, mental and physical well-being."
Still, Mr. Mian said he thought the Woodrow Wilson School was at a disadvantage at the moment because it did not have a department devoted solely to Southeast Asia. While he acknowledged it would be difficult for the school to have every region of the world covered to that extent, he said, "The lack of programmatic depth is showing here."
For his part, Mr. Bosworth of Tufts -- a former United States Ambassador to South Korea -- also said the Woodrow Wilson School was known for putting academics ahead of practitioners.
Ultimately, however, he said it was difficult to compare the top public affairs school because each had its own emphasis.
"Harvard is large and focused on domestic policy," he said. "Fletcher graduates many students who go into international business. Woodrow Wilson is well-known for its emphasis on academics and public-service.
Mr. Rothschild admitted that the school's program was skewed heavily toward academics taught by experienced Princeton professors, though he said that in recent years it had been integrating more real-world practitioners into the school.
Of the handful of top-flight schools with expertise in diplomacy and international affairs, Dr. Hutchings said that the Woodrow Wilson School and Harvard's John F. Kennedy School were often compared.
"The quality of the education is similar, but the size and general feel of the place is quite different," he said.
For instance, he said that the Kennedy school "had an edge in bringing practicing experts to campus, while Woodrow Wilson's strength was in the quality of its teaching."
"In the public-policy arena, you really need people with strong theoretical training that is also linked to real-world public policy problems," Dr. Hutchings said. "I find it's easy to do one or the other, but to do both is a trick."
He agreed that "at the academic end of the spectrum, the quality of the faculty at the Woodrow Wilson School is unparalleled."
"Where we have to work harder," he said, "is to relate our work to real-world public policy issues."
For years, Mrs. Tilghman said, public policy education had focused largely on economics and political science.
"But one of the great strengths of the Wilson school is the much greater breadth of academic disciplines that impact on public policy," she said. "I would argue that's one of the great strengths of the school."
She said the Woodrow Wilson School has tended to be more fundamental, but that the direction of the school would be determined in large part by a new dean, whom she hoped to select by July.
After a tenure of six years, Mr. Rothschild, an economic theorist, announced this year that he would return to full-time research and teaching.
"I can think of nothing better," he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 10
