HEADLINE: A Mittenless Autumn, for Better and Worse 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK and ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Across the Northeast, people opened their doors yesterday to discover something unfamiliar: a chill in the air.
 Weeks later than usual, temperatures have finally descended into something like their normal late-December range. The cold snap followed an autumn in which sidewalk cafes stayed open into December, golf courses were packed with plaid and the first World Series game ever played in November felt more like May. The unseasonal curveball that the weather threw at the calendar affected almost everyone, for better and for worse. 
 Varel Bailey, a cattle and pig farmer in Anita, Iowa, has been spending 5 percent to 10 percent less on grain because cattle eat less when it is not cold. 
In New Mexico, Ski Santa Fe, a snow-starved resort, had to postpone its planned Thanksgiving Day opening to Dec. 8, and even now has less than half its skiing areas open.
In the natural world, daffodils bloomed, and the grass at the New York Botanical Garden was a lush green the week before Christmas. In Pennsylvania, a baby killdeer hatched in December instead of April. And in Massachusetts, Bill Davis, a state wildlife biologist, came home from a deer station one recent day with a sunburn.
"It's global warming, dude," said Pito Robles, 28, an auto mechanic who on Thursday was dangling his fishing line into the Hudson River near West 66th Street in Manhattan. "I don't care if the whole planet burns up in a hundred years. If I can get me a fish today, it's cool by me."
In fact, the warm spell that settled over much of the nation this fall may not be caused by global warming, the gradual but potentially calamitous rise in worldwide temperatures that most scientists attribute, at least in part, to fuel-burning human activities like making electricity and driving. When burned, fuels release carbon dioxide and other "greenhouse gases" that trap heat in the atmosphere.
The fall weather could have been a fluke, climatologists agree, because in the short run weather often does unanticipated things.
But the unusually balmy fall seems to fit at least two longer-term patterns. One is that the weather has become significantly more erratic and variable, and that is likely to continue, scientists say.
Another is that the warming trend is destined to continue. This year is expected to be the second warmest on earth since 1860, when temperatures were first measured systematically. Nine of the 10 warmest years have occurred since 1990. And one of the world's leading forecasting agencies, the Hadley Center for Climate Prediction and Research in Britain, says there is a 75 percent chance that next year will be even warmer than this year.
So far, the results of global warming in North America seem to be a mix of good and bad. Since 1960, New England has seen the last hard freeze come a day earlier every three years, extending the growing season. But in the Middle Atlantic and the South, shores are receding as seas, slowly raised by melting glaciers, eat away at coasts. 
And Alaska, where warming has been most pronounced, is undergoing a host of changes. Glaciers are receding, permafrost melting, shrubs spreading across previously barren tundra. The start of the Iditarod dog race this year had to be moved north because the trail near the usual starting point was too mushy.
But the growing variability of the weather may be as troublesome as the warming. This weekend, after a mittenless fall, temperatures are plummeting quickly across the country. And the prospect of a sudden, sustained cold snap is making many people uneasy.
Will birds that delayed their ritual migration be trapped up north by frigid weather? Will buds that bloomed in December's warm chicanery burst their pipes and suffer winter damage? 
"The party is almost over for people who like warm weather," said Jon B. Davis, a meteorologist for Salomon Smith Barney in Chicago. "Wednesday's 49 degrees in Chicago was probably the warmest we will see until late March. We are headed into a major-league cold pattern."

Labor and Industry
Even if this winter is about to earn its reputation, the fall's warm weather has made its mark -- economically, environmentally and in other ways.
It has been a boon to workers at the site of the World Trade Center disaster. Joe Bradley, the foreman of a crew of machine operators struggling to clear rubble at ground zero, said the mild weather allowed them to clean up the site quickly and to recover bodies they might not have otherwise found. 
"It gave us an opportunity to get the bulk of the work done," Mr. Bradley said. "It was a gift from God, a real miracle." 
Economically, the warm spell has cut both ways, benefiting some industries while hurting others. Warm weather, it turns out, may get people out of their houses, but not necessarily into stores. Foot traffic may have increased, retailers say, but people tend to window-shop. And they are not buying the winter supplies that stores have stocked. As a result, retailers have slashed prices on things like coats, scarves and gloves.
"Warm weather is not good for retailers," said Scott Bernhardt, senior vice president in charge of retail research at Planalytics, a consulting firm in Wayne, Pa., that provides long-range weather predictions and marketing advice to retailers. "A winter like this hurts because retailers don't plan on it." 
Snow shovel sales are down about two-thirds for the 7,200 hardware stores in the TruServ cooperative in Chicago, said Ray Winkel, its director of inventory management. But snow blowers are selling well. "Unlike snow shovels, they are not an impulse purchase, and people remembered what a tough winter last year was," Mr. Winkel said.
And other industries are clearly benefiting from the warmth. Scott Arves, president of Schneider National in Green Bay, Wis., the huge trucking company known for its orange fleet, said the mild weather had resulted in hundreds fewer accidents, lower maintenance costs and on-time delivery rates rare in late fall and winter, when a single storm can delay 1,000 Schneider trucks. 
Warm weather has depressed demand for natural gas, and, partly as a result, prices have fallen sharply -- to $2.60 per million B.T.U.'s of gas to be delivered next month, from $10 last winter. That has helped consumers in the upper Midwest, where gas provides 90 percent of the home heating energy.
In agriculture, the warmth has generally been welcome. Livestock farmers can buy less grain, not only because cows eat less in warm weather but also because breeding stock can stay out in the fields longer to forage. Grain farmers can expect to pay less for fertilizer, because natural gas is a major component.
In states like Florida, rising temperatures may change growing patterns. A 1989 freeze pushed the citrus belt south, said Jim Lushine, a National Weather Service meteorologist, but warmer weather may have the opposite effect. "We could see a return, a northward shift in some of the growing climates in Florida," he added, "and that might actually prove to be a boon for some people."

Flora and Fauna
Some plants and animals have reacted to the warm cycle as if it were a false spring.
Spring peepers are calling, woodpeckers and ruffed grouse have been drumming, said Mr. Davis, the wildlife biologist. More ticks seem to be active late into the year, he said. And in Montana, the Bitterroot Valley has been alive with butterflies that would normally be hibernating.
Most birds that migrate over long distances are not affected by the warmth because they would already have been in the tropics by September. But other species, like ducks and geese, which migrate shorter distances, have stayed north.
Two calliope hummingbirds were first spotted at Fort Tryon Park in Manhattan about a month ago, when they would ordinarily be in Mexico, and were still at the park last week. 
The birds that have stayed north could suffer if a sudden cold snap causes ponds and lakes to freeze, making food unavailable for several days, said Dr. Jeff Price, director of Climate Change Impact Studies for the American Bird Conservancy.
Deer may actually benefit from the warmth. The deer population got winter coats on time, but then was less active and consumed fewer calories because of the higher temperatures, Mr. Davis said, adding, "This sends them into winter in better condition to survive."
Many plants may not do as well. At the New York Botanical Garden, Dr. Kim Tripp, vice president for horticulture and living collections, said the prolonged warmth, coupled with a long drought, had left trees and other plants discombobulated and stressed. To survive the winter, Dr. Tripp said, plants have to go through a long process of shutting down: annuals die, perennials kill off their tops, deciduous plants shed their leaves, evergreens pump antifreeze into their needles.
"It's still October for the plants," she said. If it suddenly goes from October to January, water could freeze in the plants' cells and burst them. If the freeze hits anything that has actually flowered, it will not develop buds for next spring, she said.
Several years of these conditions could take a toll on trees, too. Mature canopy could be lost because such stress leaves trees more vulnerable to disease and insects.
"You fight off a cold better when you are healthy and vigorous," Dr. Tripp said. "When you are stressed your metabolism is slower and healing is slower."

The Outlook
Even if this past fall's warm weather was only a blip in the global thermostat, most scientists are beginning to believe that human alteration of the atmosphere is at least partly responsible for a warming trend that has been going on for decades.
"I think it's increasingly clear that humans are influencing the climate," said Dr. Peter H. Gleick, director of the Pacific Institute for Studies in Development, Environment and Security in Oakland, Calif. "I think the debate over whether the climate is going to change is over, and now the debate is what will the impacts be, how bad will they be and what should we do about it."
Dr. Edward S. Sarachik, a professor of atmospheric sciences at the University of Washington in Seattle, said it was especially significant that 2001 had proved so warm. Usually, the conditions in a single year are discounted by climate scientists because weather conditions vary naturally over short time spans, pushed this way or that by unpredictable shifts in sea temperatures and wind patterns. 
But in 2001 there was no such push -- in particular, no sign of El Nino, the ocean condition in which unusually warm waters spread across the Pacific. El Nino has exerted a powerful influence in many other recent unusually warm years, including 1998, the warmest year on record. But this year, the Pacific has just emerged from the opposite, cooler condition, La Nina.
A milder climate has short-term and long-term consequences for everything from water supplies to beaches.
Higher temperatures, for example, mean reduced snow melt from the Sierras, on which California's reservoirs depend.
"As the earth is warming, less of our precipitation will be snow and more will fall as rain, and that has a whole series of problems for us," Dr. Gleick said. "It means we're going to get more runoff in the winters when we're most worried about floods. And at the other end it means our spring and our summer runoff is going to be reduced -- and that's when we need it most."
In Alaska -- and much of Siberia -- the annual mean temperature has risen 3 to 5 degrees over the last 30 years, said Prof. Gunter Weller, director of the Cooperative Institute for Arctic Research at the University of Alaska at Fairbanks.
"There's no doubt over all that the Arctic has warmed pretty substantially, and that it's causing serious problems," Professor Weller said. Among the effects are increased coastal erosion from melting glaciers, which have raised the sea level in the region, and thawing in the permafrost that has wreaked havoc with roads and could eventually damage structures like the 800-mile-long trans-Alaska pipeline.
Elsewhere, continued warming could produce rising sea levels and more frequent and more severe storms. Seas will rise with temperatures because water expands as it warms, and because melting terrestrial ice will send water flowing into oceans. Hurricanes draw their energy from the heat in ocean waters, so warming could make them more frequent and more powerful.
The consequences would be most serious for the East and Gulf Coasts, which are lined with low-lying barrier islands. A rise of one to three feet in the sea level, which many scientists predict by the end of this century, could send sea water 100 feet or more inland on these stretches of coast, in communities where the federal government is spending tens of millions of dollars a year to pump sand onto shrinking beaches.
The new evidence of human-caused warming comes as the Bush administration is turning its attention back to climate change, which it had approached with skepticism and a determination to choose no remedies that might hinder the use of coal, oil and other fossil fuels.
Most notably, last March Mr. Bush rejected the Kyoto Protocol, the first international agreement that would require industrialized countries to cut emissions of greenhouse gases or face penalties. The last details were approved by almost every other major country at a meeting in November, although the treaty still awaits ratification.
In the next month or two, the Commerce Department, answering a request by Mr. Bush last summer, is planning to issue a new research plan aimed at improving United States climate monitoring and modeling efforts.
Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, is one of many from both parties in Congress seeking significant new efforts, especially climate research. 
"I have asked that consideration be given in the coming budget to increase activities," Mr. Stevens said, "to zero in on places where they know they can get some firm data and get some firm predictions."
Others in Congress are proposing bills to limit releases of carbon dioxide from power plants, but Mr. Bush rejected such a move last spring.
While officials debate how to deal with the phenomenon, temperatures continue to climb.
Along with whatever warming might be happening because of human activities, federal scientists say, the Pacific is emerging from its most recent cool spell and the warm waters of another El Nino are getting ready to spread.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS; 
A Scientific Search for Cougars

BYLINE:  By Bob Butz 

DATELINE: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. 

 BODY:
Wildlife officials have maintained that cougars have been extinct in Michigan for almost a century, but Dr. Patrick Rusz, without benefit of traps, a tranquilizer gun or a pack of yowling hounds, recently brought back evidence to the contrary.
 Schooled as a habitat biologist, Rusz serves as director of wildlife programs at the Michigan Wildlife Habitat Foundation. The foundation recently released his 64-page study, "The Cougar in Michigan: Sightings and Related Information," which outlined decades' worth of physical evidence, including sightings, plaster casts of tracks and even video footage. Still, it took Rusz, two college assistants and a handful of volunteers equipped with good hiking boots and a couple of boxes of resealable plastic bags to get the scientific proof. 
 The bags Rusz and his team brought home were filled with scat that DNA tests confirmed as coming from a cougar. Rusz located the evidence (along with numerous tracks and the remains of some deer that he suspects cougars killed) in two areas of the Upper Peninsula: along a 33-mile section of Lake Michigan shoreline near Seul Choix Point and in the deep woods north of Baraga, 100 miles away, closer to Lake Superior.
"I believe these cougars are what remains of a population that was never completely wiped out," Rusz said. "They are neither transients from the West or Canada nor released pets, but rather a small breeding population."
Florida is the only state east of the Mississippi known to harbor a breeding population of wild cougars. Elsewhere in the East, and specifically in heavily forested states like Pennsylvania and New York, efforts have yet to yield scientific evidence of cougars. Organizations have so far been relying on sightings and tracks that critics easily shrug off. Given the irrefutable results of fecal genetic analysis, a process refined only in the last decade, others might soon be taking Rusz's lead.
As for Rusz, he is prepared to begin a new search in Michigan's more densely populated Lower Peninsula.
"Until recently, all we had in the Lower Peninsula were tracks and sightings," he said in an interview.
Rusz presented still photos taken from a video given to him by a woman in Mesick, about 20 miles south of Traverse City and about halfway up the Lake Michigan coastline from the Indiana border. The photos are grainy, but the animal in the pictures, with its tawny hide and long tail, is clearly a cougar skulking through the maples in deep snow.
"Some Michigan Department of Natural Resources employees told her this was a house cat," Rusz said. He traveled to the site where the video was shot, and after comparing the photos and taking measurements of specific trees the cougar passed in the footage, determined the cat in the picture was close to 30 inches at the shoulder: clearly no barnyard kitty.
Dale Willey of Tower, roughly an hour's drive northeast of Traverse City, reported a young colt in his pasture killed by a cougar. He said he saw the cougar July 3 and later found signs of how the cat, after killing the 50-pound colt, had cleared a five-foot fence and dragged its prey into some nearby bushes to feed.
In cooperation with Rusz, Willey bulldozed a half-mile-long road along the edge of his property and checked it every other day for tracks. He found some on the 14th day, and Rusz later identified them as a cougar's.
"Reliable sightings have come in from the Fife Lake area in Wexford and Kalkaska County, the Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore and other spots around Traverse City," Rusz said. The next step is to expand his study to include these areas and find the cougar scat necessary to back up his beliefs.
The big question is when will somebody capture a cougar? For many who dismiss Rusz's work, a genuine cougar is the only thing that will sway them.
"But even those people won't be convinced," Rusz said. 
The latest naysayers contend that any cougars in the Michigan woods are probably released pets. A 1987 law, in accordance with the Endangered Species Act, prohibits private ownership of cougars. A Department of Natural Resources roster shows the names of roughly 20 people owning cougars grandfathered under the 1987 law, but most of these animals are dead and the rest in the waning years of old age. Further, preliminary DNA analysis of the scat samples Rusz found in the Upper Peninsula did not show any of the South American genotypes typically found in cougars kept as pets.
"It's really not hard to imagine cougars surviving up here," Rusz said. "You have to look at what the landscape was like 100 years ago, when killing a cougar was worth a sizable bounty. A century ago, hunters stayed away from areas that would have been hard to rout cougars from for simple economic reasons. In the dense swamps and outlying areas, the output of effort required to kill a cougar was just too much, and here is where cougars were able to hold on."
Rusz also believes that, like Florida's panthers, Michigan's cougars are probably suffering from decades of inbreeding. Although he thinks collaring a cougar is unnecessary, Rusz believes that somebody soon will. "Fecal analysis is cheap and can tell you almost as much as running a cat up a tree," he said. "Since cougars rarely stray from their established home range, unless the cat is a transient male, all collaring a cougar would show is it moving around its territory. With further fecal analysis we can determine the sex of a cougar, even whether or not there are troubles with inbreeding."
If cougars do exist in Michigan, they are protected by the Endangered Species Act and cannot be hunted, trapped or harassed. Capturing a cougar is not part of Rusz's immediate plan, but he is applying for an official scientific collector's permit. Since the results of his study were released, Rusz has secured scat samples in the more densely populated Lower Peninsula and is awaiting test results that could show that cougars are closer than anyone ever imagined.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
A Shy Ramirez Tries to Find His Comfort Zone

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The first priority of the new Boston Red Sox owners should be a campaign. Call it "Make Manny Mine."
 John Henry, the incoming managing partner, could initiate it. Larry Lucchino, who will be the team's president and chief executive officer, could carry it out. Besides giving Manny Ramirez his $15.5 million salary next season, the new boys on the block can listen to their silent star's agent and do whatever is necessary to make him comfortable. 
 "When Manny signed with the Red Sox, we knew there would be an adjustment period," Jeff Moorad, Ramirez's agent, said last week. "The truth is the adjustment is continuing." 
For $160 million over eight years, give or take a few deferred dollars, the Red Sox have reason to expect Ramirez to have completed his adjustment already. But it may not be possible for him to reach that stage of satisfaction until certain steps are taken.
Moorad initially revealed Ramirez's concerns during the winter meetings in Boston earlier this month. He said the outfielder, in his first season with the Red Sox, was forced to assume a role as team spokesman, which he never had to be in his seven seasons in Cleveland. He blamed it on the layout of the team's clubhouse at Fenway Park.
The clubhouse, smaller than the facilities at newer parks, apparently deprived the shy Ramirez of the privacy he craves and enjoyed in Cleveland. When he switched from the Indians to the Red Sox, he left his comfort zone behind.
"Manny performs best in a relaxed environment, and it was anything but that last year," Moorad said in Boston. "It's no secret that the Cleveland Indians allowed him to sneak out the clubhouse door, and often he was the first one out of the clubhouse."
Before consulting the incoming owners, Dan Duquette, the Red Sox general manager, at least for now, said he was looking at some changes in the clubhouse.
Moorad suggested the possibility of separate press areas.
"It was not an easy decision for Manny to leave the Indians last off-season," Moorad said in an interview the other day. "Yet there was a burning desire on his part to take on a new challenge. Needless to say, in that respect, he's been challenged and he'll continue to be challenged. But along the way he is adjusting to his new environment in Boston."
Ramirez could have avoided many of the problems he encountered by remaining with the Indians, whose contract offer sported a higher number -- $171 million -- but a lower present-day value because of the amount of deferred money in the deal. But money isn't everything, as Ramirez has learned. Money minus comfort equals less enjoyment.
Ramirez might have had reasons for leaving Cleveland; he was said, for example, to have been bothered by comments the Indians' owner made questioning his desire to play. But, Ramirez, a New York native, grew up with the Indians and had a comfort zone in the Indians' clubhouse despite the turmoil created by Albert Belle and others.
Some agents, perhaps not many, try for a combination of money and happiness for their clients. They would settle for a smaller contract if they feel the player would be better off in a particular place.
"Ron Shapiro put players where they're comfortable," one executive said, citing Kirby Puckett with Minnesota and Cal Ripken with Baltimore. "They could have got more money elsewhere."
If Ramirez is not comfortable in Boston, he might want to take it up with his agent, not the Red Sox.

A Controversial Agent
Jeff Moorad has become one of the most controversial agents in the business, or more aptly, one of the most disliked. He has been widely accused of stealing players from other agents.
Players often change agents, but Moorad's critics say he uses what associates referred to as gofers to lure players to him. The associates, a baseball official said, receive as much as 30 percent of Moorad's fees from contracts signed by players they deliver to him. One of Moorad's gofers, two other agents said, is Orlando Cepeda Jr., son of the Hall of Famer.
One agent told of another agent confronting Moorad in an elevator at the recent winter meetings in Boston, saying, "You're the guy who's going around trying to steal everyone's clients."
Moorad declined to discuss the accusations. "I don't have anything to say," he said.
Manny Ramirez, Juan Gonzalez and Raul Mondesi are among the players who have left other agents for Moorad. Moorad landed Mondesi, a baseball lawyer related, after his former agent, Tom Reich, negotiated a four-year, $36 million contract with Los Angeles in 1998 but before Mondesi signed it. Moorad, the lawyer said, claimed he was entitled to the fee.
The dispute went to the players association, which certifies and monitors agents, but did not get to a hearing because union officials convinced Moorad that he had no case and Reich was entitled to the fee.
Earlier this year, a club official said, Moorad tried to lure Jason Giambi from Arn Tellem through Giambi's brother, Jeremy. His selling point, the official said, was the contract he got Ramirez with Boston.

New Challenge for Lucchino
Seven men sat in a Boston hotel room as day turned into evening last Thursday, growing increasingly pessimistic with each passing hour. They were waiting to hear if they had succeeded or struck out in their bid to buy the Red Sox.
"When we heard that a statement was coming, we made a dollar bet on what would happen," Larry Lucchino said. "No one in the room bet on us. We hadn't had any communication during the day, and we expected that if something happened, they'd have gotten to us early and given us a warning."
But they all lost their bets because they, the John Henry group, were declared the winners. What's $7 to a group of men who bid $660 million?
The development puts Lucchino in position to become president and chief executive officer of a third major league club and presents him with probably his greatest challenge: beating the Yankees and overseeing the first World Series championship for the Red Sox since 1918. 
"Oh-three," Lucchino said. "There is something special about '03 coming up. They won in '03."
Indeed, the Red Sox, nee the Pilgrims, won the first World Series in 1903, and their second season under the Henry group will mark the 100th anniversary of that season. 
Another challenge will be the future of Fenway Park. Lucchino has become adept at developing new parks, Camden Yards in Baltimore, one in the early stages of construction in San Diego, and now he gets a chance to work on renovating and expanding 90-year-old Fenway.

Trading Options
Fortunately for them they did not have to travel to the cities whose teams acquired them.
The Colorado Rockies obtained infielder Pokey Reese from Cincinnati last Tuesday, then traded him to Boston for catcher Scott Hatteberg last Wednesday. The next day, the Rockies opted not to tender Hatteberg a contract, making him a free agent.
Philadelphia acquired pitcher John Wasdin from Baltimore Dec. 13 and a week later did not tender him a contract, making him a free agent.
Among the 34 players not tendered contracts, the most interesting is Rick Helling, a 20-game winner for Texas in 1998. The Rangers let him go only two weeks after he attended his first union executive board meeting as the American League player representative, succeeding David Cone.

Selig Edits Himself
When the blue-ribbon panel report on baseball economics was released 17 months ago, there were reports that Commissioner Bud Selig had sent back the panel's drafts several times before the four members turned in a draft acceptable to him. Selig denied the reports.
What to think, then, when during his testimony at a House Judiciary Committee hearing earlier this month the commissioner mentioned the report and added "which I put together."
Asked about the statement the other day, Selig corrected himself. "I put together the blue-ribbon committee," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Manny Ramirez said the layout of the Boston clubhouse deprived him of the privacy he enjoyed in Cleveland. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Discord Delays Choice of Interim Leader for Argentina 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 

 BODY:
The Argentine Congress was deadlocked tonight as it attempted to ratify a new president who will serve until presidential elections are held. But the eventual leadership change is likely to be the easy part in dealing with the mounting economic crisis.
 Most economists predict that the new interim president will, in the next few weeks, preside over the largest debt default in history and a potentially chaotic devaluation, which could ignite large-scale inflation if not handled smartly. 
 Gov. Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, who was chosen by Justicialist Partyleaders on Friday, was supposed to be ratified easily tonight to serve until presidential elections can be held March 3. But back room negotiations between various parties broke down over the timing and rules for a new election. Distinguished guests arrived at the presidential palace for an inauguration early this evening, only to find out that there still was not a new president. 
Nevertheless Mr. Rodriguez Saa was still considered to be the strong favorite to emerge as the new leader in a vote by a joint session of Congress scheduled for Sunday. The governor, until recently not a major player on the national scene, called this week for "the suspension of payments of the public debt until all Argentines have a job," suggesting that he could rule as a populist, at least in oratory. "I will govern for the most humble and for those who suffer," he said.
But he also indicated that he would like to retain the decade-old policy of pegging the value of the peso to the dollar, even though most economists here and on Wall Street say Argentina will be forced to let the peso float to a level of about one-half its current value. For years, the peg was an effective weapon against inflation. However later it began to have ill consequences, making Argentine goods, reflecting the strong dollar, too costly on world markets.
Before any devaluation, aides to Mr. Rodriguez Saa say, he will print scrip money in the form of low-interest bonds to pay government salaries and inject money into the sagging economy.
Mr. Rodriguez Saa, 54, a lawyer and accomplished bridge player known among his friends for his passion for neatness and punctuality, has kept San Luis Province's finances in order during 18 years as governor, but he has no experience commensurate to running South America's second-largest economy.
He or another leader might be able to pull it off, but it will not be easy, economists say.
Whoever is chosen will almost certainly be a member of the Justicialist Party, which controls Congress, and therefore can expected to have ample legislative support. He will also stand to benefit from the good will of an anxious public because no one can blame him for the crisis.
The Bush administration may try to help the future president in an effort to protect Argentina's democratic institutions, and the International Monetary Fund could be enticed to come up with what would be its 14th emergency bailout package since civilian rulers replaced a military junta in 1983. France has already called on international financial institutions, which turned off the loan spigots to Argentina in recent weeks, to reopen talks with Buenos Aires. And Italy, another source of investment here, restored lines of credit to Argentina on Friday.
Because the future president may govern for as little as three months, he will probably be able to do many things without worrying about disenchanting the electorate.
Most Justicialist leaders, who were in the opposition until Fernando de la Rua resigned the presidency on Thursday, have said the country must halt payments on the $132 billion public sector debt and free itself from the currency bind. "We have to tell the people the truth," said Gov. Nestor Kirchner of Santa Cruz Province, an influential Justicialist. "The country is broke and cannot meet its debt obligations. Our mission now is to reinstall confidence by governing with popular support."
The deepening economic crisis that forced Mr. de la Rua to resign has much to do with a slowing world economy and declining agricultural export prices, which no Argentine government can control. Restive labor unions and groups of unemployed workers have staged numerous strikes and highway blockades, slowing the economy even more.
During the last three months, industrial production, consumer sales and tax receipts have declined by more than 15 percent from a year earlier. Economists project that the economy, which is expected to shrink by 3.5 percent this year, will decline by a further 7 percent or more in the first half of 2002.
Many economists predict that the future president, to keep the government afloat, will be forced to seize dollar-denominated bank accounts and to give less valuable pesos back to the depositors after a devaluation. Should the devaluation be as sharp as some Wall Street analysts have predicted, per capita income, which has fallen by 14 percent in the last four years, could plunge by another 20 percent or 30 percent. 
If releasing the Argentine peso from its dollar anchor were a magic bullet that could solve all of the country's woes, the previous government would have done it. But a devaluation has many risks. Eighty percent of the country's loans are in dollars, meaning that people and businesses whose peso earnings will decrease in value will find it harder to meet their dollar interest obligations.
Many Justicialist economists have proposed to devalue the loans as well, by turning the dollar debts into pesos by mandate. That would help many borrowers, but it would hurt the banks, which are already in trouble, making lending more difficult. 
There could be other economically important losers. Medium-size and large Argentine businesses that depend on bond sales abroad would not benefit from a loan devaluation, because foreign lenders would probably be unwilling to go along with such a scheme. But the goods they sold would still be priced in pesos -- much devalued pesos.
Business bankruptcies, which have risen sharply in recent months, would be likely to increase further, throwing more people out of work.
A devaluation might also set off another wave of hyperinflation, a familiar Argentine woe before the peso was pegged to the dollar in 1991.
The new government could decide to drop the peso altogether for the dollar, but such a shift, without a devaluation, would not help solve Argentina's lack of competitiveness on world markets. And a third possibility is a devaluation followed by "dollarization" as a brake on a currency free fall.
All the options promise to produce months of confusion and years of legal battles between lenders and borrowers. This week, the Wall Street analysts that Argentina must win over in order to regain flows of foreign capital were decidedly pessimistic about the future.
"I expect a disorderly default process," David Malpass, a senior analyst at Bear, Stearns, said on Friday.
"The resignation of President de la Rua and the imposition of a bank holiday," a Credit Suisse First Boston report said, "signal a period of intense political turmoil and escalating civil unrest, a deeper economic collapse, imminent default and indefinite debt moratorium and the likely total loss of control of the currency."

HEADLINE: Downtown Is Slower to Embrace Optimism; 
Uneasiness and Worries Persist for Many Residents and Workers

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
The subterranean fires have subsided and the breeze no longer carries a sickly odor, but in the shadowed canyons of Wall Street and the lazy side streets of TriBeCa, the veneer of normalcy is not what it seems.
 There is a stubborn malaise afflicting Chinatown's sidewalk vendors, worried about lackluster sales, and the black-jacketed barkers of Little Italy, frantically trying to fill empty restaurants. In Battery Park City, it is the unnerving sight of yet another moving van or the silence of once-teeming playgrounds. It is visible in the jittery knot of office workers smoking outside 40 Broad Street, flinching when a crate loudly crashes off the back of a truck. It can be felt in the desperate solicitations of a downtown day care center, forced to lay off half its teachers, begging the public for donations. 
 With holiday crowds mobbing Times Square and Rockefeller Center, it sometimes feels as if the rest of the city has moved on in its quest for closure. For many New Yorkers, the scar tissue has already begun to form. But here on streets that abruptly end at ground zero, a place still piled high with debris and human remains, the laughter is more subdued, the atmosphere almost funereal. 
To be sure, three months after it was blanketed with smoke and choking ash, Lower Manhattan has largely returned to its former harried self. Gone are the National Guardsmen who stood sentinel at the avenues below Canal Street, checking ID's. Most businesses in the area formerly known as the frozen zone have reopened. Some of SoHo's most stylish restaurants, once eerily empty, are happily turning away diners on Saturday nights. 
"The pessimism has lifted and there's a joyousness in the air," said Ashley Massie, 32, a Stuyvesant High School teacher and Battery Park City resident who almost moved away. "For the first time in months, we feel like we can live again."
But for every optimist, there are a dozen pessimists still fitful and sad, uncertain whether their beloved neighborhoods will fully recover. Take Ray Wong, for example, an inveterate downtowner who has been beseeching his neighbors to stay put.
Born and raised near the South Street Seaport, Mr. Wong, 29, has always lived in the shadow of the World Trade Center, a comforting beacon whose birth and maturation mirrored his own. One of Mr. Wong's earliest memories, he said, was the sight of a helicopter affixing the giant antenna atop the north tower to ensure high-quality television transmission. As a child, he and his friends played tag in the trade center's underground shopping concourse. His first kiss was savored in the windswept plaza that anchored the two towers.
"I loved, loved, loved downtown," he said last week, pausing on the Hudson River esplanade as he walked his two dachshunds, a pair of yellow-tinted sunglasses shielding his eyes. "I never wanted to live anywhere else."
Yet with shame and sorrow, Mr. Wong admits he might be joining the exodus from Battery Park City. His melancholy can be measured by the score of friends who have already left, and by the growing piles of takeout menus that litter the doorsteps of departed neighbors. At night, his heart sinks when he looks out on the darkened windows around him.
"I'm a little messed up still," he said, as a truck dumped its scorched payload into a waiting barge. "My favorite restaurants on Vesey Street are gone. My building is half empty. The energy is gone. The community I loved is gone."
For outsiders, such changes are nearly invisible, at least beyond the carnage of ground zero. Water trucks that spray down the soot-covered streets every hour or so are just a curiosity. To them, the onslaught of "50 percent off" banners are not a sign of economic distress, but an opportunity to shop. In the financial district, where a tourist from Kansas City might see packed sidewalks and giddy Christmas cheer, Naeem Sheikh, the owner of a nut and fragrance store on Nassau Street, sees something more ominous. It is 5 p.m. and the pavement surges with office workers, but Mr. Sheikh sits alone in his empty shop and wrings his hands.
"Look at them rushing to go home," he said. "People feel scared. They don't want to spend money here. I used to employ three people. Now I have nothing to do." 
The vulnerability felt by many Americans is not an abstraction downtown, where workers and residents still choke up when describing their wounded psyches. The unease intensifies closer to ground zero, especially for those who lived through the smoke and blackness and terror of that morning. To them, Midtown feels like a soothing refuge. 
Oz Rosario, 25, a sales representative for a telecommunications company, visits clients all over the city but feels his gut tighten when he returns to his office on Broad Street. "It's especially eerie in the morning, when you come to work and the streets are so quiet," he said, a few paces from the New York Stock Exchange, with its maze of metal barricades. "Uptown, people are more relaxed. Here, everyone has a much shorter fuse." 
For Robert Brown, who serves lattes to customers on Wall Street, the fear has become oppressive. "I don't want to work down here anymore," he said from behind the counter at Timothy's Coffee. "You never know what's going to happen." 
Everyone is yearning for a more humdrum past. Some are wistful for the cacophonous gridlock of Wall Street, now off limits to cars, while others wish tourists would stop photographing the scenes of destruction. The endless detours, the police on every other corner and the inability to have lunch delivered are all irksome reminders of life out of whack.
Sometimes gruff and unyielding traffic officers make Krista Bojanowski cry as she tries to navigate the street closings on her drive home. "I know it's for my own safety, but they change the blockades every day," said Ms. Bojanowski, 27, a nanny who lives on Exchange Place. "I just want my old life back."
Still, most people express optimism, even if their voices are edged with apprehension. "Life goes on," they say with a shrug. "Time heals all wounds."
For some, especially residents, anger and frustration have largely replaced the fear of future attacks. Many worry about the air they have been breathing, a concern raucously driven home last Tuesday in City Hall Park, where dozens rallied to demand answers from a government they view as uncaring.
Maria Marra, 37, a commercial real estate broker, said she looked at two dozen apartments before deciding to remain in her home on Chambers Street. Her love for the neighborhood -- and a 30 percent rent reduction from her landlord, she said -- helped change her mind. "I'm glad I stayed," she said. "But I worry about the air, and worry that I might regret that decision 10 years from now."
Still, the stalwarts insist that downtown will recover. They shield their eyes from the disturbing nighttime glow of ground zero or look away when the trucks, laden with twisted girders, rumble up West Street. Some even try to relish the newfound tranquillity on streets drained of traffic.
"Ironically, with fewer people and cars, the neighborhood feels like it used to and our quality of life is better than it has been in years," said Robert Lyons, 42, a theater director who lives on Wooster Street.
For Ms. Massie, the teacher, it means free on-street parking. "It's awesome because I save the $250 a month I used to spend on a garage," she said. 
While most downtown businesses are still ailing, the somber ground zero pilgrimage has produced a windfall, especially for those hawking 9/11 memorabilia. Cindy Taylor, whose bakery on Chambers Street used to be nearly empty on weekends, is thankful for the tourists and recovery workers who have offset the loss of displaced workers.
"I'm almost embarrassed to say, but my business has doubled," she said before racing back to the kitchen. 
Then there is the surge in kindness and camaraderie that persists. Former strangers are on a first-name basis, and "How are you?" is still offered with earnestness.
"You see people at the dry cleaner and you feel a sense of relief that they're still here," said Suzanne Tinley, a 14-year resident of Greenwich Street, as she walked home with her two children. "A lot of people who came here because it was trendy TriBeCa have left. More than ever, those of us who stayed feel like this is our home and that we're in it together." 
Those who work in Lower Manhattan's skyscrapers have little choice but to stay. At 2 World Financial Center, where almost everyone lost a friend or business associate, the brokers and analysts try not to glance out the windows facing east. When the Merrill Lynch workers come down for their cigarette breaks, they hover beneath the building's sheltered entrance, their backs to the expanse of rubble behind them.
Sharon Doucette, a senior project manager, does one better: she walks around the corner and stands alone on the western side of the building, braving an icy wind off the river.
"I'm trying to avoid looking at it," she said, using her head to gesture to the unseen. "I'm trying to move on, trying to adapt."
Just then a band of tourists, their faces blank, passed by and Ms. Doucette seemed to absorb their gravity, at least for a moment. "We'll all get through this," Ms. Doucette said, stamping her feet against the damp chill. "I know we will."

HEADLINE: DECEMBER 16-22: CONGRESS; 
CONGRESSIONAL ROUNDUP

BYLINE:  By Adam Clymer

 BODY:
 Congress went home playing the blame game over who killed the economic stimulus package, but first it passed a rewrite of aid to education to put more money into schools in poor areas and test annually to see results. It also agreed to more base-closings, raised military pay by at least 5 percent, and added $8.3 billion to homeland defense and $8.2 billion for New York reconstruction aid -- more than President Bush sought.

HEADLINE: DECEMBER 16-22: NATIONAL; 
KILLINGS RISING

BYLINE:  By Fox Butterfield

 BODY:
 In what may be a leading indicator that crime is starting to increase again, after a nearly decade-long decline, homicides in many big cities have increased sharply. 
The rise was led by Boston and Phoenix, which both have had a greater than 60 percent jump in homicides so far this year. Not all cities are up -- in New York, homicides have fallen 5.2 percent. But police chiefs worry that several factors may be pushing violent crime up: rising unemployment, a growing number of inmates being released from the nation's expanded prison system, and a new surge in domestic killings. Fox Butterfield

HEADLINE: Imagine; 
Headlines From the Cutting Room Floor

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

 BODY:
THE world did not stop on Sept. 11; it only seemed that way. Many people, riveted by the extraordinary, paid little attention to anything else. 
 Life went on, of course. Argentina is in trouble, the Yankees lost the World Series, the Democrats and Republicans are fighting about everything but terrorism, and V. S. Naipaul won the Nobel Prize. Muggles in droves went to the Harry Potter movie. 
 What follows is a selection, arbitrary and incomplete, of some of the events of the past 100 days that were overlooked or that might have played out differently had the world's gaze not been fixed on terrorism.

The Higher Cost of Drugs
From George W. Bush to Edward M. Kennedy, there was widespread agreement in the 2000 campaign that the nation's elderly badly needed some assistance to cope with the soaring costs of prescription drugs. Nobody thought it would be easy to enact that benefit, but 2001 was considered the most auspicious year.
That changed in September, when terrorism and a slowing economy transformed the agenda in Washington and created some grim new budgetary realities. Creating a substantial prescription drug benefit for a group that uses more drugs than any other is an expensive proposition. As the surplus slipped away, lawmakers quickly realized that prescription drug benefits -- like so much else on the domestic agenda -- were too.
Health advocates had also hoped to provide new assistance for the nation's uninsured, who numbered just under 40 million last year. That effort also failed, even as experts warned that the recession would leave many more Americans without insurance. 
Now, many experts are warning of a health care crisis, a "perfect storm," as one study put it, fueled by soaring increases in health care costs and a wave of layoffs. Governors, meanwhile, are warning that the basic safety net program for low-income people -- Medicaid -- is under immense pressure as well, and have pleaded for help from the federal government.
 ROBIN TONER

HEADLINE: Imagine; 
Raiding the Lockbox

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
Remember the Social Security lockbox? 
 It was not long ago that both parties in Washington swore on all that is holy not to touch the portion of the federal budget surplus generated by the retirement system. To do so would invite certain political death. 
 Now, with the nation mired in a full-scale recession, the first in a decade, and President Bush having gotten his $1.35 trillion tax cut, the surplus has turned into an almost-certain deficit for the next few years. The lockbox has been broken open. 
The goal of paying off the national debt now seems unrealistic. Both parties will have to shelve their more ambitious and expensive proposals, like overhauling Social Security. In addition, Democrats will have to decide whether to stick to their Clinton-era position that fiscal responsibility brings benefits in the form of lower long-term interest rates, and Republicans will have to decide whether they are willing to accept chronic budget deficits as the price of higher defense spending and continued tax cuts.
 RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: Into That Darkness, Again 

BYLINE:  By Gabriel Schoenfeld; Gabriel Schoenfeld is the senior editor of Commentary magazine.

 BODY:
 THE HEALING WOUND
Experiences and Reflections
on Germany, 1938-2001.
By Gitta Sereny.
Illustrated. 386 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95.
 Gitta Sereny, a writer perhaps best known for her extraordinary 1995 biography of Albert Speer, has spent most of her 78 years attempting to understand human evil. As we learn from this collection of essays, some of them autobiographical, this preoccupation came to her naturally enough.
Of Hungarian-German parentage and raised as a Protestant, Sereny was a precocious 15-year-old in Vienna when Hitler annexed Austria in 1938. Her mother traveled in Jewish circles, and young Gitta, whose father had died when she was 2, saw the unfolding terror firsthand. Unlike so many Austrians, she tells us, she did not jeer at the Jews on their hands and knees forced to scrub the pavement with toothbrushes; on one such occasion, she even impetuously risked her life to intervene. Not long after that harrowing episode, with her mother under threat for her engagement to a Jew -- the economist Ludwig von Mises -- the two fled to Switzerland. 
Placed in a finishing school, Sereny soon ran away and made her way to Paris. She was all of 17 when, with the fall of France, she found herself living under Nazi occupation, working as a volunteer nurse with orphaned children and hiding an occasional British airman for the Resistance. Tipped off to her imminent arrest, she crossed the Pyrenees on foot, and then the Atlantic by boat to the United States. Only near the war's end did she return to Europe as a child-welfare officer for the United Nations, working with the shattered children freshly liberated from Nazi imprisonment at Dachau. 
Wrenching as this assignment was, the next was more so. The Nazis had spent the war years scouring occupied Eastern Europe for "racially valuable children" for their Lebensborn program, whose purpose was to augment the German genetic stock. These they simply kidnapped by the hundreds of thousands, appraising them according to 62 pseudoscientific criteria, murdering many of the "deficient" ones in extermination camps and placing those deemed Aryan in the hands of unwitting German families seeking to adopt. One of Sereny's duties was to track down these "adoptees" and return them, where possible, to their natural parents. 
The actual task of separation, Sereny writes in "The Healing Wound," was "never anything but traumatic. I only had to do it once, and I will never forget the inconsolable grief of the couple who loved the 5-year-old I had to take away, and the uncomprehending wild anger of the child himself, who had no memory of his birth parents or native language and for whom the German parents were his world."
Exposed to so much misery, stunned by the magnitude of Nazi iniquity, Sereny set out in 1947 to try to account for all the horror. Over the next decades, as a journalist based in England, she came to write essays and books that would bring her even deeper into the interior of Nazi evil. This book includes selections from these works: mostly biographical sketches, thoroughly researched and supplemented by interviews, of Nazis and their collaborators, ranging from Leni Riefenstahl, Hitler's favorite filmmaker, to John Demjanjuk, the concentration camp guard who settled in Cleveland. 
In her snapshot of Riefenstahl, one sees Sereny in a typical mode. She converses politely with the aging filmmaker, drawing her out about her childhood, her sexual escapades, her artistry, while never losing sight of her as a target. Then, at a natural moment in the conversation, Sereny quietly springs her trap, confronting Riefenstahl with documents that demonstrate something she has always denied: her own immersion in, and promotion of, murderous anti-Semitic hatred. The result is only more denial -- but the exchange is dramatic all the same. "When she is honest," Sereny concludes in this dialogue interspersed with her own commentary, Riefenstahl "is very likable" -- but about the things that count, Sereny also shows, she has never been honest. 
Another figure whom Sereny sought out, more directly culpable than Riefenstahl, was Franz Stangl, who in 1970 was sentenced to life in prison by a German court for his role as commandant of Sobibor and Treblinka, where he had personally overseen the murder of over a million Jews. To Sereny, he appeared to be the one perpetrator who possessed "a semblance of moral awareness," and who therefore might be able to reveal something about the "inner lives" of those who carried out the Nazi enormity.
Sereny's exchange with Stangl, excerpted from her 1974 book, "Into That Darkness," is transfixing. Step by step, she leads him to recount the web of circumstances that brought him to his gruesome assignment, and elicits from him comments about his work. Initially, he confides to her, it was arduous -- the smell of "the hundreds, no, the thousands of bodies everywhere, putrefying, decomposing," was "indescribable" -- but presently it settled into routine. Processing a morning's round, a transport of perhaps 5,000 Jews -- unloading them, stripping, searching and shaving them, herding them down what the SS mockingly called the "Road to Heaven" and into the gas chambers, then burning their corpses on massive iron racks -- was "normally dealt with in two or three hours. At 12," Stangl informed Sereny, "I had lunch and after that about half an hour's rest. Then another round and more work in the office." 
Unblinkingly conversing with mass murderers, Sereny writes about Nazism with urgency and grace and fidelity to historical fact, and she is clearly a woman of some courage. Yet despite these commendable qualities, her mind is not consistently a match for the moral immensity of her subject.
After decades spent probing for some "new truth" about the men who slaughtered millions, Sereny is strikingly unable to convey what she has learned. Offering some thinly considered platitudes about the ills of "racism," she speaks about the Nazi gas chambers in the same breath as "the disproportionate number of blacks on death row in America" and "the apparent unwillingness of the rich white West to supply poor black Africa" with medication for AIDS. This conjunction of incommensurables echoes the self-exculpatory refrain emitted by the various accused and convicted war criminals themselves, including Stangl. 
The former United Nations secretary general Kurt Waldheim also appears in "The Healing Wound." Pressed by Sereny in an interview about his role as a Wehrmacht intelligence officer in the Balkans and Greece, he explains helpfully that it was a "savage war," like "Vietnam, and now the West Bank," where the Israelis "are breaking people's bones." Ineffectively challenging such remarks, Sereny goes on to judge Waldheim a "fundamentally decent man." 
Worse, Sereny does not merely confine herself to hearing out witnesses but sometimes appears to have set herself the task of engaging in a personal mission of salvation. In her dealings with Stangl, she speaks, largely on the basis of his contorted facial expressions, of his "intense desire to seek and tell the truth," and she permits his "despair" and "hopeless grief" to evoke in her "an instant of sympathy." Passages in "Into That Darkness" that are not reprinted here tell of how she brought a "special soup" to his prison cell that made him feel "wonderful"; by confessing to her, she wrote, he was able, at least for "a fleeting moment," to become "the man he should have been." 
Such passages bring to mind something that Adolf Eichmann once said in a moment of boastfulness: "I will leap into my grave laughing because the feeling that I have five million Jews on my conscience gives me extraordinary satisfaction." Sereny seems constitutionally incapable of assimilating a sentiment like that, let alone of grasping, after a lifetime of studying it, the radical nature of Nazi evil. Her chapter on Stangl, entitled "Colloquy With a Conscience," records a vain attempt to help one of history's worst criminals to cease "blocking" his own "acknowledgment of personal guilt," and thereby realize himself as a more complete human being. At such times, she enters into complicity with Stangl's own well-developed powers of self-pity and evasiveness, becoming in effect an agent of redemption for the irredeemable. 
How came such a manifestly astute and well-intentioned woman to compromise herself in this way? She herself provides a hint. Visiting Rome after her talks with Stangl, still tormented by the encounter, she spoke with "a kind bishop" at the Vatican. "If one exposes oneself to the devil," the bishop warned her, "he can invade one. Be careful, my child," he said.

HEADLINE: A Surge in Controversy for Power Proposal 

BYLINE:  By GARY SANTANIELLO 

 BODY:
FAIRFIELD COUNTY may be the engine of Connecticut's economic growth, but a few cities and towns in this critical corridor are challenging Connecticut Light and Power Company's current proposal to provide it with more power.
 C. L. and P., a subsidiary of Northeast Utilities, wants to upgrade transmission capacity in the state's most populous county by adding a 345,000-kilovolt (kV) line from Bethel south to Norwalk along the existing 20-mile right of way. 
 The upgrade, which runs through Redding, Weston and Wilton, would require much taller transmission poles and a wider right of way. That change, opponents say, would affect the appearance of the largely rural area and possibly have a negative affect on the adjacent natural environment, such as the waterways, vegetation and wildlife.
Its overall impact, said State Rep. Toni Boucher, a Republican of Wilton, is outside of expanding Route 7, "the most controversial local issue we've had in a while. This is not about not wanting additional capacity. It's about how to do it without damaging the environment. 
"This is a bad proposal for many reasons," she added. "There has to be another way."
Citing an October 2001 report from I.S.O.-New England, a not-for-profit corporation that manages the bulk generation and transmission of electricity in New England, C. L. and P. said that transmission bottlenecks cost New England consumers $125 million to $600 million annually, and congestion is most acute in southwestern Connecticut. It maintains that a new 345-kV line will provide Fairfield County reliable access to lower-priced energy from throughout the New England power grid well into the future.
Opponents contend the company is overstating power needs, minimizing the proposal's impact on the environment, property values, historic districts and health, and ignoring less intrusive options.
"A lot of the information in C. L. and P.'s application is incomplete," said Monte Frank, a lawyer hired by Redding, Wilton and Weston to represent those towns' interests before the Connecticut Siting Council, which has jurisdiction on such issues. The only point on which there is some agreement is a need for increased transmission capacity in Fairfield County, which accounts for 26 percent of the state's population and roughly one-third of its retail sales. Further, according to the company's application, "its residents consume relatively more power, on average and at peak times, than those elsewhere in the state."
"We know energy demand in Fairfield County is growing, whether it's 1.25 percent, 2 percent or 3 percent," said Joe Dolan, a Redding resident and president of Communities for Responsible Energy, an umbrella organization comprising representatives from four of the towns challenging C. L. and P.'s plan. "The question is, to what extent is new capacity needed, and what are the alternate solutions?"
C. L. and P.'s preferred option is combining an existing 115-kV line and the 345-kV line on new steel monopoles, thereby minimizing the need for a wider right of way. The monopoles would average 130 feet in height, however, depending upon topography, and require right of ways averaging 125 feet.
Current transmission structures average 70 feet in height and require a right of way of 80 feet.
As required by law, the company's application presented alternatives: replacing the current 115-kV overhead line with the 345-kV line and burying a 115-kV line under current roadways; and an underground 345-kV line along public streets, primarily heavily-traveled Route 7. The former would sacrifice a wider right of way for shorter poles, and C. L. and P. claims the technology is unproven for a 22-mile underground route.
"The population is growing, and the need for power is growing even faster than that," said Frank Poirot, a company spokesman. C. L. P. estimates annual demand for power will grow by 1.5 percent, "but we're also required to plan for increases in peak usage," he added. Over the past two years, peaks have increased 15 percent, Mr. Poirot said, and two daily usage records were set last summer.
Even the State Department of Environmental Protection agrees that in terms of electricity transmission, Fairfield County is considered "a highly congested area," thus highlighting the needing for greater access to power generated throughout New England. 
"We ran into this precise problem in August, when we had 400 megawatts of power in Maine and no way of getting it to that part of Connecticut," Mr. Poirot said. "As a result, we were incredibly close to rolling blackouts."
And Representative Boucher, perhaps more than anyone else, knows what that means. "If the power is out," she said, "I get calls."
Critics of the company's proposal denounce the 345-kV line as "overkill" and insist a second 115-kV line, either on existing transmission poles or underground along Route 7, is a more appropriate option for meeting current and future energy demand.
Citing a report commissioned from Synapse Energy Economics, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., "one additional 115-kV line is sufficient to meet needs through 2017," said Monte Frank, the lawyer representing three towns.
The first selectmen of Bethel, Redding, Wilton and Weston began discussing the ramifications of C. L. and P.'s proposal soon after it was announced in July, and resistance has gathered ever since. Studies were ordered, public meetings were held, groups were mobilized, lawyers were hired. Approximately 100 Wilton residents attended a meeting called by First Selectman Paul Hannah on Dec. 11 at Cider Mill School to alert residents to C. L. and P.'s plans and galvanize opposition before the siting council.
The siting council, an appointed board of nine members, is charged by the Legislature with reconciling statewide need for such services with their impact on the environment. When it formally accepted C. L. and P.'s application on Nov. 29, the council set dates early next year for public hearings in the five affected towns, as well as for field inspections for the overhead and underground routes. The council has a year to make a decision on the application, during which it will gather information from various state agencies as well as individuals and municipalities. It can require Connecticut Light and Power to make design changes it deems appropriate, after which the company would formalize its design plan and seek construction rights and permits. C. L. and P's goal is having the new line operational by the end of 2003.
Opponents also are concerned about C. L. and P.'s plans for related projects, which have yet to be formally presented. They include a 65-mile, 345-kV line from Middletown into south Wilton, creating a transmission loop in southwestern Connecticut and allowing greater access to energy, and running new and replacement transmission cables beneath Long Island Sound from Norwalk to Hempstead Harbor and Northport on Long Island.
"C. L. and P. tried to make it sound like the three phases are going to be great for Connecticut," said Tom Schrum of Wilton, another member of Communities for Responsible Energy. "They just want to sell energy to Long Island."
Mr. Schrum is also the president of the Arrowhead Community Association, which is a group of homeowners on a 10-house cul-de-sac in south Wilton. Their homes are in the immediate vicinity of the power lines.
"It's a very difficult situation for this area to swallow, because of the deep-seated suspicion toward C. L. and P.," said Representative Boucher. "Their proposal is just so large and impactful."
For now, though, the opposition's focus remains fixed on the 345-kV from Bethel to Norwalk.
"This is not over," Representative Boucher told those attending the meeting at Cider Mill School. "People need to show up and provide testimony to the siting council. That will be significant for them to see."
Mr. Dolan added: "The solution may be a 115-kV line underground. We'll see. If we can keep the pressure on, we can accomplish our objectives. We're looking for the least invasive solution to meet the need that is there."

HEADLINE: Pushing to Speed Up East Side Rail Link 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
THE Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center has prompted the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to speed up work on the East Side Access Project, which would provide Long Island Rail Road riders another route into Manhattan.
 The project was initially scheduled for completion in 2010, but an M.T.A. spokesman said the agency now hoped to finish it by 2008 or 2009. 
 "The incident of Sept. 11 shows the importance of East Side Access to a greater degree," said Kenneth J. Bauer, the railroad's president. "If something happened at the East River tunnel, you wouldn't be able to run trains to Penn Station. The Long Island Rail Road gets 75 percent of the Nassau residents who go to New York City; 25 percent use cars. Can you imagine what it would be like if 100 percent had to use the roads to go to New York?" 
The vulnerability of the transit system was highlighted by an M.T.A. report released just after the terrorist attacks. "It was clearly the flexibility and capacity of the subway system in Lower Manhattan that helped the M.T.A. through this ordeal," the report said. "That makes more critical than ever the two important system capacity expansion projects," East Side Access and the Second Avenue subway projects.
To advance the $4.3 billion East Side Access Project, the M.T.A. is to receive a portion of the $54 billion Governor Pataki requested from the federal government after Sept. 11, an M.T.A. spokesman said. He did not know how much money that might be.
Already $323 million in contracts have been awarded for the design of the project, program management and engineering work. And earlier this year, the Long Island Rail Road and the New York & Atlantic Railway exchanged storage yards in a move needed to make East Side Access a reality.
The L.I.R.R. received two yards in Long Island City. During off-peak hours, they will store trains used for East Side Access during peak hours. The yards are near what will be the entrance to the rail tunnel that will run under city streets to the existing 63rd Street tunnel from Queens to Manhattan. The upper level of that tunnel is already being used for subway trains, and under plans for East Side Access, the lower level will be used for L.I.R.R. trains heading to Central Central Terminal over new tracks. 
At Grand Central, plans call for a new L.I.R.R. terminal below the Metro-North terminal. The L.I.R.R. terminal is to include a new ticketing and waiting area, passenger concourse, four island platforms serving eight tracks, passageways connecting to Metro-North and the subways, and new entrances and exits. 
Dean Skelos, Republican of Rockville Centre, the deputy majority leader of the State Senate, stressed the importance of East Side Access not only for safety but economic reasons. "It is critically important for the economic stability and growth of the region for it to go forward," he said. "I believe there will continue to be an increase in ridership and that a quick ride into the city is important for companies staying in New York City and the region."
Mitchell Pally, a vice president of the Long Island Association, the region's chamber of commerce, said that his group would welcome an earlier completion of the East Side Access Project "because the more options Long Islanders have with regard to where they are going to live and work, the better." The same would be true for city residents who want to work on the Island.
Senator Skelos said he came away from a recent meeting with members of the state's Congressional delegation with the belief that "there is an opportunity for additional funding for our rail tunnels and for those in Maryland and Washington." 
Mr. Bauer, the L.I.R.R.'s president, said that the East Side Access Project would increase the Long Island Rail Road's operating capacity by 45 percent, which he called critical because Pennsylvania Station was now at capacity.
An M.T.A. study projects that by 2010 that there will be 120,000 commuters using the Long Island Rail Road to get to Manhattan during the morning rush and that 70,000 of them will opt to use Grand Central Terminal. The L.I.R.R. currently carries 90,000 daily commuters to Penn Station.
Through November, ridership for the year was up 1.1 percent over last year, which recorded the most riders since 1949.
State Senator Caesar Trunzo, Republican of Brentwood, said he viewed the East Side Access and Second Avenue subway projects as a priority, along with safety improvements needed in the East River rail tunnels, which are owned by Amtrak.
"If a train gets stuck in there, there could be another disaster," he said. Improvement that are needed are more emergency exits and a new ventilation system to pump in fresh air and remove smoke, he said. 
Although the East Side Access Project is only for passenger trains, a tunnel for freight trains is also proposed. Mr. Pally of the Long Island Association said that Congress recently appropriated $5 million for an environmental impact statement for what is being called the Cross Harbor Freight Rail Tunnel, which would link Long Island to Manhattan or New Jersey.
"It would be very beneficial for freight operations," he said. "We are supportive of increasing rail access to Long Island" because it would mean fewer trucks on the road.
Bruce A. Lieberman, the chairman of the New York & Atlantic Railway, said that in the four years since his company bought the L.I.R.R.'s freight operations, business had increased 25 to 30 percent. That translates to 12,000 to 13,000 cars of freight a year, up from 9,500 cars. 
"This is a business that had 25,000 carloads in the 80's and 75,000 carloads in the 70's," he said, explaining that as the aerospace industry declined on Long Island, so did the need for freight service. Final figures for 2001 are not yet available, but Mr. Lieberman said that the slowing economy and the Sept. 11 attacks had had a negative effect on freight shipments.

A new Sunnyside station, left, is planned in Queens. Tunnel boring machines like this, top left, will be used in Queens and possibly Manhattan.
