HEADLINE: Chills in the Balance-Sheet Shadows 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
PAY no attention to those liabilities behind the curtain.
 That is the message corporate America has sent to investors in recent years as executives have shunted billions of dollars in new and existing financial obligations off their books and into the nether world known as "off the balance sheet." 
 When the stock market roared, investors were only too happy to believe that what they didn't know about their company's true financial picture couldn't hurt them. But now, in a crestfallen market reverberating with shock waves from Enron's collapse, shareholders are realizing that just because an obligation is absent from a company's balance sheet does not mean that it can't come back to bite them. 
What occurred at the Enron Corporation, at considerable distance from the assets and liabilities on its balance sheet, may of course prove an anomaly. The company, now in bankruptcy but once the world's dominant energy trader, was an aggressive user of partnerships separated from the parent but for which the parent's shareholders remained on the hook. Perhaps worse, it also committed the ultimate sin of omission -- it failed to disclose the extent of its contingent liabilities related to those partnerships. Under federal securities laws, those details should probably have been listed in at least the footnotes to the company's financial statements. 
In itself, off-balance-sheet financing is no vice. Companies can use it in perfectly legitimate ways that carry little risk to shareholders. The trouble is, while more companies are relying on off-balance-sheet methods to finance their operations, investors are usually unaware that a company with a clean balance sheet may be loaded with debt -- until it is too late.
"One intent of these structures is to try to move debt off the radar screen so that companies appear less financially leveraged than they actually are," said Scott Sprinzen, co-chairman of the corporate bond rating criteria committee at Standard & Poor's. "We try to reflect these off-balance-sheet obligations in our assessments. But if someone was just to take the financial statements at face value and not delve very deeply into these arrangements, then the statements could be misunderstood."
During the last decade, thousands of companies in many industries have used off-balance-sheet financing to power their expansions. Their obligations range from the mundane -- payments on leased aircraft or on real estate that is owned by third parties or liabilities associated with operations in which a company has a minority interest -- to the more arcane, including complex derivatives transactions. 
The most aggressive users of off-balance-sheet financing are, not surprisingly, financial services businesses like banks and brokerage firms. But retailers, airline companies, automakers and even gambling concerns use these financing techniques.
Each publishes their liabilities -- or not -- pretty much as they see fit.
WITH the boom phase of the economic cycle over, it is especially crucial for shareholders to have a complete grasp of a company's leverage. Banks and other lenders are no longer in the mood to offer companies easy money; some have reduced their appetite for lending or have chosen not to roll over existing debt. Unseen obligations at companies can destroy shareholders' wealth faster than the weather changes in Maine. Descents like Enron's are not called "death spirals" for nothing: it took less than a week after a credit rating downgrade for the company to file for bankruptcy protection.
These days, then, the aggressive use of off-balance-sheet financing is especially dangerous, said Sean J. Egan, managing director at Egan-Jones Ratings, a Wynnewood, Pa., credit rating firm that, unlike Moody's and Standard & Poor's, the biggest agencies, is not compensated by the issuers whose debt it assesses.
"Companies are in much worse shape now than they were maybe three years ago -- their balance sheets, their income statements," he said. "There are some egregious examples of companies like Enron that are rapidly growing and attempting to shield their growth in leverage from the market. With the increased volatility in the market, they are getting into difficulty."
One straw in this increasingly turbulent wind can be found at the major ratings agencies: the number of downgrades they assign to corporate bonds, compared with upgrades. Based on data through Dec. 17, Moody's Investors Service has downgraded 616 bond issues this year, well above the 2000 count of 472. This year, for every upgrade, 2.88 bonds have been downgraded -- versus 2.26 last year. 
The current number is the highest since 1991, the last recession, when it reached 2.93 (though it is well below the 4.39 in 1990).
Because disclosure is so spotty, it is hard to determine exactly how much debt resides off the balance sheet at American companies -- and at which companies. But many bond market experts agree that the explosive growth in this method of financing has occurred over the last 20 years and is a result of Wall Street ingenuity as well as changes in the way Americans finance their buying.
Decades ago, for example, airlines typically owned their planes, but today most lease them through arrangements with leasing companies, often off the balance sheet. While these arrangements allow airline companies to borrow less, they also mean that airlines have fewer assets to sell if they need to raise money.
Consumers have also contributed to the growth in off-balance-sheet financing. Many more Americans use credit cards today than they did just two decades ago. But banks and other credit companies do not want to carry those borrowings on their books. Instead, they have found ways to bundle small loans and to "securitize" them, selling them to subsidiaries, unrelated companies or institutional investors.
Carol Levenson, the editor of Gimme Credit, an investment advisory newsletter in Chicago that focuses on high-grade bonds, said the nature of these financing techniques had changed recently.
"There has been off-balance-sheet project financing and even acquisition financing for years," she explained, but it usually left the parent company unexposed. "It seems to me what's changed in recent years is the contingent obligation of the parent."
Indeed, in the old days, certainly before the last recession, if an obligation was moved off a company's balance sheet it was usually because the company had no liability whatsoever for the debt. 
BUT in today's loosey-goosey world of financial statements, off-balance-sheet obligations include those that keep a company exposed to some liability. Today's definition of off-balance-sheet financing has been stretched in much the same way the definition of earnings has -- with individual companies deciding what expenses they will count, or not, in "pro forma" earnings.
"For debt to be considered truly off balance sheet, there would have to be full and complete risk transference," said Pamela Stumpp, chief credit officer at Moody's Investor Service. "If there is any hook to the parent or if the parent is liable for any aspect of the operation, then it might not be a true off-balance-sheet liability."
Yet, as the Enron case showed, liabilities can remain on companies' books.
Investors, meanwhile, have been kept in the dark, Ms. Stumpp said, because many companies have not disclosed the details of the liabilities. For example, management at Calpine, a seller and trader of energy, has not disclosed in filings the existence of a $300 million letter of credit facility arranged with Credit Suisse First Boston in late August. The letter of credit was revealed by a Moody's analyst who downgraded the company's debt to junk status on Dec. 14.
A Calpine spokesman said that because the $300 million was not drawn, it did not constitute indebtedness. The company's securities counsel has stated that it was not required to be reflected in Calpine's periodic reports.
But that is emblematic of what Ms. Stumpp criticizes. "Financial officers are increasingly making judgment calls as to what to include about these things in the financials," she said. "Certain off-balance-sheet obligations are not included in disclosure. There is a need for better disclosure to clarify these structures because clearly there is risk that needs to be assessed in connection with them." 
After a debacle like Enron's, regulators may begin to examine disclosure lapses. Analysts and investors, meanwhile, are scrambling to understand where the fault lines are; Enron, whose shares trade for 53 cents, demonstrated how risky off-balance-sheet deals can be for shareholders.
Understanding that risk is not easy. Off-balance-sheet financings, even when disclosed, are highly arcane and can vary considerably, even at the same company.
Assessing the risk of something even as plain vanilla as financing of auto loans is problematic for investors. Ford Motor, for example, carries only $12 billion in debt on its balance sheet, 14 percent of its assets. But in the third quarter, Ford Motor Credit held $40 billion in operating leases. They are backed by the cars that Ford has leased, but in a distressed situation, it is not clear that those assets would have enough value to pay off the loans.
Essentially, companies assess their risk themselves, and Walter P. Schuetze, former chief accountant to the Securities and Exchange Commission and chief accountant of its enforcement division, expressed fears that companies are not pricing their retained risks properly. "Consequently, we are getting overstated gains and understated losses when the paper is sold and periodically thereafter we are getting understated liabilities," said Mr. Schuetze, who is retired but remains a consultant to the commission. 
Why does the mispricing occur? The wrong people are in charge of assessing the risks, Mr. Schuetze said. "The reporting enterprise or company is setting those numbers, and auditors look at them and say, 'That's about right,' " he said. "The enterprise should not be making that determination, and the auditor doesn't have the expertise to make that determination. It should be made by someone outside the reporting enterprise who is a competent expert." Then, Mr. Schuetze said, the expert's opinion should be included in company filings with the S.E.C. 
As off-balance-sheet financing techniques have grown in popularity -- and imagination -- several areas appear especially perilous, according to corporate bond experts. The use of special-purpose vehicles, like those at Enron that housed the partnerships and benefited certain insiders -- but for which the shareholders were ultimately liable -- is particularly troublesome as a result of Enron's failure.
Glenn E. Reynolds, chief executive of Credit Sights, an independent credit analysis firm in New York, said special-purpose vehicles were common at brokerage firms. In most of them, Mr. Reynolds said, the assets are unidentified and the risks unfathomable. 
IN a typical setup, a brokerage firm creates an unregulated subsidiary specifically to hold a high-risk asset -- such as debt issued by an emerging-market country like Argentina. The firm then makes a loan backed by the asset to a special-purpose vehicle that is off the brokerage firm's balance sheet. Because the subsidiary is unregulated, it may not have to record changes in the asset's value, known as marking to market. But if the asset defaulted, it would have to be marked to market and could cause repayment on the loan made to the special-purpose vehicle. 
The problem with these transactions, Mr. Reynolds said, is "you just don't see transparently the risk portfolio."
"If it blows up," he said, "then it sees the light of day. Until then, the fact there's a bomb down there is not so obvious to the outside investor."
Other lending arrangements that are used to minimize debt can also become a problem for a company, especially if it loses the confidence of investors. At any company with a trading business -- Enron was one, but other merchant energy companies include the Williams Companies, Calpine and Dynegy -- the brokerage firms or banks financing their trades may ask for additional collateral if they start to lose confidence in the companies' abilities to raise money in the capital markets. Such a reeling in of credit would not be seen by outsiders, but it could cause a squeeze if the company had little cash on hand, or access to it. That is why Enron drew down all of its credit lines, $3.3 billion, as soon as trouble loomed.
"A big difference today from 1991 is how extremely powerful global financial institutions have generated huge credit lines with these companies," Mr. Reynolds said. These credit lines, which can be generous in good times, can be withdrawn in a matter of hours if a problem surfaces, he pointed out.
Other off-balance-sheet arrangements back complex transactions designed to insure institutional investors' holdings. Known as credit derivatives, they had a notional value of $360 billion in the third quarter of 2001 and are a fast-growing segment of the overall derivatives market, rising 60 percent annually since late 1997, according to David Hendler, financial company strategist at Credit Sights. "The top seven banks control 97 percent of all the derivative trades in the United States," he said. The exposure of J. P. Morgan Chase, he added, stands at more than three times the bank's tangible equity.
Yet the risks associated with derivatives trades have never been tested in a sour economy; their consequences are unknown.
ANY company, not just a bank, can have obscured risks. One involves corporate bonds held in the issuing company's Employee Stock Ownership Plan. Known as ESOP notes, they often carry features that require the company to pay back the bonds if its credit rating falls below investment grade. 
Armstrong World Industries, a subsidiary of Armstrong Holdings, a maker of floor coverings and cabinets, filed for bankruptcy protection a year ago. The company had $142 million outstanding in ESOP bonds at the time. When Armstrong's credit rating fell to below investment grade, the company had to repay the bonds.
But Mr. Reynolds said these stipulations seldom showed up anywhere in filings, even in the footnotes to the financial statements. "Armstrong's was not even included in its detail debt footnote on ESOP notes at year-end," he said. "These details typically do not get disclosed unless the crisis is upon you."
Almost everyone agrees that companies must disclose more details about their off-balance-sheet transactions and entities -- and soon. The absence of disclosure, according to Mr. Reynolds, "reflects the abuse of substance in accounting today."
"There is no reason for these things not to be disclosed," he said. "It's just withholding material information. That can lead to shocks, and where there are shocks in the market, it leads to decline in confidence."
Ms. Levenson, the bond analyst, agreed. "I truly believe if Enron had kept all this stuff on the balance sheet and worked it into its maturity schedule just like any other debt, even if it meant carrying a $3 billion higher debt load," she said, "it may not have been a strong triple-B credit but it might still be a going concern today."

HEADLINE: THE CITIES; 
A Governor In Search Of a Policy For Old Cities

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
IN his successful run for governor, James G. McGreevey piled up impressive majorities in most of the state's urban areas. He was such a regular fixture it seemed -- even when not campaigning at black churches in poor urban communities -- that aides joked he was his own advance man. They marveled how at times he even recalled birthdays and anniversaries.
 But as Jim McGreevey the campaigner morphed into Jim McGreevey the governor-elect this month, the looming budget deficit -- estimated at $1.9 billion -- seemed to have taken his memory away and in the process doused the hopes of many in Camden and Newark. 
 In the lame-duck legislative session there are two measures pending that -- for the price of some concessions to the Republicans and suburban interests -- may begin to pull Camden out of its long swoon and add momentum to Newark's effort at revitalization. 
But Mr. McGreevey, invoking the budget problems, called a $180 million rescue package to try to bring Camden back on its feet too costly. And in the case of Newark, he endorsed the notion of building a $355 million arena for the New Jersey Nets and New Jersey Devils -- supporting the idea of using a portion of sales taxes from the district -- as well as private borrowing but not involving any direct state subsidies.
Yet he concluded that the price of closing the deal -- set by exiting Republican leaders in the form of millions in direct state aid for projects in South Jersey and Bergen -- was too high a cost, and he refused to bargain.
Like prom dates all dressed up with nowhere to go, State Senator Wayne Bryant of Camden, who sponsored that city's rescue bill, and Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, who had sought a compromise to allow the arena bill to pass the Assembly, were left with only the promise that a McGreevey administration would take a fresh look at these issues after inauguration on Jan. 15.
Then, in the new light of changed political balances in the Legislature, Mr. McGreevey said he would present his own urban assistance programs.
But this begged the question of just what a McGreevey urban policy would look like. In a recent interview, the governor-elect's approach sounded much like the established programs that relied heavily on tax abatements and incentives to private businesses and developers to encourage them to return to the cities. He evoked such staunchly Republican programs as those enacted by Tom Ridge, the former governor of Pennsylvania, the Keystone Opportunities Zones, and John Engler's Rennaissance Zones in Michigan, which rely heavily on private investment as the key to success.
"I am strongly and unequivocally committed to redevelopment of our urban centers," said Mr. McGreevey. "But, respectfully, with my $1.9 billion budget shortfall, I have stated to both Senator Bryant and Sharpe James that there is a need to stave off any discretionary spending due to that shortfall."
Mr. McGreevey said that on its own merits, the proposal for a new sports arena in Newark was perhaps the most sound. The idea was to create a state entity that would receive a portion of the sales tax revenue generated in a sports and entertainment district surrounding the proposed downtown arena. The proceeds would help pay off $190 million in borrowed money that the owner of the two teams, the YankeeNets, would get from the sale of bonds.
The team owners would contribute $115 million of their own money to the project, and city and county governments would provide the remaining $50 million in the form of infrastructure improvements to roads, public transportation facilities and other publicly used areas.
"But attached to this program were certain Christmas tree items," said Mr. McGreevey, referring to a range of programs including a sports facility at Rowan University, a rowing center in Camden, a Disney World-like family entertainment complex in the Meadowlands and a Nascar track in South Jersey. "My only concern is these unrelated expenditures."
Camden was more problematic, requiring a bit more in direct state spending to finance nearly $150 million in state borrowing that would go directly to a newly created Camden Economic Recovery Board. The money would be used for grants and loans for street improvements, neighborhood rehabilitation, demolition of abandoned structures, home purchases by low-income residents, improvements to the sewer and water system and bolstering publicly supported hospitals and colleges that could in turn support a resurging commercial sector.
Still, Mr. McGreevey praised the bill's provisions for improved management of the city's affairs and accountability through the recovery board's supervision of local elected officials. But while it was long on accountability, he said, it was short of attracting private capital.
"Long-range growth of the city depends on that, and even though we are heading into an economic downturn we can create incentives to businesses to locate in the region," he said. "And with the Keystone Opportunities program that Tom Ridge started in Pennsylvania and the Renaissance Opportunity Zones in Michigan, you have programs that produce sustained private investment."
That would come as a surprise to those evaluating the two-year-old program in Pennsylvania who say that they have not yet determined how effective -- much less how sustained -- the private investment has been.
Under the Pennsylvania program, 12 regions of the state can each designate up to 5,000 acres of land on which they will abate more than a dozen municipal, school, county and state taxes ranging from the property, sales and income taxes to a variety of corporate and franchise taxes. The extensive abatements are intended to attract businesses and jobs to sites in rural and blighted urban areas alike that that would otherwise be left vacant. They would last for 12 years, and then the owners would begin paying state and local taxes.
Matthew Goodburn, an analyst with the Allegheny Institute for Public Policy, a nonprofit research organization hired by Pennsylvania to evaluate the three-year-old program, said: "The program is doing well, but we are still doing in-depth analysis. One thing we are seeing is different interpretations of how to use the program with some areas designating really hard-to-develop properties that require a lot of infrastructure investment and others choosing the more site-ready properties such as old industrial parks."
Mr. Goodburn said some thought that by waiving the tax incentives, businesses would come running. But "it has not been that easy," he said.
Bruce Katz, director of the Brookings Institution's Center on Urban and Metropolitan Policy, said that in the last two decades such programs of tax incentives for private investment had become "the conventional wisdom" of urban policy, though he said that while perhaps necessary, they were not sufficient in themselves to arrest urban distress in cities like Camden.
There are several government subsidies that need to be dammed and redirected, he said, including greater subsidies for mass transit, de-emphasizing state spending on suburban schools and putting more emphasis on their urban counterparts, and steering more spending toward the infrastructures of the older areas rather than the newer exurban ones.
"I support empowerment zones, but they don't address the larger flows of public subsidy," he said. "We treat tax credits like the holy grail, but people tend to move where there are functioning schools, a good real estate market and safety."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
A Finger in the Wind Suggests It's Already 2002

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
WHAT if the stock market rally for 2002 has already happened? What if the bond selloff that normally comes with an economic recovery has come in the last seven weeks of 2001?
 That "what if?" is not hard to swallow. The Dow Jones industrial average has climbed 22 percent from its low on Sept. 21, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 19 percent. The Nasdaq composite has jumped an even more spectacular 37 percent. Those are impressive returns by any standard. 
 As for the bond market, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note has shot up as high as 5.19 percent, above where it was at the end of 2000 and not all that far from the peak of 5.5 percent that some forecasters are predicting for 2002. The yield was 5.08 percent on Friday.
But why would next year's stock rally and bond selloff come early? Maybe investors have become so intent on being ahead of the curve that they have jumped on the bandwagon before it even starts moving. Many analysts contend that investors in both stocks and bonds are already assuming that a recovery is under way -- and that it will be strong.
If the best news for stocks and the worst for bonds has already been factored into the markets, there may be much less scope for what can happen next year. If a recovery comes later and is weaker than expected, then the disappointment could undermine stocks, while interest rates could hold steady or even decline somewhat until the recovery is further along.
Such an outcome is not inconsistent with some forecasts: Richard Bernstein, the new chief United States equity strategist at Merrill Lynch, says stocks will be flat next year. Nor is it inconsistent with optimistic-sounding economic data like the report last week that housing starts surged 8.2 percent in November. That surge, in fact, could help explain why a recovery may not be as swift as many investors have hoped.
Housing starts jumped to an annual rate of 1.645 million in November. Unusually good weather, however, caused some of that increase and could also give housing starts another lift in December. More important, the gains mean that housing starts have not suffered in this recession and have no trough to surge from -- so they cannot fuel an economic recovery as they have in the past.
In the 1990-91 recession, housing starts plunged 48.5 percent in 12 months, to an annual rate of 798,000 in January 1991, then climbed by 51.6 percent over the next two years. In this recession, which officially began in March, housing starts have actually risen, supported by unexpectedly strong consumer demand, low interest rates and subdued inflation, according to Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley.
Housing starts are 1.4 percent above where they were in March, 5.5 percent above their level a year ago and just 1.3 percent below their high for this year. At the November level, the annual rate of starts would have to climb only 11 percent to reach a 15-year high.
WITHOUT a sharp decline to rally from, and with mortgage rates rising with Treasury interest rates, "it doesn't make much sense to talk of a housing-led recovery," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. The average weekly rate on 30-year mortgages nationally is now 7.17 percent, according to Freddie Mac, up from 6.45 percent in early November.
Bernie Schaeffer, chairman of Schaeffer's Investment Research, sees another problem for stocks. By one of his favorite technical measures of performance, the market is still in a bear phase, and he questions the persistence of any market rebound until stocks move through this bear barrier.
His measure is the 40-month moving average of the S.& P. 500, which is now 1,293.59. The index closed at 1,144.89 on Friday. That means it would take an 8 percent rally to surpass the moving average, and that may be difficult if the economic recovery disappoints.

HEADLINE: Russia's Last Line 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
Because of Moscow's exploding middle class, you quickly notice two things driving around this increasingly European city -- sushi bars are opening all over (yes, from borscht to Big Macs to California-Kremlin rolls in one decade!) and so many people have cars now that traffic is permanently snarled (imagine Jakarta with snow and ice and you've got today's Moscow). So sitting in gridlock the other day in Pushkin Square, I had plenty of time to ask my Russian friend Viktor a cosmic question: Is your life easier or harder now than it was under Communism?
 "Both," he remarked. "It's easier because I don't have to hunt for food every day and wait in lines for everything. Stores are full now. No lines. But it all costs a lot of money. The saying here now is that there is only one line left in Russia -- the line for money." 
 So Karl Marx's theories have finally triumphed in today's Russia: it's all about money. That's the key to understanding President Vladimir Putin, too. He's not a tougher Mikhail Gorbachev, or a more sober Boris Yeltsin. He is Russia's first Deng Xiaoping -- Mao's pragmatic successor who first told the Chinese that "to get rich is glorious" and put in place the modernizing reforms to do it.
Abba Eban once said that men and nations will always do the right thing in the end -- after they exhaust every other possibility. That is Mr. Putin's basic message to Russians: "For a decade, we've tried every bad idea, from default to devaluation to shock therapy. Now there's only one idea left: passing real reform legislation so we can get real investment to build a real modern economy. Because in this world, without a real economic foundation, you're nothing. So we're going to focus now on the only line that matters -- the line for money." This is Putinism: From Das Kapital to DOScapital.
And it explained to me why Mr. Putin rolled over so meekly on President Bush's decision to walk away from the ABM treaty, limiting missile defenses. In 1972, when that treaty was forged, Russian foreign policy was about one thing -- geopolitics, the ideologically driven global competition for influence with the U.S., and everything, particularly economics, was subordinated to that. Hence all the food lines. Today, Russian foreign policy is about two things -- geopolitics and geoeconomics -- and there is a real competition between the two. So if Russia can save money and win Western help by walking away from the ABM treaty, then walk it will.
Don't be fooled, though. Russia's military and foreign policy elite considered Mr. Bush's ABM move "a slap in the face," said the Russian pollster Igor Bunin. If the U.S. doesn't come through now with what Mr. Putin believes he's been promised -- a new accord for deep cuts in nuclear weapons, a real Russia-NATO partnership, plus debt relief, W.T.O. membership and Western investment, Mr. Putin will be seen as another Gorbachev -- always giving and never receiving. "Then elites could start to form a front against him," added Mr. Bunin. But for now, Mr. Putin is ignoring the whispers because in his view Russia will never again be a player in geopolitics unless it first masters geoeconomics.
What's new in today's Moscow is that there are young capitalists coming of age, and they believe they can get rich the Chinese way, by making things, not the old Russian way, by taking things from the state or from the ground. And without anyone noticing, in 2001 Russia's Parliament quietly passed a lot of the judicial and tax reform legislation that America was beating on it to pass for a decade.
I had lunch the other day in a combination art gallery-restaurant, Ulitsa OGI, which is part of a successful new chain started by Dmitry Jekovich and his partner. "The difference between us and the oligarchs is that we're oriented on creating something new, not just privatizing something that existed before," he explained.
The confidence of Russia's new generation that it can actually do this "capitalist thing" has enormous geopolitical significance. One reason that Russia was so zealous about keeping so many nukes, and reflexively opposing the U.S., was because these were the only currency that defined it as a superpower. If Russians believe they can be powerful on the basis of geoeconomics, they aren't going to surrender all their nukes or quest for influence, but the chances of their being real partners with the West will be much, much greater.
So keep rootin' for Putin -- and hope that he makes it to the front of Russia's last line. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: FRONT LINES 

BYLINE:  By ANDREA KANNAPELL

 BODY:
MILITARY CAMPAIGN -- There was a price for the reliance on Afghan opposition forces on the ground, and the United States has begun paying it. Afghan commanders considered the war over when they captured the mountainous territory of Tora Bora, while American and allied forces prepared to send a large force to search its caves themselves for Al Qaeda leaders, especially Osama bin Laden. Many fighters have already escaped into Pakistan. Phase 2 in the war on terror, Page 3.
 There are continuing hints that Afghan commanders sometimes cut their own deals. Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban's chief, may be being sheltered. The group's other top leaders appear to have survived the campaign: the highest ranking casualty was reportedly a deputy foreign minister. In Kunduz, an Al Qaeda supporter suspected of being an adviser to Central Asia's largest terrorist group, the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, slipped from Northern Alliance custody. 

PEACE -- Who will pay for the peace is another question. The World Bank says the first five years of rebuilding schools, roads and communications networks, underwriting the new government and taking on the myriad other projects associated with reviving Afghanistan could be $10 billion or more. International expectations were that the United States would pay a third, with Europe paying another third and the rest of the world, led by Japan, picking up the rest. But the Bush administration says it may have already done its financial duty, having spent about $1 billion a month on the war.
Still, peace appears to be marching on. The United Nations approved a peacekeeping force to be led by Britain. The International Security Assistance Force's first troops, British marines, began arriving in time to install the interim power-sharing government headed by the Pashtun leader Hamid Karzai and three Northern Alliance figures.

MINES -- Peace has lured farming families back to northern Afghanistan, but their soil holds hidden danger: land mines laid during 22 years of war. Some 400 Afghan demolition specialists from Halo Trust, a British nonprofit that has been working in the country since 1988, have begun clearing the mines, as well as removing discarded munitions from retreating Taliban fighters.

MONEY TRAILS -- Investigators trying to tease apart Al Qaeda's finances have new material. A Saudi captured in Afghanistan was identified as an official with the Wafa Humanitarian Organization, a Saudi-based Islamic charitable organization suspected of funneling money to the terrorist network. And in Kosovo, NATO troops raided the offices of Global Relief Foundation, which, like a second American charity, Benevolence International Foundation, is suspected of aiding Al Qaeda. The Treasury Department and the F.B.I. raided both groups' domestic offices. The Bush administration also froze the assets of a Pakistani group blamed for the recent attack on India's parliament. The group, Lashkar-e-Taiba, seeks independence for the Muslim-dominated Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir and has links to Al Qaeda.

MORE EMBASSY BOMBING SUSPECTS -- A British court allowed the extradition of three men to stand trial in the United States on charges of conspiring with Osama bin Laden to bomb American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998. The three, a London-based Saudi businessman, Khalid al-Fawwaz, 37, and two Egyptians, Ibrahim Eidarous, 39, and Adel Abdul Bary, 42, had fought the case for three years. Last May, after a four-month trial in Manhattan, four men were convicted in the case -- and sentenced just days after the Sept. 11 attacks.

IRAQ -- The United States has been hearing some support from Arab nations for a move against Iraq, which has for three years barred United Nations inspectors seeking to make sure Iraq is not making banned weapons. There is no new credibility to early suspicions that Iraq was involved in the attacks (Unclear links, Page 3); rather, the support grew out of the rapid success of the military action in Afghanistan. Europe remains opposed to a move on Iraq, but Middle Eastern diplomats say Turkey would allow the United States to use its bases -- a critical piece of regional support.
The Iraqi National Congress, the exile opposition group that has repeatedly sought American support for the overthrow of Saddam Hussein, produced a defector, Adnan Ihsan Saeed al-Haideri, with an eye-opening report. He said that he was a civil engineer and that he had worked on renovating facilities for biological, chemical and nuclear weapons in wells, private villas and even under the Saddam Hussein Hospital in Baghdad. 

ISRAEL -- The region seemed to take a half step back in its otherwise inexorable march toward open war. After his televised appeal to Palestinians to halt further attacks on Israel, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, closed more offices of the radical militant group Hamas. Both Hamas and another radical group said they would suspend suicide attacks against Israel -- but with such promises, only time will tell. The Israeli security forces, despite their government's declaration that Mr. Arafat was irrelevant, met with Palestinian counterparts to discuss the West Bank and perhaps loosening their iron grip so that Palestinian forces could maneuver again.

BIODEFENSE -- President Bush decided that the secretary of the Health and Human Services Department, which has a seat on the Homeland Security Council, should be able to classify information as secret. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention gave 200 public health workers classes on how to recognize and contain a terrorist attack involving smallpox. And federal health officials began offering the anthrax vaccine to workers on Capitol Hill and to some postal employees.

GOOD OLD AMERICAN COMPENSATION -- The federal victims' fund may pay as much as $1.6 million to the families of each of those killed Sept. 11, according to its overseer, Kenneth R. Feinberg. But some say the funds' rules are too restrictive to allow payments anywhere near that. ANDREA KANNAPELL

HEADLINE: Blair and Putin Agree to Begin Exchange of Intelligence Data 

BYLINE:  By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 22 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Tony Blair ended two days of talks with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia promising new intelligence exchanges and saying relations between Moscow and the West were the closest they had been in decades.
 Mr. Blair praised Russia for its cooperation with the antiterror coalition since the attacks on the United States on Sept. 11 and said that other nations backed Mr. Putin's efforts to extend trust to Moscow. 
 "What I have found extraordinary and encouraging is the way not just Russia but NATO partners have embraced the idea of this new relationship in a way which would have been unthinkable a few years ago," Mr. Blair said. 
Mr. Putin said that "Russia is ready for such a relationship." He said he planned to meet in May with NATO leaders to set up a timetable for establishing the mechanics of such cooperation. 
This weekend's meeting was the fifth this year between the Russian president and Mr. Blair, who was the first Western leader to go to Russia, in March, 2000, when Mr. Putin emerged as the country's likely new leader. Last month, Mr. Blair began the push to give Russia increased access to Western organizations, sending a letter to Lord Robertson, the NATO secretary general, and all leaders of the 19-nation alliance suggesting a special auxiliary council on nonmilitary matters of mutual interest that would include Russia. 
"This is a relationship that I value hugely," Mr. Blair said Friday night with Mr. Putin standing by his side as the two men took a break from their talks at Chequers, the prime minister's official country residence in Buckinghamshire. 
Mr. Blair said he endorsed Russia's interest in becoming a member of the World Trade Organization and wanted it to happen "as swiftly as possible." He said economic reforms in Russia appeared to be working. The Russians are planning a forum in London in April as a showcase for their emerging economy and, in particular, their energy business. 
On Friday, Mr. Putin met with oil company executives, Lord Browne of BP and Philip Watts of Royal Dutch/ Shell, to discuss investment opportunities. Some Western leaders have speculated that oil from Russia could be the answer for countries wanting to reduce dependence on the volatile nations of the Middle East. 
Mr. Blair drew a parallel between the bombings of buildings in Moscow that killed nearly 300 people two years ago and the terror attacks on the United States, saying that both were examples of the kind of terrorism the world was now united in fighting. The comment bolstered Mr. Putin's assertion, still disputed in some Western capitals, that his government's war in Chechnya is part of the same struggle as the campaign against Al Qaeda. 
Mr. Blair also praised Mr. Putin for his reasoned reaction to President Bush's announcement last week that the United States was withdrawing from the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, a move resisted by Moscow. The Russian president said, "We are not going to overdramatize the situation and we hope that the dialogue with all our partners including the United States will continue." 
Asked about extending the anti-terror war to Iraq, a move that Russia is firmly against, Mr. Blair said there was a clear need to deal with weapons of mass destruction but also an imperative to move forward only "within the deliberation and consultation of key allies."

HEADLINE: U.S. Providing $8.2 Million To Rebuild TV Antennas 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 

 BODY:
The federal government is providing millions of dollars to help restore television service to hundreds of thousands of viewers in the New York City region who lost it as a result of the collapse of the World Trade Center.
 Tucked into the $8.2 billion emergency aid package that Congress approved last week for New York was an $8.2 million appropriation specifically earmarked to help rebuild the main antennas that stood atop the trade center's north tower. 
 The money was sought by local television executives who have been predicting that their stations would suffer significant losses in advertising revenue unless they found a way to restore their ability to reach every possible viewer in the region. 
The money is not expected to cover the entire cost of building a new broadcast tower, estimated at $30 million to $40 million.
But today, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York noted that any money that Washington provided at this point was welcome, particularly since the broadcast industry was already bracing for advertising revenue losses before the terrorist attacks.
"Television and communications are key industries in New York," said Mr. Schumer, who lobbied to set aside money for broadcasters. "To leave them with a significant hole in their broadcast network is bad for the New York economy."
Because the main antennas atop the north tower came down, virtually all local New York stations lost a significant part of their audiences, from 10 percent to 35 percent. The biggest loss has been experienced by WNET, Channel 13, because it has the smallest percentage of viewers who subscribe to cable television.
The destruction of the antennas left hundreds of thousands of viewers -- those who do not subscribe to cable -- access to only two television stations, Channels 2 and 41, which have backup antennas on the Empire State Building. 
Roughly 20 percent of the 7.3 million homes in the New York metropolitan television market are not hooked up for cable or satellite service. Many homes have only some of their sets wired for cable and depend on the broadcast signal for other sets.
The situation had financial impact for broadcasters. According to an estimate by the BIA Financial Network, a firm that tracks advertising spending on local television stations, advertising revenue for the New York market will fall by about 16 percent for this year, twice the drop the firm was predicting before Sept. 11.
For now, local stations are using space on the Empire State Building tower or one in Alpine, N.J., that enables viewers in some areas to receive some stations. But the Alpine tower is far too small to broadcast clear pictures throughout the metropolitan region, and the Empire State Building has too little space and electrical power to accommodate the demands of all the stations.
The long-term situation may lie in the construction of an enormous stand-alone broadcast tower, perhaps as tall as 2,000 feet, preferably somewhere near the twin towers site. But that solution has its own complications, chief among them the $30 million to $40 million cost, which would be divided among the stations.
The location will be critical, since the new antennas could interfere with television signals in cities like Philadelphia and Boston, and cannot be within established flight patterns for local airports. The 10 local stations have formed a coalition to address the problems, and it was this group that lobbied for the money that Congress approved last week.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Rebuilding A's Lineup Is in Baseball's Interest

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
WHILE Yankees fans argue the merits of Derek Jeter leading off and Jason Giambi hitting cleanup or third in the best lineup cable revenue can buy, the poor rabid A's rooter waits for a measly run-producing bat to be deposited under the Christmas tree.
 David Justice, unwrapped and unappreciated, apparently does not count. 
 "We need another hitter," my friend Billy reported from his couch in front of his newly installed cable box in Napa, Calif. "One more hitter, and I'm not conceding anything to anyone." 
Fair enough, I said in our most recent conversation, our first since breakfast in Berkeley the morning of what would become the Derek Jeter Game. Billy was buoyant over his French toast and as we strolled the university campus, stopping to worship at the building in which he earned his master's in math. His Oakland A's led the division series, 2-0, and had a nasty southpaw, Barry Zito, lined up for the kill.
"If Jeremy Giambi had slid," Billy said, not completing the thought because it's already part of baseball lore, and as ancient a topic as Grover Cleveland Alexander. Little G didn't slide and Big G couldn't beat the Yankees and opted to join them, taking the strapped A's owners off the hook for the $91 million they offered while thinking, "Just say no." Now the question is what, if anything, this unique playoff-competitive and modestly budgeted team can do about it.
Billy is not to be confused with Billy Beane, the crafty A's general manager, who again has the assignment of trying to do more with less, or Billy Ball, for that matter, the stylistic appellation applied to the early 1980's A's of Billy Martin. This Billy, the best man at my wedding nearly 16 years ago, forsook his deep Yankee roots when he moved west and has followed the A's through a quarter-century of dramatic qualitative swings and what seems like a half-dozen Rickey Henderson eras.
But we digress from the challenge before General Manager Beane, to appropriate some of the money not spent on Giambi and Johnny Damon, and fortify one of the two or three American League teams that may even be allowed into the same conversation as the Yankees in 2002.
I know George Steinbrenner is proud to have finished first in the Giambi Stakes' field of one, and Yankee fans are thrilled to have Giambi's offensive assets. It would nonetheless be a crying shame if the A's fell backward after assembling such a talented young pitching staff that, with Jason Giambi, has twice taken the Yankees to their only decisive A.L. playoff games during their five World Series seasons under Joe Torre. This was a real rivalry brewing, more than the wishful romance of the New England summer.
There must be some Yankee fans not relishing the thought of watching them flex in the mirror through mid-October, all the way to another World Series.
"Obviously it's the Yankees and everyone else in terms of them just going out and getting the players they want," Billy said. "So maybe we should just pack up, disband and volunteer to go into a dispersal draft." 
California cynicism, with a dose of economic realism, but also flavored with that saucy A's optimism. 
As Beane told me last summer, the A's losing players for financial reasons goes all the way back to Philadelphia, through Kansas City. History's lineup of significant Yankees imported from the A's begins with Roger Maris and runs through Reggie Jackson, Catfish Hunter, Ken Holtzman, Henderson, Scott Brosius and now Giambi. The A's are nonetheless second in the A.L. to the Yankees in World Series appearances with 14. "In Oakland," Beane says, "the glass is always half full."
My Billy's sentiments exactly. "We have young players, Miguel Tejada and Eric Chavez, just reaching stardom," he said. "Terrence Long, Jermaine Dye, maybe Justice can hit 25 home runs. Billy Koch as the closer -- better, hopefully, than Isringhausen. Except for the Yankees, we'll have the best starting pitching, and Clemens is going to be another year older. Winning, you know, is a matter of subtle chemistry, and the Yankees are going to have a lot of new players."
As long as his team has pitching, it has hope, so Billy is one A's fan of presumably many asking for just one big bat for Christmas. Tino Martinez would have been perfect, but he went to St. Louis last week. There was a Bay Area buzz about Barry Bonds's switching teams, but that didn't happen. Juan Gonzalez and Mo Vaughn, both on the bottomless wish list of the New York baseball culture, would be better off helping other teams that might help make the summer more interesting, less inevitable. That's the view from somewhere west of the Hudson.
General Manager Beane is telling Bay Area reporters that he has a couple of moves to make. His fans are waiting. All baseball fans still wanting to believe in competition more than coronation should be rooting for these A's to not give in, to refortify their lineup. The long-term alternative for too many major league baseball teams is to pack up, disband and volunteer to go into a dispersal draft.
